This study aims to assess the anti-fibrotic effect of \ncombination of clove (Syzygium aromaticum) ethanolic extract (CEE) with \nSilymarin® on carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced liver fibrosis in an effort to \nadvance their synergistic clinical application as well as their antibacterial \nand anti-inflammatory activities. Adult rats were divided into six groups (10 \nanimals each) as follows: group (1) included normal rats as control, group (2) \nincluded normal rats daily CEE, group (3) comprise of CCl4-induced liver \nfibrosis and acts as positive control, group (4) CCl4-induced liver fibrosis \nrats those were treated with CEE, (5) CCl4-induced liver fibrosis rats those \nwere treated with Silymarin® and group (6) CCl₄-induced liver fibrosis rats \nthose were treated CEE and Silymarin® for six weeks. By using HPLC analysis, \neleven significant constituents were identified, including four flavonoids and \nseven phenolic acids. The combination of CEE and Silymarin® exhibited potent \nantibacterial activity against Streptococcus mutans, Staphylococcus aureus, \nPseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli with MIC values ranging from 182.32 \nto 201.63\xa0μg/mL. The combination of CEE and Silymarin® significantly reduced \nnitric oxide levels and increased superoxide dismutase activity in \nlipopolysaccharide (LPS)-inflamed HepG-2 cells more than CEE and Silymarin® \nalone, thereby this combination acting as a potent anti-inflammatory and \nantioxidant candidate. The results indicated that the combination of CEE and \nSilymarin® was successfully reduced CCl4-induced liver fibrosis as approved by a \nlarge increase in serum CD4 and albumin levels and the activity of hepatic \nantioxidant enzymes. These consequences boosted by reduction in several hepatic \ninflammation markers and distressed the structural restoration of the liver's \nhistological images. In conclusion, the combination of CEE and Silymarin® exert \na hepatoprotective complement manner as attributed to the synergistic effect of \nCEE and Silymarin®.\n\n© 2025. Chemical analysis \nunveiled the substantial presence of phenols, flavonoids, and anthocyanins in \nLCEE, with cyanidin emerging as the predominant anthocyanidin. Antioxidant \nassays confirmed the potent antioxidant capabilities of LCEE. The DEC treated \nwith LCEE led to conspicuous inhibition zones, reduced growth rates, and \ndemonstrated notable efficacy, with low minimum inhibitory concentration and \nminimum bactericidal concentration values against DEC. LCEE exerted strong \nantimicrobial abilities on DEC by reducing bacterial motility, disrupting \nbiofilm and pre-formed biofilm. LCEE was observed to induce alterations in cell \nmorphology and internal structure, enhance membrane permeability, and induce \ncellular dysfunction, including cell membrane hyperpolarization and decreased \nintracellular ATP concentration. SDS-PAGE analysis demonstrated LCEE interfered \nwith protein synthesis, while quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR) assays \nrevealed that LCEE inhibited biofilm formation possibly by reducing the \nexpression levels of genes (including luxS, fliC, csgA, and fimA) associated \nwith biofilm-formation. Cytotoxicity assessments indicated that LCEE exhibited \nno cytotoxic effects in vitro. These findings highlight the potential of LCEE as \na natural antimicrobial agent for mitigating DEC contamination in food, thereby \nlowering the risk of DEC infections.\n\n© 2025. Online ahead of\n print.\n\nGenomic and functional characterization of the L‑sorbose phosphotransferase \nsystem in high-risk Escherichia coli lineages.\n\nSwiatek L-S(1), Eger E(1), Surmann K(2), Meller F(1), Schulig L(3), Harms M(2), \nEchelmeyer T(1), Hentschker C(2), Völker U(2), Schwabe M(1), Schaufler K(1)(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Epidemiology and Ecology of Antimicrobial Resistance, Helmholtz \nInstitute for One Health, Helmholtz Centre for Infection Research HZI, \nGreifswald, Germany.\n(2)Department of Functional Genomics, Interfaculty Institute for Genetics and \nFunctional Genomics, University Medicine Greifswald, Greifswald, Germany.\n(3)University of Greifswald, Institute of Pharmacy, Pharmaceutical and Medicinal \nChemistry, Greifswald, Germany.\n(4)University Medicine Greifswald, Greifswald, Germany.\n\nCertain Escherichia coli strains belong to international high-risk clonal \nlineages exhibiting a combination of multidrug resistance, enhanced fitness, and \nincreased virulence, posing major public health challenges. Investigation of \ncharacteristics beyond antibiotic resistance genes and classical virulence \nfactors is crucial to gain understanding of common traits among these pathogens. \nAnalysis of 22,267 publicly available E. coli genomes from five pathogenic and \none commensal sequence type (ST) revealed the L-sorbose phosphotransferase \nsystem (PTS ) as a pathogen-enriched marker. Although previously investigated \nfor evolutionary insights, this system has not been functionally assessed within \nhigh-risk clonal lineages, as performed in the present study. Our multi-omics \nresults demonstrate that the L-sorbose PTS is induced in pathogenic strains of \nST131 and ST648 in the presence of L-sorbose, conferring a competitive advantage \ncompared to a commensal ST10 strain. Transcriptomic analysis revealed \nco-regulated pathways involving metabolism, flagellar motility, and capsular \npolysaccharide production, indicating roles in niche adaptation. Despite some \nstrain-specific variations, functional assays with knock-out/knock-in mutants \nand Galleria mellonella infection models confirmed the operon's impact on \ncompetition and fitness.\nIMPORTANCE: This study highlights the value of combining large-scale genomic \nanalyses with functional validation for identifying and analyzing the L‑sorbose \nphosphotransferase system in different E. coli high-risk clones. This knowledge \nmay be applied in future studies to address the need for identifying \nalternative, pathogen-specific targets.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/msystems.01274-25\nPMID: 41363471"}],

PLoS One. 2025 Dec 9;20(12):e0338703. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0338703. \neCollection 2025.\n\nDiversity of ESBL-producing E. coli in various water and sediment types.\n\nMaric L(1)(2), Rupnik M(1)(3), Janezic S(1)(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department for Microbiological Research, Centre for Medical Microbiology, \nNational Laboratory of Health, Environment and Food, Maribor, Slovenia.\n(2)Biotechnical Faculty, University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia.\n(3)Faculty of Medicine, University of Maribor, Maribor, Slovenia.\n\nAntimicrobial resistance is a major global health threat, and aquatic ecosystems \nserve as critical interfaces between human activity and the environment, \nproviding reservoirs and pathways for the spread of resistant bacteria. In this \nstudy, we investigated the prevalence and diversity of ESBL-producing \nEscherichia coli across multiple aquatic environments in Slovenia by analysing \nwater, sediment, and wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) influent samples \ncollected between June 2023 and April 2024. ESBL-producing E. coli was detected \nin 93% of WWTP influents, 61% of water, and 35% of sediment samples. From 315 \npositive samples, 564 isolates were subjected to whole genome sequencing. In \ntotal, 134 MLST-sequence types (STs) were identified, with globally prevalent \nlineages (ST131, ST38, ST10, ST69, ST1193) occurring across regions and sample \ntypes. Clonally related isolates occurred in geographically distant sites, and \npersistent strains were observed over time, suggesting both local persistence \nand broader dissemination. Fourteen distinct ESBL genes were detected, \npredominantly plasmid-encoded blaCTX-M-15. Water samples captured the greatest \nST diversity, whereas sediment and WWTP influents provided complementary \ninsights. Combining sample types improved detection of overall diversity, with \nwater and sediment or WWTP samples providing the most comprehensive overview. \nOur findings demonstrate widespread and dynamic dissemination of ESBL-producing \nE. coli in Slovenian aquatic environments and emphasize the value of integrated \nsampling strategies for effective surveillance.\n\nCopyright: © 2025 Maric et al.     'abstract': '1. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2025 Dec 9:e0160325. doi: 10.1128/aem.01603-25. Online\n ahead of print.\n\nInvolvement of Escherichia coli-encoded Lon protease and its substrates in \nphenotypic antibiotic resistance elicited by 4-amino-2-nitrophenol.\n\nNandini SS(1), Jagdish S(1), Rana S(2), Nandi D(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Biochemistry, Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, \nKarnataka, India.\n(2)Materials Research Centre, Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, Karnataka, \nIndia.\n\nIn prokaryotes, the energy-dependent protein degradation is controlled, \nprimarily, by two ATP-dependent proteases, Lon and Clp. This study investigates \nthe roles of Escherichia coli (E. coli)-encoded Lon protease in the metabolism \nof 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), a toxic industrial compound. Enhanced conversion \nof yellow-colored 2,4-DNP to a reddish-brown product was observed in a strain \nlacking Lon protease (Δlon). This observation led us to characterize and \nunderstand the mechanisms of 2,4-DNP metabolism. UV-visible and LC-MS analyses \nrevealed differences in the conversion products between the wild-type and Δlon. \nOne of the substrates of Lon protease is MarA, a transcription factor, and \nstudies with different mutants followed by trans complementation demonstrated \nMarA-dependent conversion. The bathochromic shift of spectral peaks suggested \nreduction processes and possible involvement of nitroreductase enzymes. Indeed, \nthe expression of two genes encoding nitroreductases, nfsA and nfsB, increased \nwith 2,4-DNP and was dependent on MarA. Importantly, the production of the \nreddish-brown product was lower in strains lacking nfsA or nfsB. Finally, LC-MS \nanalysis identified one of the conversion products of 2,4-DNP to be \n4-amino-2-nitrophenol (4,2-ANP). Dose studies with purified 4,2-ANP demonstrated \nthat it did not lower the growth of E. coli (unlike 2,4-DNP) and induced \nphenotypic antibiotic resistance in an acrB-dependent (like 2,4-DNP) but in a \nmarA-independent (unlike 2,4-DNP) manner. This study revealed how E. coli in the \nenvironment converts a toxic compound (2,4-DNP) into a lesser toxic compound \n(4,2-ANP) and helps survive in the presence of antibiotics. Overall, this study \ncontributes to our understanding of biological responses to nitroaromatics.\nIMPORTANCE: E. coli is one of the common microorganisms in feces-contaminated \nsewage and often interacts with several pollutants. This study identifies the \nroles of Lon protease and its substrate MarA in inducing nitroreductases, NfsA \nand NfsB, in reducing toxic 2,4-DNP to less toxic 4,2-ANP, a novel inducer of \nphenotypic antibiotic resistance in E. coli. This study sheds light on the roles \nof E. coli-encoded Lon protease upon exposure to harmful nitroaromatics. Common \nenvironmental pollutants can act as a selective pressure, favoring the survival \nas well as proliferation of bacteria containing antibiotic-resistant genes, \nwhich can easily be transferred to other bacteria through horizontal gene \ntransfer. This study offers insights into mitigation methods in E. coli, a \nwell-characterized model. It is possible that such environmental pollution \nstrategies may be translated to other models, such as Pseudomonas, which are \ncommonly used in bioremediation studies.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/aem.01603-25\nPMID: 41364024'},

    'abstract': '1. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2025 Dec 16;122(50):e2514125122. doi: \n10.1073/pnas.2514125122. Epub 2025 Dec 9.\n\nHeterogeneous template-dependent transcription dynamics of T7 RNAP revealed by \nsingle-molecule imaging.\n\nZernia S(1), Deplazes-Lauber J(1), Huber J(1), Stigler J(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Gene Center and Department of Biochemistry, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität \nMünchen, München 81377, Germany.\n\nBacteriophage T7 RNA polymerase (T7 RNAP) is commonly used for large-scale RNA \nsynthesis in science and industry. Although T7 RNAP exhibits high processivity, \nits usage faces two major challenges: During initiation, the enzyme frequently \naborts transcription, producing potentially immunogenic short RNA by-products; \ntransient pausing during elongation facilitates premature termination, which \nleads to shorter transcripts and reduces the overall product yield. Here, we \npresent a single-molecule high-throughput transcription assay using DNA curtains \nto study initiation, elongation, pausing, and termination of individual \npolymerases and examine what drives transcription aborts. We introduced two \ndifferent promoter sites on the template DNA and found that transcription \ninitiation is directly influenced by the DNA shape parameters of the initiation \nregion downstream of the conserved promoter sequence. Furthermore, we showed \nthat dimethyl sulfoxide can alleviate the effects of suboptimal initiation \nsequences. During elongation, we identified two sequence-dependent pause types \nthat differ in length, of which the short pauses relate to ubiquitous pauses in \nbacterial polymerases. Longer pauses emerged by direct contact of the enzyme \nwith a recognition motif on the template and were stabilized through \ninteractions of the nascent RNA with the enzyme. These insights into \ntranscriptional initiation and pausing highlight common impediments to the \nperformance of the T7 RNAP transcription system.\n\nDOI: 10.1073/pnas.2514125122\nPMID: 41364756 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Competing interests statement:The authors \ndeclare no competing interest.'},

Arch Microbiol. 2025 Dec 9;208(1):50. doi: 10.1007/s00203-025-04591-x.\n\nDual-promoter systems drive plasmid loss via non-translational burden in \ngeraniol-producing E. coli.\n\nZhou J(1), Cheng M(1), Su S(1), Li Z(1), Lv M(1), Hu D(1), Zhang X(1), Zhou \nY(1), Shi H(1), Tan Z(1), Xin Y(1), Wang D(1), Tian B(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Faculty of Life Science and Food Engineering, HuaiYin Institute of \nTechnology, Huaian, 223003, PR China.\n(2)Faculty of Life Science and Food Engineering, HuaiYin Institute of \nTechnology, Huaian, 223003, PR China. tianbaoxia@hyit.edu.cn.\n\nPlasmid-driven metabolic burden in Escherichia coli poses a critical challenge \nfor industrial terpenoid production, yet the molecular origins of \ntranscriptional stress remain unclear. Online ahead of print.\n\nThe acquisition of rmpADC can increase virulence of classical Klebsiella \npneumoniae in the absence of other hypervirulence-associated genes.\n\nSalisbury SM(1), Miner TA(1), Kent LA(1), Lam MMC(2), Holt KE(2)(3), Miller \nVL(1)(4), Walker KA(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Microbiology and Immunology, University of North Carolina \nSchool of Medicine, Chapel Hill, North Carolina, USA.\n(2)Department of Infectious Diseases, School of Translational Medicine, Monash \nUniversity, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.\n(3)Department of Infection Biology, London School of Hygiene and Tropical \nMedicine, London, United Kingdom.\n(4)Department of Genetics, University of North Carolina School of Medicine, \nChapel Hill, North Carolina, USA.\n\nKlebsiella pneumoniae is one of the most common causes of nosocomial infections, \nand the rise of drug-resistant K. pneumoniae strains is complicating treatment \nand contributing to a mounting global health crisis. K. pneumoniae has two \npathotypes: classical (cKp) and hypervirulent (hvKp). CKp typically causes \nopportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals in healthcare settings \nand often is multi-drug resistant. HvKp can be community-acquired and cause \nhigh-mortality infections in immunocompetent individuals. Concerningly, \nantibiotic-resistant cKp strains with hypervirulence-associated genes and traits \nhave recently emerged. Determining if and how hv-associated genes contribute to \nincreased virulence of cKp strains is essential to addressing this growing \nthreat. The rmpADC operon is an hv-associated locus that confers \nhypermucoviscosity (HMV), a key virulence phenotype, and rmp genes are often \nfound in convergent strains. In this study, we aimed to determine if the rmp \ngenes alone could increase the virulence of cKp strains in the absence of other \nhv-associated genes. We introduced genetically distinct rmp loci from different \nlineages into a broad array of cKp isolates and found that, while many isolates \nbecame HMV positive, only a subset of these strains showed an increase in \nvirulence in a mouse model of pneumonia. Sequence type and capsule type were not \npredictive of how rmp acquisition impacted the clinical isolates. Our results \nindicate that HMV is likely necessary but not sufficient for hypervirulence and \nthat rmp sequence can influence virulence potential in cKp \nstrains.IMPORTANCEKlebsiella pneumoniae is a global pathogen, and gene exchange \nbetween hypervirulent (hvKp) and classical (cKp) strains is a rising threat. It \nis essential to understand how hvKp genes impact virulence phenotypes and \nidentify the cKp strain backgrounds most amenable to enhanced virulence. \nHypermucoviscosity (HMV) is a critical virulence factor in hypervirulent K. \npneumoniae, conferred by the rmpADC locus. The rmp genes are encoded on mobile \ngenetic elements and have been detected in convergent antibiotic-resistant K. \npneumoniae strains of concern. In this study, we explored the impact of rmp \nacquisition in a broad set of classical clinical isolates. We observed that HMV \nappears necessary, but not sufficient, for increased virulence. Sequence type, \ncapsule type, and HMV capacity could not predict which classical isolates gain \nan rmp-dependent colonization benefit. These insights increase our understanding \nof the distinctions between cKp and hvKp and further our ability to identify and \ntreat new strains of concern.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/mbio.03122-25\nPMID: 41363447'},

In this study, we \ncompared the genomic characteristics of MDR in classical and hypervirulent K. \npneumoniae clinical isolates. Sixty-four isolates were collected from two \nhealthcare institutions in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan, and identified using \nstandard microbiological techniques. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) was performed \non 30 selected isolates using an Illumina platform. The sequencing data were \nanalysed with the Kleborate tool. WGS analysis identified sequence types ST147 \n(n\u2009=\u20097, 23%) and ST2629 (n\u2009=\u20095, 16.6%) as the most prevalent lineages. \nAdditionally, 13 other ST were detected, including ST147-1LV (n\u2009=\u20091, 3.3%) and \nST859 (n\u2009=\u20091, 3.3%), which exhibited hypervirulent MDR traits. The \nmost prevalent plasmid replicons were Col(pHAD28), IncFIB(K), and IncR, with the \nhypervirulent ST147-1LV isolate carrying the highest number. These findings \nunderscore the significant public health threat posed by hypervirulent and MDR \nK. pneumoniae strains, highlighting the extensive burden of virulence and \nresistance genes that complicate treatment strategies.\n\n© 2025. Chickenpox was confirmed by positive polymerase chain reaction \n(PCR), positive IgM, viral culture, and low IgG. Acyclovir 800 mg orally, five \ntimes a day, was given for ten days to treat chickenpox infection because \nacyclovir inhibits varicella zoster virus replication. This study designed and evaluated \nthe performance of an in-house multiplex real-time PCR for simultaneous \ndetection of these viruses. Materials and Methods: Plasma samples from 270 \ntransplant patients were tested using an in-house multiplex real-time PCR assay \nspecifically designed for HSV, VZV, and EBV. Analytical specificity and the \nassay's limit of detection (LOD) were determined. Statistical analyses were \nperformed to evaluate the agreement between the in-house assay and the reference \nkit. Results: The method had a specificity of 98% for HSV, 97% for VZV, and 95% \nfor EBV, alongside 100% sensitivity for all three viruses. No cross-reactivity \nwas observed with other viral or bacterial DNA. The LOD for the in-house assay \nwas determined to be 6.25, 25, and 25 copies/mL for HSV, VZV, and EBV, \nrespectively. Additionally, precision analysis showed low CV values in both \nintra-assay and interassay evaluations (HSV: 1.5%-1.8%; VZV: 2.3%-2.6%; and EBV: \n3.7%-3.9%), confirming the assay's robust analytical precision. Bland-Altman \nanalysis showed mean differences of 1.35, -3.29, and 1.75 for HSV, VZV, and EBV, \nrespectively. This multiplex real-time PCR method enables detection at lower \nconcentrations. Cross-reactivity testing confirmed no interaction with DNA from \nother viruses or nontarget microorganisms. Bland-Altman and linear regression \nanalyses also showed a strong agreement between commercial and in-house methods. \nConclusion: These findings, compared to Altona diagnostic kits, highlight the \nvalue of designing and applying advanced diagnostic assays in managing viral \ninfections in transplant patients.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Reyhaneh Kalhor et al. Antiviral \nagents are critical for controlling these infections; however, an open-access \ndatabase dedicated specifically to antiviral agents remains unavailable. Here, \nwe present AntiviralDB (https://www.antiviraldb.com/), an expert-curated \nresource that compiles both approved and experimental antiviral agents with \nlaboratory-confirmed in vitro activity against a broad spectrum of human \nviruses. These include the human immunodeficiency virus, coronaviruses, \nhepatitis viruses, influenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus, herpes simplex \nvirus, varicella-zoster virus, human cytomegalovirus, human papillomavirus, \ndengue virus, Zika virus, Ebola virus, mpox virus, norovirus, chikungunya virus, \nand 16 other common or life-threatening pathogens. Each antiviral agent in the \ndatabase is annotated with key information, including its molecular target, in \nvitro antiviral activity (IC50, EC50, and CC50 across specific viral strains and \ncell lines), mechanism of action, and relevant pharmacokinetic and \npharmacodynamic parameters. AntiviralDB also provides clinical efficacy and \nsafety data derived from randomized clinical trials. Unlike existing drug \ndatabases, AntiviralDB offers two distinctive features: (i) standardized \nlaboratory protocols for antiviral drug screening under appropriate biosafety \nconditions and (ii) clinical guidelines for the therapeutic use of antiviral \nagents against viral infections. By serving as a comprehensive repository of \nantiviral agents and their clinical applications, AntiviralDB aims to advance \nantiviral drug discovery and support the effective clinical management of viral \ninfectious diseases.\nIMPORTANCE: Over the past decade, viral infectious diseases have caused \nsignificant morbidity and mortality worldwide, underscoring the urgent need for \neffective antiviral therapies. However, there is a lack of an open-access \ndatabase that consolidates detailed information on antiviral agents, clinical \nguidelines, and laboratory protocols. To address this need, AntiviralDB was \ndeveloped to integrate extensive data on antiviral agents-including clinical \nefficacy, safety profiles, pharmacokinetic parameters, and in vitro and in vivo \nactivities-together with standardized experimental protocols and clinical \ntreatment guidelines. This resource empowers researchers and clinicians to (i) \nidentify promising antiviral candidates for controlling infectious diseases, \n(ii) accelerate the discovery and development of novel therapeutics, (iii) \noptimize the clinical use of existing antiviral drugs, and (iv) enhance a quick \nresponse to emerging viral outbreaks.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/mbio.02013-25\nPMCID: PMC12506027\nPMID: 40932285 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest.'}],

This case report describes a rare \ntransmission of chickenpox potentially linked to an indirect route via surface \ncontamination rather than direct person-to-person contact. In this case report, the patient's \nface, neck, and scapulae were the most infected areas of the body, and the rest \nof the body, except the legs, hands, genital areas, and buttocks, was also \nhighly infected. Chickenpox was confirmed by positive polymerase chain reaction \n(PCR), positive IgM, viral culture, and low IgG. Acyclovir 800 mg orally, five \ntimes a day, was given for ten days to treat chickenpox infection because \nacyclovir inhibits varicella zoster virus replication. It is typically unable to \neradicate VZV from the latent state in neurons. The patient showed marked \nimprovement within a week and fully recovered without complications or \npost-herpetic sequelae. This study designed and evaluated \nthe performance of an in-house multiplex real-time PCR for simultaneous \ndetection of these viruses. Materials and Methods: Plasma samples from 270 \ntransplant patients were tested using an in-house multiplex real-time PCR assay \nspecifically designed for HSV, VZV, and EBV. Analytical specificity and the \nassay's limit of detection (LOD) were determined. Statistical analyses were \nperformed to evaluate the agreement between the in-house assay and the reference \nkit. Results: The method had a specificity of 98% for HSV, 97% for VZV, and 95% \nfor EBV, alongside 100% sensitivity for all three viruses. No cross-reactivity \nwas observed with other viral or bacterial DNA. The LOD for the in-house assay \nwas determined to be 6.25, 25, and 25 copies/mL for HSV, VZV, and EBV, \nrespectively. Additionally, precision analysis showed low CV values in both \nintra-assay and interassay evaluations (HSV: 1.5%-1.8%; VZV: 2.3%-2.6%; and EBV: \n3.7%-3.9%), confirming the assay's robust analytical precision. Bland-Altman \nanalysis showed mean differences of 1.35, -3.29, and 1.75 for HSV, VZV, and EBV, \nrespectively. This multiplex real-time PCR method enables detection at lower \nconcentrations. Cross-reactivity testing confirmed no interaction with DNA from \nother viruses or nontarget microorganisms. Bland-Altman and linear regression \nanalyses also showed a strong agreement between commercial and in-house methods. \nConclusion: These findings, compared to Altona diagnostic kits, highlight the \nvalue of designing and applying advanced diagnostic assays in managing viral \ninfections in transplant patients.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Reyhaneh Kalhor et al. Antiviral \nagents are critical for controlling these infections; however, an open-access \ndatabase dedicated specifically to antiviral agents remains unavailable. Here, \nwe present AntiviralDB (https://www.antiviraldb.com/), an expert-curated \nresource that compiles both approved and experimental antiviral agents with \nlaboratory-confirmed in vitro activity against a broad spectrum of human \nviruses. These include the human immunodeficiency virus, coronaviruses, \nhepatitis viruses, influenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus, herpes simplex \nvirus, varicella-zoster virus, human cytomegalovirus, human papillomavirus, \ndengue virus, Zika virus, Ebola virus, mpox virus, norovirus, chikungunya virus, \nand 16 other common or life-threatening pathogens. Each antiviral agent in the \ndatabase is annotated with key information, including its molecular target, in \nvitro antiviral activity (IC50, EC50, and CC50 across specific viral strains and \ncell lines), mechanism of action, and relevant pharmacokinetic and \npharmacodynamic parameters. AntiviralDB also provides clinical efficacy and \nsafety data derived from randomized clinical trials. Unlike existing drug \ndatabases, AntiviralDB offers two distinctive features: (i) standardized \nlaboratory protocols for antiviral drug screening under appropriate biosafety \nconditions and (ii) clinical guidelines for the therapeutic use of antiviral \nagents against viral infections. By serving as a comprehensive repository of \nantiviral agents and their clinical applications, AntiviralDB aims to advance \nantiviral drug discovery and support the effective clinical management of viral \ninfectious diseases.\nIMPORTANCE: Over the past decade, viral infectious diseases have caused \nsignificant morbidity and mortality worldwide, underscoring the urgent need for \neffective antiviral therapies. However, there is a lack of an open-access \ndatabase that consolidates detailed information on antiviral agents, clinical \nguidelines, and laboratory protocols. To address this need, AntiviralDB was \ndeveloped to integrate extensive data on antiviral agents-including clinical \nefficacy, safety profiles, pharmacokinetic parameters, and in vitro and in vivo \nactivities-together with standardized experimental protocols and clinical \ntreatment guidelines. This resource empowers researchers and clinicians to (i) \nidentify promising antiviral candidates for controlling infectious diseases, \n(ii) accelerate the discovery and development of novel therapeutics, (iii) \noptimize the clinical use of existing antiviral drugs, and (iv) enhance a quick \nresponse to emerging viral outbreaks.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/mbio.02013-25\nPMCID: PMC12506027\nPMID: 40932285 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest.'}],

Epidemiological data \nindicate heterogeneous effects on common infections such as Adenoviral \nconjunctivitis due to varying compliance with hygiene measures. Therapeutic challenges are \ndefined by the persistent threat of antiviral resistance, primarily driven by \nmutations in the viral Thymidine Kinase (TK) gene. To overcome poor ocular \nbioavailability, novel drug delivery systems (NDDS), such as Acyclovir-loaded \nNiosomes and Cubosomes, show promise by enabling sustained drug release and \nenhanced corneal permeation. Effective future VIOD control requires a \nmulti-pronged strategy integrating robust global surveillance, rapid deployment \nof advanced molecular diagnostics, and the clinical implementation of \nresistance-beating therapies delivered via optimized nanocarrier platforms. Dis Aquat Organ. 2025 Dec 4;164:143-148. doi: 10.3354/dao03878.\n\nFeasibility of setting epidemiological cut-off values for Aeromonas spp.\n\nSmith P(1), Baron S(2), Kronvall G(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)School of Natural Science, University of Galway, Galway H91 TK33, Ireland.\n(2)Anses, Ploufragan-Plouzané-Niort Laboratory, Mycoplasmology Bacteriology \nAntimicrobial Resistance Unit, 22440 Ploufragan, France.\n(3)Department of Laboratory Medicine, Division of Clinical Microbiology, \nKarolinska Institute, SE-17177 Stockholm, Sweden.\n\nThis study analysed published data on the distributions of minimum inhibitory \nconcentrations of a group of freshwater isolates classified as Aeromonas spp. \nwith the aim of establishing whether they provided any evidence that \nepidemiological cut-off values set from these data would be unreliable. This \ngroup contained 233 isolates and included members of at least 11 species. The \nstandard deviations (SDs) of the wild-type distributions for 10 antimicrobial \nagents were calculated for this multi-species group using the ECOFFinder and \nnormalised resistance interpretation (NRI) algorithms. These were compared to \nthe SDs of 110 distributions established for individual species published by the \nEuropean Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing. Fifty-one of these \ndistributions had been generated by multiple laboratories and 59 by single \nlaboratories. When the ECOFFinder algorithm was used to calculate the SDs, the \nmean for the multi-species group was 0.63 log2 µg ml-1, and the 51 individual \nspecies and multiple-laboratory groups were 0.68 and 0.65 log2 µg ml-1, \nrespectively. When the NRI algorithm was used, the mean for the multi-species \ngroup was 0.79 log2 µg ml-1, and the 51 individual species and \nmultiple-laboratory groups were 0.79 and 0.76 log2 µg ml-1, respectively. These \ncomparisons indicate that the heterogeneity in the susceptibility to \nantimicrobial agents within the multi-species group of Aeromonas is not \nsignificantly different from that recorded for individual species. This \nanalysis, therefore, suggests that epidemiological cut-off values designed to be \napplied to all members of the genus Aeromonas would not be inherently \nunreliable.\n\nDOI: 10.3354/dao03878\nPMID: 41342222 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},

This study aims to \nidentify the underlying causes of summer mortality syndrome in fish and to \nevaluate modern mitigation strategies to protect aquaculture systems \neffectively. Mortality rates of stocked fish ranged between 30% and 70%, with \nsome instances reaching 100%. The reasons behind summer mortality syndrome are \ncomplex and multifactorial. Contributing factors include pathogenic agents such \nas bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites, as well as poor management practices \nand unfavorable environmental conditions. Most types of bacteria that caused \nmortality rates in many fish species were Aeromonas spp., Flexibacter \ncolumnaris, Flavobacterium columnare, Pseudomonas spp., and Enterobacteriaceae, \nnamely Edwardsiella tarda, Yersinia spp., and Streptococcus spp. To mitigate the \nimpact of this syndrome, several protective measures can be implemented. These \ninclude applying some nutritional inventions such as herbal additives, essential \noils, natural compounds, water management, antibiotics, vaccinations, modern \ntechnology, and improved management practices. By addressing these factors \ncomprehensively, the risk of summer mortality syndrome can be significantly \nreduced. This review provides further evidence regarding the effects of summer \nmortality syndrome in fish. The main causes of this phenomenon are pathogens and \npoor management. Nutritional additives and vaccinations were effective ways to \nmitigate these harmful effects to maintain fish production. Further research is \nneeded to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of these mitigation strategies \nand to develop guidelines for sustainable fish farming practices under changing \nclimatic conditions.\n\n© The authors.\n\nDOI: 10.5455/javar.2025.l951\nPMCID: PMC12665324\nPMID: 41328249\n\nConflict of interest statement: The author declares that there is no conflict of \ninterest.'},

The E-strip disk diffusion method showed susceptibility in \n65.52 % of isolates, while the BDE and DSE methods demonstrated susceptibility \nin 54.31 % and 58.62 %, respectively. Resistance to the CZA-ATM combination was \nnotably high in Pseudomonas spp., likely due to non-carbapenemases mechanisms \nlike efflux pump activity or porin mutations. Compared to the E-strip disk \ndiffusion method, BDE method showed an agreement of 78.4 %, while DSE method \nexhibited an agreement of 89.7 %. Methodological inconsistencies in sampling and reporting \n(particularly regarding contaminants, duplicates, and anaerobes) further \ncomplicated interpretation and underscore the need for standardized protocols. \nNevertheless, findings consistently confirmed a polymicrobial flora dominated by \na small group of recurrent species. Despite \nmarked heterogeneity, the consistent predominance of Staphylococcus aureus, \nEnterobacteriaceae, Streptococcus spp., Enterococcus spp., Pseudomonas spp., and \nBacteroides spp. provides a valuable framework for empiric therapy. The most common causative organisms include Staphylococcus spp., \nPseudomonas spp., and Fusarium spp., with rising concerns about antimicrobial \nresistance. Several risk factors have been identified, including the use of \ntopical corticosteroids, systemic immunosuppression, and fungal infections, \nparticularly those caused by Fusarium. Fluorescent Pseudomonas are often implicated in such \nsuppressiveness, but their genomic determinants and distribution in suppressive \nvs. non-suppressive (i.e., conducive) soils remain unclear.\nRESULTS: We investigated the taxonomic and functional diversity of Pseudomonas \npopulations from wheat rhizospheres in four agricultural soils with contrasting \nsuppressiveness to Fusarium graminearum-induced seedling disease. rpoD-based \nmetabarcoding and culture-dependent isolation revealed distinct Pseudomonas \ncommunity structures linked to soil suppressiveness. However, major phylogenetic \ngroups were shared across soils. From 406 isolates, 29 representative strains \nspanning seven subgroups of the P. fluorescens group were selected for \nwhole-genome sequencing. Comparative genomics revealed 14 putative novel \nPseudomonas genomospecies (dDDH\u2009<\u200970% with closest described type strains). \nGenomic screening revealed wide distribution of genes linked to biocontrol and \nplant-growth promotion, including siderophore biosynthesis, hormone modulation, \nphosphate solubilization, and production of antimicrobial compounds. \nBiosynthetic genes for phenazine and pyrrolnitrin were detected exclusively in \nP. chlororaphis strains isolated from suppressive soils, and rpoD alleles \ncorresponding to these strains were not found in conducive soils within our \nmetabarcoding dataset. Other traits such as hydrogen cyanide, ACC deaminase, and \nauxin biosynthesis were broadly distributed across isolates from all soils. \nFunctional assays demonstrated variable expression of predicted traits, \nindicating regulatory or environmental influence. Several strains inhibited F. \ngraminearum mycelial growth via volatile organic compounds, while two strains \nalso reduced conidia germination, including isolates from both suppressive and \nconducive soils.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that Pseudomonas genomic traits important \nfor biocontrol are not restricted to suppressive soils, and that functional \nredundancy and context-dependent expression may shape the contribution of \nPseudomonas to disease suppression. Our results highlight the need for \nintegrative analyses combining community profiling, genome-based prediction, and \nphenotyping to better understand microbiome-mediated plant protection. The \nidentification of novel genomospecies and lineage-specific biosynthetic traits \nadvances our knowledge of Pseudomonas diversity in agricultural soils and \nsupports future development of targeted microbial consortia.\n\n© 2025. J Adv Vet Anim Res. 2025 Sep 12;12(3):890-907. doi: 10.5455/javar.2025.l951. \neCollection 2025 Sep.\n\nA comprehensive review of summer mortality syndrome in fish: Causes, climate \nimpact, and mitigation strategies.\n\nShafi ME(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Sustainable Agriculture Production Research Group, Department of Biological \nSciences, Zoology, King Abdulaziz University, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.\n\nGlobal warming poses a significant threat to aquatic animals, particularly fish \nproduction, because of the rising summer temperatures, leading to issues such as \nsummer mortality syndrome. This issue could impact fish farms, leading to \n30%-100% mortality rates and significant financial losses. This study aims to \nidentify the underlying causes of summer mortality syndrome in fish and to \nevaluate modern mitigation strategies to protect aquaculture systems \neffectively. Mortality rates of stocked fish ranged between 30% and 70%, with \nsome instances reaching 100%. The reasons behind summer mortality syndrome are \ncomplex and multifactorial. Contributing factors include pathogenic agents such \nas bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites, as well as poor management practices \nand unfavorable environmental conditions. Most types of bacteria that caused \nmortality rates in many fish species were Aeromonas spp., Flexibacter \ncolumnaris, Flavobacterium columnare, Pseudomonas spp., and Enterobacteriaceae, \nnamely Edwardsiella tarda, Yersinia spp., and Streptococcus spp. To mitigate the \nimpact of this syndrome, several protective measures can be implemented. These \ninclude applying some nutritional inventions such as herbal additives, essential \noils, natural compounds, water management, antibiotics, vaccinations, modern \ntechnology, and improved management practices. By addressing these factors \ncomprehensively, the risk of summer mortality syndrome can be significantly \nreduced. This review provides further evidence regarding the effects of summer \nmortality syndrome in fish. The main causes of this phenomenon are pathogens and \npoor management. Nutritional additives and vaccinations were effective ways to \nmitigate these harmful effects to maintain fish production. Further research is \nneeded to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of these mitigation strategies \nand to develop guidelines for sustainable fish farming practices under changing \nclimatic conditions.\n\n© The authors.\n\nDOI: 10.5455/javar.2025.l951\nPMCID: PMC12665324\nPMID: 41328249\n\nConflict of interest statement: The author declares that there is no conflict of \ninterest.'},

Online ahead of \nprint.\n\nFluorescent Pseudomonas spp. from suppressive and conducive soils share genomic \nand functional traits relevant to Fusarium graminearum disease suppression.\n\nTodorović I(1)(2)(3), Abrouk D(2), Kyselková M(4), Rey M(2), López-Mondéjar \nR(5), Raičević V(3), Jovičić-Petrović J(3), Moënne-Loccoz Y(2)(6), Muller D(7).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Hydroecology and Water Protection, Institute for Biological \nResearch ¨Siniša Stanković¨, National Institute of the Republic of Serbia, \nUniversity of Belgrade, Bulevar despota Stefana 142, Belgrade, 11060, Serbia.\n(2)UMR5557 Ecologie Microbienne, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, INRAE, \nVetAgro Sup, 43 bd du 11 novembre 1918, Villeurbanne, F-69622, France.\n(3)Department of Microbial Ecology, Faculty of Agriculture, University of \nBelgrade, Nemanjina 6, Belgrade, Zemun, 11080, Serbia.\n(4)Laboratory of Environmental Microbiology, Institute of Microbiology of the \nCzech Academy of Sciences, Vídeňská 1083, 14220, Prague 4, Czech Republic.\n(5)Department of Soil and Water Conservation, CEBAS-CSIC, Campus Universitario \nde Espinardo, Murcia, 30100, Spain.\n(6)Institut Universitaire de France (IUF), Paris, F-75005, France.\n(7)UMR5557 Ecologie Microbienne, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, CNRS, INRAE, \nVetAgro Sup, 43 bd du 11 novembre 1918, Villeurbanne, F-69622, France. \ndaniel.muller@univ-lyon1.fr.\n\nBACKGROUND: Soils suppressive to fungal pathogens harbor microbiomes that can \ninhibit disease development despite the presence of virulent pathogens and \nsusceptible hosts. Fluorescent Pseudomonas are often implicated in such \nsuppressiveness, but their genomic determinants and distribution in suppressive \nvs. non-suppressive (i.e., conducive) soils remain unclear.\nRESULTS: We investigated the taxonomic and functional diversity of Pseudomonas \npopulations from wheat rhizospheres in four agricultural soils with contrasting \nsuppressiveness to Fusarium graminearum-induced seedling disease. rpoD-based \nmetabarcoding and culture-dependent isolation revealed distinct Pseudomonas \ncommunity structures linked to soil suppressiveness. However, major phylogenetic \ngroups were shared across soils. From 406 isolates, 29 representative strains \nspanning seven subgroups of the P. fluorescens group were selected for \nwhole-genome sequencing. Comparative genomics revealed 14 putative novel \nPseudomonas genomospecies (dDDH\u2009<\u200970% with closest described type strains). \nGenomic screening revealed wide distribution of genes linked to biocontrol and \nplant-growth promotion, including siderophore biosynthesis, hormone modulation, \nphosphate solubilization, and production of antimicrobial compounds. \nBiosynthetic genes for phenazine and pyrrolnitrin were detected exclusively in \nP. chlororaphis strains isolated from suppressive soils, and rpoD alleles \ncorresponding to these strains were not found in conducive soils within our \nmetabarcoding dataset. Other traits such as hydrogen cyanide, ACC deaminase, and \nauxin biosynthesis were broadly distributed across isolates from all soils. \nFunctional assays demonstrated variable expression of predicted traits, \nindicating regulatory or environmental influence. Several strains inhibited F. \ngraminearum mycelial growth via volatile organic compounds, while two strains \nalso reduced conidia germination, including isolates from both suppressive and \nconducive soils.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that Pseudomonas genomic traits important \nfor biocontrol are not restricted to suppressive soils, and that functional \nredundancy and context-dependent expression may shape the contribution of \nPseudomonas to disease suppression. Our results highlight the need for \nintegrative analyses combining community profiling, genome-based prediction, and \nphenotyping to better understand microbiome-mediated plant protection. The \nidentification of novel genomospecies and lineage-specific biosynthetic traits \nadvances our knowledge of Pseudomonas diversity in agricultural soils and \nsupports future development of targeted microbial consortia.\n\n© 2025. We suggest risk factors for \ntransmission may include shared equipment, environmental and PPE contamination, \nand failure of effective hand hygiene. With COVID-19 infection endemic, if \nSARS-CoV-2 patients require cohort nursing in bays with sessional use gowns, we \nrecommend these are short-sleeved, to facilitate effective hand hygiene. We \nargue strict Infection Control policy, including enhanced cleaning, is critical \nto reduce transmission of hypervirulent K. pneumoniae and advocate for enhanced \nnational surveillance systems.\n\n© 2025 The Authors.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.infpip.2025.100492\nPMCID: PMC12661296\nPMID: 41323289\n\nConflict of interest statement: None declared.'},

    'abstract': '1. Microbiol Spectr. 2025 Nov 26:e0310825. doi: 10.1128/spectrum.03108-25. Online\n ahead of print.\n\nPredicting bacterial-mediated entomopathogenicity through comparative genomics \nand statistical modeling.\n\nYanez Ortuno D(1), Chen MY(1), McDonald K(1), Gacad A(2), Carrillo J(2), Haney \nCH(1)(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The University of British \nColumbia, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.\n(2)Faculty of Land and Food Systems, The University of British Columbia, \nVancouver, British Columbia, Canada.\n(3)Department of Biological Sciences, The University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, \nPennsylvania, USA.\n\nBacterial genomes encode vast functional diversity and have both beneficial and \ndetrimental effects on insect hosts. While genotype-to-phenotype relationships \nare known for specific insecticidal genes on individual insect hosts, whether \nthese mechanisms will be effective on a phylogenetically distinct insect host is \nnot always known. To determine if known virulence genes are effective on a new \nhost, we developed a method to merge existing mechanistic knowledge with in vivo \ntests on a small number of bacterial isolates to predict bacterial genes \nassociated with entomopathogenesis. We used a model consisting of Drosophila \nmelanogaster interactions with pathogenic and commensal genome-sequenced strains \nof Pseudomonas bacteria. We compiled a database of previously described \ninsecticidal and biocontrol genes within the Pseudomonas genus and used \ncomparative genomics to probe the distribution of these genes across Pseudomonas \nstrains. We found natural variation in the presence of known insecticidal genes \nacross the genus. We tested the insect-killing capacity of 13 Pseudomonas spp. \nstrains against D. melanogaster and found natural variation in insecticidal \nactivity. To identify bacterial genes associated with fly mortality, we employed \ntwo statistical models to correlate bacterial virulence with the presence of \npreviously described insecticidal activity. To validate our predictions, we used \na P. aeruginosa PAO1 transposon mutant library and identified eight operons that \nare necessary for killing D. melanogaster. We show that by combining existing \nliterature with phenotyping a small number of strains, we identified both known \nand novel genes associated with insecticidal activity in D. melanogaster, using \na rapid, scalable screening framework. More broadly, these findings illustrate a \ndiscovery pipeline for bacterial virulence mechanisms, accelerating the \ndiscovery of insect pest biocontrol mechanisms.IMPORTANCEBacteria with \ninsecticidal properties offer a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, \nbut identifying effective strains and their underlying mechanisms remains a \nchallenge. Here, we used Pseudomonas-D. melanogaster as a model to develop a \npredictive framework for determining which known bacterial genes with \ninsecticidal activity are effective in a new host. By integrating comparative \ngenomics, statistical modeling, and experimental validation, we identified \ninsecticidal genes that are effective in D. melanogaster and highlighted new \ncandidates for future study, demonstrating the utility of our integrative \nmodeling approach. Our findings show that genetic predictors of virulence vary \nacross Pseudomonas phylogenetic groups, highlighting the potential for targeted \nbiocontrol strategies. We also demonstrate that disrupting specific pathways \nsignificantly reduces insecticidal activity, confirming their role in bacterial \nvirulence. As Pseudomonas strains are found in diverse environments, this \napproach may be broadly applicable for predicting insecticidal efficacy in other \nbacterial genera. By improving our ability to identify and engineer microbial \nbiocontrol agents, this work advances sustainable pest management strategies and \nprovides new tools for reducing reliance on conventional pesticides.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/spectrum.03108-25\nPMID: 41294238'}]},

Therefore, these bacterial strains exhibit strong potential for \napplication in the bioremoval of heavy metals from wastewater.\n\n© 2025. In \nconclusion, this study reveals that Comamonas may act as an important reservoir \nfor antibiotics-resistance genes and plasmids in the environment. Sex Transm Dis. 2026 Jan 1;53(1):59-66. doi: 10.1097/OLQ.0000000000002237.\nEpub  2025 Sep 9.\n\nMyocarditis and Pericarditis as a Complication of Mpox: Case Series and \nLiterature Review.\n\nHalani S, Cai S, Zanoria C(1), Monge JC, Mishra S, Brouillard P, Tremblay C, \nPinho AI(2), Rodriguez-Nava G(3), Cooper JD, Narasimhan S, Kadlecik P(4), Khera \nSS, Tan DHS.\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Division of Infectious Diseases, Unity Health Toronto.\n(2)Department of Cardiology, São João University Hospital Centre, Porto, \nPortugal.\n(3)Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford.\n(4)Mid-Atlantic Permanente Medical Group, Rockville, MD.\n\nMonkeypox virus is a DNA virus in the orthopoxvirus family, and a multicountry \noutbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern both in \n2022 and 2024. Myocarditis is a known complication of many viral infections, and \nchest pain and electrocardiogram changes may occur from 1 to 4 weeks \npost-infection. We present 2 clinical cases of mpox-related myocarditis from \nCanada. We identified 19 additional cases of myocarditis and/or pericarditis in \nthe literature, and data were synthesized with our 2 cases. All 20 patients with \navailable data were hospitalized, 6 of whom were admitted to an intensive care \nunit. Median time of cardiac symptom onset after initial mpox symptom onset was \n5 (range, 0-14) days, elevated troponin was present in 19 of 19 cases (range, \n165-21,200 ng/L), arrhythmias were described in 1 patient with Mobitz type 1 and \n2 atrioventricular blocks, and echocardiograms showed reduced ejection fraction \nin 4 of 15 patients. There were no deaths reported. Management of mpox involves \nsymptom control and anti-inflammatories. Recent trials have not shown benefit of \ntecovirimat compared with placebo in shortening time to lesion resolution; \nhowever, in this article, we discuss nuances regarding antivirals in the setting \nof mpox-related myocarditis.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Author(s). Consistent ART \nmarkedly improves prognosis, highlighting the need for early identification of \nhigh-risk patients and integrated management-including sustained ART and \ntargeted Mpox treatment-to reduce severe outcomes.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Wang, Zhou, Yuan, Wang, Yin, Zhao, Shi, Chen and Li.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2025.1705001\nPMCID: PMC12675438\nPMID: 41356465\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest."},

Here, we \ndescribe a thermally regulated asynchronous CRISPR-enhanced (TRACE) assay that \nrapidly and sensitively detects multiple DNA targets in a streamlined, one-pot \nformat. TRACE exhibits a 2.5 copies/test limit of detection - 40 times lower \nthan a canonical one-pot CRISPR. When applied to clinical samples, it achieves \n99.5% accuracy across diverse sample types, and can detect MPXV within \n11\u2009minutes. Given the high sensitivity of bioinformatics data, \nparticularly gene sequences, plaintext transmission and processing in cloud \nenvironments pose risks of privacy leakage. To address this, this study \ninnovatively proposes an analytical method combining Mamba neural network-based \ngene sequence prediction with homomorphic encryption, enabling secure data \ntransmission while employing deep learning for sequence prediction. Using the \nmonkeypox virus experimental ID SRX17751190 and sequencing ID SRR21755835 as \nexamples, the study first decomposes the original gene sequence using VMD modal \ndecomposition, then predicts the gene sequence from the decomposed components \nusing the Mamba neural network, and finally performs homomorphic encryption and \nspatial similarity analysis on the predicted data in a cloud computing \nenvironment. Experimental results demonstrate that the average MAE, MSE, RMSE, \nMAPE, and MSPE for the top ten predicted gene sequences are 0.0140, 0.0003, \n0.0190, 0.6527, and 789.52959, respectively, with an average CKKS homomorphic \nencryption computation error of 0.582492456. This ensures secure similarity \ncalculations for gene sequence data in cloud environments.\n\nCopyright © 2025. Cross-reactivity \namong orthopoxivuses, stemming from high sequence conservation, complicates \ndistinguishing antibody responses from natural MPXV infection versus vaccination \nor other orthopoxvirus exposures. We validated the Meso Scale Discovery (MSD) \nV-PLEX Orthopoxvirus Panel 1 (IgG) Kit, which quantifies antibody levels to five \nMPXV antigens and their vaccina virus (VACV) orthologs, following Good Clinical \nLaboratory Practice (GCLP) guidelines. We assessed assay performance using serum \nfrom 26 individuals with prior mpox, 52 JYNNEOS vaccine recipients, and 179 \nunexposed controls. The assay reliably detected antibody responses in all \nexposed cohorts with peak levels observed 2-months post-vaccination. Antibody \nlevels to specific antigens also correlated with Modified Vaccinia Ankara (MVA) \nneutralization titer, particularly for MPXV B6R/VACV B5R, MPXV E8L/VACV D8L, and \nMPXV M1R/VACV L1. Genetic \nevidence for intra- and inter-species recombination has been obtained for AdVs \nof humans and captive great apes, but evidence from wild great apes is lacking. \nIn this study, potential HAdV-B members of wild Eastern gorillas were analysed \nfor evidence of recombination. Outbreaks and epidemics are generally centred in \nclose-contact settings, such as childcare facilities, and transmission occurs \nthrough faecal-oral and airborne pathways. AdVs have coevolved across the \nprimate lineage, but very little is known about whether the early-life dynamics \nin non-human primates mirror those in humans. Here, we leverage longitudinal \ndata collected on a population of geladas (Theropithecus gelada) in the Simien \nMountains National Park, Ethiopia, to evaluate AdV dynamics across the gelada \nlifespan. We identified ten coding-complete AdV genomes representing seven \nunique simian adenovirus (SAdV) types, four of which are adequately different \nfrom the known ones to establish new species. We assessed behavioural and \nseasonal drivers of SAdV presence and richness across repeated faecal samples \nfrom known individuals. Contrary to our expectation that the highest risk would \noccur after the initiation of play behaviour in infancy (~6\u2009months of age), when \npeer-to-peer transmission risk is expected to increase, SAdV likelihood was \nhighest in infants under 6\u2009months of age. Risk and richness declined over the \nlifespan, with very few adults infected, and higher minimum temperatures were \nweakly but significantly negatively associated with richness. Microb Genom. 2025 Dec;11(12). doi: 10.1099/mgen.0.001595.\n\nEarly-life infection dynamics and genomic diversity of adenoviruses in a wild \nprimate (Theropithecus gelada).\n\nSaroff MJ(1), Haile AA(2), Baniel A(3), Kraberger S(4), Regney M(1)(4), Harrach \nB(5), Kaján GL(5), Lu A(6), Beehner JC(7)(8), Bergman TJ(8)(9), Snyder-Mackler \nN(1)(10)(11), Varsani A(1)(10)(12)(4), Schneider-Crease IA(10)(11)(13).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)School of Life Sciences, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, USA.\n(2)Ethiopian Wildlife Conservation Authority, Debark, Ethiopia.\n(3)Institut des Sciences de l'Évolution de Montpellier UMR5554, CNRS, IRD, EPHE, \nUniversité de Montpellier, Montpellier, France.\n(4)The Biodesign Center of Fundamental and Applied Microbiomics, Arizona State \nUniversity, Tempe, AZ, USA.\n(5)HUN-REN Veterinary Medical Research Institute, Budapest, 1143, Hungary.\n(6)Department of Anthropology, Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, New York, \nUSA.\n(7)Department of Anthropology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA.\n(8)Department of Psychology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA.\n(9)Department of Ecology and Evolution, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, \nUSA.\n(10)Center for Evolution and Medicine, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, USA.\n(11)School of Human Evolution and Social Change, Arizona State University, \nTempe, AZ, USA.\n(12)Structural Biology Research Unit, Department of Integrative Biomedical \nSciences, University of Cape Town, Cape Town, 7925, South Africa.\n(13)School of Technology for Public Health, Arizona State University, Phoenix, \nArizona, USA.\n\nIn humans, adenoviruses (AdVs) are frequently associated with respiratory \nillnesses, posing risks to children with developing immune systems and \nimmunocompromised individuals. Outbreaks and epidemics are generally centred in \nclose-contact settings, such as childcare facilities, and transmission occurs \nthrough faecal-oral and airborne pathways. AdVs have coevolved across the \nprimate lineage, but very little is known about whether the early-life dynamics \nin non-human primates mirror those in humans. Here, we leverage longitudinal \ndata collected on a population of geladas (Theropithecus gelada) in the Simien \nMountains National Park, Ethiopia, to evaluate AdV dynamics across the gelada \nlifespan. We identified ten coding-complete AdV genomes representing seven \nunique simian adenovirus (SAdV) types, four of which are adequately different \nfrom the known ones to establish new species. We assessed behavioural and \nseasonal drivers of SAdV presence and richness across repeated faecal samples \nfrom known individuals. Contrary to our expectation that the highest risk would \noccur after the initiation of play behaviour in infancy (~6\u2009months of age), when \npeer-to-peer transmission risk is expected to increase, SAdV likelihood was \nhighest in infants under 6\u2009months of age. Risk and richness declined over the \nlifespan, with very few adults infected, and higher minimum temperatures were \nweakly but significantly negatively associated with richness. Our results \nsuggest that, unlike in humans, SAdV exposure occurs prior to the initiation of \nclose-contact play behaviours and likely results from the close spatial \nproximity of conspecifics throughout the dependent period. Like AdVs in humans, \nSAdVs in geladas maintain low levels in adulthood, with early infections \npotentially conferring life-long immunity.\n\nDOI: 10.1099/mgen.0.001595\nPMID: 41364497 [Indexed for MEDLINE]"},

Viruses. 2025 Nov 6;17(11):1480. doi: 10.3390/v17111480.\n\nWhole-Genome Sequencing of Adenovirus Genotypes and Clinical Implications in \nPediatric Patients.\n\nForqué L(1), Fox V(1), Scutari R(1), Mastropaolo M(1), Merli P(2), Di Maio \nVC(3), Fini V(3), Linardos G(3), Coltella L(3), Ranno S(3), Russo C(3), Villani \nA(4), Perno CF(1)(3), Colagrossi L(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Multimodal Laboratory Medicine, Bambino Gesù Children's Hospital, IRCCS, \n00165 Rome, Italy.\n(2)Department of Hematology/Oncology, Cell and Gene Therapy, Bambino Gesù \nChildren's Hospital, IRCCS, 00165 Rome, Italy.\n(3)Microbiology and Diagnostic Immunology Unit, Bambino Gesù Children's \nHospital, IRCCS, 00165 Rome, Italy.\n(4)General Pediatric and Infectious Disease Unit, Pediatric Emergency Medicine, \nBambino Gesù Children's Hospital, IRCCS, 00165 Rome, Italy.\n\nHuman adenoviruses (HAdV) comprise more than 100 genotypes with species-specific \ndifferences in tropism and immune response and can cause severe infections in \nimmunocompromised patients. This study aimed to characterise the HAdV species \ninvolved in pediatric infections to assess their clinical impact and guide \nfuture therapeutic strategies based on AdV-specific T-cell responses. Between \nJanuary and October 2024, 595 pediatric HAdV diagnoses were made at the Bambino \nGesù Children's Hospital (Rome), and whole-genome sequencing was performed on 60 \nsamples. Most patients (91.7%) were hospitalised, including both immunocompetent \n(75%) and immunocompromised (25%) children. Gastrointestinal and respiratory \nsymptoms were more common in immunocompetent patients, whereas immunocompromised \npatients experienced longer hospitalisations and persistent viral infections. \nSpecies F (F41) was most prevalent (63.3%), especially among immunocompetent \npatients, while species C and A predominated in immunocompromised children, with \nspecies A associated with severe disease. Viral loads were significantly higher \nfor species F than for species A and C, independent of immune status. \nCo-infections were frequent (63.3%), with species C particularly linked to them. \nIn conclusion, HAdV distribution differed by immune status, with species F \npredominating in immunocompetent children and species C and A more common in \nimmunocompromised patients. Whole-genome sequencing may enhance surveillance, \nenable earlier diagnosis, and support the development of genotype-specific \nimmunotherapies.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/v17111480\nPMCID: PMC12656921\nPMID: 41305502 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflicts of interest."},

This study aimed to investigate molecular \nepidemiology of HAdV infection in children with acute gastroenteritis in six \ndifferent prefectures of Japan from 2018 to 2023 by using PCR method and \nsequencing at hypervariable regions and non-hypervariable region in hexon gene. \nThe overall prevalence of HAdV infection was 10.8% before and during the \nCOVID-19 pandemic (2018-2022), while it increased to 27.7% in the post-pandemic \nperiod (2022-2023). Eight HAdV genotypes, F41, C1, C2, C5, C6, B3, A31, and D56 \nwere detected, and F41 was detected as the most prevalent genotype. It should be \nnoted that HAdV-D56, which generally caused epidemic keratoconjunctivitis and \nrespiratory diseases, was detected for the first time in a patient with acute \ngastroenteritis in Japan in this study. In addition, HAdV-F40 was detected as a \nco-predominant with HAdV-F41 genotype, whereas it was undetectable in this \nstudy. The findings indicated that the distribution of HAdV genotypes \nparticularly enteric HAdV-F41 had changed over time. In addition, an emergence \nof HAdV-D56 in a patient with acute gastroenteritis is a potential implication \nof HAdV-D56 involvement in acute gastroenteritis and it is essential to be \ncontinually monitoring worldwide.\n\n© 2025 Wiley Periodicals LLC.\n\nDOI: 10.1002/jmv.70700\nPMID: 41235873 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'}]},

Medicine (Baltimore). 2025 Nov 14;104(46):e45906. doi: \n10.1097/MD.0000000000045906.\n\nClinical evaluation of multiplex PCR for the differential diagnosis of major \npathogenic mycobacteria in East China.\n\nFang T(1), Peng L, Li Z, Li H, Li H, Cai L.\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Clinical Laboratory Center, Hangzhou Red Cross Hospital, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, \nChina.\n\nDistinguishing between Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and nontuberculous \nmycobacteria infections remains clinically challenging due to their drastically \ndifferent treatment regimens, underscoring the critical need for rapid and \naccurate mycobacterial identification to guide effective patient management. \nThis study aimed to develop a multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay \nfor the detection and typing of major pathogenic mycobacteria - including MTB, \nMycobacterium avium complex (MAC), Mycobacteroides chelonae - Mycobacteroides \nabscessus group (MCAG), and Mycobacterium kansasii - and to evaluate its \ndiagnostic performance. The assay was designed with species-specific primers \ntargeting 5 key genes: 16S rRNA, RD9, ITS (internal transcribed spacer) \nregion-MAC, ITS region-MCAG, and mkan-rs12360. Its feasibility and lower limit \nof detection (LOD) were validated using 6 standard mycobacterial strains; \ndiagnostic accuracy was further assessed using 68 clinical isolates and 130 \nclinical sputum samples, with whole-genome sequencing and targeted \nnext-generation sequencing serving as the respective gold standards for isolates \nand sputum specimens. The multiplex PCR assay exhibited high specificity for the \ntarget genes and primers: for standard strains, the LOD ranged from 0.7 to 5.0 \npg/μL; for artificially simulated sputum samples, the LOD was 5.6 to 26.7 pg/μL \nfor single infections and 7.1 to 43.9 pg/μL for mixed infections. Against \nwhole-genome sequencing, the assay achieved 100% detection rate and accuracy for \nclinical isolates. When compared with targeted next-generation sequencing for \nclinical sputum samples, the detection rates for single infections of MTB, MAC, \nMCAG, and M kansasii were 26%, 75%, 56.5%, and 50%, respectively, with an \noverall detection rate of 51.2% and 100% diagnostic accuracy. This multiplex PCR \nassay enables rapid and accurate identification of major pathogenic mycobacteria \nin clinical isolates; however, its sensitivity limitations - evidenced by \nrelatively low detection rates in clinical sputum samples, especially mixed \ninfections - highlight the need for further optimization with more sensitive \nprobe-based technologies to enhance clinical applicability.\n\nCopyright © 2025 the Author(s). A total of 52 NTM culture-positive isolates were collected \nin 2020 from Kashgar, China. All strains were confirmed to be NTM species by \nwhole genome sequencing (WGS). Drug susceptibility testing was performed using \nSensititre SLOMYCO plates. Of the 52 NTM isolates, 88.46% (46/52) were rapidly \ngrowing mycobacteria (RGM). The predominant NTM species were Mycolicibacterium. \nsp (23.07%, 12/52) and M. elephantis (15.38%, 8/52), followed by Mycobacteroides \nchelonae (9.61%, 5/52). At least, two suspected new species were identified. Two \ncore virulence genes were identified in more than 95% of the isolates. \nAntimicrobial susceptibility testing revealed high resistance among RGM isolates \nto imipenem (73.91%), while remained sensitive to amikacin and ciprofloxacin. \nAll slowly growing mycobacteria isolates exhibited the highest resistance rate \nagainst doxycycline (83.3%, 5/6), but most strains were sensitive to \nclarithromycin, rifabutin, amikacin, ciprofloxacin, moxifloxacin, rifampin, and \ntrimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. The prevalence of NTM isolates in Kashgar \npresents a very specific features and some rarely reported species constitute \nbig proportions. Amikacin and moxifloxacin may represent effective therapeutic \noptions for NTM infections in Kashgar.\n\n© 2025. J Food Prot. 2022 Dec 1;85(12):1848-1854. doi: 10.4315/JFP-22-168.\n\nIsolation of Staphylococcus aureus, Uropathogenic Escherichia coli, and \nNontuberculous Mycobacteria Strains from Pasteurized Cheeses and Unpasteurized \nCream Sold at Traditional Open Markets in Mexico City.\n\nRios-Muñiz D(1)(2), Cerna-Cortes JF(1), Lopez-Saucedo C(2), Angeles-Morales \nE(1), Bobadilla-Del Valle M(3), Ponce-DE Leon A(3), Estrada-Garcia T(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Departamento de Microbiología, Escuela Nacional de Ciencias Biológicas, \nInstituto Politécnico Nacional, Prolongación Carpio y Plan de Ayala S/N, Col. \nCasco de Santo Tomas, Mexico City CP 11340, Mexico.\n(2)Department of Molecular Biomedicine, CINVESTAV-IPN, Av. IPN 2508, Zacatenco, \nMexico City CP 07360, Mexico.\n(3)Departamento de Enfermedades Infecciosas, Instituto Nacional de Ciencias \nMédicas y Nutrición Salvador Zubiran, Mexico City CP 14080, Mexico.\n\nABSTRACT: Fresh cheeses and cream are important garnishes of traditional Mexican \nfood, often purchased at street or itinerant open markets or tianguis. However, \nthere is scarce information regarding the microbiological quality of cheeses and \ncream sold in tianguis. For 2 years, three dairy stalls from three tianguis in \nMexico City were visited once each season, trading practices were registered, \nand 96 dairy products were purchased. In total 72 fresh pasteurized cheeses that \nwere hand-cut to order (24 Panela, 24 Canasto, and 24 Doble Crema) and 24 \nunpasteurized Crema de Rancho samples were collected. All dairy products \nremained without refrigeration for 8 h. Based on the National Guidelines limits, \n87.5% of cheeses and 8% of Crema de Rancho samples were of low microbiological \nquality, and 1 sample of each type of cheese and 3 samples of Crema de Rancho \nexceeded the guidelines limits for Staphylococcus aureus. All dairy products \nwere negative for Salmonella, Listeria monocytogenes, and all diarrheagenic \nEscherichia coli pathotypes, including Shiga toxin-producing E. coli. Among the \n96 dairy samples, the prevalence of uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) and of \nmycobacteria strains were determined because food items contaminated with these \nstrains have been associated with urinary tract infections and mycobacteriosis, \nrespectively. UPEC strains were isolated from 43% of cut-to-order cheeses and \n29% of Crema de Rancho samples. Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) strains were \nidentified in 12.5% of Doble Crema cheese samples and 21% of Crema de Rancho \nsamples. From the eight NTM-positive samples, 10 strains were identified (3 \nstrains of Mycolicibacterium fortuitum, 2 of Mycobacteroides abscessus, 2 of \nMycobacteroides chelonae, 2 of Mycolicibacterium porcinum, and 1 of \nMycolicibacterium rhodesiae). All produced biofilms, and 70% had sliding \nmotility (both virulence traits). Trading practices of cut-to-order pasteurized \ncheeses and unpasteurized Crema de Rancho in tianguis increase the risk of \nmicrobiological contamination of these products, including with human pathogens, \nand their consumption may cause human illness.\n\nCopyright ©, International Association for Food Protection.\n\nDOI: 10.4315/JFP-22-168\nPMID: 36454541 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},

Marine sponges \nare a rich source of promising bioactive compounds. Due to their sessile nature \nand filter-feeding lifestyle, sponges are prone to attack by competitors, \npredators, and pathogens. To combat these threats, they produce a diverse array \nof bioactive compounds. Notably, the microbial communities residing within the \nsponges make many of these beneficial compounds. Twenty-one bacterial isolates \nfrom various marine sponges from the Indian coast were selected for this study. \nThe bacterial isolates were fermented to obtain crude extracts, which were then \nscreened against critical bacterial pathogens. Based on the MIC (minimum \ninhibitory concentration) results, two isolates, Bacillus velezensis NIO_002 and \nStutzerimonas stutzeri NIO_003 showing good activity, were characterized by \nmorphological, biochemical, and molecular methods. Genome mining predicted \nmultiple antibiotic biosynthetic gene clusters, most of which showed a high \ndegree of similarity to known gene clusters, and some with low or no similarity \nwhich may be indicative of novel gene clusters. LC-MS (liquid \nchromatography-mass spectrometry) data revealed the putative presence of certain \nantibacterial compounds previously reported in the literature. To our knowledge, \nthis is the first study to report the antimicrobial activity of marine \nsponge-associated Bacillus velezensis and Stutzerimonas stutzeri strains \ncharacterized by whole genome sequencing, thereby indicating the novelty of our \nstrains. This study emphasizes the potential of our bacterial isolates for \nfurther development as a source of promising antibiotics to address the \nescalating challenge of drug-resistant pathogens.\n\n© 2025. Cases were \ndefined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC)\xa0<\xa01000/µL. Controls without \nneutropenia were matched by age (+/-1 year), transplanted organ, and duration of \nVGCV prophylaxis. We used a published population pharmacokinetic model to inform \npredictions of GCV concentrations using Pmetrics, accounting for each subject's \ntime-dependent variables (age, weight, creatinine clearance). We then calculated \n24-h, 7-day, and cumulative area under the curve (AUC) in each subject and used \nconditional logistic regression to compare GCV exposures among cases and \ncontrols.\nRESULTS: Among 164 pSOT recipients prescribed VGCV, we identified 35 \ncase-control matches. There were no statistically significant differences in the \n24-h (odds ratio [OR] 0.990, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.964-1.018), 7-day \n(OR 1.000, 95% CI 0.996-1.004), or cumulative AUCs (OR 1.00, 95% CI 0.9996-1.00) \namong all cases and controls. AUC metrics by SOT type also showed no \nstatistically significant differences.\nCONCLUSIONS: Predicted GCV exposures were similar among pSOT recipients with and \nwithout neutropenia, suggesting that differences in dosing and pharmacokinetics \ncovariates did not drive toxicity in our population. Measurement of GCV \nconcentrations may discern whether toxicity relates to exposures/concentrations \nor intrinsic factors (i.e., genetics) in the pSOT population.\n\n© 2025 Wiley Periodicals LLC.\n\nDOI: 10.1111/tid.70146\nPMID: 41364029"},

J Peripher Nerv Syst. 2025 Dec;30(4):e70087. doi: 10.1111/jns.70087.\n\nHuman Cytomegalovirus Associated Neuropathies: A Comprehensive Review From \nPathophysiology to Clinical and Therapeutic Considerations.\n\nBehanan N(1), Mohamed S(1), Chen R(2), Mak G(3), Lu JQ(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Pathology and Molecular Medicine, McMaster University, \nHamilton, Ontario, Canada.\n(2)Health Sciences, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada.\n(3)Department of Neurology/Medicine, The University of Alberta, Edmonton, \nAlberta, Canada.\n\nHuman cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a neurotropic, double-stranded DNA virus from \nthe Herpesviridae family. It has a large genome, infects the majority of \npopulations, and typically causes asymptomatic infections in healthy \nindividuals. After the initial infection with established lifelong latency, HCMV \ncan reactivate and cause disorders including neuropathies. Besides the \ninfections typically in immunocompromised patients, HCMV may also trigger \nautoimmunity leading to tissue injury and associated pathologies. \nHCMV-associated neuropathies are a pathogenically heterogeneous group of \nperipheral nervous system (PNS) disorders that include direct HCMV infection of \nthe nerve(s), as well as non-infectious associated neuropathies such as axonal \nor degenerative, vasculitic/ischemic or necrotizing, inflammatory demyelinating, \nand immune-mediated forms. Congenital HCMV-associated neuropathies primarily \ninvolve the cochlear/auditory and optic nerves with somewhat distinct pathogenic \nmechanisms compared with their postnatal counterparts, largely due to the \nimmaturity of the fetal immune system. This article reviews the pathophysiology \nof PNS involvement in HCMV infection, followed by congenital HCMV-associated \nneuropathies with a case demonstration, and various postnatal HCMV-associated \nneuropathies, including a detailed review of HCMV-associated optic neuropathies, \nfrom pathogenic mechanisms to clinical and therapeutic implications. As the PNS \nhas a few immune protective mechanisms against pathogens, direct HCMV infection \nof nerves is rare and occurs only in immunocompromised patients; most \nHCMV-associated neuropathies are secondary with multiple pathogenic mechanisms \nincluding varying degrees of autoimmunity. While the clinical manifestations of \nHCMV-associated neuropathies are variable, their treatment is typically \nempirical and case-based, focusing on antiviral therapy often combined with \nimmunomodulatory approaches. Prompt and appropriate management can improve \noutcomes of HCMV-associated neuropathies.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s). Journal of the Peripheral Nervous System published by \nWiley Periodicals LLC on behalf of Peripheral Nerve Society.\n\nDOI: 10.1111/jns.70087\nPMID: 41362154 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},
