    'abstract': '1. J Virol. 2025 Dec 8:e0156725. doi: 10.1128/jvi.01567-25. Online ahead of\nprint.\n\nInitiation of human cytomegalovirus secondary envelopment requires the gM/gN \nglycoprotein complex and involves palmitoylation.\n\nCortez Rayas L(1), Rogg R(1), Voll M(2), Thompson C(3), Lieber D(1), Read C(4), \nvon Einem J(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Institute of Virology, Ulm University Medical Center, Ulm, Germany.\n(2)Thermo Fisher Scientific France, Bordeaux, France.\n(3)Materials and Structural Analysis, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Eindhoven, the \nNetherlands.\n(4)Central Facility for Electron Microscopy, Ulm University, Ulm, Germany.\n\nGlycoprotein M (gM) of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) forms a conserved protein \ncomplex with glycoprotein N (gN), whose precise function in viral morphogenesis \nis poorly understood. To elucidate the function of the gM/gN complex in \nsecondary envelopment, we employed a combination of viral mutants, siRNA \nknockdown, and ultrastructural analyses. Ultrastructural examination of a mutant \nvirus with a cysteine-to-serine mutation in the cytoplasmic tail of gN \n(TB-gN-C123S) showed a defect in the initiation of secondary envelopment as most \ncapsids in TB-gN-C123S-infected cells were either not in contact with \ncytoplasmic membranes or, when near membranes, lacked signs of budding. The \ndefect in secondary envelopment was associated with an accumulation of partially \ntegumented capsids in the peripheral region of the cytoplasmic viral assembly \ncompartment (cVAC). Additionally, large protein aggregates were observed within \nand near the cVAC, often associated with non-enveloped capsids. A comparable \nultrastructural phenotype was observed in wild-type virus-infected cells treated \nwith siRNA against gM. Further evidence underscoring the role of the gM/gN \nglycoprotein complex in viral morphogenesis was obtained by investigating gM- \nand gN-null mutants, which displayed the same altered capsid distribution \nobserved in TB-gN-C123S infections and after siRNA knockdown of gM. Finally, the \ninhibition of palmitoylation in wild-type virus-infected cells resulted in \nanalogous defects, including an accumulation of partially tegumented capsids in \nthe periphery of the cVAC and protein aggregates associated with capsids. In \nsummary, our findings indicate a crucial role for the gM/gN complex in \ninitiating secondary envelopment and highlight the involvement of palmitoylation \nin this process.IMPORTANCEHuman cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a widespread \nherpesvirus that can cause severe illness in newborns and immunocompromised \nindividuals. Like other herpesviruses, HCMV assembles its infectious particles \nthrough a complex process where the virus acquires its envelope through \nsecondary envelopment. In this study, we investigated the role of glycoprotein M \n(gM) and glycoprotein N (gN), which form a conserved complex across \nherpesviruses. Using genetic mutants, RNA interference, and electron microscopy, \nwe found that the gM/gN complex is crucial for initiating secondary envelopment. \nDisruption of gM or gN function, or palmitoylation inhibition, prevents capsids \nfrom budding into membranes, resulting in partially tegumented capsids that \naccumulated at the periphery of the cytoplasmic viral assembly compartment \n(cVAC). Our findings highlight the important role of the gM/gN complex and \npalmitoylation in HCMV assembly and suggest that the assembly occurs in a \nspatially organized manner within the cVAC, providing new insights into how \nherpesviruses produce infectious particles.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/jvi.01567-25\nPMID: 41358725'}],

Follow-up \nanalyses of a vaccine directed against the fusion protein glycoprotein B \n(gB/MF59) identified a vaccine-specific response (AD-6) that correlated with \nprotection. Subsequently, it was demonstrated that AD-6 antibodies are \nanti-viral by preventing cell-associated spread. Here we now demonstrate AD-6 \nantibodies limit HCMV reactivation - an event critical for pathogenesis via \nhematogenic spread in vivo. To better understand the AD-6 immunogen, we use \nstructural homology to identify putative AD-6 regions in related herpesviruses \nand show, despite limited sequence similarity, they share key physico-chemical \nproperties. Of note was that AD-6 mapped to a region under high molecular \nfrustration within gB - arguing AD-6 antibodies inhibit gB function by targeting \nactivity dependent on conserved conformational changes. Consistent with \nstructural conformation being crucial, we observe that both rabbit and human \nHCMV AD-6 antibodies recognise other herpesvirus AD-6s and that AD-6 antibodies \nare potently antiviral against HSV-1. Thus, a combinatorial in silico, \nbiochemical and immunological approach reveals conformational epitopes within \nAD-6 are critical components of the gB/MF59 vaccine, represent crucial conserved \nelements of AD-6 in gB structure and function which makes it an attractive \ntarget of multiple herpesviruses.\n\n© 2025. BMC Infect Dis. 2023 Aug 22;23(1):548. doi: 10.1186/s12879-023-08506-3.\n\nA case of meningitis caused by Ralstonia insidiosa, a rare opportunistic \npathogen.\n\nLiao L(#)(1), Lin D(#)(1), Liu Z(1), Gao Y(1), Hu K(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Clinical Pharmacy, The First People's Hospital of Neijiang, \n641000, Neijiang, China.\n(2)Department of Clinical Pharmacy, The First People's Hospital of Neijiang, \n641000, Neijiang, China. However, infections caused by Ralstonia \ninsidiosa are still rare. Only a few cases of respiratory infections and \nbloodstream infections have been reported, none of which involved meningitis. To \nthe best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of meningitis caused \nby R. insidiosa worldwide. It is necessary to report and review this case.\nCASE PRESENTATION: We report a case of meningitis caused by R. insidiosa \nfollowing lumbar surgery in China. The patient exhibited symptoms of headache, \ndizziness, and recurrent fever. The fever remained unresolved after empiric \nantibiotic therapy with intravenous cefotaxime and vancomycin in the initial \ndays. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture yielded Gram-negative non-fermentative \nbacteria, which were identified as R. insidiosa. As there was a lack of \nantibiotic susceptibility testing results, clinical pharmacists conducted a \nliterature review to select appropriate antibiotics. The patient's condition \nimproved after receiving effective treatment with intravenous cefepime and \nlevofloxacin.\nCONCLUSIONS: Uncommon pathogens, such as R. insidiosa, should be considered in \npostoperative central nervous system (CNS) infections, particularly in cases \nwith unsatisfactory results of empiric anti-infective therapy. This is the first \nreported case of meningitis caused by R. insidiosa worldwide. MALDI-TOF MS \nprovides rapid and accurate identification of this pathogen. The antibiotic \nsusceptibility testing results of R. indiosa may be interpreted based on the \nbreakpoints for Pseudomonas spp., Burkholderia cepacia spp., and Acinetobacter \nspp. Our case presents a potential option for empiric therapy against this \npathogen, at least in the local area. This is crucial to minimize the severity \nand mortality rates associated with meningitis. Standardized antibiotic \nsusceptibility testing and breakpoints for the Ralstonia genus should be \nestablished in the future as cases accumulate. Cefepime and levofloxacin may be \npotential antibiotics for infections caused by R. indiosa.\n\n© 2023. The \nspecific pathogen free (SPF) mice were employed to perform the study. Genomic \nsequencing showed that the intrinsic microbes in the heart and liver of SPF \nmice, which were primarily of the genera Burkholderia and Ralstonia, functioned \nin organic metabolism, environmental information processing, cellular processes, \nand genetic information processing. Lactobacillus sp. were found in the liver \nbut not in the heart. The \ndominant bacterial phyla in the liver and heart were Bacillota, Bacteroidota, \nPseudomonadota, Thermodesulfobacteriota, andActinomycetota, which comprised \n98.2% of total bacteria. In conclusion, intrinsic bacteria present in the \nheart and liver alleviate infection by pathogens, environmental and genetic \ninformation processing, and cellular processes during heat stress exposure. J Am Heart Assoc. 2024 Sep 17;13(18):e033221. doi: 10.1161/JAHA.123.033221.\nEpub  2024 Sep 9.\n\nMicrobial Heterogeneity Identification of Cerebral Thrombi Via Metagenomic \nNext-Generation Sequencing-Based Strategy.\n\nChen X(1), He Y(1), Zhou L(1), Li X(1), Jiang M(1), Wu M(1), Li J(1), Chen L(1), \nXu H(2), Gui L(1), Zhou Z(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Neurology Southwest Hospital, Third Military Medical University \n(Army Medical University) Chongqing China.\n(2)Vision Medicals Center for Infection Diseases Guangzhou China.\n\nBACKGROUND: Diagnosis of the cause of cerebral thrombi is vital for recurrence \nprevention but also challenging. The presence of the microbiome has recently \nbeen confirmed in thrombus, suggesting a novel approach to distinguish cerebral \nthrombi of different origins. However, little is known about whether there is \nheterogeneity in microbiological colonization of cerebral thrombi of different \nsources.\nMETHODS AND RESULTS: Forty patients experiencing acute ischemic stroke were \nincluded and clinical data were collected. Metagenomic next-generation \nsequencing was adopted to detect bacterial and genomic signatures of human \ncerebral thrombi samples. We found similar species diversity between the \nlarge-artery atherosclerosis thrombi and cardioembolic thrombi but different \nspecies composition and distribution of cerebral thrombus microbiota. Compared \nwith the group with cardioembolism, the group with large-artery atherosclerosis \nshowed a significantly higher relative abundance of Ralstonia insidiosa among \nthe top 10 bacterial species in cerebral thrombi. Twenty operational taxonomy \nunits were correlated with 11 clinical indicators of ischemic stroke. The Gene \nOntology enrichment analysis revealed 9 different enriched biological processes \n(translation and carbohydrate metabolic process, etc). The enriched Kyoto \nEncyclopedia of Genes and Genomes pathways included ribosome, butanoate \nmetabolism, and sulfur metabolism.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study, based on the approach of metagenomic next-generation \nsequencing, provides a diagnostic microbiological method to discriminate \nindividuals with cardioembolic thrombi from those with large-artery \natherosclerosis thrombi with human cerebral thrombi samples. Our findings \nprovide a fresh perspective on microbial heterogeneity of cerebral thrombi and \ndemonstrate biological processes and pathway features of cerebral thrombi.\n\nDOI: 10.1161/JAHA.123.033221\nPMCID: PMC11935637\nPMID: 39248272 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},

IDCases. 2025 Nov 20;42:e02434. doi: 10.1016/j.idcr.2025.e02434. eCollection \n2025.\n\nFirst case of bloodstream infection caused by Cupriavidus metallidurans in \nJapan.\n\nHosoya K(1), Yokoo H(1), Takei S(2), Ogura N(1), Nakamura A(1), Yoshii H(3), \nMatsubara T(4), Miyazaki T(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Clinical Laboratory, Juntendo Tokyo Koto Geriatric Medical \nCenter, Tokyo, Japan.\n(2)Department of Clinical Laboratory Medicine, Juntendo University, Tokyo, \nJapan.\n(3)Department of Medicine, Diabetology and Endocrinology, Juntendo Tokyo Koto \nGeriatric Medical Center, Tokyo, Japan.\n(4)Department of Medicine, Cardiology, Juntendo Tokyo Koto Geriatric Medical \nCenter, Tokyo, Japan.\n\nWe report the first case in Japan of a bloodstream infection caused by \nCupriavidus metallidurans. The patient was a 77 years old man hospitalized for \ntreatment of heart failure and diabetes. On day 83 of hospitalization, he \ndeveloped a fever of 38.0°C, followed three days later by an elevation in \nC-reactive protein. His condition improved with the administration of \ncefmetazole, cefepime, and levofloxacin, and antibiotic therapy was discontinued \non the 17th day after the onset of fever. Blood cultures collected at the onset \nof fever revealed growth in the aerobic bottle after 21\u202fh, and Gram staining \nrevealed slightly slender Gram-negative rods. Based on colony morphology, \nBurkholderia or Ralstonia was initially suspected. However, identification kit \nID Test NF-18 yielded multiple possible organisms, and a definitive \nidentification could not be made. The isolate was ultimately identified as C. \nmetallidurans by phylogenetic analysis of the 16S rRNA gene. Because this \nspecies is not included in general bacterial identification kits and cannot be \nreliably distinguished based biochemical characteristics alone, 16S rRNA gene \nsequencing was essential for diagnosis. To date, only five cases of bloodstream \ninfection caused by this species have been reported, in Canada and Italy, and \nthis is the first reported case in Japan. As this bacterium is present in the \nJapanese environment, reports of its detection may increase in the future, \nparticularly among elderly or immunocompromised patients.\n\n© 2025 The Authors.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.idcr.2025.e02434\nPMCID: PMC12682029\nPMID: 41362658\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that they have no known \ncompeting financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared \nto influence the work reported in this paper.'},

    'abstract': "1. mBio. 2025 Dec 8:e0291225. doi: 10.1128/mbio.02912-25. Online ahead of print.\n\nRprR is a plant-responsive regulator of exopolysaccharide production, biofilm \nformation, and virulence in Ralstonia pseudosolanacearum.\n\nO'Banion BS(#)(1), Carter MD(#)(1), Sanchez-Gallego JA(1), Li H(1), Wagner N(2), \nChu LT(3), Bui L(3), Tran TM(2), Allen C(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Plant Pathology, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, \nWisconsin, USA.\n(2)Department of Biology, University of South Alabama, Mobile, Alabama, USA.\n(3)Department of Biology, University of Dayton, Dayton, Ohio, USA.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nRalstonia pseudosolanacearum (Rps), which causes bacterial wilt disease of many \ncrops, must integrate environmental signals to successfully transition from soil \nto its pathogenic niche in host plant xylem tissue. Mutating a gene encoding a \nputative sensing/signaling protein had little transcriptomic effect on Rps \nstrain GMI1000 in culture. However, when the mutant grew in tomato, over 180 \ngenes were differentially expressed relative to the wild type. The gene was \ntherefore named rprR for Ralstonia plant-responsive regulator. In planta, the \n∆rprR mutant dysregulated genes for diverse traits, including stress response, \ndegradation of phenolic compounds, motility, attachment, and production of \nextracellular polysaccharide (EPS), which is a key bacterial wilt virulence \nfactor. Quantifying Rps EPS by ELISA found increased levels in stems of plants \ninfected with ∆rprR as compared to the wild type. Functional assays showed that \n∆rprR is defective in attachment to tomato roots, colonization of tomato stems, \nand bacterial wilt virulence. In a rich medium, ∆rprR formed biofilm normally, \nbut the mutant formed less biofilm in tomato stem homogenate and in tomato xylem \nsap under flow. This phenotype correlates with the mutant's altered expression \nof EPS biosynthetic genes and aberrant extracellular matrix. When grown in \ntomato stem homogenate, ∆rprR produced 57% more of the bacterial signal cyclic \ndi-GMP (c-di-GMP) than the wild type. This is consistent with the presence, in \nRprR, of predicted c-di-GMP-modulating domains. Together, these findings reveal \nthat RprR, which is highly conserved across plant pathogenic Ralstonia, \nmodulates several bacterial wilt virulence traits in response to the plant \nhost.IMPORTANCEMembers of the Ralstonia solanacearum species complex (RSSC) \ncause bacterial wilt, a globally destructive disease of market and subsistence \ncrops. Like other plant-associated microbes, bacteria in the RSSC must integrate \na complex array of biotic and abiotic signals to successfully infect plant \nhosts. All RSSC genomes encode an unusual protein, termed RprR, that contains \nmultiple sensing and signaling domains, including two putative modulators of the \nsecondary messenger c-di-GMP. Deleting RprR in Ralstonia pseudosolanacearum \naffected many virulence properties, including production of biofilm and \nexopolysaccharide, and increased intracellular c-di-GMP levels, all in a \nstrictly plant-dependent fashion. While c-di-GMP has been investigated in other \nplant pathogenic bacteria, this is the first report of its role in the RSSC. \nMost importantly, rprR was required for Ralstonia to effectively colonize plants \nand cause wilt disease. Thus, RprR is a plant-responsive sensor-regulator that \ncontrols pathogen adaptation to the host environment and virulence.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/mbio.02912-25\nPMID: 41358747"},

Mol Plant Pathol. 2025 Dec;26(12):e70185. doi: 10.1111/mpp.70185.\n\nExperimental Coevolution Reveals That Ralstonia pseudosolanacearum PhcA \nContributes to the Infection of Filamentous Phage RSCq.\n\nLiang H(1), Chen J(1), Xu Y(2), Bin S(1), Qin X(1), Qin G(1), Zheng D(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)State Key Laboratory for Conservation and Utilization of Subtropical \nAgro-Bioresources, Guangxi Key Laboratory of Agro-Environment and Agro-Product \nSafety, College of Agriculture, Guangxi University, Nanning, China.\n(2)School of Pharmacy, Guangxi Medical University, Nanning, China.\n\nThe interaction between bacteria and filamentous phages, particularly in the \ncontext of bacterial pathogenesis, remains poorly understood compared with the \nwell-documented interactions involving lytic phages. Here, we investigated the \ncoevolutionary dynamics between Ralstonia pseudosolanacearum, the causative \nagent of plant bacterial wilt disease, and filamentous phages. Experimental \ncoevolution revealed the critical role of the global virulence regulator PhcA in \nfilamentous phage infection, demonstrating that its requirement for successful \nfilamentous phage infection is independent of the type IV pili receptor. \nNotably, while PhcA deficiency conferred phage resistance, it did not impair \nfilamentous phage genome replication or egress. Moreover, trade-offs between \nfilamentous phage resistance and bacterial virulence were observed, highlighting \nthe potential implications of filamentous phage for biocontrol strategies \nagainst R. pseudosolanacearum. Overall, our findings shed light on the intricate \ninterplay between Ralstonia pathogens and filamentous phages, providing insights \ninto the development of novel approaches for disease management.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s). Online ahead of \nprint.\n\nIntegrated analysis of transcriptome, sRNAome and degradome sequencing provides \ninsights into bacterial wilt resistance in potato.\n\nYang Y(#)(1), Zhang X(#)(1), Ma J(#)(1), Xiao J(1), Feng Z(1), Yu J(1), Li W(1), \nJiang P(2), Zhu G(3), Geng Y(4), Liu J(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Yunnan Key Laboratory of Cell Metabolism and Diseases, Center for Life \nScience and School of Life Sciences, Yunnan University, Kunming, 650500, China.\n(2)School of Life Sciences, The National Engineering Laboratory of Crop \nResistance Breeding, Anhui Agricultural University, Hefei, 230036, China.\n(3)School of Life Sciences, Yunnan Key Laboratory of Potato Biology, Yunnan \nNormal University, Southwest United Graduate School, Kunming, 650500, China.\n(4)State Key Laboratory for Vegetation Structure, Function and Construction \n(VegLab), Ministry of Education Key Laboratory for Transboundary Ecosecurity of \nSouthwest China, School of Ecology and Environmental Science, Yunnan University, \nKunming, 650500, China.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nBACKGROUND: Potato (Solanum tuberosum) is one of the most important global food \ncrops. However, potato bacterial wilt, a destructive soil-borne disease caused \nby Ralstonia solanacearum, poses a huge threat to global potato production and \nquality, leading to serious economic losses worldwide. The wild potato species \nSolanum commersonii exhibits resistance to bacterial wilt, but the underlying \nmolecular mechanisms remain largely obscure.\nRESULTS: In this study, we identified differentially expressed miRNAs \n(microRNAs), phased secondary short-interfering RNAs (phasiRNAs), along with \ntheir target transcripts, and elucidated the potential pathways involved in \nbacterial wilt resistance through high-throughput sequencing analyses of \ntranscriptome, sRNAome, and degradome on normal and R. solanacearum-infected \npotato roots, which were collected from the susceptible diploid potato clone S. \ntuberosum group Phureja SP15-65 and the resistant diploid S. commersonii \ngermplasm CM804. Among these \ndifferentially expressed miRNAs, some miR482, miR6024, and miR390 family members \ntriggered the biosynthesis of phasiRNAs through the cleavage of \nphasiRNA-generating (PHAS) precursor transcripts, as validated by \ndegradome-seq.\xa0The resulting phasiRNAs directed the cleavage of their downstream \ntarget mRNAs. Six miRNA-mRNA pairs and four pairs of phasiRNA-mRNA displayed \nnegatively correlated expression changes, which may be related to bacterial wilt \nresistance in potato.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study sheds lights on the regulatory roles of small RNAs in \npotato resistance against bacterial wilt, and will provide a theoretical \nfoundation for the cultivation of disease-resistant potato varieties.\n\n© 2025.     'abstract': '1. Front Plant Sci. 2025 Nov 17;16:1688379. doi: 10.3389/fpls.2025.1688379. \neCollection 2025.\n\nMechanism of tobacco-sweet potato intercropping in suppressing Ralstonia \nsolanacearum in flue-cured tobacco.\n\nYang L(1), Liu Y(2), Guo S(2), Li T(1), Nie Q(1), Zhang Y(3), Zeng S(1), Wang \nF(3), Liu L(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Sichuan Agricultural University, Chengdu,\xa0China.\n(2)Sichuan Provincial Tobacco Company of China National Tobacco Corporation, \nChengdu,\xa0China.\n(3)Luzhou City Tobacco Company of Sichuan Provincial Tobacco Company, \nLuzhou,\xa0China.\n\nTobacco bacterial wilt (Ralstonia solanacearum) is a fatal pathogen of tobacco, \ncausing severe losses annually. Intercropping has been proposed as a sustainable \nstrategy to mitigate soil-borne pathogens through rhizosphere interactions. \nHowever, the mechanisms by which tobacco-sweet potato intercropping specifically \naffects the microecological environment and suppresses R. solanacearum remain \npoorly understood. To investigate the effect of the TSP model on the soil-borne \npathogen of bacterial wilt (Ralstonia solanacearum) in tobacco-growing soil, \nthis study compared and analyzed the characteristics and differences in \nbacterial wilt incidence, Ralstonia solanacearum content, phenolic acid \ncomponents, metabolome, and metagenome between (T) and (TSP) systems. The \nresults showed that compared to the T treatment, the TSP treatment reduced the \nincidence of bacterial wilt in flue-cured tobacco and significantly decreased \nthe abundance of R. solanacearum in the soil by 21.4%, while increasing the \ntotal phenolic acid content by 21.9%. The total phenolic content in the TSP soil \nwas increased by 21.9% compared to T. Differentially abundant metabolites \nbetween TSP and T were primarily enriched in carbohydrate metabolic pathways, \nsuch as nucleotide sugar biosynthesis, fructose, and mannose metabolism. The \ncontent of substances such as rhamnose, D-allose, and mannitol in T-treated soil \nwas 2.14-6.62 times higher than that in TSP-treated soil, with new tobacco \nalkaloids being up to 91.09 times higher. In this study, plastic degrading microorganisms were isolated from \nagriculture soil and metal nanoparticles such as Zinc oxide (ZnO) and \nZinc-Magnesium oxide (ZnO-MgO) nanoparticles were synthesized using \nCo-precipitation method. Thus prepared inorganic metal nanoparticles were \nsubsequently added to enhance the microbial degradation action. The synthesised \nnanoparticles appeared as hexagonal nanoflakes with a size range of 32.8 and \n35\xa0nm respectively. The isolated strain from the soil Stutzerimonas stutzeri, a \ngram negative bacterium was identified using 16S rRNA sequencing technique. The \nplastic films treated with isolated strain, showed 65% of degradation efficiency \nrate in the presence of synthesised nanoparticles as enhancers. SEM analysis \nconfirmed the bacterial adhesion and revealed significant structural damage such \nas cracks, pits, holes and erosion in plastic film. FT-IR analysis revealed the \npresence of functional groups such as carbonyl (C=O) and (-CH) stretching at \n1076\xa0cm-1 and 719\xa0cm-1 as a indication of polymer degradation. Further, simpler \nmetabolic by-products formation such as fatty acids and succinic acid were \nanalyzed using Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS). Further, metabolic \nbyproducts were analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) and \ntheir toxicity was assessed using the Allium cepa as an invitro plant model. The \nabsence of negative effects on mitotic cell division suggested that no toxic \ncompounds were released during the microbial degradation process. This study \nreveals about an improved method of nanoparticles assisted biodegradation which \nmay pave a better pathway for sustainable solution in plastic waste management.\n\n© 2025. KGN cell \nmodels with lentivirus-mediated miR-23a overexpression or knockdown were used to \nverify the therapeutic mechanism of LBP.\nRESULTS: Cisplatin treatment significantly inhibited cell viability, induced \napoptosis, decreased AMH level, caused ultrastructural abnormalities, increased \nBax and caspase-3 expression, and lowered Bcl-2 expression in KGN cells. \nCisplatin also suppressed the activation of the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway and \nupregulated miR-23a expression in the cells. LBP intervention obviously \nalleviated cisplatin-induced injuries in KGN cells, and in particular, LBP \ntreatment at the medium dose for 24 h significantly improved KGN cell viability, \nreduced apoptosis, enhanced their endocrine function, and ameliorated \nultrastructural abnormalities. Mechanistically, medium-dose LBP obviously \nactivated the PI3K/AKT pathway by downregulating miR-23a in cisplatin-treated \ncells, subsequently inhibiting Bax and caspase-3 while upregulating Bcl-2. \nOverexpression of miR-23a weakened while knockdown of miR-23a significantly \nenhanced the protective effects of LBP.\nCONCLUSIONS: LBP alleviates cisplatin-induced apoptosis in KGN cells by \ninhibiting miR-23a expression and activating the PI3K/AKT pathway, suggesting a \npotential therapeutic strategy for ovarian function preservation.\n\nPublisher: 目的: 研究枸杞多糖（LBP）对顺铂损伤的卵巢颗粒细胞的保护作用及其潜在机制。方法: 采用顺铂（2.5 µg/mL，24 \nh）诱导人颗粒细胞样肿瘤细胞系（KGN）建立KGN损伤模型，采用不同浓度LBP（100、500、1000 \nmg/L）干预受损KGN，各组细胞分别用细胞计数试剂盒-8检测细胞活力，流式细胞术检测凋亡率，ELISA法检测抗苗勒管激素（AMH）水平，透射电镜观察超微结构，Western \nblotting检测凋亡相关蛋白（Bax、caspase-3、Bcl-2）及PI3K/AKT信号通路的表达情况，RT-qPCR法检测微小RNA（miR）-23a表达情况。通过慢病毒转染构建miR-23a过表达/敲低模型，验证LBP的作用机制。结果: \n顺铂抑制KGN活力（P<0.01），诱导凋亡（P<0.01），降低AMH水平（P<0.01），造成染色质凝聚、细胞核固缩、细胞质空泡化等超微结构异常，并增加促凋亡基因Bax、caspase-3的表达（P<0.01），减少抑凋亡基因Bcl-2的表达（P<0.05），下调PI3K/AKT信号通路的表达与活化（P<0.01），上调miR-23a的含量（P<0.01）。LBP干预可不同程度地逆转上述损伤，中剂量LBP作用24 \nh可改善KGN细胞活力、凋亡率、内分泌功能和超微结构（P<0.01）。中剂量LBP通过下调miR-23a（P<0.01）激活PI3K/AKT通路（P<0.01），抑制Bax、caspase-3（P<0.01），上调Bcl-2（P<0.05）。miR-23a过表达削弱LBP的保护作用，而敲低miR-23a则增强其疗效（P<0.01）。结论: \nLBP通过抑制miR-23a表达，激活PI3K/AKT通路，抑制顺铂诱导的KGN凋亡，为保护卵巢功能提供了潜在治疗策略。.\n\nDOI: 10.12122/j.issn.1673-4254.2025.11.06\nPMCID: PMC12676684\nPMID: 41311075 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},

The cellular effects of \nadiponectin on trophoblast are mainly mediated by adiponectin receptor isoform 2 \n(AdipoR2) resulting in the activation of PPARα and synthesis of ceramides, which \ninhibit insulin and mTOR signaling. We have recently demonstrated that \ntrophoblast-specific overexpression of AdipoR2 in pregnant mice inhibits \nplacental mTORC1 signaling and nutrient transport, resulting in fetal growth \nrestriction. Trophoblast mTORC1 signaling is a positive regulator of \nmitochondrial respiration. However, it is unknown if placental adiponectin \nsignaling is mechanistically linked to mitochondrial function. Moreover, placental AdiopoR2-OX decreased GLUD1, \nTOM22 and PGC1α protein expression. In the junctional zone, we found no \nsignificant differences between control (SCR) and AdipoR2-OX groups. In \nconclusion, our data suggests that maternal adiponectin signaling in the \ntrophoblast decreases placental mitochondrial respiration, specifically in the \nlabyrinth zone. A functional cure, defined as sustained HBsAg loss for \n≥ 24\xa0weeks, undetectable hepatitis B e antigen/HBV DNA, and normal liver \nfunction, is the ideal and achievable treatment endpoint for chronic HBV \ninfection. This review focuses on PEG-IFN-α-induced functional cure in special \npopulations with chronic HBV infection, including patients with partial response \nor low-level viremia (LLV), fibrosis or compensated cirrhosis, HBV-related \nhepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), HBV/human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) \ncoinfection, and pediatric patients. Patients living with HBV/HIV-1 coinfection have a \nhigh rate of HBsAg loss/seroconversion in response to effective antiretroviral \ntherapy, and the administration of add-on PEG-IFN-α may further increase the \nrate of HBV functional cure. IFN-α/PEG-IFN-α-based therapy is beneficial for \nyounger children with chronic HBV infection despite the viral load, HBeAg, and \nliver inflammation status. Viruses. 2025 Oct 29;17(11):1437. doi: 10.3390/v17111437.\n\nNeutralizing Antibodies Against the Porcine Endogenous Retroviruses (PERVs).\n\nBan J(1), Krabben L(1), Kaufer BB(1), Denner J(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Institute of Virology, Free University Berlin, 14163 Berlin, Germany.\n\nXenotransplantation using pig cells, tissues or organs may be associated with \nthe transmission of porcine zoonotic or xenozoonotic microorganisms. Porcine \nendogenous retroviruses (PERVs) pose a special risk for xenotransplantation as \nthese viruses can infect human cells and are integrated in multiple copies in \nthe genome of all pigs and, therefore, they cannot be eliminated as other \nviruses can. To prevent PERV transmission to the recipient, several strategies \nhave been developed: PERV-C-free animals, siRNA and genomic editing. Another \nstrategy is the generation of vaccines based on neutralizing antibodies in order \nto protect the recipient. To investigate whether a protective vaccine is \nfeasible in the case of PERV, the recombinant transmembrane (p15E) and the \nsurface envelope (gp70) protein of PERV were cloned, produced, purified and used \nto immunize rats. For the first time, an adjuvant type that is approved for \nhuman use was used. In all cases we obtained virus binding antibodies as shown \nin Western blot assays and neutralizing antibodies as shown in neutralization \nassays, indicating the potential for a protective vaccine. The epitopes \nrecognized by the antisera against p15E were determined using overlapping \npeptides. Two main epitopes were found in the sequence of p15E, one in the \nmembrane proximal external region (MPER) and one in the fusion peptide proximal \nregion (FPPR). The epitopes correspond to epitopes determined previously when \nimmunizing different animal species with p15E of PERV. Antibodies against these \nepitopes block the conformational changes in the transmembrane envelope proteins \nthat are required for membrane fusion, thereby inhibiting infection. The epitope \nin the MPER is related by sequence and location to an epitope in the \ntransmembrane envelope protein of the human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) \nrecognized by a broadly neutralizing antibody from infected patients.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/v17111437\nPMCID: PMC12656915\nPMID: 41305460 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflicts of interest. \nThe funders had no role in the design of the study; in the collection, analyses, \nor interpretation of data; in the writing of the manuscript; or in the decision \nto publish the results.'},

Cureus. 2025 Oct 29;17(10):e95684. doi: 10.7759/cureus.95684. eCollection 2025\n Oct.\n\nPatient Characteristics and Reasons for Switching to \nBictegravir/Emtricitabine/Tenofovir Alafenamide: A Retrospective Cohort From a \nLarge Urban HIV Clinic.\n\nGao H(1), Manchukonda B(1), Simoes P(2), Hamlyn E(2), Barber TJ(2)(3), Hunter \nA(2), Hart J(4), Johnson M(2)(3), Kinloch-de Loes S(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Acute Medicine Department, King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, \nLondon, GBR.\n(2)The Ian Charleson Day Centre, Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust, London, \nGBR.\n(3)Institute of Global Health, Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust, London, \nGBR.\n(4)Department of Virology, Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust, London, GBR.\n\nIntroduction Second-generation integrase strand transfer inhibitor \n(INSTI)-containing regimens have been preferred in almost all international \nguidelines for the treatment of human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) since the \nearly 2010s. This study aimed to determine patient characteristics and primary \nreasons for switching to a bictegravir/emtricitabine/tenofovir alafenamide \n(B/F/TAF) regimen in a large, inner-city cohort of people living with HIV-1 in \nLondon, United Kingdom (UK), and to assess the impact of the 2022 UK National \nProcurement Policy on prescribing patterns. Methods A retrospective review of \nelectronic patient records was conducted for all individuals on antiretroviral \ntherapy (ART) who switched to B/F/TAF at the Royal Free Hospital, London, United \nKingdom. Sociodemographic data, clinical markers including HIV-1 viral load, \nCD4+ T cell count, and previous ART regimen, and the documented reason for the \nswitch were collected. Data were censored on 20 November 2022, allowing for a \ncomparison of switch frequency before and after the implementation of the UK \nNational Procurement for HIV Treatment and Prevention on 1 February 2022. Data \ncollection was completed in the timeframe of 20 November 2022 till 30 June 2023. \nResults The cohort included 386 individuals who switched to B/F/TAF, of whom \n74.1% were male, 25.9% were female, 56% were White, and 27% were \nAfrican/Caribbean, with a median age of 58.5 years. Median duration of living \nwith diagnosed HIV-1 and ART exposure prior to the switch were both 20 years. \nThe most common reason for switching was regimen simplification (n=169, 43.8%), \nfollowed by toxicity (n=115, 29.8%); nearly 10% (n=38, 9.8%) switched due to \nvirological failure. Number of switches increased from 74 in the observed period \nfrom April-November 2021 to 168 between April-November 2022 following the \nimplementation of the National Procurement Policy. Conclusions The primary \nreason for switching to B/F/TAF was the desire for regimen simplification, a \ntrend that appears to have been reinforced by the National Procurement Policy. \nHowever, toxicity, adherence issues, and virological failure were also key \nclinical motivations for switching. These findings highlight the role of B/F/TAF \nin ART optimisation for a diverse and treatment-experienced population of people \nliving with HIV.\n\nCopyright © 2025, Gao et al.\n\nDOI: 10.7759/cureus.95684\nPMCID: PMC12585167\nPMID: 41194834\n\nConflict of interest statement: Human subjects: Informed consent for treatment \nand open access publication was obtained or waived by all participants in this \nstudy. The rapid change in HIV \ngenomes intricates HIV transmission and progression and attributes HIV \nresistance to antiretroviral therapy (ART). In East Africa, as in other parts of \nthe globe, HIV-1 occurs in various subtypes, circulating recombinant form (CRF) \nand unique recombinant forms, with subtype A1 being the most predominant. \nSurveillance of HIV-1 molecular diversity and drug resistance mutations (DRMs) \nis a linchpin for monitoring viral evolution and treatment efficiency. However, \nconsolidated reports on the same are limited, and therefore, the pursuit of \nmeta-analysis was sought to analyze genetic diversity and drug resistance \npatterns of HIV-1 pol gene and their geographical distributions in four East \nAfrican countries (Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, and Ethiopia). We retrieved 7614 \nHIV-1 pol gene sequences, deposited between 2015 and 2025 from the Los Alamos \nHIV databases. The predominant HIV-1 subtypes were A1 (40.2%), C (21.5%), and D \n(17.7%), with geographical variability. A notable frequency of inter-subtype \nrecombinant was observed with recombinants A1D (9.5%) and A1C (2.94%) being \nprevalent. Few CRFs (> 0.1%) were identified. DRM were present in 42.8% of the \nsequences, with the majority associated with NNRTIs (36.5%) and NRTIs (25.5%). \nThe most frequently associated mutations were K103N and M184V. Although \nresistance to INSTI (3.7%) remained minimal, its presence warrants continued \nmonitoring. A significant association between HIV-1 subtypes and DRM prevalence \nwas observed (χ 2\u2009=\u2009102.43, p < 0.0001), with subtypes showing varied resistance \nburdens. This review explores the \nbiological degradation of α-solanine and α-chaconine, with a focus on microbial \nprocesses mediated by fungi (Plectosphaerella, Gibberella, Aspergillus, \nPenicillium), plant pathogens (Phytophthora infestans) and bacteria \n(Arthrobacter, Bacillus, Glutamicibacter). A comprehensive review of \nthe literature conducted through PubMed, Web of Science, and Google Scholar was \nconducted to analyze relevant studies. Elucidating these degradation processes \nwill help enhance in our understanding of glycoalkaloid deglycosylation and \nprovide valuable insights into the development of effective strategies to \nmitigate glycoalkaloid contamination in food products and reduce the \nenvironmental impact.\n\n© 2025 The Authors. Microbes Environ. 2025;40(3):ME24115. doi: 10.1264/jsme2.ME24115.\n\nAmplicon Analysis of Dictean Cave Microbial Communities and Essential Oils as a \nMild Biocide.\n\nMartzoukou O(1), Oikonomou A(2), Amillis S(1), Hatzinikolaou DG(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Enzyme and Microbial Biotechnology Unit, Department of Biology, National and \nKapodistrian University of Athens.\n(2)Ephorate of Palaeoanthropology and Speleology, Hellenic Republic Ministry of \nCulture.\n\nNaturally occurring caves are sites of significant cultural value, while also \ndisplaying the unique biodiversity of associated microbiomes that may provide an \nuntapped source of potentially beneficial organisms. Therefore, an efficient approach to \ncontrolling these ecological niches without irreversibly disturbing microbial \ndiversity is needed, and essential oils are currently being investigated as a \nmild cleaning method. The present study exami-ned the microbial diversity of the \nDictean cave using 16S and 18S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing and methods for \nquantitative metabolic activity estimations and also investigated the \napplication of a formulation containing specific essential oils as a mild \ncleaning method. Regen Ther. 2025 Nov 17;31:101043. doi: 10.1016/j.reth.2025.11.008.\neCollection  2026 Mar.\n\nMicrobial contamination risks and clinical safety in platelet-rich plasma \ntherapy and evaluation of rapid microbial detection methods.\n\nArita A(1), Saita Y(2), Fujiwara N(3), Homma Y(4), Tobita M(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Medical Technology Innovation Center, Juntendo University, A-Bld, 3F, 2-1-1 \nHongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8421, Japan.\n(2)Department of Regenerative Medicine for Locomotive Organ, Juntendo \nUniversity, Faculty of Medicine, 3-1-3 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8431, Japan.\n(3)Department of Pediatric General and Urogenital Surgery, Juntendo University \nGraduate School of Medicine, 2-1-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8421, Japan.\n(4)Department of Medicine for Orthopaedics and Motor Organ, Juntendo University \nGraduate School of Medicine, 2-1-1 Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8421, Japan.\n\nINTRODUCTION: Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) is widely used for pain relief, wound \nhealing, and so on. However, recent reports have documented cases of infections \noccurring after PRP therapy. In this study, we aimed to examine potential \nmicrobial contamination risks associated with PRP therapy and evaluate rapid \nmicrobial detection methods suitable for clinical use.\nMETHODS: We assessed the risk of microbial contamination during blood \ncollection, PRP preparation, and sterility testing. To evaluate suitable \ndetection methods, we compared the microbial detection sensitivities of flow \ncytometry (FCM) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for identifying microbial \ncontamination in PRP. For this purpose, PRP samples were inoculated with \nStaphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp., Cutibacterium acnes, Micrococcus \nspp., Bacillus subtilis, and Candida albicans.\nRESULTS: Following skin disinfection, microbial colonies were detected at the \nvenipuncture site in six out of ten patients. Environmental monitoring \nidentified airborne microbial colonies in two out of three anonymous PRP \npreparation facilities. Sterility tests revealed negative results for all 85 \nresidual PRP and 15 platelet-poor plasma (PPP) cases. FCM sensitivity for \nmicrobial detection in PRP was effective at a concentration of 102-103 colony \nforming units (cfu)/mL or higher. While C. albicans could not be detected \nseparately from non-specific PRP signals using FCM, it was detectable in PPP at \n≥102\xa0cfu/mL. PCR sensitivity for microbial detection was excellent when \nanalyzing pure microbial suspensions, however, it yielded a high rate of \nfalse-negative and false-positive results when PRP samples contained certain \nmicrobial strains.\nCONCLUSION: The risks of microbial contamination were identified during both \nvenipuncture and PRP production. To reduce these risks, it may be necessary to \nimprove disinfection protocols for venipuncture sites and blood collection \nmethods, implementing appropriate facility-specific measures. Although requiring \nfurther detection sensitivity improvements, FCM is a promising method for \ndetecting viable bacteria in PRP. Given that microbial contamination cannot be \ncompletely eliminated, clinicians providing PRP therapy should remain alert to \nthe potential for postoperative infections and ensure appropriate follow-up \nprotocols are established.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.reth.2025.11.008\nPMCID: PMC12666433\nPMID: 41333320\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare the following financial \ninterests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing \ninterests: Morikuni Tobita reports financial support was provided by AMED. \nYoshitomo Saita reports financial support was provided by AMED. Yasuhiro Homma \nreports financial support was provided by AMED. Morikuni Tobita reports a \nrelationship with Gaudi Clinical that includes: board membership, equity or \nstocks, and funding grants. Morikuni Tobita reports a relationship with Sysmex \nCorporation that includes: funding grants. If there are other authors, they \ndeclare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal \nrelationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this \npaper.'},

Am J Ophthalmol Case Rep. 2025 Nov 7;40:102466. doi:\n10.1016/j.ajoc.2025.102466.  eCollection 2025 Dec.\n\nConjunctival retraction with deposits after trabeculectomy.\n\nZeng B(1), Chen Z(1), Yu M(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)State Key Laboratory of Ophthalmology, Zhongshan Ophthalmic Center, Sun \nYat-sen University, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Ophthalmology and \nVisual Science, Guangzhou, China.\n\nPURPOSE: To describe a case of late-onset conjunctival flap retraction after \nfornix-based trabeculectomy, presenting with chronic subconjunctival \naccumulation of yellow crystalline material, which responded to antifungal and \nbroad-spectrum antibiotic therapy.\nOBSERVATION: A 26-year-old female patient with a history of congenital glaucoma \nunderwent combined trabeculotomy and fornix-based trabeculectomy in the left eye \nat 4 months of age. These findings not only provide the first comprehensive \nevidence of the joint cavity microbiota but also unveil M. luteus G18 as a \nmicrobial driver of OA progression. This study reshapes the understanding of OA \npathogenesis and opens new avenues for microbial-based diagnostics and \ntherapeutics-pointing toward a previously overlooked dimension of joint biology \nthat deserves further exploration.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s). J Microbiol Methods. 2025 Dec;239:107326. doi: 10.1016/j.mimet.2025.107326.\nEpub  2025 Nov 11.\n\nImproving bacterial smear detection with Wright-Giemsa staining: A multicenter \nstudy in clinical microbiology laboratories.\n\nJi P(1), Yuan S(2), Zeng T(3), Wu B(4), Ma J(5), Zhang Z(6), Yao L(2), Li N(7).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Laboratory Medicine, the 1(st) School of Clinical Medicine, \nLanzhou University; the First Hospital of Lanzhou University, Lanzhou, 730000, \nGansu Province, China. Electronic address: ldyy_jipyy@lzu.edu.cn.\n(2)Department of Laboratory Medicine, the 1(st) School of Clinical Medicine, \nLanzhou University; the First Hospital of Lanzhou University, Lanzhou, 730000, \nGansu Province, China.\n(3)Department of Laboratory Medicine, the First Affiliated Hospital of Nanchang \nUniversity, Nanchang, 330038, Jiangxi Province, China.\n(4)Department of Laboratory Medicine, Dazhou Central Hospital, Dazhou, 635000, \nSichuan Province, China.\n(5)Department of Laboratory Medicine, Linxia People's Hospital, Linxia City, \nLinxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture, 731199, Gansu Province, China.\n(6)Department of Laboratory Medicine, Luqu People's Hospital, Luqu County, \nGannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, 747200, Gansu Province, China.\n(7)Department of Immunology, School of Basic Medical Sciences, Lanzhou \nUniversity, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu Province, China. Electronic address: \nnl@lzu.edu.cn.\n\nImprovement in bacterial detection in smear is needed because pathogens in \nsmears and positive blood cultures (PBCs) can be missed by microscopy if Gram \nstaining is used. This study assessed the efficacy of Wright-Giemsa staining in \nremedying bacterial detection failures. We conducted a prospective multicenter \nstudy involving 5667 sputum specimens and 5502 PBCs collected from five distinct \ncenters. When initial Gram staining did not identify bacteria, Wright-Giemsa \nstaining was performed. The study also analyzed cases of missed detections and \nthe undetected microorganism types. Among the sputum specimens, 3.0\xa0% (170 \ncases) that were negative for Gram staining were successfully identified using \nWright-Giemsa staining, revealing 321 previously undetected microbial forms. Of \nthe PBCs, 5.1\xa0% (283 cases) exhibited no microorganisms upon initial Gram \nstaining, and subsequent Wright-Giemsa staining identified bacteria in 119 PBCs \n(42.0\xa0% of the 283 cases). Culture identification further confirmed the \nbacterial presence in 77 PBCs (64.7\xa0% of the 119 cases). The predominant \ncontaminants were coagulase-negative staphylococci, Micrococcus spp., \nCorynebacterium spp., and alpha-hemolytic streptococci, which accounted for \n64.9\xa0% of the total isolates. For both specimens, the missed detection rate in \nprimary hospitals was significantly higher than in regional central hospitals \n(p\xa0<\xa00.001). Incorporating Wright-Giemsa staining can substantially decrease the \nmissed detection rate in bacterial smears, potentially harmonizing \ninter-laboratory discrepancies. For Gram-staining-negative sputum specimens or \nPBCs, Wright-Giemsa staining may enhances detection in microbiology \nlaboratories, particularly in primary hospitals with limited specimens or \ndiagnostic experience.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Authors.     'abstract': "1. Am J Infect Control. 2025 Dec 4:S0196-6553(25)00739-4. doi: \n10.1016/j.ajic.2025.11.026. Online ahead of print.\n\nRISK OF EXPOSURE TO BIOAEROSOLS IN CLINICAL ENVIRONMENTS: BRONCHOSCOPY.\n\nGómez-Sánchez N(1), Alcalde L(2), Sancho-Chust JN(3), Boira I(3), Gálvez B(4), \nEsteban V(3), Chiner E(3), Yubero E(5), Colom MF(6), Ferrer C(6).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Plant Production and Microbiology, Miguel Hernández University, \nSan Juan de Alicante, Alicante, Spain; Institute for Sanitary and Biomedical \nResearch of Alicante (ISABIAL), Alicante, Spain; Department of Applied Physics, \nMiguel Hernández University, Elche, Spain. Electronic address: \nNoelia.gomezs@umh.es.\n(2)Department of Plant Production and Microbiology, Miguel Hernández University, \nSan Juan de Alicante, Alicante, Spain.\n(3)Department of Respiratory Medicine, University Hospital of San Juan, \nAlicante, Spain.\n(4)Department of Respiratory Medicine, University Hospital of Vinalopó, Elche, \nSpain.\n(5)Department of Applied Physics, Miguel Hernández University, Elche, Spain.\n(6)Department of Plant Production and Microbiology, Miguel Hernández University, \nSan Juan de Alicante, Alicante, Spain; Institute for Sanitary and Biomedical \nResearch of Alicante (ISABIAL), Alicante, Spain.\n\nINTRODUCTION: Healthcare professionals face a heightened risk of occupational \ninfections, with procedures such as bronchoscopy further increasing this risk by \ngenerating aerosols containing diverse microorganisms. This study quantified \nbioaerosol concentrations during bronchoscopy to evaluate occupational exposure.\nMETHODOLOGY: Aerosol samples were collected during routine bronchoscopies in two \nhospitals using personal samplers with quartz filters attached to healthcare \nprofessional's clothing. Samples were cultured on various media, with bacterial \ncolonies identified by 16S rDNA sequencing and fungal colonies by ITS1-2 region \nsequencing. Respiratory viruses (SARS-CoV-2, influenza A/B, RSV) were detected \nvia RT-PCR.\nRESULTS: A total of 44 aerosol samples were collected: 7 pre-procedure, 32 \nduring bronchoscopy, and 5 between patients. From samples taken during \nbronchoscopies, 287 microbial colonies were isolated. The most abundant \nbacterial genera were Micrococcus, Staphylococcus, and Bacillus, while fungal \ngenera included Aspergillus, Talaromyces and Cladosporium. A structured \nliterature review was conducted using the PubMed, EMBASE, Scopus, and Web of \nScience databases. Keywords included terms related to cross-reactivity, acute \nhepatitis, serological testing, molecular diagnostics, and specific viral \nagents. While PCR offers superior specificity and \nsensitivity, its implementation is limited by cost and accessibility in \nlow-resource settings. Members of \nthis genus are the inhabitants of both natural and artificial thermal \nenvironments. We performed phylogenomic analyses and comparative genomic studies \nto unravel the genomic diversity among the strains belonging to the genus \nThermus in geographically different thermal springs. Sixteen Thermus strains \nwere isolated and sequenced from hot springs, Qucai hot springs in Tibet and \nTengchong hot springs in Yunnan, China. 16S rRNA gene based phylogeny and \nphylogenomic analyses based on concatenated set of 971 Orthologous Protein \nFamilies (supermatrix and gene content methods) revealed a mixed distribution of \nthe Thermus strains. Whole genome based phylogenetic analysis showed, all 16 \nThermus strains belong to five species; Thermus oshimai (YIM QC-2-109, YIM 1640, \nYIM 1627, 77359, 77923, 77838), Thermus antranikianii (YIM 73052, 77412, 77311, \n71206), Thermus brokianus (YIM 73518, 71318, 72351), Thermus hydrothermalis (YIM \n730264 and 77927) and one potential novel species 77420 forming clade with \nThermus thalpophilus SYSU G00506T. Although the genomes of different strains of \nThermus of same species were highly similar in their metabolic pathways, but \nsubtle differences were found. CRISPR loci were detected through genome-wide \nscreening, which showed that Thermus isolates from two different thermal \nlocations had well developed defense system against viruses and adopt similar \nstrategy for survival. Additionally, comparative genome analysis screened \ncompetence loci across all the Thermus genomes which could be helpful to acquire \nDNA from environment. In the present study it was found that Thermus isolates \nuse two mechanism of incomplete denitrification pathway, some Thermus strains \nproduces nitric oxide while others nitrious oxide (dinitrogen oxide), which show \nthe heterotrophic lifestyle of Thermus genus. However, \nthe denitrification abilities of the genus as a whole remain poorly \ncharacterized. Here, we describe diverse denitrification phenotypes and \ngenotypes of a collection of 24 strains representing ten species, all isolated \nfrom a variety of geothermal systems in China. Confirmed terminal products of \nnitrate reduction were nitrite or N2O, while nitric oxide (NO) was inferred as \nthe terminal product in some strains. Most strains produced N2O; complete \ndenitrification was not observed. Denitrification phenotypes were largely \nconsistent with the presence of denitrification genes, and strains of the same \nspecies often had the same denitrification phenotypes and largely syntenous \ndenitrification gene clusters. Genes for nirS and nirK coexisted in three \nThermus brockianus and three Thermus oshimai genomes, which is a unique hallmark \nof some denitrifying Thermus strains and may be ecologically important. These \nresults show that incomplete denitrification phenotypes are prominent, but \nvariable, within and between Thermus species. The incomplete denitrification \nphenotypes described here suggest Thermus species may play important roles in \nconsortial denitrification in high-temperature terrestrial biotopes where \nsufficient supply of oxidized inorganic nitrogen exists.\n\n© 2022. Based on conserved domain \nanalyses and metabolic pathway mapping, the cluster was classified into upper- \nand peripheral-pathway operons. The upper-pathway genes, responsible for the \ndegradation of p-hydroxybenzoate and vanillate, are located on a 0.27-Mb \nplasmid, whereas the peripheral-pathway genes, responsible for the \ntransformation of ferulate, are spread throughout the plasmid and the \nchromosome. In addition, a lower-pathway operon was also identified in the \nplasmid that corresponds to the meta-cleavage pathway of catechol. \nSpectrophotometric and gene induction data suggest that the upper and lower \noperons are induced by p-hydroxybenzoate, which the strain can degrade \ncompletely within 4\u2009days of incubation, whereas the peripheral genes are \nexpressed constitutively. The upper degradation pathway follows a less common \nroute, proceeding via the decarboxylation of protocatechuate to form catechol, \nand involves a novel thermostable γ-carboxymuconolactone decarboxylase homolog, \nidentified as protocatechuate decarboxylase based on gene deletion experiments. \nThis gene cluster is conserved in only a few members of the Thermales and shows \ntraces of vertical expansion of catabolic pathways in these organisms toward \nlignoaromatics.IMPORTANCE High-temperature steam treatment of lignocellulosic \nbiomass during the extraction of cellulose and hemicellulose fractions leads to \nthe release of a wide array of lignin-derived aromatics into the natural \necosystem, some of which can have detrimental effects on the environment. Not \nonly will identifying organisms capable of using such aromatics aid in \nenvironmental cleanup, but thermostable enzymes, if characterized, can also be \nused for efficient lignin valorization. However, no thermophilic lignin \ndegraders have been reported thus far. The present study reports T. oshimai JL-2 \nas a thermophilic bacterium with the potential to use lignin-derived aromatics. \nThe identification of a novel thermostable protocatechuate decarboxylase gene in \nthe strain further adds to its significance, as such an enzyme can be \nefficiently used in the biosynthesis of cis,cis-muconate, an important \nintermediate in the commercial production of plastics.\n\nCopyright © 2021 American Society for Microbiology.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/AEM.01589-20\nPMCID: PMC8208148\nPMID: 33741620 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},

While microbial community \ncomposition and succession have been previously described during HTC, the \nmetabolic activity and adaptation of thermophilic microbiomes remain largely \nunexplored. Despite intense research efforts and prior \nevidence of a rather widespread phylogenetic occurrence of the related genetic \nmachinery, reports on extreme thermophilic and hyperthermophilic \npolyhydroxyalkanoates producers remain scarce. However, thermophilic cell \nfactories for bioplastic production would serve as an excellent example of \nNext-Generation Industrial Biotechnology. In this study, \nusing various extraction and analytical methods, no evidence of \npolyhydroxyalkanoate production was found under the tested conditions. Epub 2018 Jan 12.\n\nStabilization of mesophilic Allochromatium vinosum cytochrome c' through \nspecific mutations modeled by a thermophilic homologue.\n\nYamane-Koshizawa D(1), Fujii S(1)(2), Maruno T(3), Kobayashi Y(3), Yamanaka \nM(4), Wakai S(5), Sambongi Y(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)a Graduate School of Biosphere Science , Hiroshima University , \nHigashi-Hiroshima , Japan.\n(2)b Global Career Design Center , Hiroshima University , Higashi-Hiroshima , \nJapan.\n(3)c Graduate School of Engineering , Osaka University , Suita , Japan.\n(4)d Graduate School of Materials Science , Nara Institute of Science and \nTechnology , Ikoma , Japan.\n(5)e Graduate School of Science Technology and Innovation , Kobe University , \nKobe , Japan.\n\nAVCP cytochrome c' from mesophilic Allochromatium vinosum exhibits lower \nstability than a thermophilic counterpart, Hydrogenophilus thermoluteolus \ncytochrome c' (PHCP), in which the six specific amino acid residues that are not \nconserved in AVCP are responsible for its stability. Epub\n 2024 Jun 26.\n\nConformational rigidity of cytochrome c'-α from a thermophile is associated with \nslow NO binding.\n\nFujii S(1), Wilson MT(2), Adams HR(2), Mikolajek H(3), Svistunenko DA(2), Smyth \nP(4), Andrew CR(5), Sambongi Y(6), Hough MA(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Diamond Light Source Ltd, Harwell Science and Innovation Campus, Didcot, \nUnited Kingdom; Research Complex at Harwell, Harwell Science and Innovation \nCampus, Didcot, United Kingdom; Graduate School of Integrated Sciences for Life, \nHiroshima University, Higashi-Hiroshima, Japan. Electronic address: \nsofuji@hiroshima-u.ac.jp.\n(2)School of Life Sciences, University of Essex, Colchester, United Kingdom.\n(3)Diamond Light Source Ltd, Harwell Science and Innovation Campus, Didcot, \nUnited Kingdom; Research Complex at Harwell, Harwell Science and Innovation \nCampus, Didcot, United Kingdom.\n(4)Diamond Light Source Ltd, Harwell Science and Innovation Campus, Didcot, \nUnited Kingdom; Research Complex at Harwell, Harwell Science and Innovation \nCampus, Didcot, United Kingdom; School of Life Sciences, University of Essex, \nColchester, United Kingdom.\n(5)Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Eastern Oregon University, La \nGrande, Oregon.\n(6)Graduate School of Integrated Sciences for Life, Hiroshima University, \nHigashi-Hiroshima, Japan; Seto Inland Sea Carbon-neutral Research Center, \nHiroshima University, Higashi-Hiroshima, Japan.\n\nCytochromes c'-α are nitric oxide (NO)-binding heme proteins derived from \nbacteria that can thrive in a wide range of temperature environments. Studies of \nmesophilic Alcaligenes xylosoxidans cytochrome c'-α (AxCP-α) have revealed an \nunusual NO-binding mechanism involving both heme faces, in which NO first binds \nto form a distal hexa-coordinate Fe(II)-NO (6cNO) intermediate and then \ndisplaces the proximal His to form a proximal penta-coordinate Fe(II)-NO (5cNO) \nfinal product. Here, we characterize a thermally stable cytochrome c'-α from \nthermophilic Hydrogenophilus thermoluteolus (PhCP-α) to understand how protein \nthermal stability affects NO binding. Electron paramagnetic and resonance Raman \nspectroscopies reveal the formation of a PhCP-α 5cNO product, with time-resolved \n(stopped-flow) UV-vis absorbance indicating the involvement of a 6cNO \nintermediate. Relative to AxCP-α, the rates of 6cNO and 5cNO formation in PhCP-α \nare ∼11- and ∼13-fold lower, respectively. Notably, x-ray crystal structures of \nPhCP-α in the presence and absence of NO suggest that the sluggish formation of \nthe proximal 5cNO product results from conformational rigidity: the Arg-132 \nresidue (adjacent to the proximal His ligand) is held in place by a salt bridge \nbetween Arg-75 and Glu-135 (an interaction not present in AxCP-α or a \npsychrophilic counterpart). Overall, our data provide fresh insights into \nstructural factors controlling NO binding in heme proteins, including 5cNO \ncomplexes relevant to eukaryotic NO sensors.\n\nCopyright © 2024 Biophysical Society. Published by Elsevier Inc. All rights \nreserved.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.bpj.2024.06.026\nPMCID: PMC11365222\nPMID: 38937973 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declaration of interests The authors declare no \ncompeting interests."},

Immun Inflamm Dis. 2024 Jan;12(1):e1097. doi: 10.1002/iid3.1097.\n\nAnalysis of intestinal flora in elderly Uygur patients with sarcopenia.\n\nShan Z(1), Cheng N(1), Zhu J(1), Chen F(1), Ji J(1), Meilibana(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)People's Hospital of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, Urumqi, China.\n\nOBJECTIVE: This study was designed to analyze the structural characteristics of \nthe intestinal flora of elderly Uygur patients with sarcopenia, thereby \nproviding new ideas for clinical treatment.\nMETHODS: Firstly, fecal samples were collected from 40 elderly Uygur patients \nwith sarcopenia (Sarcopenia group) and 40 healthy people (Control group). Next, \nsignificant differences in the intestinal flora between the two groups were \nanalyzed based on 16S rDNA high-throughput sequencing. The linear discriminant \nanalysis effect size (LEfSe) was used to estimate the magnitude of the effect of \neach component (species) abundance on the differential effect. Additionally, an \nanalysis was also performed on the relationship between the intestinal flora and \nthe cytokines in the peripheral blood of patients with sarcopenia.\nRESULTS: The results of β diversity showed that there were differences in the \nstructure of the intestinal flora between the two groups. Besides, the phylum \nlevel of intestinal flora between the two groups was not significantly \ndifferent. However, the difference was significant in the intestinal flora at \nthe order, family, and genus levels between the two groups. Among them, \nLachnoclostridium, Photobacterium, Anaerobic Bacillus, Hydrogenophilus, and \nEubacterium were enriched in the Sarcopenia group; Prevotella 9, Firmicutes \nFCS020 group, Streptobacillus, Aggregatibacter, Corynebacterium, Clostridium \nDifficile, and Haloanaerobium were enriched in the Control group. The LEfSe \noutcomes further showed that Lachnoclostridium was highly enriched in the \nSarcopenia group; Prevotella 9 and Firmicutes FCS020 group were significantly \nenriched in the Control group. Furthermore, the relative abundance of \nLachnoclostridium and Streptobacillus were significantly different in patients \nwith high and low IL-6 levels.\nCONCLUSION: In conclusion, Lachnoclostridium is significantly enriched in the \nintestines of elderly Uygur patients with sarcopenia; the increase in \nLachnoclostridium abundance and the decrease in Streptobacillus abundance are \nassociated with high levels of IL-6. Therefore, abnormal intestinal flora is \nrelated to inflammatory reflexes in patients with sarcopenia.\n\n© 2024 The Authors. Syst Appl Microbiol. 2022 Nov;45(6):126359. doi: 10.1016/j.syapm.2022.126359. \nEpub 2022 Sep 13.\n\nMicrobial community composition and hydrochemistry of underexplored geothermal \nwaters in Croatia.\n\nMitrović M(1), Kostešić E(1), Marković T(2), Selak L(1), Hausmann B(3), Pjevac \nP(4), Orlić S(5).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Ruđer Bošković Institute, Division of Materials Chemistry, Laboratory for \nPrecipitation Processes, Bijenička cesta 54, 10 000 Zagreb, Croatia.\n(2)Croatian Geological Survey, Milan Sachs 2 Street, 10 000 Zagreb, Croatia.\n(3)Joint Microbiome Facility of the Medical University of Vienna and the \nUniversity of Vienna, Djerassiplatz 1, 1030 Vienna, Austria; Department of \nLaboratory Medicine, Medical University of Vienna, Währinger Gürtel 18-20, 1090 \nVienna, Austria.\n(4)Joint Microbiome Facility of the Medical University of Vienna and the \nUniversity of Vienna, Djerassiplatz 1, 1030 Vienna, Austria; University of \nVienna, Department of Microbiology and Ecosystem Science, Divison of Microbial \nEcology, Djerassiplatz 1, 1030 Vienna, Austria.\n(5)Ruđer Bošković Institute, Division of Materials Chemistry, Laboratory for \nPrecipitation Processes, Bijenička cesta 54, 10 000 Zagreb, Croatia; Center of \nExcellence for Science and Technology-Integration of Mediterranean Region \n(STIM), Split, Croatia. Electronic address: sorlic@irb.hr.\n\nIn Croatia, a variety of geothermal springs with a wide temperature range and \nvaried hydrochemical conditions exist, and they may harbor different niches for \nthe distribution of microbial communities. In this study, 19 different sites, \nmainly located in central and eastern Croatia, were selected for primary \ncharacterization of spring hydrochemistry and microbial community composition. \nUsing 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing, it was found that the bacterial \ncommunities that dominated most geothermal waters were related to Proteobacteria \nand Campylobacteria, while most archaeal sequences were related to \nCrenarchaeota. At the genus level, the prokaryotic community was highly \nsite-specific and was often dominated by a single genus, including sites \ndominated by Hydrogenophilus, Sulfuricurvum, Sulfurovum, Thiofaba and \nNitrospira, while the most abundant archaeal genera were affiliated to the \nammonia-oxidizing archaea, Candidatus Nitrosotenuis and Candidatus \nNitrososphaera. Whereas the microbial communities were overall highly \nlocation-specific, temperature, pH, ammonia, nitrate, total nitrogen, sulfate \nand hydrogen sulfide, as well as dissolved organic and inorganic carbon, were \nthe abiotic factors that significantly affected microbial community composition. \nFurthermore, an aquifer-type effect was observed in the community composition, \nbut there was no pronounced seasonal variability for geothermal spring \ncommunities (i.e. the community structure was mainly stable during the three \nseasons sampled). These results surprisingly pointed to stable and \ngeographically unique microbial communities that were adapted to different \ngeothermal water environments throughout Croatia. Knowing which microbial \ncommunities are present in these extreme habitats is essential for future \nresearch. They will allow us to explore further the microbial metabolisms \nprevailing at these geothermal sites that have high potential for \nbiotechnological uses, as well as the establishment of the links between \nmicrobial community structure and the physicochemical environment of geothermal \nwaters.\n\nCopyright © 2022 Elsevier GmbH. Front Microbiol. 2022 Nov 24;13:1018940. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2022.1018940. \neCollection 2022.\n\nDepth wide distribution and metabolic potential of chemolithoautotrophic \nmicroorganisms reactivated from deep continental granitic crust underneath the \nDeccan Traps at Koyna, India.\n\nMandal S(1), Bose H(2), Ramesh K(1), Sahu RP(2), Saha A(2), Sar P(2), Kazy \nSK(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Environmental Microbiology and Biotechnology Laboratory, Department of \nBiotechnology, National Institute of Technology Durgapur, Durgapur, WB, India.\n(2)Environmental Microbiology and Genomics Laboratory, Department of \nBiotechnology, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur, WB, India.\n\nCharacterization of inorganic carbon (C) utilizing microorganisms from deep \ncrystalline rocks is of major scientific interest owing to their crucial role in \nglobal carbon and other elemental cycles. In this study we investigate the \nmicrobial populations from the deep [up to 2,908 meters below surface (mbs)] \ngranitic rocks within the Koyna seismogenic zone, reactivated (enriched) under \nanaerobic, high temperature (50°C), chemolithoautotrophic conditions. Subsurface \nrock samples from six different depths (1,679-2,908 mbs) are incubated \n(180\u2009days) with CO2 (+H2) or HCO3 - as the sole C source. Estimation of total \nprotein, ATP, utilization of NO3 - and SO4 2- and 16S rRNA gene qPCR suggests \nconsiderable microbial growth within the chemolithotrophic conditions. We note a \nbetter response of rock hosted community towards CO2 (+H2) over HCO3 -. 16S rRNA \ngene amplicon sequencing shows a depth-wide distribution of diverse \nchemolithotrophic (and a few fermentative) Bacteria and Archaea. Comamonas, \nBurkholderia-Caballeronia-Paraburkholderia, Ralstonia, Klebsiella, unclassified \nBurkholderiaceae and Enterobacteriaceae are reactivated as dominant organisms \nfrom the enrichments of the deeper rocks (2335-2,908 mbs) with both CO2 and HCO3 \n-. For the rock samples from shallower depths, organisms of varied taxa are \nenriched under CO2 (+H2) and HCO3 -. Pseudomonas, Rhodanobacter, \nMethyloversatilis, and Thaumarchaeota are major CO2 (+H2) utilizers, while \nNocardioides, Sphingomonas, Aeromonas, respond towards HCO3 -. H2 oxidizing \nCupriavidus, Hydrogenophilus, Hydrogenophaga, CO2 fixing Cyanobacteria \nRhodobacter, Clostridium, Desulfovibrio and methanogenic archaea are also \nenriched. Enriched chemolithoautotrophic members show good correlation with CO2, \nCH4 and H2 concentrations of the native rock environments, while the organisms \nfrom upper horizons correlate more to NO3 -, SO4 2- , Fe and TIC levels of the \nrocks. Co-occurrence networks suggest close interaction between \nchemolithoautotrophic and chemoorganotrophic/fermentative organisms. Carbon \nfixing 3-HP and DC/HB cycles, hydrogen, sulfur oxidation, CH4 and acetate \nmetabolisms are predicted in the enriched communities. Our study elucidates the \npresence of live, C and H2 utilizing Bacteria and Archaea in deep subsurface \ngranitic rocks, which are enriched successfully. Significant impact of depth and \ngeochemical controls on relative distribution of various chemolithotrophic \nspecies enriched and their C and H2 metabolism are highlighted. These endolithic \nmicroorganisms show great potential for answering the fundamental questions of \ndeep life and their exploitation in CO2 capture and conversion to useful \nproducts.\n\nCopyright © 2022 Mandal, Bose, Ramesh, Sahu, Saha, Sar and Kazy.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2022.1018940\nPMCID: PMC9731672\nPMID: 36504802\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest.'},

Int Dent J. 2025 Nov 11;76(1):103988. doi: 10.1016/j.identj.2025.103988.\nOnline  ahead of print.\n\nMicrobial Characteristics of the Extrinsic Black Stain in Primary Dentition.\n\nBai X(1), Dong X(2), Liu J(3), Wu Q(4), Zhao W(3), Li G(5), Zhang S(6).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Yunnan Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital, Kunming, China; School and \nHospital of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, China.\n(2)People's Hospital of Yuxi City, Yuxi, China; School and Hospital of \nStomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, China.\n(3)School and Hospital of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, \nChina.\n(4)State Key Laboratory for Conservation and Utilization of Bio-Resources & Key \nLaboratory for Microbial Resources of the Ministry of Education, School of life \nSciences, Yunnan University, Kunming, China.\n(5)Yunnan Key Laboratory of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, \nChina. Electronic address: guidingli@163.com.\n(6)School and Hospital of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, \nChina. Electronic address: zhangshinan@kmmu.edu.cn.\n\nINTRODUCTION AND AIMS: Extrinsic black stain (EBS), a pigmented dental deposit \nprevalent in primary dentition, is challenging to remove, tends to recur \nrapidly, and poses aesthetic and psychological concerns. While the microbiota \nplays a key role in EBS formation, the specific microbial features remain poorly \nunderstood. Int Dent J. 2025 Nov 11;76(1):103988. doi: 10.1016/j.identj.2025.103988.\nOnline  ahead of print.\n\nMicrobial Characteristics of the Extrinsic Black Stain in Primary Dentition.\n\nBai X(1), Dong X(2), Liu J(3), Wu Q(4), Zhao W(3), Li G(5), Zhang S(6).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Yunnan Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital, Kunming, China; School and \nHospital of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, China.\n(2)People's Hospital of Yuxi City, Yuxi, China; School and Hospital of \nStomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, China.\n(3)School and Hospital of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, \nChina.\n(4)State Key Laboratory for Conservation and Utilization of Bio-Resources & Key \nLaboratory for Microbial Resources of the Ministry of Education, School of life \nSciences, Yunnan University, Kunming, China.\n(5)Yunnan Key Laboratory of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, \nChina. Electronic address: guidingli@163.com.\n(6)School and Hospital of Stomatology, Kunming Medical University, Kunming, \nChina. Electronic address: zhangshinan@kmmu.edu.cn.\n\nINTRODUCTION AND AIMS: Extrinsic black stain (EBS), a pigmented dental deposit \nprevalent in primary dentition, is challenging to remove, tends to recur \nrapidly, and poses aesthetic and psychological concerns. While the microbiota \nplays a key role in EBS formation, the specific microbial features remain poorly \nunderstood. The aim of the study was to explore the microbial characteristics of \nchildren aged 3-5 years with the EBS.\nMETHODS: EBS (30) and healthy (30) supragingiva plaque samples were collected \nfor comparative analysis. The microbial features of the 2 groups were \ninvestigated using Illumina MiSeq sequencing technology and verified by \nquantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR). Potential EBS-dominant genera \nwere isolated and identified, followed by whole-genome sequencing and \nbio-informatic analysis.\nRESULTS: The qPCR results verified that Abiotrophia, Lautropia and Arachnia were \nsignificantly more enriched in the EBS group than that in the healthy group (P < \n.05). Four species of the above genera were isolated and identified, including \nE11004 (Abiotrophia defectiva), E3101(Lautropia mirabilis), E1715 (Arachnia \npropionica) and E10012 (Arachnia rubra). E3101 possessed the highest number of \niron metabolism and biofilm-related genes among the isolates. Two genes, \nincluding 4-hydroxyphenylacetate hydroxylase (K23470) and \n4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (K05606), encoding key enzymes in the \nmelanin synthesis pathway, were found in E3101, E1715 and E10012.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study identifies E11004, E3101, E1715 and E10012 as \nspecies-level contributors to EBS, with genomic evidence implicating their \npotential roles in iron metabolism, biofilm formation and melanin production. \nThese findings highlight the need for functional studies to elucidate their \nmechanistic roles in EBS pathogenesis.\nCLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE: Identifying E11004, E3101, E1715 and E10012 as key \ncontributors to EBS offers potential targets for novel preventive or therapeutic \nstrategies, such as antimicrobial agents or biofilm inhibitors, to reduce \nrecurrence and alleviate the aesthetic burden in affected children.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Authors. This study aims to address the dynamic changes in oral \nmicrobiome following cancer treatment and their prognostic implications in NPC \npatients.\nPATIENTS AND METHODS: Unstimulated whole saliva samples were collected from 23 \nNPC patients before and after treatment, with an average of 2.8 samples per \npatient, and post-treatment saliva samples were collected from additional 13 NPC \npatients that enrolled after treatment. The declining taxa included two previously reported NPC-enriched \nbacteria, Lautropia mirabilis and Capnocytophaga sputigena. In contrast, in the \nonly recurrent case, the abundances of the two bacteria did not decrease, but \nremained at high levels or even increased until recurrence occurred.\nCONCLUSION: NPC treatment can cause persistent decline in microbial diversity of \nsalivary microbiome and abundances of NPC-associated bacteria, and candidate \nbacteria could be an explanatory factor for NPC prognosis and deserve intensive \nresearch.\n\nPlain Language Summary: Community diversity of oral microbiome decreased after \ntreatment in NPC patients.Overall abundance of NPC-enriched bacteria declined \nafter treatment.Specific bacteria could be potential indicators for NPC \nrecurrence.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s). Less significant differences \nin abundances of individual taxa were observed between shallow and deep pockets. \nOverall dysbiosis measured in terms of Subgingival Microbial Dysbiosis Index \n(SMDI) differentiated between GCP and no-periodontitis with 95% accuracy.\nCONCLUSIONS: The results suggest that several periodontal pathogens involved in \nthe adult-type periodontitis also play a role in JP2 genotype-associated GCP. \nThe potential role of non-conventional taxa in the pathogenesis of GCP warrants \nfurther investigation.\n\n© 2023 Molli, Kissa, Baraniya, Gharibi, Chen, Al-Hebshi and Albandar.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/froh.2023.1288499\nPMCID: PMC10682098\nPMID: 38033462\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest.
