    'abstract': "1. J Transl Med. 2025 Dec 8. doi: 10.1186/s12967-025-07541-9. Online ahead of \nprint.\n\nIntegrated salivary microbiome and metabolome profiling reveals ecological and \nfunctional alterations in severe early childhood caries.\n\nLiu Y(1)(2), Yu S(1)(2), Wang X(1)(2), Ye D(1)(2), Aili M(1)(2), Fu X(1)(2), Zou \nJ(3)(4), Ma Q(5).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)State Key Laboratory of Oral Diseases & National Center for Stomatology & \nNational Clinical Research Center for Oral Diseases, West China Hospital of \nStomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, 610041, China.\n(2)Department of Pediatric Dentistry, West China Hospital of Stomatology, \nSichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, 610041, China.\n(3)State Key Laboratory of Oral Diseases & National Center for Stomatology & \nNational Clinical Research Center for Oral Diseases, West China Hospital of \nStomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, 610041, China. \nzoujing@scu.edu.cn.\n(4)Department of Pediatric Dentistry, West China Hospital of Stomatology, \nSichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, 610041, China. zoujing@scu.edu.cn.\n(5)State Key Laboratory of Oral Diseases & National Center for Stomatology & \nNational Clinical Research Center for Oral Diseases, West China Hospital of \nStomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan, 610041, China. \nmqz2080@scu.edu.cn.\n\nBACKGROUND: Early childhood caries (ECC), particularly severe early childhood \ncaries (S-ECC), remains a prevalent chronic disease, significantly affecting \nchildren's health and quality of life. Despite extensive research, the detailed \necological and metabolic shifts underlying S-ECC pathogenesis are still poorly \ncharacterized. Integrating microbial and metabolic profiling of saliva may \nprovide crucial insights and identify novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets.\nMETHODS: We performed high-throughput 16S rRNA gene sequencing and untargeted \nmetabolomics to comprehensively profile the salivary microbiome and metabolome \nin children with S-ECC (n\u2009=\u200930) compared to caries-free (CF) controls (n\u2009=\u200930). \nDifferential microbial taxa and metabolites were identified, and their \nfunctional implications were explored through KEGG pathway enrichment analysis. \nFurthermore, integrated correlation analysis was conducted to uncover \ninteractions between key microbial taxa and metabolites.\nRESULTS: Microbial community analysis revealed significant ecological \nalterations in the saliva of children with S-ECC, characterized by enrichment of \npotentially cariogenic taxa, including Rothia, Lautropia, Lactobacillus, \nAchromobacter, as well as Streptococcus mutans, Prevotella histicola, and \nLachnoanaerobaculum saburreum. Conversely, health-associated genera such as \nBergeyella and Acinetobacter were more abundant in CF children. Metabolomics \nidentified a total of 4,325 salivary metabolites, among which 1,226 differed \nsignificantly between groups. Notably, metabolites involved in amino acid \nmetabolism pathways-phenylalanine, tyrosine, D-amino acids, aminobenzoate, \narginine, and proline-were upregulated in S-ECC saliva. Integrated analysis \nfurther revealed strong positive correlations between key cariogenic bacteria \n(S. mutans, P. histicola, L. saburreum) and multiple metabolites, including \nsuccinic acid, 2-piperidone, D-3-phenyllactic acid, 5-aminovaleric acid, L-malic \nacid, 2-hydroxypalmitic acid, LPE (16:0), vitamin K1 2,3-epoxide, leucylproline, \nand L-valine.\nCONCLUSIONS: Our findings demonstrate distinct ecological and functional \nsignatures in the salivary microbiome and metabolome associated with S-ECC. The \nidentified microbial and metabolic alterations, particularly in amino acid \nmetabolism, provide novel insights into the pathogenesis of S-ECC and highlight \npotential biomarkers for early detection and targeted intervention. However, the \ncross-sectional design and single time-point saliva collection limit the ability \nto assess longitudinal dynamics. Future longitudinal studies are warranted to \ntrack microbial and metabolomic changes during disease progression and \nintervention.\n\n© 2025. The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1186/s12967-025-07541-9\nPMID: 41361886\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declarations. Ethics approval and consent to \nparticipate: This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of the Faculty of \nWest China Hospital of Stomatology, Sichuan University, China \n(WCHSIRB-D-2025-128), and was conducted in accordance with the Declaration of \nHelsinki. Written informed consent was obtained from the parents or legal \nguardians of all participants prior to enrollment. Consent for publication: Not \napplicable. Competing interests: The authors declare no conflicts of interest."},

At a finer level, certain \nsubcommunities may exhibit stable signature across the sampling space. There can \nalso be similarity of differential patterns across different body sites. In view \nof above, and leveraging recent advancements in analytical strategies, we \nrevisit a multi-factorial Iranian ColoRectal Cancer (CRC) dataset, and explore \nstable and persistent patterns in the microbiome. For this purpose, 16S rRNA \ngene is amplified from saliva and stool samples of CRC patients using healthy \ncontrols as a baseline (n = 80). The dataset is supplemented with demographical \nand nutritional data of the study participants that were collected through \nfilled questionnaire. Our results indicate that certain microbial species i.e., \nActinobacteriota, Bifidobacterium, Prevotella and Fusobacterium are consistently \npresent in the CRC patients suggesting their potential as diagnostic biomarkers \nof disease. Additionally, we identified a group of microbes such as Akkermansia, \nSelenomonas, Clostridia_UCG-014, Lautropia, Granulicatella, Bifidobacterium, and \nGemella that exhibit similar differential response across body sites \nirrespective of where they are found, whether in saliva or stool samples. This \nsuggest that a part of saliva microbiome can act as a proxy for stool microbiome \ngiving further credence to oral-gut axis. Overall, our findings underscore the \nimportance of exploring stable microbial biomarkers in multifactorial CRC \ndataset by marginalizing out variabilities, with the potential for improved \ndiagnosis and treatment strategies.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Ashraf, Rezasoltani, Feizabadi, Jasemi, Aghdaei, Bakudezfouli, \nIjaz and Sechi.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2025.1449642\nPMCID: PMC12162472\nPMID: 40520381\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest. Front Cell Infect Microbiol. 2025 May 29;15:1560083. doi: \n10.3389/fcimb.2025.1560083. eCollection 2025.\n\nUnveiling the gut-heart potential connection: microbiota's role in kawasaki \ndisease and coronary artery lesions.\n\nYang Q(1), Tang W(1), Ren J(1), Li M(1), Zhao C(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Pediatrics, Qilu Hospital of Shandong University, Jinan, China.\n\nBACKGROUND: Kawasaki disease (KD) is an acute systemic immune vasculitis \npredominantly affecting medium and small arteries, commonly observed in \npediatric patients. It represents the most common form of acquired heart disease \nin this population. Emerging evidence suggests that gut microbiota can modulate \nthe gut-vascular axis, influencing coronary artery lesions (CALs). This study \naims to elucidate the potential association between gut microbiota, KD, and \nCALs, as well as identify bacterial biomarkers for CALs.\nMETHODS: We analyzed the gut microbiota composition of 60 children with KD (15 \nin the acute phase, 45 in the nonacute phase) and 30 healthy controls using \nalpha diversity indices and t-tests. Microbial biomarkers were identified \nthrough LEfSe to analyze the interplay between gut microbiota and CALs in KD \nduring acute and non-acute phases.\nRESULTS: In the acute phase, KD children exhibited decreased richness and \ndiversity of gut microbiota, characterized by dysbiosis, particularly a \nreduction in short-chain fatty acid-producing bacteria and overgrowth of \nopportunistic pathogens. Thirteen genera showed statistically significant \nchanges, including Enterococcus, Bacteroides, Faecalibacterium, Agathobacter, \nLachnospiraceae_NK4A136_group, Roseburia, Monoglobus, etc. LEfSe analysis \nrevealed enrichment of Burkholderia-Caballeronia-Paraburkholderia, Hungatella, \nand Clostridium_innocuum group in patients with concurrent CALs, while Halomonas \nwas depleted. In the nonacute phase, gut microbiota diversity was similar to \nhealthy controls, but Streptococcus was upregulated, while \nEubacterium_eligens_group and Erysipelotrichaceae_UCG_003 were downregulated. \nCALs were associated with reduced Anaerostipes, Subdoligranulum, Roseburia, and \nLachnospira. LEfSe analysis also showed enrichment of Coprobacillus, Paludicola, \nLautropia, UCG-009, Acetanaerobacterium, Methylobacterium-Methylorubrum, and \nAlistipes in patients with CALs.\nCONCLUSIONS: Our findings provide evidence of gut microbiota dysbiosis in KD \nchildren, suggesting its involvement in CALs development. Epub \n2025 Apr 19.\n\nMethane enhancing nitrous oxide consumption in microaerobic sludge systems.\n\nHe R(1), Li X(1), Zhang X(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Solid Waste Treatment and Recycling, \nSchool of Environmental Science and Engineering, Zhejiang Gongshang University, \nHangzhou, 310012, China.\n(2)Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Solid Waste Treatment and Recycling, \nSchool of Environmental Science and Engineering, Zhejiang Gongshang University, \nHangzhou, 310012, China. J Genet Eng Biotechnol. 2022 Jun 16;20(1):87. doi: 10.1186/s43141-022-00373-w.\n\nCellulase activity of a novel bacterial strain Arthrobacter woluwensis TDS9: its \napplication on bioconversion of paper mill sludge.\n\nDas T(1), Ali F(1), Rahman MS(2)(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Microbiology, University of Chittagong, Chattogram, 4331, \nBangladesh.\n(2)Department of Microbiology, University of Chittagong, Chattogram, 4331, \nBangladesh. mrahman7@lakeheadu.ca.\n(3)Department of Biology, Lakehead University, 955 Oliver Road, Thunder Bay, \nOntario, Canada. mrahman7@lakeheadu.ca.\n\nBACKGROUND: Lignocellulosic biomasses produced from agriculture and forest-based \nindustries are the cheapest or negative-cost biomass with a great potential for \nbiotransformation to value-added bioproducts. Paper mill sludge, an important \nlignocellulosic biomass creates an environmental threat, which requires \nfinancial input for disposal. Thus, this study was aimed to isolate a novel \nbacterial strain capable of degrading cellulosic biomass including paper mill \nsludge to produce reducing sugar and other value-added bioproducts.\nRESULTS: A novel bacterial strain Arthrobacter woluwensis TDS9 isolated from the \nsoil was screened for its cellulolytic activity using carboxymethyl cellulose \n(CMC) as the sole carbon source. The incubation\xa0period, temperature, pH, carbon, \nand nitrogen sources are the most important factors ruling the CMCase and sugar \nproductions of the strain A. woluwensis TDS9, and an alkaline pH (pH 8.0) led to \nenhanced sugar production up to 1100.09 μg/mL after 72 h of incubation at 25°C \nin a medium containing 1.5% CMC and 1.25% beef extract. The optimal conditions \nfor maximum CMCase activity were defined, and the potassium ion boosted the \nCMCase activity up to 1.06 U/mL when the enzymatic reaction was performed for 30 \nmin at 50°C and pH 8 using CMC as a substrate. Moreover, the strain A. \nwoluwensis TDS9 produced 433.33 μg/mL reducing sugar from 1% pretreated paper \nmill sludge. Significant alterations in the structural arrangement of cellulosic \nfiber of paper mill sludge observed under microscope after each step of chemical \ntreatment process helped for loosening the cellulose fibers and increased the \nsaccharification for enzymatic hydrolysis. Endoglucanase IV (33 KDa) and \nbeta-glucosidase II (53 KDa) were identified in crude enzyme based on the \nzymogram analysis and substrate specificity.\nCONCLUSIONS: The research has for the first time proved that this A. woluwensis \nTDS9 strain can efficiently convert cellulose. Therefore, the strain TDS9 could \nbe a potential candidate for cellulase production in an industrial \nbiotransformation process of paper mill sludge to produce reducing sugar. This \nsugar stream can be further used as a substrate to produce biofuels and other \norganic acids using another microorganism, which represents a greener \nalternative to add value to the paper production helping paper mill industries.\n\n© 2022. Over a 6-year period, \ntwo reference laboratories isolated or received 11 strains which were eventually \nidentified as belonging to the genus Arthrobacter. These strains had been \ninitially identified as Centers for Disease Control and Prevention coryneform \ngroup B-1 and B-3 bacteria (whitishgrayish colonies of 2 mm or greater in \ndiameter after 24 h of incubation, respiratory metabolism, absent or weak acid \nproduction from sugars, and hydrolysis of gelatin). Peptidoglycan and 16S rRNA gene sequence analyses \ndemonstrated that three of the strains studied were representatives of a new \nArthrobacter species for which the name Arthrobacter cumminsii sp. nov. is \nproposed and that one other strain represented a second new Arthrobacter species \nfor which the name Arthrobacter woluwensis sp. nov. is proposed. But with the \ncommencement of more sophisticated advances in agricultural techniques, organic \nfarming has gradually become limited in the world. Culture-dependent plant \ngrowth-promoting bacterial isolates were isolated from the bulk and rhizospheric \nsoil, of the native high yielding pole type organic pea (Pisum sativum L.) \ncultivar Dentami of Dentam, West Sikkim, India. Based on the 16S rRNA gene \nsequencing identification of these isolates, it was found that from the bulk \nsoil, Actinobacteria (58%) was the dominant phyla followed by Firmicutes (28%), \nand Proteobacteria (14%). In the rhizospheric soil it was dominated by \nProteobacteria (56%), followed by Firmicutes (33%), and Bacteriodetes (11%). A \ntotal of 40 bacterial isolates were initially screened for the plant \ngrowth-promoting (PGP) activity and out of them only four bacterial isolates \ni.e., Bacillus cereus P8, Arthrobacter woluwensis DP2, Paenarthrobacter \nnitroguajacolicus PP3, and Bacillus mycoides PP10 with accession numbers \nMN589697, MN559516, MN519462 and MN589696 respectively were found to possess \nhigher PGP activity (i.e. phosphorous, potassium solubilization and \nnitrogen-fixing activity) as compared to the other bacteria present in the soil. \nBased on the indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) quantitative assay and siderophore \nproduction assay, it was found that Bacillus cereus (MN589697) produced the \nhighest IAA (65.5\xa0µg mL-1) and siderophore (71%) when compared with the other \nisolates. The statistical correlation suggests that pH and available phosphorus \nwere the strongest influencing factors for the distribution of Proteobacteria in \nthe rhizospheric soil. The results indicate that these isolates can be potential \nplant growth promoter under the agro-climatic conditions of Sikkim, India. To \nthe best of our knowledge the present study is the first report of its kind and \nshowcases significant findings pertaining to the assessment of diversity, \nisolation and identification of plant growth-promoting rhizobacteria of organic \npea grown in Sikkim.\n\n© 2021 The Author(s). Microbiome. 2023 Oct 19;11(1):229. doi: 10.1186/s40168-023-01654-3.\n\nBacillus subtilis and Macleaya cordata extract regulate the rumen microbiota \nassociated with enteric methane emission in dairy cows.\n\nJia P(#)(1)(2), Dong LF(#)(1), Tu Y(3), Diao QY(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Institute of Feed Research, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences/Sino-US \nJoint Lab On Nutrition and Metabolism of Ruminant/Key Laboratory of Feed \nBiotechnology of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Beijing, 100081, \nPeople's Republic of China.\n(2)State Key Laboratory of Grassland Agro-Ecosystems, Key Laboratory of \nGrassland Livestock Industry Innovation, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural \nAffairs, College of Pastoral Agriculture Science and Technology, Lanzhou \nUniversity, Lanzhou, 730020, People's Republic of China.\n(3)Institute of Feed Research, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences/Sino-US \nJoint Lab On Nutrition and Metabolism of Ruminant/Key Laboratory of Feed \nBiotechnology of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Beijing, 100081, \nPeople's Republic of China. tuyan@caas.cn.\n(4)Institute of Feed Research, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences/Sino-US \nJoint Lab On Nutrition and Metabolism of Ruminant/Key Laboratory of Feed \nBiotechnology of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Beijing, 100081, \nPeople's Republic of China. diaoqiyu@caas.cn.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nBACKGROUND: Ruminant livestock production is a considerable source of enteric \nmethane (CH4) emissions. In a previous study, we found that dietary inclusions \nof Bacillus subtilis (BS) and Macleaya cordata extract (MCE) increased dry \nmatter intake and milk production, while reduced enteric CH4 emission in dairy \ncows. The objective of this study was to further elucidate the impact of feeding \nBS and MCE on rumen methanogenesis in dairy cows using rumen metagenomics \ntechniques.\nRESULTS: Sixty dairy cows were blocked in 20 groups of 3 cows accordingly to \ntheir live weight, milk yield, and days in milk, and within each group, the 3 \ncows were randomly allocated to 1 of 3 treatments: control diet (CON), control \ndiet plus BS (BS), and control diet plus MCE (MCE). After 75 days of feeding \nexperimental diets, 12 cows were selected from each treatment for collection of \nrumen samples for the metagenomic sequencing. Results showed that BS decreased \nruminal acetate and butyrate, while increased propionate concentrations, \nresulting in decreased acetate:propionate ratio. The metagenomics analysis \nrevealed that MCE reduced relative abundances of Methanobrevibacter wolinii, \nMethanobrevibacter sp. AbM4, Candidatus Methanomassiliicoccus intestinalis, \nMethanobrevibacter cuticularis, Methanomicrobium mobile, Methanobacterium \nformicicum, and Methanobacterium congolense. Both BS and MCE reduced relative \nabundances of Methanosphaera sp. WGK6 and Methanosphaera stadtmanae. The \nco-occurrence network analysis of rumen bacteria and archaea revealed that \ndietary treatments influenced microbial interaction patterns, with BS and MCE \ncows having more and stronger associations than CON cows. The random forest and \nheatmaps analysis demonstrated that the Halopenitus persicus was positively \ncorrelated with fat- and protein-corrected milk yield; Clostridium sp. CAG 269, \nClostridium sp. 27 14, Haloarcula rubripromontorii, and Methanobrevibacter \ncurvatus were negatively correlated with rumen acetate and butyrate \nconcentrations, and acetate:propionate ratio, whereas Selenomonas rumiantium was \npositively correlated with those variables.\nCONCLUSIONS: The present results provided new information for mitigation of \nenteric methane emissions of dairy cows by feeding BS and MCE to influence rumen \nmicrobial activities. This fundamental knowledge is essential for developing \nenteric CH4 reduction strategies to mitigate climate change and reduce dietary \nenergy waste. Video Abstract.\n\n© 2023. The etiology of AD is complex and \ndepends on age, genetics, the immune system, environmental factors, and the skin \nmicrobiome, with a key role for pathogenic Staphylococcus aureus in the \ndevelopment of severe AD. However, the composition of the skin microbiome in \nmild AD is understudied. Here, using metagenomic shallow shotgun sequencing, we \nshowed that mild AD lesions did not show a significant difference in the \ndiversity of the skin microbiome compared to samples from non-AD patients and \nthat the relative abundance of S. aureus did not differ in these mild AD \nlesions. However, when we assessed other taxa, Mycobacterium ostraviense, \nPedobacter panaciterrae_A and four Streptomyces species were identified with \nhigher abundances in mild AD lesions and species of 15 genera were decreased in \nabundance. The highest fold decreases were observed for Paracoccus marcusii, \nMicrobacterium lacticum, Micrococcus luteus, and Moraxella sp002478835. These \nmicrobiome compositional insights are a first step towards novel \nmicrobiome-based diagnostics and therapeutics for early intervention at the \nstage of mild AD and provide a path forward for the functional study of species \ninvolved in this often-overlooked patient population.\n\n© 2024. C. lház. 3. em. 1, H-1095 \nBudapest, Hungary.\n(4)Department of Medicine and Oncology, Faculty of Medicine, Semmelweis \nUniversity, Korányi Sándor u. 2/a, H-1083 Budapest, Hungary.\n(5)Endocrine Molecular Pathology Research Group, Eötvös Lóránd Research Network, \nKorányi Sándor u. 2/a, H-1083 Budapest, Hungary.\n(6)Centre for Bioinformatics, University of Veterinary Medicine Budapest, István \nu. 2, H-1078 Budapest, Hungary.\n\nThe beneficial effects of balneotherapy have been proven by numerous clinical \nstudies on locomotor disorders. To date, there is only scant data on changes in \nthe microbiome system of the skin during balneotherapy. The aim of this study \nwas to compare the effects of thermal water and tap water on the skin's \nmicrobiome in healthy volunteers. 30 healthy female volunteers participated in \nthe study. The experimental group (of 15 women) spent 30-min 10 times, in \nGabriella Spring's thermal baths (i.e., mineral water containing sodium hydrogen \ncarbonate).The controlled group (15 women) had the same, but in tap water. The \nresults of this study have proven that there is a difference in the influencing \neffects of tap water and medicinal water on the microbiome of the skin. After \nbathing in the thermal water of Lakitelek, Deinococcus increased significantly \nat the genus level, and the tendency for Rothia mucilaginosa bacteria also \nincreased. At the species level, Rothia mucilaginosa increased significantly, \nwhile Paracoccus aminovorans and the tendency for Paracoccus marcusii decreased. \nWhen the values of the two trial groups after bathing at the genus level were \ncompared, Rothia bacteria increased significantly, while Haemophilus tended to \nincrease, Pseudomonas tended to decrease, Neisseria tended to increase \nsignificantly, and Flavobacterium tended to decrease. At the species level, \nGeobacillus vulcani decreased significantly, and the tendency for Burkholderia \ngladioli decreased. The growth of Rothia mucilaginosa and the decrease in the \ntendency of Paracoccus, Pseudomonas, Flavobacteroium, and Burkholderia gladioli \nconfirm the beneficial effect of balneotherapy. In this study, trends are \nrepresented by the uncorrected p value. The main result was that the thermal \nwater changed certain bacteria of the skin, both on the genus and species \nlevels, but there were no significant changes in the tap water used, either at \nthe genus or species level. We first compared the worlds of thermal water and \ntap water's microbiome systems. The thermal water decreased the number of \ncertain inflammatory infectious agents and could enhance some of their positive \neffects, which have been proven at the molecular level. Our results can provide \nan important clue in the treatment of certain skin diseases. The research of the \nskin microbiome during balneotherapy can be one of the most intriguing and \nexciting topics of the future and can bring us closer to understanding the \nmechanism of action of balneotherapy.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/life13030746\nPMCID: PMC10051609\nPMID: 36983902\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest."},

Microorganisms. 2020 Oct 23;8(11):1634. doi: 10.3390/microorganisms8111634.\n\nMicrobial Reference Frames Reveal Distinct Shifts in the Skin Microbiota after \nCleansing.\n\nSfriso R(1), Claypool J(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)DSM Nutritional Products, Personal Care, Wurmisweg 576, CH-4303 Kaiseraugst, \nSwitzerland.\n(2)DSM Nutritional Products, Nutrition Innovation Center, Lexington, MA 02421, \nUSA.\n\nSkin cleansing represents a process of mechanical and chemical removal of dirt, \npollutants as well as microbiota from the skin. While skin cleansing can help \nmaintain good health, protect us from infections, illnesses and ailments, skin \ncleansing can also strip away lipids and moisture from the skin, leading to \nirritation, barrier impairment and disturbance of the delicate cutaneous \nmicrobiome. This study investigated how skin cleansing impacts skin\'s microbial \ncomposition. Thirty Caucasian women were enrolled in a placebo controlled \nclinical study where participants applied on their volar forearms a liquid body \nwash twice daily for 1 week in order to mimic frequent showering. Skin \nmicrobiome samples were collected by swabbing at defined timepoints and 16S rRNA \nsequencing was performed. Using "reference frames", we could identify shifts in \nthe microbial composition and several microbiota were identified as being \ncharacteristically associated with the presence of saccharide isomerate, a \nwell-known skin moisturizer. The microbial shift was quite immediate, and we \ncould observe it already at 1 h post cleansing. Interestingly, the new microbial \ncomposition reached a certain dynamic equilibrium at day 1 which was then \nmaintained until the end of the study. Paracoccus marcusii, a potentially \nbeneficial carotenoid-producer microorganism, was enriched by the active \ntreatment and, at the same time, the abundance of several potential pathogenic \ntaxa, Brevibacterium casei and Rothia mucilaginosa, diminished.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/microorganisms8111634\nPMCID: PMC7690701\nPMID: 33113896\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest.'}],

Environ Microbiome. 2025 Feb 25;20(1):25. doi: 10.1186/s40793-025-00684-8.\n\nMicrobial landscape of Indian homes: the microbial diversity, pathogens and \nantimicrobial resistome in urban residential spaces.\n\nAwasthi S(1)(2), Hiremath VM(1)(2), Nain S(1)(2)(3), Malik S(4), Srinivasan \nV(5), Rose P(1), Choudhury A(1)(6), Grover R(4), Sharma R(7)(8).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)CSIR-Institute of Genomics and Integrative Biology, New Delhi, India.\n(2)Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad, Uttar \nPradesh, 201002, India.\n(3)Present address: Source Bioscience, Endeavour House, Cambridge, UK.\n(4)Reckitt (India) Ltd, Research & Development, Gurgaon, India.\n(5)Reckitt Benckiser L.L.C., Global Research and Development for Lysol and \nDettol, Montvale, NJ, 07645, USA.\n(6)Present address: Department of Molecular Genetics, Erasmus University Medical \nCentre, Erasmus MC Cancer Institute, Rotterdam, Netherlands.\n(7)CSIR-Institute of Genomics and Integrative Biology, New Delhi, India. \nrsharma@igib.res.in.\n(8)Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad, Uttar \nPradesh, 201002, India. rsharma@igib.res.in.\n\nBACKGROUND: Urban dwellings serve as complex and diverse microbial community \nniches. Interactions and impact of house microbiome on the health of the \ninhabitants need to be clearly defined. Therefore, it is critical to understand \nthe diversity of the house microbiota, the presence and abundance of potential \npathogens, and antimicrobial resistance.\nRESULTS: Shotgun metagenomics was used to analyze the samples collected from 9 \nlocations in 10 houses in New Delhi, India. The microbiota includes more than \n1409 bacterial, 5 fungal, and 474 viral species en masse. The most prevalent \nbacterial species were Moraxella osloensis, Paracoccus marcusii, Microbacterium \naurum, Qipengyuania sp YIMB01966, and Paracoccus sphaerophysae, which were \ndetected in at least 80 samples. The location was the primary factor influencing \nthe microbiome diversity in the Indian houses. The overall diversity of \ndifferent houses did not differ significantly from each other. The surface type \ninfluenced the microbial community, but the microbial diversity on the cemented \nand tiled floors did not vary significantly. A substantial fraction of the \nbacterial species were potentially pathogenic or opportunistic pathogens, \nincluding the ESKAPE pathogens. Escherichia coli was relatively more abundant in \nbedroom, foyer, and drawing room locations. Analysis of the house microbiome \nantimicrobial resistome revealed 669 subtypes representing 22 categories of \nantimicrobial resistance genes, with multidrug resistance genes being the most \nabundant, followed by aminoglycoside genes.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study provides the first insight into the microbiomes of \nhouses in New Delhi, showing that these houses have diverse microbiomes and that \nthe location within the house significantly influences the microbiota. The \npresence of potential pathogens and a repertoire of antimicrobial resistance \ngenes reflect possible health risks, as these could lead to infectious disease \ntransmission. This study builds a framework for understanding the microbial \ndiversity of houses in terms of geographical location, environment, building \ndesign, cleaning habits, and impact on the health of occupants.\n\n© 2025. The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1186/s40793-025-00684-8\nPMCID: PMC11863970\nPMID: 40001165\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declarations. Ethics approval and consent to \nparticipate: Not applicable. Consent for publication: All the authors reviewed \nthe content of the paper and agreed to its publication. Competing interests: \nThis work was sponsored by Reckitt (India) Ltd, Research & Development, Gurgaon, \nIndia, to RS. SM and RG are affiliated with Reckitt (India) Ltd, Research & \nDevelopment, Gurgaon, India, and VS with Reckitt Benckiser L.L.C., Global \nResearch and Development for Lysol and Dettol, Montvale, NJ 07645, U.S.A. \nReckitt is a manufacturer of hygiene, health, and nutrition brands.'},

    'abstract': '1. Curr Microbiol. 2021 Feb;78(2):634-641. doi: 10.1007/s00284-020-02326-3. Epub \n2021 Jan 4.\n\nDraft Genome Sequence of a Highly Pigmented Bacterium Paracoccus marcusii KGP \nCapable of Producing Galacto-oligosaccharides Synthesising Enzyme.\n\nPooja KK(1), Gomathinayagam S(1), Gothandam KM(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)School of Bio Sciences and Technology, Vellore Institute of Technology, \nVellore, Tamil Nadu, 632014, India.\n(2)School of Bio Sciences and Technology, Vellore Institute of Technology, \nVellore, Tamil Nadu, 632014, India. gothandam@gmail.com.\n\nThe genome of Paracoccus marcusii KGP, isolated from the marine sediment \ncollected from the coast of the Bay of Bengal, was sequenced using Oxford \nNanopore sequencing technology. The assembled genome sequence consists of seven \ncontigs and has a 4,085,678\xa0bp circular chromosome with 1647 coding genes and a \nG+C content of 66.7%. Besides, the genome of P. marcusii KGP contains three \ncopies of the rrn operon.     'abstract': '1. J Appl Microbiol. 2021 Mar;130(3):665-676. doi: 10.1111/jam.14839. Epub 2020\nSep  14.\n\nBiological control of mites by xerophile Eurotium species isolated from the \nsurface of dry cured ham and dry beef cecina.\n\nOrtiz-Lemus JF(1)(2)(3), Campoy S(1)(2), Martín JF(1)(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Área de Microbiología, Departmento de Biología Molecular, Universidad de \nLeón, León, Spain.\n(2)Instituto de Biotecnología de León, INBIOTEC, León, Spain.\n(3)Departamento de Microbiología, Universidad de Pamplona, Pamplona, Colombia.\n\nSome meat dry products, including dry cured ham and dry beef cecina, are cured \nin cellars at moderately cold temperature allowing the growth of a lawn of fungi \non their surface. During the curing process, frequently these products became \ncontaminated with fungivore mites of the Acaridae family that feed on fungal \nmycelium and spores.\nAIMS: The aim of this article is to study the possible biological control of \nmites by fungi that form part of the normal microbiota of these meat products.\nMETHODS AND RESULTS: Some yellow/orange pigmented fungi growing on the ham \nsurface decreased the proliferation of mites; therefore, we isolated from ham \nand cecina xerophilic yellow/orange coloured fungal strains that were identified \nas members of the genus Eurotium (recently reclassified as Aspergillus section \nAspergillus). Using molecular genetic tools, we have identified 158 strains as \nEurotium rubrum (Aspergillus ruber), Eurotium repens (Aspergillus pseudoglaucus) \nand Eurotium chevalieri (Aspergillus chevalieri). Two strains, E. rubrum C47 and \nE. rubrum C49, showed strong miticidal activity. The toxic compound(s) are \nassociated with the formation of cleistothecia. In synchronized mite development \nexperiments, we observed that all stages of the mite lifecycle were inhibited by \nthe E. rubrum C47 strain. In addition, we searched for miticidal activity in 13 \nculture collection Eurotium strains isolated from different habitats, and found \nthat only one, Eurotium cristatum NRRL 4222 (Aspergillus cristatus) has a strong \nmiticidal activity.\nCONCLUSIONS: These fungal strains have proliferated on the surface of ham and \ncecina for decades, and possibly have acquired miticidal activity as a \nresistance mechanism against fungivores.\nSIGNIFICANCE AND IMPACT OF THE STUDY: Biological control of infecting mites by \nfavouring growth of E. rubrun C47, in place of the normal mixed population of \nAspergillus and Penicillium, is an attractive approach to control mite \ninfestations.\n\n© 2020 The Society for Applied Microbiology.\n\nDOI: 10.1111/jam.14839\nPMID: 32869458 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'}],

Electronic address: xmzhang@jiangnan.edu.cn.\n(7)Department of Food Science, Rutgers University, 65 Dudley Road, New \nBrunswick, NJ 08901, USA. Electronic address: ctho@sebs.rutgers.edu.\n\nAreca nut, one of the most historically representative chewing products in \nChina, faces challenges from harmful microbial growth that causes both product \nsafety and quality problems. To elucidate the mechanism underlying these \nmicrobial threats and develop targeted control strategies, this study analyzed \ndynamic microbial profiles of Hainan areca nuts during the processing stages. \nAlpha diversity analysis and total fungal counts (TFC) of Hainan areca nuts were \nmonitored during different processing stages. Our \nanalysis revealed distinct genetic requirements for growth in vitro, including \nseveral genes involved in responding to environmental stresses. Genome mining \nhas revealed many predicted siderophore biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) in \nbacterial genomes, however the structures of their siderophore products remain \nmostly undetermined. This limits our molecular-level understanding of how \nbacteria acquire iron, as well as how they interact with other taxa that may use \nthe same siderophores within bacterial communities. Here, we apply inverse \nstable isotope labeling (InverSIL) to rapidly connect predicted siderophore BGCs \nto their products. With InverSIL, bacteria are grown on 13C-substituted carbon \nsources and then fed predicted biosynthetic precursors at their natural isotopic \nabundance to identify BGC products by mass spectrometry, which removes issues \nwith the availability of isotopically substituted precursors. We use InverSIL to \ndetermine the structures of the siderophore products of predicted BGCs from the \nmethylotrophic genera Methylophilus and Methylobacterium, and the siderophores \nproduced by the opportunistic pathogen Chromobacterium violaceum, which were \npreviously shown to be essential for virulence yet remained structurally \nuncharacterized. J Med Case Rep. 2025 Nov 6;19(1):572. doi: 10.1186/s13256-025-05555-x.\n\nFirst reported case of abdominal Nocardia pseudocyst in the setting of a \nventriculoperitoneal shunt: a case report and review of literature.\n\nCliett J(1), Lee M(1), Vale F(1), Macomson S(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Neurosurgery, Medical College of Georgia at Augusta University, \nAugusta, GA, USA.\n(2)Department of Neurosurgery, Medical College of Georgia at Augusta University, \nAugusta, GA, USA. smacomso@augusta.edu.\n\nINTRODUCTION: Ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement is a common neurosurgical \nprocedure that is used to divert cerebrospinal fluid from the ventricular system \nto the peritoneal cavity to alleviate hydrocephalus. Ventriculoperitoneal shunts \ncarry the risk of several complications, from mechanical shunt failure and \ninfection to rarer complications such as abdominal pseudocysts. Skin flora has \nbeen found to be the cause of most ventriculoperitoneal shunt-related \npseudocysts. In this case presentation, we describe what we believe to be the \nfirst reported case of Nocardia species-induced ventriculoperitoneal \nshunt-related abdominal pseudocyst.\nCASE REPORT: A 27-year-old white male with a past medical history of cerebral \npalsy, congenital seizures, and hydrocephalus treated with four separate \nventriculoperitoneal shunts presented to the emergency department for abdominal \npain and distension for several months. A computed tomography scan of the \nabdomen showed a 6.1\xa0cm\u2009×\u200910.7\xa0cm\u2009×\u200914\xa0cm thinly encapsulated fluid collection \ncontaining the peritoneal ends of the ventriculoperitoneal shunts, which was \nindicative of an abdominal pseudocyst. Percutaneous aspiration of the pseudocyst \nfluid grew Nocardia paucivorans. The patient had no history of \nimmunosuppression. The patient underwent externalization of All the shunts along \nwith pseudocyst drainage. Antibiotic therapy was guided by the infectious \ndisease team. Daily cerebrospinal fluid samples were sent until three \nconsecutive cultures demonstrated no growth. The patient later underwent \nrevision of the shunt systems with placement of the distal catheters into the \npleural cavities. He was discharged on oral Bactrim and scheduled for a 4-week \nfollow-up in the neurosurgery clinic and the infectious disease clinic. We \nconducted a systematic review that yielded a total of 27 articles. Our case \nrepresents the first case of a Nocardia-infected abdominal pseudocyst associated \nwith a ventriculoperitoneal shunt that has been reported in literature.\nCONCLUSION: Abdominal pseudocysts are a rare complication of \nventriculoperitoneal shunt placement and can be associated with an underlying \nshunt infection. We present the first reported case of a Nocardia-infected \nabdominal pseudocyst associated with a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. Currently, studies have examined EGT \nimport systems and its physiological roles in various organisms. Despite the \nbroad applicability of EGT, industrial production with high productivity has not \nyet been achieved. In this study, we aimed to develop fermentative production \nmethods for EGT using Corynebacterium glutamicum as a host and successfully \nachieved the highest yield of EGT (459 mg L-1) reported to date. A \ncysteine-producing strain C. glutamicum CYS-2, which was constructed in a \nprevious study, was engineered to enhance the biosynthesis of histidine and \nS-adenosylmethionine, both of which, along with cysteine, are required for EGT \nproduction. Additionally, heterologous metabolic pathways for EGT biosynthesis \nfrom Mycolicibacterium smegmatis and Methylobacterium pseudosasicola were \nintroduced into the engineered strain, which was designated CHS2. In batch \ncultivation, the CHS2 strain produced more EGT than the CYS-2 strain harboring \nthe same EGT biosynthesis pathway. Interestingly, batch cultivation of the CHS2 \nstrain under high osmotic pressure conditions prolonged the time for EGT \nproduction and increased the intracellular accumulation of EGT. These results \nsuggest that increasing osmotic pressure together with engineering the \nbiosynthesis of cysteine, histidine, and S-adenosylmethionine is an effective \nstrategy for enhancing EGT production in recombinant C. glutamicum harboring \nheterologous EGT biosynthesis pathways. KEY POINTS: • Ergothioneine production \nin C. glutamicum was enhanced by metabolic engineering. • Osmotic pressure \naffects ergothioneine production in engineered C. glutamicum. • Ergothioneine \nmay function as a compatible solute in C. glutamicum.\n\n© 2025. The results showed that PM mass concentrations in Yokohama (urban, \nSPM-PM2.5 =\xa05.6\u202fμg/m3; PM2.5 =\xa011.8\u202fμg/m3) were higher than those in Toyama \n(suburban, SPM-PM2.5 =\xa03.8\u202fμg/m3; PM2.5 =\xa09.4\u202fμg/m3), but values remained below \nJapan\'s environmental standard. Water-soluble inorganic ions (WSII) and \nCarbonaceous species (CS) were the dominant chemical compositions, accounting \nfor 65.6\u202f%-72.4\u202f% of the total PM mass. Potential ecological risk (RI) reached a \n"serious" level at both sites (Toyama: 4839.6; Yokohama: 5443.4), with Sb as the \ndominant contributor (Ei = 701.1 and 832.7, respectively), indicating that \nmetal-enriched fine particles may exert ecological pressure even when PM mass \nremains within regulatory limits. Microbial community analysis indicated a \npredominance of plant-associated bacteria such as Methylobacterium (18.9\u202f%) and \nSphingomonas (7.8\u202f%) in Toyama. Yokohama, by contrast, were dominated by \nhuman-associated microorganisms including Corynebacterium (9.5\u202f%) and \nStreptococcus (6.4\u202f%). Co-occurrence network and redundancy analysis (RDA) \nfurther indicated that Yokohama\'s PM2.5 network had 2.8 times higher modularity \nthan Toyama\'s and was mainly driven by As, Pb (representing combustion and \nindustrial source elements, CSE), and elemental carbon (EC), while Toyama was \nprimarily influenced by Fe, K, and Rb (representing sea salt and crustal source \nelements, SCE). These findings highlights how land use patterns control the \nsources and composition of airborne microorganisms in atmospheric particles.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. However, recent reports have documented cases of infections \noccurring after PRP therapy. In this study, we aimed to examine potential \nmicrobial contamination risks associated with PRP therapy and evaluate rapid \nmicrobial detection methods suitable for clinical use.\nMETHODS: We assessed the risk of microbial contamination during blood \ncollection, PRP preparation, and sterility testing. To evaluate suitable \ndetection methods, we compared the microbial detection sensitivities of flow \ncytometry (FCM) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for identifying microbial \ncontamination in PRP. For this purpose, PRP samples were inoculated with \nStaphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus spp., Cutibacterium acnes, Micrococcus \nspp., Bacillus subtilis, and Candida albicans.\nRESULTS: Following skin disinfection, microbial colonies were detected at the \nvenipuncture site in six out of ten patients. Environmental monitoring \nidentified airborne microbial colonies in two out of three anonymous PRP \npreparation facilities. Sterility tests revealed negative results for all 85 \nresidual PRP and 15 platelet-poor plasma (PPP) cases. FCM sensitivity for \nmicrobial detection in PRP was effective at a concentration of 102-103 colony \nforming units (cfu)/mL or higher. While C. albicans could not be detected \nseparately from non-specific PRP signals using FCM, it was detectable in PPP at \n≥102\xa0cfu/mL. PCR sensitivity for microbial detection was excellent when \nanalyzing pure microbial suspensions, however, it yielded a high rate of \nfalse-negative and false-positive results when PRP samples contained certain \nmicrobial strains.\nCONCLUSION: The risks of microbial contamination were identified during both \nvenipuncture and PRP production. To reduce these risks, it may be necessary to \nimprove disinfection protocols for venipuncture sites and blood collection \nmethods, implementing appropriate facility-specific measures. Although requiring \nfurther detection sensitivity improvements, FCM is a promising method for \ndetecting viable bacteria in PRP. Given that microbial contamination cannot be \ncompletely eliminated, clinicians providing PRP therapy should remain alert to \nthe potential for postoperative infections and ensure appropriate follow-up \nprotocols are established.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.reth.2025.11.008\nPMCID: PMC12666433\nPMID: 41333320\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare the following financial \ninterests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing \ninterests: Morikuni Tobita reports financial support was provided by AMED. \nYoshitomo Saita reports financial support was provided by AMED. Electronic address: \nfkhan055@pknu.ac.kr.\n\nHyaluronic acid (HA) is a major component of the extracellular matrix that \npromotes skin hydration, elasticity, and repair. Human and bacterial \nhyaluronidases (HAases) degrade HA, leading to inflammation, skin aging, and \nmicrobial invasion. Bioactive compounds commonly used in skincare products may \nexert antioxidant, anti-aging, and antibacterial effects on skin through \ninhibitory effects on human and bacterial HAases, which remain unexplored. In \nthis study, we investigated the evolutionary relationships between human and \nbacterial HAases and the anti-HAase activities of 16 skincare bioactives. \nBioinformatics analyses showed limited sequence similarity but conserved \ncatalytic residues, particularly among Streptococcus and Cutibacterium acnes \nisoforms. A complementary mechanistic and functional analysis of these \nbioactives revealed that epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), rosmarinic acid (RA), \nretinol (ROL), ascorbic acid (AA), and hydroquinone (HQ) demonstrated relatively \nstrong binding profiles to human and bacterial HAase, with favorable skin \npenetration and safety profiles. Molecular dynamics simulations further \nconfirmed the stable binding of EGCG to both human and bacterial HAases. The \nminimum inhibitory concentration of HQ, EGCG, and ROL against Streptococcus \nagalactiae ranged from 32 to 512\xa0μg/mL, while HQ, kojic acid (KA), and azelaic \nacid (AzA) against C. acnes ranged from 1024 to 2048\xa0μg/mL. Furthermore, enzyme \nassays revealed that ROL, EGCG, HQ, and AA inhibited S. agalactiae HAase \n(ranging from 84.68 to 99.37\xa0%). AA, EGCG, AzA, alpha-tocopherol (AT), and \nsalicylic acid (SA) showed anti-HAase activity against C. acnes (ranging from \n94.23 to 99.51\xa0%). These findings on the anti-HAase activities of these \ncompounds provide a foundation for cosmetic and therapeutic approaches.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Elsevier B.V. In the more urbanized Finnish Karelia, allergic diseases \nare markedly more prevalent than in the more rural Russian Karelia. Prior \nstudies, based on amplicon sequencing, have demonstrated major differences in \nskin microbiotas between the two populations. However, compositional differences \nin microbiota between sensitized and non-sensitized (NS) individuals have not \nbeen characterized. Here, in a selected population of 112 allergen-sensitized \nand NS adolescents, we used shotgun metagenomics to characterize the \nprokaryotic, eukaryotic and viral species in the skin potentially involved in \nallergic sensitization via distinct environmental exposures. In the more urban \nFinnish Karelia, the microbiome species composition was associated with \nIgE-mediated allergen sensitization status, while in the more rural Russian \nKarelia, the composition was associated with exposure to furry pets. Finnish \nparticipants showing high IgE-mediated sensitization to common allergens \n(allergen-specific IgE >7.5\u2009kU/L) had less Cutibacterium acnes and Malassezia in \ntheir skin and displayed weaker interconnectedness of the microbial \nco-occurrence network compared with NS participants. Moreover, Malassezia \nrestricta strain-level differences were related to allergen sensitization in \nboth Finnish and Russian participants. In summary, we found distinct skin \nmicrobiomes between allergen-sensitized and NS participants and tracked the \nbacterial and fungal species associated with the degree of allergic \nsensitization in the more urbanized part of the Karelian region. These findings \nprovide new insights into the factors that shape the human skin microbiome and \ninfluence allergic diseases.\n\nDOI: 10.1099/mgen.0.001527\nPMID: 41335477 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'},

BMC Microbiol. 2025 Jul 31;25(1):468. doi: 10.1186/s12866-025-04103-3.\n\n2bRAD-M reveals circulating microbiome in chronic antibody-mediated rejection \n(CAMR) and IgA nephropathy (IgAN) after kidney transplantation.\n\nTao YX(1)(2)(3), Zhang ED(1)(2)(3), Yue JX(1)(2)(3), Wan ZL(1)(2)(3), Fan \nJW(1)(2)(3), Li Y(1)(2)(3), Fan Y(4), Yan L(5)(6)(7).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Laboratory Medicine, West China Hospital, Sichuan University, \nChengdu, China.\n(2)Sichuan Clinical Research Center for Laboratory Medicine, Chengdu, China.\n(3)Clinical Laboratory Medicine Research Center of West China Hospital, Chengdu, \nChina.\n(4)Department of Urology, Institute of Urology and Organ Transplantation Center, \nWest China Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu, China. kidney_fy@163.com.\n(5)Department of Laboratory Medicine, West China Hospital, Sichuan University, \nChengdu, China. yanlin@wchscu.cn.\n(6)Sichuan Clinical Research Center for Laboratory Medicine, Chengdu, China. \nyanlin@wchscu.cn.\n(7)Clinical Laboratory Medicine Research Center of West China Hospital, Chengdu, \nChina. yanlin@wchscu.cn.\n\nBACKGROUND: Kidney transplantation is currently the most effective method for \ntreating end-stage renal disease. However, postoperative-related rejection and \nIgA nephropathy remains a serious obstacle to the long-term survival of kidney \ntransplant patients. Its pathogenesis is not fully understood, and potential \ncausative factors remain to be explored. In this study, we used 2bRAD-M to \nanalyze differences in the peripheral blood microbiome of renal transplant \nrecipients who were stable postoperatively (STABLE) and those who developed \nchronic antibody-mediated rejection (CAMR) or IgA nephropathy (IgAN) recurrence.\nMETHOD: Thirty one renal transplant patients were recruited, including 12 \nSTABLE, 8 CAMR and 11 IgAN patients after kidney transplantation. 2bRAD-M was \nused to characterize the microbiota in peripheral blood to explore the presence \nof microbial differences.\nRESULTS: Differences in microbial community composition were observed between \nCAMR, IgAN and STABLE. The alpha diversity of CAMR and IgAN was all higher than \nSTABLE, there are also differences in beta diversity. LEfSe was performed to \nidentify different abundance taxa, 21 discriminative features between CAMR and \nSTABLE, 39 discriminative features between IgAN and STABLE. The mean decrease \nGini index and random forest analysis indicated that Staphylococcus_epidermidis \nmight serve as indicator bacteria for CAMR, Kocuria_palustris might serve as \nindicator bacteria for IgAN. ROC analysis was performed to assess the \nperformance of some optimal marker models, and the average AUC value achieved \n89.6% between CAMR and STABLE, 67.4% between IgAN and STABLE. Functional \nannotation analysis showed 4353 different COGs and 378 related signaling \npathways between CAMR and STABLE, 4396 different COGs and 384 related signaling \npathways between CAMR and STABLE.\nCONCLUSION: The first 2bRAD-M microbiome study of CAMR and IgAN after renal \ntransplantation showed a potential association between the circulating \nmicrobiome and the disease, and provided a possible target and basis for \nsubsequent studies of the mechanisms underlying the development and progression \nof CAMR and IgAN after renal transplantation.\n\n© 2025. The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1186/s12866-025-04103-3\nPMCID: PMC12312234\nPMID: 40745634 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declarations. However, \naccording to recent literature, Kocuria spp. have been associated with human \ninfections. Kocuria palustris is an emerging opportunistic pathogen with great \npotential to cause disease in immunocompromised patients. The isolation and \nidentification of this pathogen is necessary, as timely treatment with the \nappropriate antibiotics can help in reducing mortality among these patients. We \npresent three cases of bacteremia in immunocompromised patients admitted to our \nhospital; one patient was receiving chemotherapy for gall bladder carcinoma, the \nsecond was on maintenance hemodialysis for chronic kidney disease, and the third \nwas receiving chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia. All three patients \npresented with a fever in the setting of neutropenia during the course of \ntreatment with chemotherapy (in Cases 1 and 3) or hemodialysis (in Case 2). The \nblood culture samples of all the patients had pure isolates of Kocuria species \nK. palustris, which was identified by matrix assisted laser desorption \nionisation- time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-ToF MS). However, except for a few studies, the link between microbes \nand PCa remained poorly understood. To explore the potential microbiome \nsignature associated with PCa in Indian patients, we investigated differential \ncompositions of commensal bacteria among patients with benign prostatic \nhyperplasia (BPH) and PCa using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing followed by qPCR \nanalyses using two distinct primer sets. Bacterial and fungal dysbiosis has been recently \nassociated with several chronic immune-mediated diseases including psoriasis. In \nthis comprehensive study, we investigated how different sampling sites and \nmethods reflect the uncovered skin microbiota composition. After establishing \nthe most suitable approach, we further examined correlations between bacteria \nand fungi on the psoriatic skin. We compared microbiota composition determined \nin the same sample by sequencing two distinct hypervariable regions of the 16S \nrRNA gene. We showed that using the V3V4 region led to higher species richness \nand evenness than using the V1V2 region. In particular, genera, such as \nStaphylococcus and Micrococcus were more abundant when using the V3V4 region, \nwhile Planococcaceae, on the other hand, were detected only by the V1V2 region. \nWe performed a detailed analysis of skin microbiota composition of psoriatic \nlesions, unaffected psoriatic skin, and healthy control skin from the back and \nelbow. In the same \nsamples from psoriatic lesions, we found a significantly higher abundance of the \nfungus Malassezia restricta on the back, while Malassezia sympodialis dominated \nthe elbow mycobiota. In psoriatic elbow skin, we found significant correlation \nbetween occurrence of Kocuria, Lactobacillus, and Streptococcus with \nSaccharomyces, which was not observed in healthy skin. For the first time, we \nshowed here a psoriasis-specific correlation between fungal and bacterial \nspecies, suggesting a link between competition for niche occupancy and \npsoriasis. However, it still remains to be elucidated whether observed microbial \nshift and specific inter-kingdom relationship pattern are of primary etiological \nsignificance or secondary to the disease.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2019.00438\nPMCID: PMC6437110\nPMID: 30949136'}],

The primary outcome was treatment success, defined as \ninfection eradication without further surgery or suppressive antibiotics. \nSecondary outcomes were pain and functional results measured with the \nConstant-Murley Score (CMS), the Simple Shoulder Test (SST), and the Visual \nAnalog Scale (VAS). A standard statistical analysis was performed comparing \nbaseline data of both groups and finding factors related to the primary outcome.\nRESULTS: Baseline characteristics of both groups were comparable. Overall \ninfection control was achieved in 83% of patients, nonetheless, the one-stage \ngroup showed a higher success rate compared with the two-stage group (93% vs. \n71%), although this difference did not reach statistical significance \n(p\u2009=\u20090.169; OR:0.19(0.003,2.29)). Functional outcomes assessed by CMS and VAS \ndid not differ significantly between groups, whereas SST scores were \nsignificantly better following one-stage revision (p\u2009=\u20090.006). Increased BMI and \na higher number of previous surgeries tended to be associated with treatment \nfailure.\nCONCLUSION: Single-stage revision achieved comparable infection control and \nbetter functional outcomes than two-stage revision, supporting its role as a \nreliable surgical option for shoulder PJI in appropriately selected patients, \nalthough it could be influenced by bias selection.\n\n© 2025. While C. albicans could not be detected \nseparately from non-specific PRP signals using FCM, it was detectable in PPP at \n≥102\xa0cfu/mL. Given that microbial contamination cannot be \ncompletely eliminated, clinicians providing PRP therapy should remain alert to \nthe potential for postoperative infections and ensure appropriate follow-up \nprotocols are established.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.reth.2025.11.008\nPMCID: PMC12666433\nPMID: 41333320\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare the following financial \ninterests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing \ninterests: Morikuni Tobita reports financial support was provided by AMED. \nYoshitomo Saita reports financial support was provided by AMED. Conventional \nenvironmental monitoring relies on particle counts and culture-based \ncolony-forming unit measurements. These indicators fail to capture much of the \ndiversity and provenance of airborne microbes because many taxa are \nnonculturable or require growth conditions not supported by standard culture \nmedia. Therefore, comprehensive DNA-based microbiome analysis is critical for \nevaluating microbial risks that conventional methods may overlook; however, such \nstudies remain limited in cleanroom settings. This study aimed to \ncomprehensively visualize the structure of airborne microbial communities in \ncleanroom environments and clarify microbial risks that cannot be fully captured \nby particle counts or culture-based methods.\nMETHODS: We collected airborne bacterial DNA from cleanrooms with environmental \nGrades B, C, and D using a high-volume air sampler. The DNA was extracted and \nanalyzed via 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing targeting the V3-V4 regions. \nBioinformatic analysis was performed using the QIIME2 pipeline, and microbial \ndiversity was assessed using alpha and beta diversity indices. Abundant taxa \nwere categorized based on their likely origin (environment- or skin-derived), \nand their distributions were examined in relation to facility management \npractices.\nRESULTS: Analysis revealed the consistent detection of skin-associated bacteria, \nsuch as Cutibacterium and Corynebacterium, and environmental bacteria, including \nBacillus and Paracoccus, across all cleanroom grades. Alpha- and \nbeta-diversities exhibited no significant differences among the grades. However, \ntemporary and irregular increases in skin-derived bacteria indicated \noperator-related non-persistent contamination. This interpretation was supported \nby skewness and kurtosis analyses, which indicated occasional but noticeable \nshifts in microbial abundance, particularly in high-grade cleanroom \nenvironments.\nCONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the limitations of conventional \nculture-based monitoring and underscores the value of DNA-based approaches for \ncharacterizing airborne microbial communities in cleanrooms. The detection of \ntemporary increases in skin-associated bacteria indicates that operator-related \ncontamination can occur even under stringent environmental conditions. These \nfindings support the development of integrated monitoring strategies that can \ncapture both the composition and temporal fluctuations of airborne microbiota to \nenhance microbial risk assessment.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.reth.2025.10.019\nPMCID: PMC12616117\nPMID: 41244152\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that they have no known \ncompeting financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared \nto influence the work reported in this paper.'}],

Human and bacterial \nhyaluronidases (HAases) degrade HA, leading to inflammation, skin aging, and \nmicrobial invasion. Bioactive compounds commonly used in skincare products may \nexert antioxidant, anti-aging, and antibacterial effects on skin through \ninhibitory effects on human and bacterial HAases, which remain unexplored. In \nthis study, we investigated the evolutionary relationships between human and \nbacterial HAases and the anti-HAase activities of 16 skincare bioactives. \nBioinformatics analyses showed limited sequence similarity but conserved \ncatalytic residues, particularly among Streptococcus and Cutibacterium acnes \nisoforms. The \nminimum inhibitory concentration of HQ, EGCG, and ROL against Streptococcus \nagalactiae ranged from 32 to 512\xa0μg/mL, while HQ, kojic acid (KA), and azelaic \nacid (AzA) against C. acnes ranged from 1024 to 2048\xa0μg/mL. It is vitally important to clarify the epidemiology and antibiotic \nresistance transition of BSI pathogens. This retrospective study analyzed \nclinical data, pathogen profiles, and antimicrobial susceptibility of BSI \ninpatients from 2019 to 2023 in Xiangyang, China. Among 2312 isolates, \nGram-negative bacteria (52.4%) predominated over Gram-positive bacteria (45.5%), \nwith fungi comprising 2.1%. The prevalence of Gram-negative bacteria showed an \nincreasing trend, while that of Gram-positive bacteria declined. Predominant \npathogens included Staphylococcus hominis, Staphylococcus epidermidis, \nStaphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas \naeruginosa. Notably, 37 cases of polymicrobial BSIs were identified. S. aureus, \nE. coli, and K. pneumoniae exhibited high resistance to most common antibiotics. \nAlthough resistance rates of methicillin-resistant S. aureus and \ncarbapenem-resistant K. pneumoniae have decreased, they remain substantial. \nConversely, carbapenem-resistant E. coli prevalence increased annually. The \nmicrobes causing BSI are diverse, with varying epidemic characteristics and \nantibiotic resistance trends. Continuous monitoring of BSI pathogen epidemiology \nand resistance trends is essential to guide empirical therapy and control \nresistant strain transmission.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Weiliang Cao et al. Bile from a cow, known as gall, together with garlic, wine, \nand leeks, is used in the traditional medicine recipe of Bald's Leechbook, a \nthousand-year-old Anglo-Saxon formula for the treatment of infected eyelash \nfollicles. Different aspects of previous works on bile acids have been reported, \nand this work adds antiviral, virucidal, and antibacterial properties of bile \nacids and their salts against SARS-CoV-2. Four bile acids, lithocholic acid \n(LCA, 1), deoxycholic acid (DCA, 5), ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA, 9), and \nchenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA, 13), were used to form salts with l-carnitine [X], \ncreatinine [Y], and choline [Z], which are naturally occurring compounds. Bile \nacids and their salts were evaluated for antiviral and virucidal activities \nagainst SARS-CoV-2 as well as for their antibacterial properties. Among the bile \nacids tested, LCA (1) was found to display virucidal activity against SARS-CoV-2 \nwith an EC50 of 9.69 µg mL-1 and a selectivity index (SI) of >5.16. This work provides \nevidence that certain salts of bile acids have improved antibacterial activity, \nbut they do not enhance antiviral properties.\n\nThis journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry.\n\nDOI: 10.1039/d5ra07917a\nPMCID: PMC12679602\nPMID: 41357123\n\nConflict of interest statement: There are no conflicts to declare."},

Although pH \nis known to change during infection when SE crosses the host skin to access the \nbloodstream, the impact of this pH alteration on SE pathogenicity is poorly \nunderstood. Recognizing how SE deals with pH increments will help designing \neffective prevention and treatment strategies against SE infections. To \ninvestigate the metabolic adaptations of representative A/C and B strains to pH, \nwe mimicked skin and blood pH conditions (5.5 and 7.4) and followed biomass \nformation, growth media pH and exometabolites over time. At blood pH, \nthe B strain depletes formate from the extracellular media, while its \nextracellular accumulation by the A/C strain could work as a host invasion \nstrategy. The uptake and consumption of saccharides follow similar \nprofiles and seem to be pH-regulated by both strains. The dynamic study of SE \nexometabolome has contributed to understanding the intracellular processes and \ntheir relationship with virulence.\n\nCopyright © 2025. Electronic address: \nmiragaia@itqb.unl.pt.\n\nStaphylococcus epidermidis recently emerged as a major cause of medical \ndevice-associated infections. However, the role of the nosocomial environment in \nits evolution remains poorly understood. To investigate the genomic changes \nunderlying S. epidermidis evolutionary history, we compared genomes of 1960s \nisolates, before its recognition as a human pathogen, to those from the 1990s, \nwhen it became prevalent in hospital-acquired infections. We found that S. \nepidermidis from the 1960s and 1990s shared similar population structures, with \nthe A/C cluster predominating in both periods. Recombination was frequent, \nparticularly in the A/C cluster, and occurred throughout the chromosome. \nAlterations in the mobile genetic elements of the 1990s isolates caused a \ndrastic genomic change, characterized by phage loss, and staphylococcal cassette \nchromosome elements and insertion sequences acquisition. The 1990s isolates \ngained multiple antibiotic resistance and virulence genes, which are associated \nwith biofilm formation and persistence. Genomic analysis of the orfX/rmlH \nvicinity revealed differences between the two groups of isolates. The 1960s \nisolates harbored a complex orfX/rmlH vicinity containing multiple SCC and \npseudoSCC, and genes with high homology to SCCmecIV, while the 1990s isolates \ncontained only SCCmec and ACME. Interestingly, one early isolate carried a \ndisrupted mecA, within a pseudoSCCmecIV, suggesting it may represent a precursor \nto the contemporary SCCmecIV. Our results showed that prolonged exposure to the \nhospital environment drove S. epidermidis genomic remodeling, including the \naccumulation of genes linked to antibiotic resistance, enhanced colonization, \nbiofilm formation, genome plasticity, and the loss of bacteriophages \n-contributing to its success as a persistent nosocomial pathogen.\n\nCopyright © 2025. This study aims to systematically review \nthe microbiological spectrum of SI to enhance diagnostic accuracy and inform \neffective antibiotic treatment strategies. The last search was conducted on May \n9th, 2024, from databases including EMBASE, PubMed, and Web of Science. The \noutcome variable is infection rate, and the detection method used should be \nblood culture, tissue culture, or molecular biology method. Two researchers \nindependently extracted research data and evaluated its quality using the JBI \nCritical Appraisal Tools. Out of 14,639 identified records, 156 studies \n(encompassing 13,539 patients) were included. Staphylococcus aureus was \nidentified as the most prevalent pathogen, with pooled infection rates of 17.6% \n(95%CI: 12.8-22.9%; I2=93%) in blood culture, 16.8% (95%CI: 14.0-19.8%; I2=96%) \nin tissue culture, and 12.0% (95%CI: 9.3-15.0%; I2=35%) in molecular methods. \nThe bacterial spectrum also featured Staphylococcus epidermidis, Escherichia \ncoli, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB). Molecular methods, particularly \nmetagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS), demonstrated markedly superior \nsensitivity for MTB detection, with a pooled rate of 9.7% (95%CI: 4.6-16.3%; \nI2=90%) compared to 1.3% (95%CI: 0.6-2.1%; I2=86%) by tissue culture. The odds \nratio for MTB detection with mNGS versus conventional culture was 4.24 (95%CI: \n1.68-10.73). This review confirms that a core group of pathogens, including \nStaphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, MTB, and Escherichia coli. \nOur findings underscore that tissue culture is fundamental for common pyogenic \nbacteria, while metagenomic next-generation sequencing is indispensable for \ndetecting fastidious organisms like MTB. It is vitally important to clarify the epidemiology and antibiotic \nresistance transition of BSI pathogens. This retrospective study analyzed \nclinical data, pathogen profiles, and antimicrobial susceptibility of BSI \ninpatients from 2019 to 2023 in Xiangyang, China. Among 2312 isolates, \nGram-negative bacteria (52.4%) predominated over Gram-positive bacteria (45.5%), \nwith fungi comprising 2.1%. The prevalence of Gram-negative bacteria showed an \nincreasing trend, while that of Gram-positive bacteria declined. Predominant \npathogens included Staphylococcus hominis, Staphylococcus epidermidis, \nStaphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas \naeruginosa. Notably, 37 cases of polymicrobial BSIs were identified. S. aureus, \nE. coli, and K. pneumoniae exhibited high resistance to most common antibiotics. \nAlthough resistance rates of methicillin-resistant S. aureus and \ncarbapenem-resistant K. pneumoniae have decreased, they remain substantial. \nConversely, carbapenem-resistant E. coli prevalence increased annually. The \nmicrobes causing BSI are diverse, with varying epidemic characteristics and \nantibiotic resistance trends. Continuous monitoring of BSI pathogen epidemiology \nand resistance trends is essential to guide empirical therapy and control \nresistant strain transmission.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Weiliang Cao et al. Classical \nforward genetics has defined essential genes for phage replication in a few \nmodel systems but remains laborious and non-scalable. Unbiased functional \ngenomics approaches are therefore needed for phages, particularly for large \nlytic phages. Here, we develop a phage transposon sequencing (TnSeq) platform \nthat uses the mariner transposase to insert an anti-CRISPR selectable marker \ninto phage genomes. CRISPR-Cas13a-based enrichment of transposed phages followed \nby pooled sequencing identifies both fitness-conferring and dispensable genes. \nUsing the Pseudomonas aeruginosa -infecting nucleus-forming jumbo phage ΦKZ \n(280,334 bp; 371 predicted genes) as a model, we show that ~110 genes are \nfitness-conferring via phage TnSeq. These include conserved essential genes \ninvolved in phage nucleus formation, protein trafficking, transcription, DNA \nreplication, and virion assembly. We also isolate hundreds of individual phages \nwith insertions in non-essential genes and reveal conditionally essential genes \nthat are specifically required in clinical isolates, at environmental \ntemperature, or in the presence of a defensive nuclease. Phage TnSeq is a \nfacile, scalable technology that can define essential phage genes and generate \nknockouts in all non-essential genes in a single experiment, enabling \nconditional genetic screens in phages and providing a broadly applicable \nresource for phage functional genomics.\n\nDOI: 10.1101/2025.11.23.690004\nPMCID: PMC12676376\nPMID: 41357988'}],

We also isolate hundreds of individual phages \nwith insertions in non-essential genes and reveal conditionally essential genes \nthat are specifically required in clinical isolates, at environmental \ntemperature, or in the presence of a defensive nuclease. Previous studies shed light on the important \nrole that Aspergillus nidulans gfdB, putatively encoding a NAD+-dependent \nglycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, plays in the oxidative and cell wall \nintegrity stress tolerance of this filamentous fungus model organism. The \ninsertion of A. nidulans gfdB into the genome of Aspergillus glaucus \nstrengthened the environmental stress tolerance of this xerophilic/osmophilic \nfungus, which may facilitate the involvement of this fungus in various \nindustrial and environmental biotechnological processes. On the other hand, the \ntransfer of A. nidulans gfdB to Aspergillus wentii, another promising industrial \nxerophilic/osmophilic fungus, resulted only in minor and sporadic improvement in \nenvironmental stress tolerance and meanwhile partially reversed osmophily. \nBecause A. glaucus and A. wentii are phylogenetically closely related species \nand both fungi lack a gfdB ortholog, these results warn us that any disturbance \nof the stress response system of the aspergilli may elicit rather complex and \neven unforeseeable, species-specific physiological changes. This should be taken \ninto consideration in any future targeted industrial strain development projects \naiming at the fortification of the general stress tolerance of these fungi. KEY \nPOINTS: • A. wentii c' gfdB strains showed minor and sporadic stress tolerance \nphenotypes. • The osmophily of A. wentii significantly decreased in the c' gfdB \nstrains. • Insertion of gfdB caused species-specific phenotypes in A. wentii and \nA. glaucus.\n\n© 2023. Voriconazole (VOR) is effective against FK, but its eye \ndrop formulations suffer from poor bioavailability, while intrastromal \ninjections are invasive and carry risks. This study aimed to address these \nchallenges by formulating a VOR nanosuspension (NS) and fabricating an ocular \nbilayer dissolving microneedle array patch (dMAP) incorporating the VOR NS for \nlocalized drug delivery to the cornea. Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. To address this challenge, recent research has increasingly shifted \ntoward biodegradation and upcycling as sustainable alternatives. Microbial \ndegradation of synthetic plastics has shown advancement. This includes the \nintroduction of novel strains like Aspergillus niger MG654699 for the 3.6% and \n5% degradation of polyethylene terephthalate and polystyrene, respectively. \nAlso, Streptomyces sp., Methylobacterium, Arthrobacter, and Sphingomonas have \nbeen studied to be responsible for mulch film degradation. Advances in \nmetagenomics have further revealed the complexity of microbial consortia for \ndriving these processes, whereas kinetic modeling has provided insights into \ndegradation rates and conditions. Building on this foundation, artificial \nintelligence and machine learning are now expediting enzyme discovery, \noptimizing degradation pathways, and enabling intelligent waste management \nsystems. Similarly, biosensors based on Vibrio fischeri and Escherichia coli \nimprove monitoring by detecting plastic monomers. Beyond degradation, the \nintegration of microbial and chemical processes has enabled the upcycling of \nplastic monomers into value-added products such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, \nvanillin, bacterial nanocellulose, fuels, and biochemicals, promoting a circular \nbioeconomy. These advances highlight a paradigm shift from waste accumulation to \nresource recovery, underscoring the potential of biotechnology and engineering \ninnovations to transform plastic management. The review concludes by \nhighlighting the challenges of scalability, environmental variability, and \npolicy support while positioning biodegradation and upcycling as integrated \nstrategies for a sustainable and resilient future.\n\n© 2025. Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. To address this challenge, recent research has increasingly shifted \ntoward biodegradation and upcycling as sustainable alternatives. Microbial \ndegradation of synthetic plastics has shown advancement. This includes the \nintroduction of novel strains like Aspergillus niger MG654699 for the 3.6% and \n5% degradation of polyethylene terephthalate and polystyrene, respectively. \nAlso, Streptomyces sp., Methylobacterium, Arthrobacter, and Sphingomonas have \nbeen studied to be responsible for mulch film degradation. Advances in \nmetagenomics have further revealed the complexity of microbial consortia for \ndriving these processes, whereas kinetic modeling has provided insights into \ndegradation rates and conditions. Building on this foundation, artificial \nintelligence and machine learning are now expediting enzyme discovery, \noptimizing degradation pathways, and enabling intelligent waste management \nsystems. Similarly, biosensors based on Vibrio fischeri and Escherichia coli \nimprove monitoring by detecting plastic monomers. Beyond degradation, the \nintegration of microbial and chemical processes has enabled the upcycling of \nplastic monomers into value-added products such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, \nvanillin, bacterial nanocellulose, fuels, and biochemicals, promoting a circular \nbioeconomy. These advances highlight a paradigm shift from waste accumulation to \nresource recovery, underscoring the potential of biotechnology and engineering \ninnovations to transform plastic management. The review concludes by \nhighlighting the challenges of scalability, environmental variability, and \npolicy support while positioning biodegradation and upcycling as integrated \nstrategies for a sustainable and resilient future.\n\n© 2025.
