Hypoxia, resulting in a \nrange of gastrointestinal disorders, is a significant physiological challenge in \nhigh-altitude environments. The gastrointestinal microbiota is closely linked to \nthe mucosal barrier and our previous research found that hypoxia-induced mucosal \ninjury mainly occurs in stomach and small intestine. This study aimed to \ncharacterize the temporal dynamics of gastric and small intestinal microbiota by \ndirectly analyzing the luminal contents to elucidate site-specific microbial \nalterations and their potential role in mucosal damage under hypoxic conditions. \nC57BL/6\xa0J mice were randomly assigned to four groups: normoxic control, 1-day \nhypoxic exposure, 3-day hypoxic exposure and 12-day hypoxic exposure. Fresh \ngastric and small intestinal contents were collected for 16S rRNA sequencing. \nThe operational taxonomic unit (OTU) counts, α/β-diversity and temporal \nmicrobial abundance shifts across different durations of hypoxia exposure were \nanalyzed. Our results found that short-term hypoxia (1-3\xa0days) significantly \nreduced the OTU counts and diminished α/β-diversity in the stomach and small \nintestine. However, prolonged hypoxia (day 12) reversed the diminished OTU \ncounts and α/β-diversity to near-normoxic levels. In the stomach, short-term \nhypoxia increased the abundances of the phylum Firmicutes and genus \nLactobacillus and suppressed the levels of the phyla Verrucomicrobia, \nCandidate_division_TM7, Tenericutes, Actinobacteria, and Bacteroidetes and \ngenera S24-7_unclassified and Bifidobacterium. However, at 12\xa0days of hypoxia, \nthese phyla and genera reverted to near-normoxic levels. In the small intestine, \nthe relative abundances of the phylum Firmicutes and genus Lactobacillus \nincreased and those of the phyla Actinobacteria and Verrucomicrobia and genera \nBifidobacterium and Akkermansia decreased during short-term hypoxia. However, \nthese altered bacteria returned to near-normoxic levels by day 12 of hypoxia. \nTemporal clustering revealed persistent taxon shifts; the relative abundances of \nthe phyla Gemmatimonadetes and Acidobacteria and genera Gemmatimonas, Kocuria, \nParasutterella, and Saccharopolyspora declined steadily, while Staphylococcus \nincreased consistently in the stomach. In the small intestine, the relative \nabundance of the genus Stomatobaculum consistently increased in response to \nprolonged hypoxia. This study provided a time-resolved overview of gastric and \nsmall intestinal microbiota adaptations to hypoxia, identified potential \ncandidate taxa involved in mucosal injury caused by hypoxia.\n\n© 2025. Hypoxia, resulting in a \nrange of gastrointestinal disorders, is a significant physiological challenge in \nhigh-altitude environments. The gastrointestinal microbiota is closely linked to \nthe mucosal barrier and our previous research found that hypoxia-induced mucosal \ninjury mainly occurs in stomach and small intestine. This study aimed to \ncharacterize the temporal dynamics of gastric and small intestinal microbiota by \ndirectly analyzing the luminal contents to elucidate site-specific microbial \nalterations and their potential role in mucosal damage under hypoxic conditions. \nC57BL/6\xa0J mice were randomly assigned to four groups: normoxic control, 1-day \nhypoxic exposure, 3-day hypoxic exposure and 12-day hypoxic exposure. Fresh \ngastric and small intestinal contents were collected for 16S rRNA sequencing. \nThe operational taxonomic unit (OTU) counts, α/β-diversity and temporal \nmicrobial abundance shifts across different durations of hypoxia exposure were \nanalyzed. Our results found that short-term hypoxia (1-3\xa0days) significantly \nreduced the OTU counts and diminished α/β-diversity in the stomach and small \nintestine. However, prolonged hypoxia (day 12) reversed the diminished OTU \ncounts and α/β-diversity to near-normoxic levels. In the stomach, short-term \nhypoxia increased the abundances of the phylum Firmicutes and genus \nLactobacillus and suppressed the levels of the phyla Verrucomicrobia, \nCandidate_division_TM7, Tenericutes, Actinobacteria, and Bacteroidetes and \ngenera S24-7_unclassified and Bifidobacterium. However, at 12\xa0days of hypoxia, \nthese phyla and genera reverted to near-normoxic levels. In the small intestine, \nthe relative abundances of the phylum Firmicutes and genus Lactobacillus \nincreased and those of the phyla Actinobacteria and Verrucomicrobia and genera \nBifidobacterium and Akkermansia decreased during short-term hypoxia. However, \nthese altered bacteria returned to near-normoxic levels by day 12 of hypoxia. \nTemporal clustering revealed persistent taxon shifts; the relative abundances of \nthe phyla Gemmatimonadetes and Acidobacteria and genera Gemmatimonas, Kocuria, \nParasutterella, and Saccharopolyspora declined steadily, while Staphylococcus \nincreased consistently in the stomach. In the small intestine, the relative \nabundance of the genus Stomatobaculum consistently increased in response to \nprolonged hypoxia. This study provided a time-resolved overview of gastric and \nsmall intestinal microbiota adaptations to hypoxia, identified potential \ncandidate taxa involved in mucosal injury caused by hypoxia.\n\n© 2025. A domain-shuffling strategy was \nemployed, to enhance the activity PguPHBd towards solid plastic films, by fusing \nthe SBD of CmaPHBd to the CD of PguPHBd. In the current \nstudy, we focused on StrR-like PSRs from the ramoplanin biosynthetic gene \ncluster (BGC) in Actinoplanes ramoplaninifer ATCC 33076 (Ramo5) and the \nchersinamycin BGC in Micromonospora chersina DSM 44151 (Chers28). The high diversity and \ndistribution of Actinobacteria OTUs indicate the area's potential for \ndiscovering new rare species. The Sahara's nutrient scarcity, high temperatures, and salinity drive \nunique microbial adaptations, making it a promising reservoir of novel taxa. \nThis study reports, for the first time, the isolation and characterization of \nendophytic actinobacteria from Artemisia judaica L. ssp. sahariensis, a \nmedicinal plant of the Algerian desert. More than 93% exhibited \nantagonistic effects against at least one tested pathogen. The most active \nstrains showed minimum inhibitory concentration values between 4 and 8\xa0µg/mL, \nhighlighting their strong antibacterial potential. All isolates tolerated up to \n5% NaCl, and several, including AJR36, AJR38, and AJR16, grew at 15%. Phosphate \nsolubilization was observed in 36% of isolates, while 38% displayed diverse \nenzymatic activities. Although this study focused on a single plant species, the \nobserved functional diversity underscores the biotechnological potential of \nthese desert-associated endophytes. These findings suggest that unexplored \ndesert ecosystems harbor valuable Actinomycetota resources, supporting further \ninvestigations for the discovery of novel species and their potential \napplications in agriculture and medicine.\n\n© 2025. After 4 weeks of \nincubation, 73 terrestrial actinomycetes were isolated. They were selected based \non the color of aerial mycelium, substrate mycelium, spore formation, and \npigment production. With the advent of genome-based taxonomic \napproaches and integrated genomic metrics, including sequence similarity and \nphylogenomic frameworks, it has become essential to reevaluate the taxonomic \nstatus of older taxa defined before the era of genome-based microbial taxonomy. \nApplying these modern genomic criteria enables a more accurate assessment of \nspecies boundaries and helps to determine whether the old taxa represent \ndistinct species or should be reclassified as synonyms, subspecies, or members \nof different genera. Such reclassification efforts are crucial for ensuring \ntaxonomic accuracy, improving the reliability of comparative genomics, and \nmaintaining stable and evolutionariy meaningful nomenclature. In this study, we \nre-evaluated the taxonomy of Nonomuraea using genome-based methods, including \ndigital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH), average nucleotide identity (FastANI), \naverage amino acid identity (AAI), and percentage of conserved proteins (POCP) \nanalyses, complemented by phylogenomic analysis. Based on comprehensive genomic \nstudies, our results support the elevation of both Nonomuraea roseoviolacea \nsubsp. carminata and Nonomuraea roseoviolacea subsp. roseoviolacea to an unified \nspecies without subspecies distinction: Nonomuraea roseoviolacea (ATCC \n27297T\u2009=\u2009BCRC 13406T\u2009=\u2009CBS 260.72T\u2009=\u2009CCM 3491T\u2009=\u2009CCRC 13406T\u2009=\u2009CGMCC \n4.1072T\u2009=\u2009CIP 106924T\u2009=\u2009DSM 43144T\u2009=\u2009IFO 14098T\u2009=\u2009IMET 9751T\u2009=\u2009JCM 3145T\u2009=\u2009KCTC \n9283T\u2009=\u2009NBRC 14098T\u2009=\u2009NCIB 11117T\u2009=\u2009NCIMB 11117T\u2009=\u2009NRRL B-16127T\u2009=\u2009VKM Ac-909T). \nFurthermore, we propose the reclassification of Nonomuraea recticatena, \nNonomuraea roseola and Nonomuraea dietziae as subspecies within N. roseola. \nConsequently, we propose the establishment of the following two subspecies: \nNonomuraea roseola subsp. roseola subsp. nov. (= ATCC 33579T\u2009=\u2009DSM 43767T\u2009=\u2009DSM \n44323T\u2009=\u2009IFO 14685T\u2009=\u2009IMET 9576T\u2009=\u2009INA 1671T\u2009=\u2009JCM 3323 T\u2009=\u2009KCTC 9282T\u2009=\u2009NBRC \n14685T\u2009=\u2009VKM Ac-1180T) and Nonomuraea roseola subsp. recticatena subsp. nov., \ncomb. nov. (= DSM 43937T\u2009=\u2009IFO 14525T\u2009=\u2009INA 308T\u2009=\u2009JCM 6835T\u2009=\u2009KCTC 9279T\u2009=\u2009NBRC \n14525T\u2009=\u2009VKM Ac-940T) and. In addition, we propose Nonomuraea harbinensis as \nlater heterotypic synonyms of Nonomuraea ferruginea.\n\nCopyright: © 2025 Bouras et al. Front Microbiol. 2025 Oct 9;16:1661023. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2025.1661023. \neCollection 2025.\n\nHarnessing sunflower stalk-based bowl for sustainable tobacco seedling and \ncultivation: influence on rhizosphere microbiome and carbon cycling.\n\nShi X(#)(1), Ge M(#)(1), Hou S(1), Han Q(1), Xu A(1), Jiang C(1), Ma X(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)College of Agronomy, Shenyang Agricultural University, Shenyang, China.\n(2)China National Tobacco Corporation Liaoning Provincial Company, Shenyang, \nChina.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nMicrobes in the rhizosphere make significant contributions to nutrient cycling \nand plant health maintenance. Tobacco is an important commercial crop, and the \nmethods used for seedling cultivation significantly influence the rhizosphere \nsoil microenvironment. Compared to conventional seedling practices, the use of \nagricultural waste-such as sunflower straw-to fabricate biodegradable nursery \ncontainers represents an environmentally friendly alternative technology. This \napproach may exert specific potential effects on the structure and function of \nmicrobial communities in the tobacco rhizosphere. In this study, Yunyan-301 was \nused as the test material, and field experiments were carried out at two test \nsites (BT and HCZ). Each site included two treatments: conventional seedling \ncultivation (CK) and sunflower straw-based natural bowl seedling cultivation \n(T). While tobacco was harvested, a rhizosphere soil sample of tobacco was \ncollected for microbial analysis. The results showed that sunflower straw-based \nnatural bowl seedling cultivation led to a less diverse but functionally \nspecialized microbial community. The specific alterations in the abundance of \ncore taxa (e.g., Proteobacteria, Acidobacteria, Sphingomonas, Pseudoduganella, \nLuteitalea) suggest a potential ecological advantage, where the enriched \ncommunity may be more efficient in utilizing sunflower straw-derived compounds \nand providing host-beneficial functions. Predictions of microbial community \nfunctions revealed that sunflower straw-based natural bowl seedling cultivation \nsignificantly enhanced the capacity of carbon fixation and oxidative \nphosphorylation, effectively improving the metabolic activity and carbon cycling \nability of tobacco rhizosphere microbes. In summary, sunflower straw-based \nnatural bowl seedling cultivation effectively alter the microenvironment of \ntobacco rhizosphere soil, thereby enriching functional microbial taxa and \nrelated metabolic pathways that were beneficial to soil health and tobacco \ngrowth. However, its effect was modulated by the environmental background of the \ntest sites. In future research and actual production, further optimization of \nthe sunflower straw-based natural bowl seedling cultivation should be conducted, \nand attempts should be made to assist in green and sustainable tobacco \ncultivation from the perspective of microbial community management.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Shi, Ge, Hou, Han, Xu, Jiang and Ma.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2025.1661023\nPMCID: PMC12546116\nPMID: 41140400\n\nConflict of interest statement: XM was employed by China National Tobacco \nCorporation Liaoning Provincial Company. The mechanisms underlying this phenomenon, termed central \ntrained immunity, remain poorly understood. We hypothesized that infection \ninduces histone modifications leading to changes in chromatin accessibility that \nare conserved during differentiation from HSPCs to myeloid progenitors and \nmonocytes. We conducted genome-wide surveillance of histone marks H3K27ac and \nH3K4me3 and chromatin accessibility in hematopoietic stem cells, multipotent \nprogenitor 3, granulocyte-monocyte progenitors, monocytes and macrophages of \nnaïve and Mycobacterium avium infected mice. However, histone marks and increased chromatin accessibility were \nconserved at only a few loci, notably Irf1 and Gbp6. Knock out of IRF1 disrupted \nenhanced mitochondrial respiration and bacterial killing in human monocyte cell \nlines, while GBP6 KO monocyte cell lines showed dysregulated mitochondrial \nrespiration. In summary, this study identifies IRF1 and GBP6 as two key loci at \nwhich infection-induced systemic inflammation leads to epigenetic changes that \nare conserved from HSPCs to downstream monocytes, providing a mechanistic avenue \nfor central trained immunity.\n\nDOI: 10.1172/jci.insight.193686\nPMID: 41364527"},

Several scientific studies have reported a high incidence of \nresistance among MDR-TB patients who had prior exposure to bedaquiline for \ntreating Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections. Disparate research findings \nindicate that individuals previously administered this drug exhibit a remarkable \nprevalence of resistance. Studies have further demonstrated that prior treatment \noften correlates with the emergence of resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis \nstrains. Overall, evidence from multiple investigations highlights a concerning \ntrend of increased resistance in MDR-TB cases with a history of bedaquiline \ntherapy. Moreover, bedaquiline resistance in MDR-TB strains has been linked to \nmutations in several chromosomal genes, including atpE, Rv0677c, Rv0678, and \npepQ. Consequently, it is imperative to mitigate the burden of MDR-TB and \nbedaquiline resistance. Herein, this article emphasizes structural features, \nmechanism of action, emergence of underlying resistance mechanisms, \npharmacokinetic & pharmacodynamic properties, clinical toxicity, and strategies \nto combat resistance associated with bedaquiline.\n\n© 2025. TB-induced chronic inflammation, oxidative \nstress, epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), and immune checkpoint \ndysregulation create a permissive environment for oncogenesis. This review integrates \ncurrent evidence on the overlapping pathogenic, immunological and molecular \nlandscapes of TB and lung cancer to identify shared mechanisms, diagnostic \ndilemmas and therapeutic challenges, while highlighting significant gaps needing \nactionable interventions. We also suggest some future paradigm shifts toward \ndual-disease research frameworks, critical to advance care in TB-endemic \nregions.\n\n© 2025. Online ahead of print.\n\nAssociation of HLA class I allele and tuberculosis susceptibility: a systematic \nreview and meta-analysis.\n\nKumari N(1)(2), Kumar R(3)(4), Patro IK(5), Das A(6)(7).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)ICMR-National Institute of Research in Tribal Health, Jabalpur, India.\n(2)School of Studies in Biotechnology, Jiwaji University, Gwalior, India.\n(3)ICMR-National Institute of Research in Tribal Health, Jabalpur, India. \nRavindra.kum@icmr.gov.in.\n(4)Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research, Ghaziabad, India. \nRavindra.kum@icmr.gov.in.\n(5)School of Studies in Zoology, Jiwaji University, Gwalior, India.\n(6)Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research, Ghaziabad, India.\n(7)ICMR-Regional Medical Research Center, Sri Vijay Puram, India.\n\nMycobacterium tuberculosis\xa0(M.tuberculosis) continues to cause one of the most \npressing health burdens in the world, especially in developing nations, in the \nform of tuberculosis (TB). In addition to socio-environmental factors, it is \nwidely believed that host genetic factors, particularly polymorphisms within the \nhuman leukocyte antigen (HLA) system, may play an extensive role in the \nlikelihood of a host's TB infection. Studies on the influence of HLA class I \nalleles (HLA-A, -B, -C) in human susceptibility to TB reported contradictory \nresults. Therefore, this systematic review and meta-analysis aim to see the \nassociation of HLA class I alleles with susceptibility to TB in humans. In this \nmeta-analysis, the literature was searched using PubMed, ScienceDirect, and \nGoogle Scholar, until 23rd May 2025. A total of 13 eligible case-control studies \nwere included, comprising 1951\xa0TB cases and 2109 matched healthy controls. \nTogether with a 95% Confidence interval, pooled odds ratio was calculated for \neach allele. To evaluate heterogeneity I2 statistic was used. Sensitivity and \nsubgroup analyses were also performed. Publication bias was investigated using \nEgger's and Begg's tests. The analysis results demonstrated 40 HLA class I \nalleles (12-A, 22-B, 6-C). HLA-A32 (OR\u2009=\u20091.67, 95% CI= 1.09-2.56, p\u2009=\u20090.0191) \nand B58 (OR\u2009=\u20091.45, 95% CI= 1.02-2.07, p\u2009=\u20090.0404) found to be associated with \nincreased TB risk, while HLA-A1 (OR\u2009=\u20090.70, 95% CI= 0.57-0.85; p\u2009=\u20090.0007) \nshowed a protective trend after analysis. Sensitivity analysis strengthened the \nsignificance of all different alleles. Regional variations emerged: B58 was a \nrisk allele in Africa, and A32 was a risk allele in Asia. HLA-B15 and B35 were \nreported to have a statistically significantly increased risk in North America. \nPost-sensitivity analysis revealed possible publication bias, as HLA-B17 shifted \nfrom susceptibility to a protective effect. This is the first meta-analysis that \nsystematically evaluates the associations between HLA class I alleles and TB \nsusceptibility. Our findings determine selective associations at both the allele \nand regional levels. The findings of this study can inform future studies in \nimmunogenetics and aid in formulating solutions for the prevention and treatment \nof TB that are tailored to individual alleles.\n\n© 2025. The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1038/s41598-025-31012-2\nPMID: 41361354\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declarations. Competing interests: The authors \ndeclare no competing interests."},

What makes these infections \nunique is that they are environmentally acquired, yet there remains a limited \nunderstanding of how different environments contribute to potential pathogen \nexposure. Here, we use new and existing marker gene data sets to compare the \namounts and types of NTM across three environments known to harbor mycobacteria, \nsurface waters, soil, and household plumbing biofilms, to better understand \npotential pathogen occurrence in each environment. We used 16S rRNA gene \nsequencing, in tandem with mycobacterial-specific marker gene sequencing, to \ncharacterize variation in the relative abundances of the genus Mycobacterium and \nspecific mycobacterial taxa across the three environments, with a focus on a \nclinically significant NTM. We found that household plumbing biofilms contained \nboth the highest relative abundance of the genus Mycobacterium (on average, \n13.7% of bacteria were members of the genus), as well as the highest occurrence \nof clinically relevant species detected (Mycobacterium avium and Mycobacterium \nabscessus), compared to surface waters and soil. Although mycobacteria are \nubiquitous across many different environments, mycobacterial diversity is highly \nvariable between environments with clinically relevant species largely \nrestricted to household plumbing biofilms, information that is critical for \nunderstanding the ecology and epidemiology of NTM \ndisease.IMPORTANCENontuberculous mycobacteria, or NTM, are a diverse group of \nbacteria within the genus Mycobacterium that are common in many environments. \nWhile most members of the genus pose little threat to human health, a handful of \nspecies, namely the Mycobacterium avium complex, M. abscessus, and M. kansasii, \ncan cause severe and prolonged lung infections. These environmentally acquired \ninfections are on the rise in the United States and around the world, yet we \nstill do not have a good understanding of which environment types pose the \ngreatest risk of infection to susceptible populations. Our study used \ncultivation-independent approaches to identify the specific NTM taxa found in \nover 1,000 samples from three potentially important environmental \nreservoirs-surface waters, soils, and household plumbing systems, to determine \nwhich of these environments are most likely to harbor NTM of clinical \nsignificance. Our results highlight the high degree of variability in the types \nof NTM taxa detected in different environments (including extensive novel \ndiversity within the genus) and show that household plumbing biofilms are likely \nthe most important reservoir and subsequent route of transmission for clinically \nsignificant NTM.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/aem.01552-25\nPMID: 41358737'}],

Although Cm and amikacin (Am) are \nhistorically grouped as second-line injectable drugs (SLIDs) with shared \nresistance mechanisms (e.g., rrs mutations), recent clinical and genetic data \nsuggests divergent evolutionary pathways. It remains unclear how Mtb evolves \nfrom sensitive to resistant phenotypes under Cm pressure. In this study, we \ngenerate in vitro drug-resistant Mtb models to systematically study the \nevolutionary mechanisms of Cm and Am cross-resistance. By integrating \ntranscriptome/proteome/metabolome analyses, we identify both genetic mutations \nand non-genetic factors contributing to Cm resistance. We show that Cm- and \nAm-selective pressures trigger independent cross-resistance mechanisms revealed \nby distinct genetic mutations. Gly232AsptlyA and Trp120fstlyA mutations are \ndirectly associated with low level resistance to Cm, whereas Ala48ValmmaA2, \nGln19ArgrpmA and variant at the promoter of eis (which encodes an \nN-acetyltransferase; c.-14c>t) mediate cross-resistance pathways specific to Cm \nselection. In addition, dysregulations of non-genetic factors including metal \nions transportations and lipids metabolism also lead to drug-resistance. In \nsummary, our findings systematically characterize the molecular mechanisms of Cm \nresistance, demonstrating that the "genetic factors" (DNA mutations) are often \nthe drivers that induce the stable "non-genetic factors" (dysregulated pathways, \nsuch as eis overexpression, metal ion transport, and metabolic reprogramming), \nwhich ultimately mediate the resistance phenotype. These insights uncover the \nevolutionary trajectory of Cm and Am cross-resistance and provide potential \nstrategies for optimizing Cm use to treat MDR-TB.\nIMPORTANCE: Tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, is responsible \nfor the highest mortality rate worldwide among single pathogen infections. The \ndiagnosis and treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis pose a global challenge. \nCapreomycin (Cm) is one of the drugs utilized in the management of \nmultidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) and extensively drug-resistant \ntuberculosis (XDR-TB). Currently, the clinical detection of mutations in rrs \ngene is employed to identify Cm resistance. However, the sensitivity and \nspecificity of this method are suboptimal. To further investigate the mechanisms \nunderlying Cm resistance, this study established a microevolution model in \nvitro, thereby simulating the progression of MTB from susceptible strains to \ndrug-resistant strains. The genomes of each generation were sequenced throughout \nthe evolutionary process. In addition, the transcriptome-proteome-lipid \nmetabolome analysis of representative strains were performed. Our findings \nreveal that Cm resistance is a combinatory effect of both genetic and \nnon-genetic changes, providing potential optimization strategies to the \nmolecular drug sensitivity testing used in clinical practice.\n\n© 2025 The Authors. Patients with \ncytopenia, GM-CSF antibody-negative PAP accompanied by NTM infection should be \nconsidered to have the possibility of this disease. Epub 2025 Mar 1.\n\nDirect targeted next-generation sequencing for diagnosis of drug-resistant \ntuberculosis from clinical samples - An update.\n\nGopalaswamy R(1), Subramanian B(2), Parthasarathy M(3), Padmapriyadarsini C(4), \nShanmugam S(5).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)ICMR- National Institute for Research in Tuberculosis, Chennai, India. \nElectronic address: radhagopalaswamy@gmail.com.\n(2)SRM Institute of Science and Technology, India.\n(3)Vellore Institute of Technology, India.\n(4)ICMR- National Institute for Research in Tuberculosis, Chennai, India.\n(5)ICMR- National Institute for Research in Tuberculosis, Chennai, India. \nElectronic address: shanmugam.sk@icmr.gov.in.\n\nTimely detection of drug resistance is a pre-requisite to tuberculosis \nmanagement globally. While phenotypic drug susceptibility testing (pDST) by \nliquid or solid method takes time, current genotypic DST assays can be performed \ndirectly from clinical specimens but target only a limited number of resistance \nvariants. Targeted Next Generation Sequencing (tNGS) is a rapid, cost-effective \nmethod using direct sample to perform the sequencing than compared to whole \ngenome sequencing (WGS) which requires culture. tNGS provides comprehensive drug \nresistance profiling with turnaround time of 3-4 days when done directly from \nclinical samples. For respiratory samples with rifampicin resistance, tNGS could \nbe used for the rapid detection of additional drug resistance including newer \nand repurposed drugs like Bedaquiline, Delamanid, Pretomanid, Linezolid and \nClofazimine for which no rapid molecular tests are currently available. A \nvariety of clinical samples can be used and there are wide choices available for \nDNA extraction. The targets for tNGS could be amplified using commercial kits or \nin house primers. tNGS could be performed using different platforms like \nIllumina, Oxford Nanopore Technology and/or Ion torrent and diverse \nbio-informatic pipeline options. Positioning of a tNGS with portability system \nin the current TB diagnostic algorithm and its use in the clinical management of \npatients' needs further evaluation and efforts.\n\nCopyright © 2025. Finally, in planta assays \nrevealed that both RBX7 CFS and the live culture effectively suppressed BLB \nsymptoms in rice seedlings. This study highlights a safer and more sustainable \napproach for controlling BLB in rice by utilizing RBX7 as a biocontrol agent, \nadvancing efforts toward achieving sustainable development goals in rice \nfarming.\n\n© 2025. This is of particular importance when \ndealing with disease resistance in a fruit tree like pomegranate, as determined \nafter years of research efforts. World J Microbiol Biotechnol. 2025 Dec 2;41(12):487. doi: \n10.1007/s11274-025-04623-0.\n\nHarnessing microbial consortia to induce systemic resistance and modulate gene \nexpression in cluster bean under bacterial blight (Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. \ncyamopsidis) stress.\n\nSingh D(1), Mahla HR(2), Kakani RK(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Division of Plant Improvement and Pest Management, ICAR-Central Arid Zone \nResearch Institute, Rajasthan, Jodhpur, 342003, India. devendraiari@gmail.com.\n(2)Division of Plant Improvement and Pest Management, ICAR-Central Arid Zone \nResearch Institute, Rajasthan, Jodhpur, 342003, India.\n\nBacterial leaf blight (BLB) caused by Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. cyamopsidis \n(Xac), is a major constraint to cluster bean production, particularly under hot \narid climatic conditions. This study aimed to develop effective microbial \nconsortia for sustainable management of BLB. A total of 283 fungal and 480 \nbacterial isolates were screened in vitro for antagonistic activity against the \npathogen. Four potent antagonists-Trichoderma afroharzianum (9\xa0F), \nAneurinibacillus aneurinilyticus (14B), Bacillus subtilis (26B) and Pseudomonas \nlalkuanensis (31B) were selected and showed good mutual compatibility. A pot \nexperiment with 17 treatments was conducted to assess their individual and \ncombined effects on disease suppression and plant growth promotion. Results \nrevealed that four-microbe consortium (9\xa0F\u2009+\u200914B\u2009+\u200926B\u2009+\u200931B) significantly \nreduced disease severity, lowering the PDI to 11.90% with 87.80% control \ncompared to the infected control. This treatment also significantly improved \nplant growth, biomass, number of pods per plant and yield over the infected \ncontrol. Field validation confirmed the efficacy of the consortium, showing a \nPDI reduction to 50.67% (48.88% disease control over infected control). This \ntreatment resulted in a 44.90% increase in plant height, 73.30% increase in \nfresh weight, 86.70% increase in dry weight, 200.00% increase in the number of \npods per plant and 149.60% increase in yield. The treatment also reduced \naccumulation of reactive oxygen species and enhanced the expression of \nantioxidant enzyme synthesizing genes-pod (3.49-fold), sod (3.63-fold), cat \n(3.68-fold) and plant defensin gene-pdf1.2 (2.60-fold) over the mock control in \nreal time PCR analysis. Thus, formulated microbial consortium offers a promising \neco-friendly strategy for managing BLB in cluster bean.\n\n© 2025. This study reports and characterizes the first copper-resistant strain \nof XAP (XAPCuR), which was isolated from diseased leaves of Prunus laurocerasus \nin North Carolina in 2017. Whole genome sequence analysis of XAPCuR revealed a \n~247 kb plasmid carrying a duplicated 17 kb cluster containing copper resistance \ncandidate genes copL, copA, copB, copC, copD, copM, copG, copF, cusA and cusB. \nThe two copies of the copper resistance cluster did not increase the level of \ncopper resistance compared to a single copy, but deletion of both copies led to \nthe loss of resistance. Functional analysis of the cluster revealed that copL-D \nis the major contributor to copper resistance, allowing XAP to grow on nutrient \nagar containing up to 750 µg/ml of CSP. Removing copL from copL-D decreased the \nresistance level to 300 µg/ml of CSP. The copF and cusAB genes alone did not \nconfer copper resistance, however, adding copF-cusB to copL-D increased the \nresistance level of XAP to 1000 µg/ml of CSP. Sci Rep. 2025 Dec 5;15(1):43293. doi: 10.1038/s41598-025-97020-4.\n\nLactococcus lactis subsp. lactis as a biocontrol agent against phytopathogens \ncausing rice bacterial leaf blight.\n\nBasri NNNM(1), Malek AZA(1), Hashim AM(2), Yuswan MH(3), Saidi NB(4), Zulperi \nD(5), Kamil WNIWA(1), Shariff FM(1), Mokhtar NFK(6), Bakar MFA(7).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Microbiology, Faculty of Biotechnology and Biomolecular \nSciences, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia.\n(2)Department of Microbiology, Faculty of Biotechnology and Biomolecular \nSciences, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia. \namalia@upm.edu.my.\n(3)Halal Products Research Institute (HPRI), Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, \nSelangor, Malaysia.\n(4)Department of Cell and Molecular Biology, Faculty of Biotechnology and \nBiomolecular Sciences, Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia.\n(5)Department of Plant Protection, Faculty of Agriculture, Universiti Putra \nMalaysia, Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia.\n(6)Putra Science Park (PSP), Universiti Putra Malaysia, Serdang, Selangor, \nMalaysia.\n(7)Malaysia Genome and Vaccine Institute (MGVI), National Institute of \nBiotechnology Malaysia (NIBM), Jalan Bangi, Kajang, Selangor, Malaysia.\n\nBacterial leaf blight (BLB) disease in rice caused by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. \noryzae (Xoo) and Pantoea ananatis (Pan), is a widespread problem that results in \nsubstantial economic losses in rice-growing countries, including Malaysia. \nFarmers commonly rely on chemical controls to treat this disease, which are not \nsafe for human health and the environment. Alternatively, Lactic acid bacteria \n(LAB) have gained attention for their potential in sustainable agricultural \npractices, benefitting human health and the environment. This study hypothesized \nthat LAB, specifically Lactococcus lactis subsp. lactis (RBX7), have \nantimicrobial activity against phytopathogens, namely Xoo and Pan. The research \naims to determine the antimicrobial activity of RBX7 and identify the \nantimicrobial compounds likely responsible for disease suppression. The \nantimicrobial cell-free supernatant (CFS) of RBX7 was obtained and tested for \nantimicrobial activity against Xoo and Pan using multiple methods, i.e. agar \nwell diffusion, time-kill assays, detached leaf assays, and visualized using \nscanning electron microscopy (SEM). Metabolomic profiling was conducted to \nidentify potential antimicrobial metabolites using LC-MS/MS-QTOF. Finally, the \nantibacterial effects of LAB were confirmed by in planta experiment. The \ndetached leaf assay showed no lesions following inoculation with RBX7 live \nculture and RBX7 CFS, in line with the results from agar well diffusion assays. \nSEM analysis showed Pan cell rupture and Xoo cell shrinkage when treated with \nRBX7. Metabolomic analysis of RBX7 identified antimicrobial compounds such as \ncefixime, cinchonidine, antimycin A, and bufalin. Finally, in planta assays \nrevealed that both RBX7 CFS and the live culture effectively suppressed BLB \nsymptoms in rice seedlings. This study highlights a safer and more sustainable \napproach for controlling BLB in rice by utilizing RBX7 as a biocontrol agent, \nadvancing efforts toward achieving sustainable development goals in rice \nfarming.\n\n© 2025. Curr Protoc. 2025 Dec;5(12):e70269. doi: 10.1002/cpz1.70269.\n\nEfficient and Rapid Bioassay for Xanthomonas citri pv. punicae Blight on \nPomegranate.\n\nAgarrwal R(1)(2), Sowjanya PR(1)(2), Mandave AA(1), Manjunatha N(1), Mandal \nS(3), Babu KD(1), Marathe RA(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)ICAR-National Research Centre on Pomegranate, Solapur, Maharashtra, India.\n(2)These authors contributed equally to this work.\n(3)Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India.\n\nIt is crucial that experiments dealing with plant-pathogen interactions are \nrobust and reproducible. For evaluating the disease-resistance ability of a host \nplant against any pathogen, controlled conditions are a prerequisite that cannot \nbe obtained with soil-based systems. Variation in environmental conditions \nduring challenge inoculation of a pathogen, when performed in fields or a \npolyhouse, may lead to spurious results. This is of particular importance when \ndealing with disease resistance in a fruit tree like pomegranate, as determined \nafter years of research efforts. Due to lack of uniformity and environment \nvariability, the possibility of pathogen escapes and false positives is large \nunder field or polyhouse conditions. To address these limitations, we have used \ntissue-cultured plants and developed an easy, reliable, rapid, and efficient in \nvitro bioassay for bacterial blight on pomegranate. Owing to its performance \nunder a closed system, this system minimizes the risk of pathogen escapes, \nreduces environmental variability, and provides a robust high-throughput \nscreening platform for disease resistance and tissue sampling for downstream \nfunctional genomics studies. The protocols enable reproducible experiments to \nstudy plant response to bacterial blight infection. Stepwise protocols and \ndetailed instructions are provided to carry out the screening experiment in \npomegranate or other similar plant species. © 2025 Wiley Periodicals LLC. Basic \nProtocol 1: Preparation of nodal explants and in vitro rooting Basic Protocol 2: \nIn vitro blight bioassay Basic Protocol 3: Pathogen re-isolation and \nconfirmation.\n\n© 2025 Wiley Periodicals LLC.\n\nDOI: 10.1002/cpz1.70269\nPMID: 41342473 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'}],

Int J Microbiol. 2025 Nov 25;2025:6958575. doi: 10.1155/ijm/6958575.\neCollection  2025.\n\nMolecular Identification of Human and Plant Pathogens in Municipal Domestic \nWastewater for Hydroponic System Applications.\n\nKriem LS(1), King N(1), Niemann S(1), Vainshtein Y(2), Sonntag M(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department for Water Technologies, Resource Recovery and Scale-Up, \nFraunhofer-Institut für Grenzflächen- und Bioverfahrenstechnik IGB, Stuttgart, \nBaden-Württemberg, Germany.\n(2)Department for In-Vitro Diagnostics, Fraunhofer-Institut für Grenzflächen- \nund Bioverfahrenstechnik IGB, Stuttgart, Baden-Württemberg, Germany.\n\nWater is essential for human survival and socioeconomic development, yet its \noverconsumption threatens global food security and ecosystem integrity. This \nnecessitates a 60% increase in food production, further straining water \nresources. Hydroponic systems represent a promising solution, utilizing up to \n90% less water than traditional methods while providing optimal growing \nconditions for crops. Future research should focus on enhancing detection methods and \noptimizing DNA extraction techniques to improve pathogen quantification and \nmanagement in hydroponic systems. This approach is crucial for sustainable \nagricultural practices that minimize water usage while ensuring food safety and \nenvironmental health.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Lukas Simon Kriem et al. Emerg Microbes Infect. 2025 Dec 9:2602311. doi: 10.1080/22221751.2025.2602311.\n Online ahead of print.\n\nCross-Cell Line Transcriptome Profiling Reveals Host-Virus Interactions in \nMonkeypox Virus Infection.\n\nYi H(1), Yang S(1), Deng J(1), Liu X(1), Zhang X(1), Xie X(2)(3)(4), Li J(5), \nWang J(6), Wei L(6), Zheng Z(5), Zhang M(1), Fang L(2)(3)(4), Lu H(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Institute for Hepatology, National Clinical Research Centre for Infectious \nDiseases, The Third People's Hospital of Shenzhen and The Second Affiliated \nHospital of Southern University of Science and Technology, Shenzhen 518112, \nChina.\n(2)Department of Systems Biology, School of Life Science, Southern University of \nScience and Technology, Shenzhen 518005, China.\n(3)Guangming Advanced Research Institute, Southern University of Science and \nTechnology, Shenzhen 518055, China.\n(4)Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Gene Regulation and Systems Biology, School of \nLife Sciences, Southern University of Science and Technology, Shenzhen 518055, \nChina.\n(5)Department of Cardiology, National Clinical Research Centre for Infectious \nDiseases, The Third People's Hospital of Shenzhen and The Second Affiliated \nHospital of Southern University of Science and Technology, Shenzhen 518112, \nChina.\n(6)Department of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, Linyi People's \nHospital, Linyi, Shandong 276003, China.\n\nThe monkeypox virus (MPXV), a re-emerging Orthopoxvirus, has triggered \nunprecedented global outbreaks, with over 130,000 confirmed cases reported by \nJanuary 2025. Despite its escalating public health threat, the molecular \nmechanisms governing MPXV-host interactions remain inadequately characterized. \nIn this study, we systematically explored the impact of MPXV Clade IIb infection \non the host transcriptome across diverse cell lines, unveiling both conserved \nand cell-type-specific transcriptomic changes. Our analysis revealed significant \ndisruptions in pathways associated with immune response, cell cycle regulation, \nmetabolism, protein synthesis, and epigenetic modification. Additionally, we \nevaluated two widely used mRNA sequencing methodologies for MPXV transcriptome \nprofiling, demonstrating that ribosomal RNA depletion offers a more \ncomprehensive representation of viral mRNA compared to poly(A) tail enrichment. \nThrough cross-cell-line comparisons and temporal transcriptomic analysis in A549 \ncells, we identified stage-specific regulation of MPXV gene expression. \nLeveraging the temporal host transcriptome profiles, we predicted and validated \npotential therapeutic targets, demonstrating that inhibitors targeting the mTOR \npathway and growth factor receptors effectively inhibit MPXV infection. \nCollectively, these findings provide critical insights into the intricate \ninterplay between MPXV and its host, offering a foundation for developing \nantiviral strategies and advancing our understanding of mpox pathogenesis.\n\nDOI: 10.1080/22221751.2025.2602311\nPMID: 41362268"},

Sex Transm Dis. 2026 Jan 1;53(1):59-66. doi: 10.1097/OLQ.0000000000002237.\nEpub  2025 Sep 9.\n\nMyocarditis and Pericarditis as a Complication of Mpox: Case Series and \nLiterature Review.\n\nHalani S, Cai S, Zanoria C(1), Monge JC, Mishra S, Brouillard P, Tremblay C, \nPinho AI(2), Rodriguez-Nava G(3), Cooper JD, Narasimhan S, Kadlecik P(4), Khera \nSS, Tan DHS.\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Division of Infectious Diseases, Unity Health Toronto.\n(2)Department of Cardiology, São João University Hospital Centre, Porto, \nPortugal.\n(3)Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford.\n(4)Mid-Atlantic Permanente Medical Group, Rockville, MD.\n\nMonkeypox virus is a DNA virus in the orthopoxvirus family, and a multicountry \noutbreak was declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern both in \n2022 and 2024. Myocarditis is a known complication of many viral infections, and \nchest pain and electrocardiogram changes may occur from 1 to 4 weeks \npost-infection. We present 2 clinical cases of mpox-related myocarditis from \nCanada. We identified 19 additional cases of myocarditis and/or pericarditis in \nthe literature, and data were synthesized with our 2 cases. All 20 patients with \navailable data were hospitalized, 6 of whom were admitted to an intensive care \nunit. Median time of cardiac symptom onset after initial mpox symptom onset was \n5 (range, 0-14) days, elevated troponin was present in 19 of 19 cases (range, \n165-21,200 ng/L), arrhythmias were described in 1 patient with Mobitz type 1 and \n2 atrioventricular blocks, and echocardiograms showed reduced ejection fraction \nin 4 of 15 patients. There were no deaths reported. Management of mpox involves \nsymptom control and anti-inflammatories. Recent trials have not shown benefit of \ntecovirimat compared with placebo in shortening time to lesion resolution; \nhowever, in this article, we discuss nuances regarding antivirals in the setting \nof mpox-related myocarditis.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Author(s). SternD@rki.de.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nThe 2022 global mpox outbreak highlighted the risk of zoonotic diseases \nestablishing sustained transmission in human populations and underscored the \nneed for accurate serological tools to monitor orthopoxvirus exposure. However, \ncross-reactive antibodies induced by Modified Vaccinia Ankara (MVA) vaccination \nmake it difficult to discriminate between monkeypox virus (MPXV) infection and \nvaccination-induced immunity. Here we present a machine learning (ML)-assisted \nbead-based serological multiplex assay that distinguishes MPXV infection from \nMVA vaccination and pre-immune sera by targeting antibody responses to 15 \npoxviral antigens. Of the six algorithms tested, the Gradient Boosting \nClassifier (GBC) achieves the highest performance (F1\u2009=\u20090.83) in sera from the \n2022 outbreak and from a follow-up epidemiological cohort of at-risk men who \nhave sex with men (MSM; n\u2009=\u20091,260). In an independent validation cohort \n(n\u2009=\u2009143), GBC (F1\u2009=\u20090.70) robustly detects MPXV infections, including \nbreakthrough cases, with 88% specificity and 92% sensitivity. Integrating ML \nwith high-dimensional serology enables accurate cross-sectional classification \nof orthopoxvirus immune status and provides a scalable framework for mpox \nserosurveillance and outbreak preparedness.\n\n© 2025. Here, we comprehensively \ncharacterize MPXV-specific antibody and T cell responses up to 18 months after \nnatural infection in male individuals. Neutralizing antibodies exhibit typical \nacute viral kinetics, with titers peaking early and declining over time, from a \nmean of 328 at 12 months to 180 at 18 months post-infection. Electronic address: weijiangbo@sinopharm.com.\n\nThe plaque purification is a critical step in the screening of traditional \nlive-attenuated vaccines and recombinant viral vaccines, aiming to acquire \nvaccine clones with homogeneous characteristics and desirable immunogenicity to \naddress outbreaks of emerging diseases such as monkeypox, chikungunya fever, and \ndengue fever. The traditional plaque purification process to screen out a \nvaccine strain with genetically consistent stability from a mixed pool of viral \nclones generally requires laborsome work. We utilized live-cell imaging \ntechnique enabling us to isolate monoclonal vaccine strains to simplify and \nimprove the efficiency of this process. Here, we genetically engineered the \nvaccinia virus TianTan (VTT) using CRISPR/Cas9 system to generate recombinant \nVTT viruses (VTT-WS01-EGFP) that expressed enhanced green fluorescent protein \n(EGFP). Initially, we performed 9 rounds of plaque purification using \ntraditional plaque assay, yielding 50 candidate clones. The Incucyte Live-Cell \nImaging and Analysis system was subsequently performed to conduct a rigorous, \nhigh-resolution screening of these candidates in a more automated, sensitive and \nhigh-throughput way. Through this screening process, we ultimately obtained 31 \npure viral clones that were free of parental strain contamination, followed by \nthe analysis of plaque formation, fluorescent plaque size, and plaque \nmorphology, and 11 candidate clones were selected for immunological evaluation. \nFurthermore, we found that clone 49 induced a relatively high titer of anti-VTT \nneutralizing antibodies and elicited the production of cross-reactive IgG \nagainst monkeypox virus antigens, thereby validating its potential as a \ncandidate strain as a monkeypox virus vaccine. Taken together, our data \ndemonstrates that live-cell imaging technique significantly accelerates the \nscreening process for the isolation of monoclonal viral clones as recombinant \nviral vaccines, and holds considerable potential in attenuated strain selection \nas well as investigations into biological characteristics of viruses, including \nviral replication.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Authors. Current diagnostics, \nrelying on centralized laboratory testing, require specialized personnel and \nequipment. We aimed to develop a point-of-care testing (POCT) kit that \nsimplifies nucleic acid extraction, minimizes contamination, and enables \nimmediate, accurate MPXV detection.\nMETHODS: We introduced a novel MPXV POCT kit, featuring a separate MPXV DNA \nrapid release step and a closed integrated device combining recombinase \npolymerase amplification (RPA) and lateral flow assay (LFA). A fluorescent RPA \nassay identified F3L-targeting primers and probes with superior amplification \nefficiency. The RPA system was coupled with LFA to assess the visual diagnostic \nperformance, and then integrated into a POCT device, complemented by a nucleic \nacid release agent to form the kit. The kit's specificity, sensitivity, and \ndiagnostic performance were validated through clinical body fluid samples.\nRESULTS: Our nucleic acid release agent streamlines sample processing without \ncompromising detection accuracy, eliminating the need for traditional nucleic \nacid extraction. The RPA reaction system was formulated into freeze-dried \nmicrospheres and integrated directly into the reaction chamber of the POCT \ndevice, ensuring the stability and shelf-life of the reagents and simplifying \nthe preparation and configuration process. The POCT device's enclosed design \neradicates transfer steps, significantly reducing RPA-induced aerosol \ncontamination. Results can be visually interpreted within 25\xa0min, a substantial \nimprovement over existing methods. In clinical sample validation, the POCT kit \nshowed high specificity and sensitivity, distinguishing other pathogens, with \n100% consistency with RT-qPCR results in detecting mpox patient samples. \nCompared to RT-qPCR and ddPCR, our POCT kit demonstrates stronger diagnostic \nperformance, with the lowest positive concentration we detected being 41 \ncopies/mL (2.1 copies/reaction) in clinical samples and 2.5 copies/μL (2.5 \ncopies/reaction) of DNA plasmid standards, significantly increasing the \ndetection rate of mpox.\nCONCLUSIONS: This compact, portable POCT kit, requiring no professional \noperation or precision instruments, offers a promising solution for on-site and \nhome self-testing. Its high sensitivity and specificity, coupled with the \ncapacity to swiftly adapt to new MPXV strains, positions it as an effective tool \nfor early detection, vital for controlling mpox outbreaks.\n\n© 2025. Virol J. 2025 Nov 14;22(1):377. doi: 10.1186/s12985-025-02982-6.\n\nImmunoinformatics-based strategies for developing DNA and mRNA vaccines against \nmonkeypox virus (MPXV).\n\nKhan S(1)(2), Ikram Ullah(1), Rizwan M(3), Zhang Y(1), Zeb A(4), Ubaidullah(5), \nHamza A(6), Zhang S(2), Lu X(7)(8), Feng X(9).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)School of Life Sciences, Northeast Normal University, Changchun, Jilin, \n130024, China.\n(2)School of Life Sciences, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, 450001, Henan, \nChina.\n(3)Centre for Biotechnology and Microbiology, University of Swat, Swat, Khyber \nPakhtunkhwa, Pakistan.\n(4)Department of Biotechnology, Quaid-I-Azam University, Islamabad, 45320, \nPakistan.\n(5)Postgraduate Program in Agronomy (PPGA), State University of Ponta Grossa, \nPonta Grossa, Parana, 84.030-900, Brazil.\n(6)College of Biology and the Environment, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, \n210037, China.\n(7)Precision Medicine Center, Jilin Province General Hospital, Changchun, \n130021, China.\n(8)School of Life Sciences, Changchun Normal University, Changchun, 130011, \nJilin, China.\n(9)School of Life Sciences, Northeast Normal University, Changchun, Jilin, \n130024, China. fengxc997@nenu.edu.cn.\n\nThe monkeypox virus (MPXV) is a newly discovered zoonotic orthopoxvirus that can \ninfect humans and shares similarities with the smallpox virus. With no \nclinically validated treatment for MPXV infections, it is important to develop a \nbroad-range vaccine that is effective against this disease. This study aimed to \ndesign novel multiple-epitope DNA and mRNA vaccines against MXPV using \ncomprehensive immunoinformatics and reverse vaccinology techniques. Eleven MPXV \nproteins were selected from the UniProt database and assessed for their \nantigenicity and allergenicity. Proteins exhibiting significant antigenicity and \nnon-allergenic characteristics were examined for the prediction of T-cell and \nB-cell epitopes. Four MHC-I, eight MHC-II, and six B-cell epitopes were coupled \nwith specific linkers and adjuvant peptide sequences to boost the immunological \nresponse to the developed vaccine. The designed vaccines showed antigenic nature \nwith a 0.5936 score and solubility nature with a 0.513 score, and its GRAVY \nscore of 0.147 indicates their hydrophilic nature. Structural validation \nconfirmed the superior tertiary structure of the designed vaccines. Molecular \ndocking studies demonstrated a robust interaction between human TLR-8 and the \ndeveloped vaccines, with a docking score of -1208.2\xa0kcal/mol, and Moleculae \nDynamics (MD) simulations confirmed its stability. The immune simulation results \nindicated that vaccination strongly stimulated immunity, resulting in high \nconcentrations of IgG and IgM antibodies. Cloning analysis and in silico \nrestriction prediction demonstrated the viability of integrating the developed \nvaccine into an Escherichia coli (E. coli) expression system. Furthermore, an \nmRNA vaccine was developed by incorporating a 5' cap, 5' untranslated region \n(UTR), Kozak sequence, and tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) with the CD40 \nligand (CD40L) linked to the selected epitopes using EAAAK linkers. A poly (A) \ntail, MITD1, and 3' UTR were appended to the 3' end of the construct. The mRNA \nvaccine design incorporated codon optimization, resulting in a CAI score 0.83 \nand GC content of 60.46%, indicating efficient vaccine expression within host \ncells. Analysis of several parameters revealed that the architecture of the \nsynthesized mRNA was stable with MFE: -2170.70\xa0kcal/mol. These outcomes may \ncontribute to the development of an experimental MPXV vaccine with stronger \npotency and superior safety measures. Additional in vitro and in vivo \nexperiments are required to test the safety and efficacy of these newly \ndeveloped vaccines.\n\n© 2025. J Med Case Rep. 2025 Nov 6;19(1):571. doi: 10.1186/s13256-025-05462-1.\n\nThe first Mpox case in Zambia: a case report.\n\nChipoya M(1), Sialubanje C(2), Ngulube D(3), Kapin'a M(2), Chikuluma J(4), Mambo \nC(2), Mwangilwa K(2), Simwaba D(2), Banda D(2), Sinyange N(2), Chilengi R(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Zambia National Public Health Institute, Lusaka, Zambia. \nmusolechipoya@gmail.com.\n(2)Zambia National Public Health Institute, Lusaka, Zambia.\n(3)Ministry of Health, Lusaka, Zambia.\n(4)University of Zambia, Lusaka, Zambia.\n\nBACKGROUND: Mpox, a viral infection caused by an Orthopoxvirus, has reemerged \noutside its historically endemic regions in Central and West Africa. This \ngeographical expansion introduces a potential risk of transmission in Zambia, \nwhere geographic proximity and active trade routes increase vulnerability. We \nreport the first confirmed case of Mpox in Zambia, involving a 32-year-old \nTanzanian cross-border truck driver who presented to Mukando Health Post in \nCentral Province, on 4 October 2024.\nCASE PRESENTATION: We present a 32-year-old male patient of African descent \nwhose symptoms included a history of 3-day fever, itchy rash, joint pains, \nfatigue, and sore throat. Physical examination revealed a papular rash over the \nface, trunk, and extremities with extension to the palms but spared the soles of \nthe feet. No lesions were noted in either the mucosal or genital areas. However, \nenlarged lymph nodes were palpable in the cervical region. Biological specimens \nwere collected and submitted to Zambia National Public Health Reference \nLaboratory. Samples collected, including oral swabs in transport media, whole \nblood, skin scrapping from lesions, swabs from lesions, and urine samples. \nAnalytics conducted on the samples included testing for polymerase chain \nreaction for Mpox, human immunodeficiency virus, rapid plasma reagin for \nsyphilis, and hepatitis B and C. Contact tracing identified both primary and \nsecondary contacts. Polymerase chain reaction confirmed Mpox DNA in initial \nwhole blood, with persistent detection in skin lesions and throat swabs. The \npatient was commenced on symptomatic treatment with benzyl benzoate, \nparacetamol, ibuprofen, chlorpheniramine, and phenoxymethylpenicillin and \ncontinued the same treatment after the confirmation of Mpox diagnosis. He was \nadvised to continue good hygiene practice and remain in isolation to prevent \ntransmission to others. None of the 22 traced contacts reported any symptoms nor \ntested positive.\nCONCLUSION: Our report emphasizes the transmission risk for Mpox in \ntraditionally nonendemic areas resulting from cross-border movement. This \nhighlights the need for countries to strengthen surveillance systems resulting \nin increased sensitivity, specificity, and timeliness required for early \ndetection and response to Mpox. A multifaceted collaborative approach is \nrequired between countries to ensure formalized cross-border collaboration, \nstrengthening health-seeking behavior through deployment of mobile clinics, and \nutilization of digital platforms risk communication and community engagement. \nImproved supply chain management for laboratory reagents, sample collection, and \npersonal protective equipment coupled with training of health workers is crucial \nfor adequate preparedness and successful containment of outbreaks. These \ninitiatives, collectively undertaken, will result in a robust response system \nsafeguarding public health and preventing emerging threats such as Mpox from \nbecoming endemic.\n\n© 2025. Ethics approval and consent to \nparticipate: We obtained consent from the patient on the use of their personal \ninformation in the case report. The consent form was also translated to local \nlanguage to aid understanding. Furthermore, all efforts have been made to \nanonymize the patient, to ensure we respect their confidentiality and privacy. \nConsent for publication: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient \nfor publication of this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the \nwritten consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal. \nCompeting interests: We declare that there are no competing interests."},

Cross-reactivity \namong orthopoxivuses, stemming from high sequence conservation, complicates \ndistinguishing antibody responses from natural MPXV infection versus vaccination \nor other orthopoxvirus exposures. We validated the Meso Scale Discovery (MSD) \nV-PLEX Orthopoxvirus Panel 1 (IgG) Kit, which quantifies antibody levels to five \nMPXV antigens and their vaccina virus (VACV) orthologs, following Good Clinical \nLaboratory Practice (GCLP) guidelines. We assessed assay performance using serum \nfrom 26 individuals with prior mpox, 52 JYNNEOS vaccine recipients, and 179 \nunexposed controls. The assay reliably detected antibody responses in all \nexposed cohorts with peak levels observed 2-months post-vaccination. Antibody \nlevels to specific antigens also correlated with Modified Vaccinia Ankara (MVA) \nneutralization titer, particularly for MPXV B6R/VACV B5R, MPXV E8L/VACV D8L, and \nMPXV M1R/VACV L1. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) analysis showed that \nsome individual antigens achieved high sensitivity and specificity for exposure \ndetection (AUC > 0.96 for VACV D8L, MPXV B6R, VACV B5R); however, individual \nantigens performed poorly in distinguishing infection from vaccination. In \ncontrast, antibody level ratios between some MPXV and VACV orthologs effectively \ndifferentiated MPXV infection from vaccinia vaccination with high sensitivity \nand specificity (e.g. MPXV A35R/VACV A33R ortholog ratio, AUC = 0.97, \nsensitivity = 0.97, specificity = 0.96). Our findings validate the MSD assay for \nclinical research and serosurveillance to assess MPXV immunity and support the \nutility of ortholog pair ratio analysis as a strategy to discriminate vaccinated \nand infected individuals.\n\nDOI: 10.1101/2025.10.24.25338410\nPMCID: PMC12636651\nPMID: 41282907"},

Sci Rep. 2025 Nov 19;15(1):40730. doi: 10.1038/s41598-025-24583-7.\n\nDistribution and epidemiological characteristics of nontuberculous mycobacterium \nspecies in jianghan plain.\n\nLi J(1), Chen H(2), Liu J(1), Yang S(1), Wang X(1), Zhang Y(1), Yuan X(1), Wang \nQ(3), Zhang Y(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)The First Affiliated Hospital of Yangtze University, Jingzhou, 434000, Hubei, \nChina.\n(2)National Center for Tuberculosis Control and Prevention, Chinese Center for \nDisease Control and Prevention, Beijing, 102206, China. chenhui@chinacdc.cn.\n(3)Department of respiration, Songzi People's Hospital, Songzi, 434200, Hubei, \nChina.\n(4)The First Affiliated Hospital of Yangtze University, Jingzhou, 434000, Hubei, \nChina. jzsdyrmyy2000@163.com.\n\nPulmonary nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) disease is an increasing public \nhealth concern in China. This study aimed to describe the epidemiology of \npulmonary NTM disease in the Jianghan Plain region of Central China. From 2021 \nto 2023, we collected specimens with positive mycobacterial cultures from the \nJianghan Plain and identified species using fluorescence PCR melting curve \nanalysis. We documented demographic characteristics, treatment history, \nlaboratory examination results, and comorbidities of patients with pulmonary NTM \ndisease. From 2021 to 2023, 419 cases of NTM were identified among 5,608 \nclinical specimens collected from the Jianghan Plain, accounting for 7.47% \n(419/5,608) of isolates. Among patients with pulmonary NTM, ages ranged from 16 \nto 90 years, with a median age of 64 years. The majority of cases (56.32%) \noccurred in patients over 60 years of age. The predominant species identified \nwere Mycobacterium intracellulare (224 cases, 53.46%), Mycobacterium abscessus \n(91 cases, 21.72%), Mycobacterium avium (27 cases, 6.44%), Mycobacterium \ngordonae (25 cases, 5.97%), and Mycobacterium kansasii (19 cases, 4.53%). The \nrisk of developing Mycobacterium abscessus disease significantly decreased with \nadvancing age. Compared to patients with Mycobacterium intracellulare disease, \nthose with pulmonary Mycobacterium abscessus disease were significantly more \nlikely to present with hemoptysis. No other significant differences in \ntuberculosis history or comorbidities were observed between patients with \nMycobacterium intracellulare and Mycobacterium abscessus infections. The \nisolation rate of NTM in the Jianghan Plain from 2021 to 2023 remained stable, \nslightly exceeding the national average in China. Mycobacterium intracellulare \nwas the most prevalent pathogenic NTM species, followed by Mycobacterium \nabscessus. Hemoptysis was identified as an independent risk factor for pulmonary \ndisease caused by M. abscessus.\n\n© 2025. The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1038/s41598-025-24583-7\nPMCID: PMC12630630\nPMID: 41258353 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declarations. Int J Syst Evol Microbiol. 2025 Nov;75(11):006960. doi:\n10.1099/ijsem.0.006960.\n\nMycobacterium camsae sp. nov. and Mycobacterium pumcae sp. nov., two species \nisolated from human skin infection.\n\nMei Y(1), Zhang W(1)(2), Shi Y(1)(2), Jiang H(1)(2), Zhang Q(1), Gan T(1), Peng \nJ(1), Mei H(1), Mo S(1), Wang H(1)(2)(3)(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Hospital for Skin Diseases, Institute of Dermatology, Chinese Academy of \nMedical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College, Nanjing, PR China.\n(2)Jiangsu Provincial Key Laboratory of Dermatology, Nanjing, PR China.\n(3)Center for Global Health, School of Public Health, Nanjing Medical \nUniversity, Nanjing, Jiangsu, PR China.\n(4)School of Population Medicine and Public Health, Chinese Academy of Medical \nSciences and Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, PR China.\n\nTwo slow-growing nontuberculous mycobacterial strains were isolated from \nclinical skin lesions in Jiangsu, PR China, and identified as novel species \nwithin the genus Mycobacterium. The bacterial colonies exhibited \nscotochromogenic pigmentation and rod-shaped morphology, and they were \nclassified as acid-fast bacilli. Phylogenetic analysis indicated that the two \nstrains were closely related to Mycobacterium gordonae. The two strains, X7091T \nand Z3061T, exhibited average nucleotide identity and in silico DNA-DNA \nhybridization values below the threshold for species delineation when compared \nwith other type strains of M. gordonae complex. Therefore, two novel \nMycobacterium species are proposed: Mycobacterium camsae sp. nov., with the type \nstrain being X7091T (=CGMCC 1.90336T=JCM 37414T), and Mycobacterium pumcae sp. \nnov., with the type strain being Z3061T (=CGMCC 1.90337T=JCM 37415T).\n\nDOI: 10.1099/ijsem.0.006960\nPMCID: PMC12617827\nPMID: 41236790 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: All authors declare that they have no known \ncompeting financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared \nto influence the work reported in this manuscript.'},

Epub 2025 Jun 30.\n\nA new heterozygous TYK2 gene mutation: Case report and review of the literature.\n\nXie L(1), Hu X(1), Wang H(1), Feng J(1), He R(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Respiratory Medicine, National Key Clinical Specialty, Branch \nof National Clinical Research Center for Respiratory Disease, Center of \nRespiratory Medicine, National Clinical Research Center for Geriatric Disorders, \nXiangya Hospital, Central South University, Changsha, Hunan, China.\n\nTyrosine kinase 2 (TYK2) deficiency is a rare primary immunodeficiency disease \n(PID). Patients carry TYK2 gene mutations and suffer from recurrent infections \nby intracellular pathogens, including mycobacteria. Delayed diagnosis often \nhinders timely and effective treatment, resulting in poor prognosis. In this \nstudy, we report a newly discovered TYK2 deficiency patient with recurrent \npulmonary infections. The patient, a 27-year-old Chinese man with a history of \ntuberculosis, presented with recurrent cough, phlegm, and purulent sputum. Lung \nCT scan showed bronchiectasis with concomitant infection. Next-generation \nsequencing (NGS) identified Mycobacterium gordonae and Mycobacterium chelonae in \nlung, along with heterozygous c.997G>A&c.10C>T (p.V333M&p.R4C) mutation in TYK2. \nFurther pathogenicity prediction analysis via dbNSFP (v5.1a) suggested the \npotential pathogenicity of this genetic variant. Additionally, TYK2 mRNA \nexpression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) also decreased \nsignificantly. Following anti-infective treatment, the patient improved and was \ndischarged with regular human immunoglobulin infusion. However, the patient \nunfortunately succumbed to disease exacerbation in October 2021, 15\u2009months after \ndiagnosis. Furthermore, a literature review was conducted on cases of TYK2 \ndeficiency. Previous studies have identified 24 mutation sites within TYK2 gene, \nwhich impair immune function and lead to early-onset recurrent infections. These \nmutations contribute to clinical heterogeneity, with the most common \nmanifestation being recurrent infections by opportunistic pathogens, \nparticularly mycobacteria. Our discovery of a novel TYK2 mutation expands the \ngene's mutation spectrum. Analyzing the characteristics of reported cases \nenhances understanding of TYK2 deficiency's clinical manifestations and \nfacilitates early diagnosis of this rare condition.\n\nDOI: 10.1177/03946320251351138\nPMCID: PMC12214311\nPMID: 40586332 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declaration of conflicting interestsThe \nauthor(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the \nresearch, authorship, and/or publication of this article."},

In this sense, this study aims to study how \nthe presence of mycobacteria affects the lynx population in Extremadura \n(southwest of Spain). Data Brief. 2025 Feb 4;59:111358. doi: 10.1016/j.dib.2025.111358. eCollection \n2025 Apr.\n\nImage dataset of environmental non-tuberculous mycobacteria isolated from heater \ncooler units water by the new NTM Elite agar.\n\nGiacomuzzi M(1), Memoli G(1), Garlasco J(1), Zotti CM(1), Ditommaso S(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Public Health Sciences and Pediatrics, University of Turin, Via \nSantena 5 bis, I-10126, Torino.\n\nThis article presents an image dataset of non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) \nisolated from heater-cooler units (HCU) using the recently developed NTM Elite \nagar (bioMérieux, Marcy-l'Étoile, France). NTM (e.g., Mycobacterium chimaera, \nMycobacterium gordonae, Mycobacterium chelonae, etc.) are waterborne pathogens \ncommonly found in building water systems, where they pose a primary concern for \nvulnerable patient populations and can cause severe disease. NTM can also be \nrecovered from various engineered environments, including aerosols from pools \nand spas, ice machines, and medical devices in healthcare settings, such as HCUs \nused during cardiac surgery. Due to the diverse bacterial communities that exist \nin environmental samples, isolating and recovering NTM from water using \nculture-based methods is an arduous process. Decontamination agents, although \noften successful in reducing non-mycobacterial growth, have shown limited \neffectiveness in recovering some NTM species, while also killing others. To \naddress this issue, a more selective agar known as NTM ELITE agar has been \ndeveloped. This highly selective medium includes four antimicrobial agents \n(colistin, fosfomycin, amphotericin, and C-390) and does not require a \ndecontamination step. In this data article, we present images of colonies grown \non the Elite agar that have been confirmed as NTM, captured using an iPhone 11 \ndual camera. The dataset contains high-quality images of NTM colonies (top views \nof agar plates) at different growth stages. To our knowledge, this is the first \nopen-access dataset of NTM images, which can help fill the gaps in images of \nenvironmental NTM grown on the new ELITE agar. It is also valuable for \nmicrobiologists, who can recognize mycobacteria of human origin but may have \nlimited experience in identifying NTM present in environmental samples.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.dib.2025.111358\nPMCID: PMC11876747\nPMID: 40041481"},

This paper described a rare case of globular \nshadow in the chest of an immunocompetent male who was diagnosed with M. \ngordonae pulmonary disease. He went to the hospital with chest pains that had \nlasted for more than two weeks. The routine clinical pathogen detection failed \nto discover the cause of the infection. Although metagenomic next-generation \nsequencing (mNGS) of the lung tissue was negative, M. gordonae was detected in \nthe background microorganism with only one read. Based on the pathological \nresults, it was considered to be the causative pathogen. Two months of treatment \nwith rifampicin, ethambutol, clarithromycin, and levofloxacin resulted in \nsignificant reduction and absorption of lung lesions. No abnormalities were \ndetected in either lung one year later. The lack of positive culture and other \nconventional microbiological test results make this case is not a strictly \nconfirmed case. This study also explored the clinical features and treatment \noptions of 32 cases of M. gordonae pulmonary disease through a systematic review \nof the literature. Although there is no standard recommended treatment regimen \nfor M. gordonae infection, but combination therapy with macrolides, rifampicin, \nand ethambutol has been proven effective.\nCONCLUSION: This case highlights that when the clinical highly suspected of \ninfection, mNGS can contribute to the early identification of non-tuberculous \nMycobacterium (NTM) even with low reads, when clinical suspicion is high. \nAnalyzing background microorganisms in sterile samples may help diagnose rare \npathogens.\n\n© 2024 Shi et al.\n\nDOI: 10.2147/IDR.S494310\nPMCID: PMC11645288\nPMID: 39676844\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors report no conflicts of interest in \nthis work."},

Luigi \nHospital, Orbassano, Italy.\n\nBACKGROUND: Worldwide, the detection of Mycobacterium chimaera in LivaNova \nheater-cooler units (HCUs) has led to their replacement with other HCUs, \nalthough non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) have been reported also for HCUs \nproduced by other manufacturers. Non-tuberculous mycobacteria were isolated in 150 water \nsamples (37.2%); 100% and 62% of HCU40 and HU35 devices, respectively, were \ncolonized with non-tuberculous mycobacteria. The most frequently detected \nspecies were Mycobacterium gordonae (73%) followed by Mycobacterium chelonae \n(41%) and Mycobacterium paragordonae (11%).\nCONCLUSION: Preventive strategies by disinfection with chloramine-T did not \neffectively reduce non-tuberculous mycobacteria colonization of Maquet devices. \nAlthough, to date, no cases of postoperative invasive infections linked to \nMaquet devices have been reported, our microbiological results emphasize the \nneed for (1) designing changes to increase safety of devices and (2) researching \nand developing new disinfection protocols including alternative molecules.\n\nCopyright © 2024 The Healthcare Infection Society. Open Respir Arch. 2024 Jul 26;6(4):100353. doi: 10.1016/j.opresp.2024.100353. \neCollection 2024 Oct-Dec.\n\nNontuberculous Mycobacteria Isolates in Respiratory Samples and Mycobacterial \nPulmonary Disease in an Area of Northern Spain.\n\nUgedo J(1), Tabernero E(2), Altube L(3), Leal MV(4), García JA(5).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Respiratory Medicine, San Pedro University Hospital, Logroño, \nLa Rioja, Spain.\n(2)Department of Respiratory Medicine, Cruces University Hospital, BioBizkaia \nHealth Research Institute, Barakaldo, Bizkaia, Spain.\n(3)Department of Respiratory Medicine, Galdakao University Hospital, Bizkaia, \nSpain.\n(4)Department of Respiratory Medicine, Basurto University Hospital, Bizkaia, \nSpain.\n(5)Department of Respiratory Medicine, Araba University Hospital, Araba, Spain.\n\nINTRODUCTION: The epidemiology of nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) is not well \nknown. In this study, we aimed to determine the incidence of NTM isolates and \nnontuberculous mycobacterial pulmonary disease (NTM-PD) in five closely located \nhospitals in an area of northern Spain and analyse differences between them.\nMATERIAL AND METHODS: Demographic, microbiological, clinical and radiological \ndata were collected retrospectively from all patients with a NTM isolated from \nrespiratory specimens at five hospitals between 2012 and 2019. Mycobacterium \ngordonae isolates were excluded. Once the data was collected, it was determined \nwhich patients met the NMT-PD criteria.\nRESULTS: 594 patients were included in the study. The mean incidence rate of NTM \nisolates across all five hospitals in the period studied was 4.15 per 100,000 \nperson-year, while the rate of NTM-PD was 1.2. The annual number of isolates \nshowed an upward trend over this period, but the same did not occur in the \nnumber of cases of NTM-PD. The species most frequently isolated were \nMycobacterium avium complex (MAC) and Mycobacterium xenopi and those most \nfrequently causing disease were MAC and Mycobacterium kansassi. There were \nsignificant differences between the five centres.\nCONCLUSIONS: Our results are in line with similar studies in Europe in terms of \nNTM isolation and NTM-PD incidence and species isolated; however, we do not see \nthe upward trend in NTM-PD rates described elsewhere. The great variability in \nisolation and disease rates, as well as in species isolated in geographically \nclose areas, underlines, in our opinion, the importance of local environmental \nfactors.\n\nPublisher: INTRODUCCIÓN: La epidemiología de las micobacterias no tuberculosas \n(MNT) no se conoce bien. Nuestro objetivo fue determinar la incidencia de \naislamientos de MNT y de enfermedad pulmonar por micobacterias no tuberculosas \n(EP-MNT) en cinco hospitales del norte de España, próximos entre sí, y analizar \nlas diferencias entre ellos.\nMATERIAL Y MÉTODOS: Se recopilaron retrospectivamente datos demográficos, \nmicrobiológicos, clínicos y radiológicos de todos los pacientes con una MNT \naislada en muestra respiratoria entre 2012 y 2019 en los cinco hospitales. Se \nexcluyeron los aislamientos de Mycobacterium gordonae. Una vez recogidos los \ndatos, se determinó qué casos cumplían los criterios de EP-MNT.\nRESULTADOS: Se incluyeron 594 pacientes. La tasa de incidencia media de \naislamientos de NTM en los cinco hospitales fue de 4,15 por 100.000 personas-año \ny la tasa de EP-MNT fue de 1,2. El número anual de aislamientos mostró una \ntendencia creciente durante este periodo, pero no así el de EP-MNT. Las especies \naisladas con mayor frecuencia fueron Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) y \nMycobacterium xenopi y las que causaron enfermedad con mayor frecuencia fueron \nMAC y Mycobacterium kansasii. Hubo diferencias significativas entre los cinco \ncentros.\nCONCLUSIONES: Nuestros resultados están en línea con estudios similares en \nEuropa en términos de aislamiento de MNT, incidencia de EP-MNT y especies \naisladas; sin embargo, no vemos la tendencia ascendente en las tasas de EP-MNT \ndescrita en otros lugares. La gran variabilidad entre los cinco hospitales en \nlas tasas de aislamiento y de enfermedad y en las especies aisladas resalta la \nimportancia de los factores ambientales locales.\n\n© 2024 Sociedad Española de Neumología y Cirugía Torácica (SEPAR). In this \nstudy, we report a newly discovered TYK2 deficiency patient with recurrent \npulmonary infections. The patient, a 27-year-old Chinese man with a history of \ntuberculosis, presented with recurrent cough, phlegm, and purulent sputum. Lung \nCT scan showed bronchiectasis with concomitant infection. Additionally, TYK2 mRNA \nexpression in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) also decreased \nsignificantly. Following anti-infective treatment, the patient improved and was \ndischarged with regular human immunoglobulin infusion. However, the patient \nunfortunately succumbed to disease exacerbation in October 2021, 15\u2009months after \ndiagnosis. Furthermore, a literature review was conducted on cases of TYK2 \ndeficiency. Previous studies have identified 24 mutation sites within TYK2 gene, \nwhich impair immune function and lead to early-onset recurrent infections. These \nmutations contribute to clinical heterogeneity, with the most common \nmanifestation being recurrent infections by opportunistic pathogens, \nparticularly mycobacteria. Our discovery of a novel TYK2 mutation expands the \ngene's mutation spectrum. Analyzing the characteristics of reported cases \nenhances understanding of TYK2 deficiency's clinical manifestations and \nfacilitates early diagnosis of this rare condition.\n\nDOI: 10.1177/03946320251351138\nPMCID: PMC12214311\nPMID: 40586332 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declaration of conflicting interestsThe \nauthor(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the \nresearch, authorship, and/or publication of this article."},
