BMC Infect Dis. 2025 Sep 26;25(1):1155. doi: 10.1186/s12879-025-11451-y.\n\nCryptococcus neoformans\xa0tibial osteomyelitis in an immunocompetent host: a case \ndiagnosed by tNGS.\n\nQin W(#)(1), Guo Y(#)(1), Liang Z(1), Wei H(1), Huang H(1), Zhou L(1), Tan S(1), \nWu X(1), Xie L(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Clinical Laboratory, The Second Affiliated Hospital of Guangxi \nMedical University, Nanning, Guangxi, China.\n(2)Department of Clinical Laboratory, The Second Affiliated Hospital of Guangxi \nMedical University, Nanning, Guangxi, China. drlixie@163.com.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nBACKGROUND: Cryptococcus neoformansis widely distributed in nature and primarily \ncauses infections in various parts of the body through inhalation into the \nlungs. While C.neoformans infection predominantly occurs in immunocompromised \nindividuals, there has been a significant increase in reports among \nimmunocompetent hosts in recent years. Although the lungs and central nervous \nsystem constitute the most common sites of infection, cryptococcal osteomyelitis \nremains exceptionally rare and is typically associated with disseminated disease \nin immunodeficient patients. Herein, we present a rare case of isolated tibial \ncryptococcal osteomyelitis in an immunocompetent patient.\nCASE PRESENTATION: We report a case of a 64-year-old female who presented with \npain, swelling, and increased local skin temperature in the left lower limb for \none month without any obvious cause. The patient was initially diagnosed with \nosteomyelitis at a local county hospital and underwent surgical treatment. Due \nto poor postoperative healing, she was referred to our hospital for surgical \ndebridement. Preoperative wound specimen culture revealed Luteimonas deserti. \nSimultaneously, intraoperative tissue samples were taken from the patient for \ntargeted next-generation sequencing (tNGS) testing, which revealed the presence \nof C. neoformans. While the culture was negative, the C. neoformans capsular \nantigen test was positive. The patient had normal immune function and no \nunderlying diseases. Ultimately, the patient was treated with fluconazole and \nsurgery, resulting in a good prognosis.\nCONCLUSIONS: we report a case of tibial osteomyelitis caused by Cryptococcus \nneoformans in an immunocompetent patient, with diagnosis confirmed through \ntargeted next-generation sequencing (tNGS) and serum Cryptococcal capsular \nantigen testingOur results demonstrate the great potential of tNGS in the \ndetection of infectious pathogens. In patients with negative culture results, \ntNGS can quickly detect various pathogens, providing accurate diagnosis and \nfacilitating appropriate treatment for patients.\n\n© 2025. This study aims to characterize the skin microbiome \ncommunities of young wrestlers and kickboxers in comparison with their \nnon-athlete age-peers.\nMETHODS: A total of 56 combat sport athletes (30 males and 26 females, mean age \n± SD = 18.2 ± 1.5 years) and 25 non-athlete youths (control group: 13 males and \n12 females, mean age ± SD = 19.8 ± 1.2 years) voluntarily consented to \nparticipate in the study conducted by our research team in 2023 and 2024. The \nskin microbiome analysis involved standardized sampling, DNA isolation, \nmolecular sequencing, and bioinformatic analysis, thus enabling detailed \ncharacterization and comparison of the skin microbial community in contact \nsports athletes and the control group.\nRESULTS: Our results revealed notable sexual dimorphism in the skin microbiome \ncomposition of youth. Males showed a higher relative abundance of bacterial \ngenera associated with nosocomial infections and respiratory diseases, while \nfemales had more skin inflammation- and infection-related genera (relative \nabundances in males vs. in females: Corynebacterium-12.0 vs. 7.2; \nLuteimonas-4.4. vs. 1.4; Paracoccus-8.8 vs. 5.0; Psychrobacter-6.3 vs. 4.4; \nCutibacterium-6.4 vs. 11.4; Kocuria-1.6 vs. 3.9; Micrococcus-5.8 vs. 8.5; \nPseudomonas-1.2 vs. 3.4; Streptococcus 3.3 vs. 6.2). We also found skin \nmicrobiome differences between athletes and non-athletes in both sexes: \nwrestlers, who experience frequent skin-to-skin contact and wear less covering \nsportswear, had microbiome profiles distinct from both kickboxers and \nnon-athletes (relative abundances in athletes vs. in non-athletes: \nPsychrobacter-7.3 vs. 0.4; Staphylococcus 9.5 vs. 18.5; predominance of genera \nby sports type: relative abundance of Cutibacterium and Streptococcus was higher \nin kickboxers, and relative abundance of Acinetobacter, Enhydrobacter, \nMicrococcus, and Enhydrobacter was higher in wrestlers). Bacteria linked to skin \ninfections (e.g., Aliterella, Arthrobacter, and Empedobacter) were present in \naround 30% of wrestlers and kickboxers but were absent in the control group.\nCONCLUSIONS: These results underscore the heightened risk of skin infections in \ncontact sports and highlight the importance of regular microbiome monitoring and \nhygiene protocols among young athletes.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/sports13090288\nPMCID: PMC12473315\nPMID: 41003594\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that they have no competing \ninterests.'},

Front Microbiol. 2022 Nov 16;13:1028969. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2022.1028969. \neCollection 2022.\n\nMaize-soybean intercropping facilitates chemical and microbial transformations \nof phosphorus fractions in a calcareous soil.\n\nLiu J(1), Li Y(1), Han C(1), Yang D(1), Yang J(2), Cade-Menun BJ(3), Chen Y(1), \nSui P(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)College of Agronomy and Biotechnology, China Agricultural University, \nBeijing, China.\n(2)Institute of Environment and Sustainable Development in Agriculture, Chinese \nAcademy of Agricultural Sciences, Beijing, China.\n(3)Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, Swift Current RDC, Swift Current, SK, \nCanada.\n\nIntercropping often substantially increases phosphorus (P) availability to \nplants compared with monocropping, which could be an effective strategy for soil \nlegacy P recovery and agricultural production. However, the biogeochemical \ninteractions among plants, microbes, and soil that mobilize P remain largely \nunknown in intercropping systems. Pot experiments with maize-soybean \nintercropping in a calcareous soil were conducted to investigate the potential \nchemical and biological transformation mechanisms of inorganic P (Pi) and \norganic P (Po) using sequential extraction and Illumina MiSeq sequencing. \nCompared to monocropping of each crop, maize-soybean intercropping significantly \nenhanced total P uptake of the two crops by mobilizing Ca2-Pi [extracted by \nbicarbonate (NaHCO3)], Al-Pi/Po [extracted by ammonium fluoride (NH4F)] and \nFe-Pi [extracted by sodium hydroxide and sodium carbonate (NaOH-Na2CO3)] \nfractions. Furthermore, there were significant increases in the organic carbon \ncontent and alkaline phosphomonoesterase (ALP) and phosphodiesterase (PDE) \nactivities as well as the abundances of Microvirga, Lysobacter, Microlunatus and \nSphingomonas under maize-soybean intercropping relative to monocropping. In \ncontrast, compared to monocroppping, no significant change in the soil pH was \nobserved under maize-soybean intercropping. Therefore, the enhanced P uptake of \nthe maize-soybean intercropping probably resulted from a synergistic effect of \nrhizosphere organic carbon deposit, increased activities of ALP and PDE, \ntogether with the bacteria (Microvirga, Lysobacter, Microlunatus and \nSphingomonas) which showed correlation with soil P forms, while the generally \nrecognized rhizosphere acidification was excluded in this investigated \ncalcareous soil. Moreover, the selected bacterial genera exhibited a closer \nnetwork in the rhizosphere of soybean compared to maize, suggesting enhanced \ninteractions among bacteria in the soybean rhizosphere. These results provide \ntheoretical bases for the recovery of soil legacy P by maize-soybean \nintercropping.\n\nCopyright © 2022 Jin Liu, Yang Li, Chaoqun Han, Dongling Yang, Jianjun Yang, \nYuanquan Chen, Peng Sui His Majesty the King in Right of Canada, as represented \nby the Minister of Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada for the contribution of \nBarbara J. Indoor microbial composition is \nassociated with SBS symptoms, but the impact of microbial functional genes and \npotential metabolic products has not been characterized. We conducted a shotgun \nmicrobial metagenomic sequencing for vacuum dust collected in urban and rural \nschools in Shanxi province, China. SBS symptoms in students were surveyed, and \nmicrobial taxa and functional pathways related to the symptoms were identified \nusing a multi-level linear regression model. SBS symptoms were common in \nstudents, and the prevalence of ocular and throat symptoms, headache, and \ntiredness was higher in urban than in rural areas (p\u202f<\u202f0.05). A significant \nhigher microbial α-diversity was found in rural areas than in urban areas \n(Chao1, p\u202f=\u202f0.001; ACE, p\u202f=\u202f0.002). Also, significant variation in microbial \ntaxonomic and functional composition (β-diversity) was observed between urban \nand rural areas (p\u202f<\u202f0.005). Five potential risk Actinobacteria species were \nassociated with SBS symptoms (p\u202f<\u202f0.01); students in the classrooms with a \nhigher abundance of an unclassified Geodermatophilaceae, Geodermatophilus, \nFridmanniella luteola, Microlunatus phosphovorus and Mycetocola reported more \nnasal and throat symptoms and tiredness. Students with a higher abundance of an \nunclassified flavobacteriaceae reported fewer throat symptoms and tiredness. The \nabundance of microbial metabolic pathways related to the synthesis of B vitamins \n(biotin and folate), gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), short-chain fatty acids \n(SCFAs), and peptidoglycan and were protectively (negatively) associated with \nSBS symptoms (FDR\u202f<\u202f0.05). The result is consistent with human microbiota \nstudies, which reported that these microbial products are extensively involved \nin immunological processes and anti-inflammatory effects. This is the first \nstudy to report the functional potential of the indoor microbiome and the \noccurrence of SBS, providing new insights into the potential etiologic \nmechanisms in chronic inflammatory diseases.\n\nCopyright © 2021 Elsevier B.V. Nanopelagicales'.\n\nKavagutti VS(1)(2), Chiriac MC(1), Ghai R(1), Salcher MM(1), Haber M(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Aquatic Microbial Ecology, Institute of Hydrobiology, Biology \nCentre CAS, Na Sádkách 702/7, 370 05, České Budějovice, Czech Republic.\n(2)Faculty of Science, University of South Bohemia, Branišovská 31, 370 05, \nČeské Budějovice, Czech Republic.\n(3)Department of Aquatic Microbial Ecology, Institute of Hydrobiology, Biology \nCentre CAS, Na Sádkách 702/7, 370 05, České Budějovice, Czech Republic. \nmarkus.haber@hbu.cas.cz.\n\nLow-GC Actinobacteriota of the order 'Ca. Nanopelagicales' (also known as acI or \nhgcI clade) are abundant in freshwaters around the globe. Extensive predation \npressure by phages has been assumed to be the reason for their high levels of \nmicrodiversity. So far, however, only a few metagenome-assembled phages have \nbeen proposed to infect them and no phages have been isolated. Taking advantage \nof recent advances in the cultivation of 'Ca. Nanopelagicales' we isolated a \nnovel species of its genus 'Ca. Planktophila'. Using this isolate as bait, we \ncultivated the first two phages infecting this abundant bacterial order. Both \ngenomes contained a whiB-like transcription factor and a RNA polymerase sigma-70 \nfactor, which might aid in manipulating their host's metabolism. Both phages \nencoded a glycosyltransferase and one an anti-restriction protein, potential \nmeans to evade degradation of their DNA by nucleases present in the host genome. \nThe two phage genomes shared only 6% of their genome with their closest \nrelatives, with whom they form a previously uncultured family of actinophages \nwithin the Caudoviricetes. Read recruitment analyses against globally \ndistributed metagenomes revealed the endemic distribution of this group of \nphages infecting 'Ca. Nanopelagicales'. The recruitment pattern against \nmetagenomes from the isolation site and the modular distribution of shared genes \nbetween the two phages indicate high levels of horizontal gene transfer, likely \nmirroring the microdiversity of their host in the evolutionary arms race between \nhost and phage.\n\n© 2023. Even in the omics age, cultivation is an \nessential discipline in microbial ecology since microbial cultures are necessary \nto assess the validity of an in silico prediction about the microbial metabolism \nand to isolate viruses infecting bacteria and archaea. However, the \necophysiological characteristics of predominant freshwater bacterial lineages \nremain largely unknown due to the scarcity of cultured representatives. In an \nongoing effort to cultivate the uncultured majority of freshwater bacteria, the \nmost abundant freshwater Actinobacteria acI clade has recently been cultivated \nfrom Lake Soyang through catalase-supplemented high-throughput cultivation based \non dilution-to-extinction. This method involves physical isolation of target \nmicrobes from mixed populations, culture media simulating natural habitats, and \nremoval of toxic compounds. In this protocol, we describe detailed procedures \nfor isolating freshwater oligotrophic microbes, as well as the essence of the \ndilution-to-extinction culturing. As a case study employing the \ncatalase-supplemented dilution-to-extinction protocol, we also report a \ncultivation trial using a water sample collected from Lake Soyang. Of the 480 \ncultivation wells inoculated with a single lake-water sample, 75 new acI strains \nbelonging to 8 acI tribes (acI-A1, A2, A4, A5, A6, A7, B1, B4, C1, and C2) were \ncultivated, and each representative strain per subclade could be revived from \nglycerol stocks. These cultivation results demonstrate that the protocol \ndescribed in this study is efficient in isolating freshwater bacterioplankton \nharboring streamlined genomes.\n\nDOI: 10.1007/s12275-020-0452-2\nPMID: 33125668 [Indexed for MEDLINE]'}],

Electronic address: pfdunfie@ucalgary.ca.\n\nSurface mining and extraction of oil sands in Canada produces fluid tailings \nthat contain several compounds of concern for the environment. One option for \nmine reclamation is the construction of Pit Lakes (PLs) to contain and remediate \nthese tailings. Ultimately, PLs should support food webs typical of boreal \nlakes. From 2015 to 2021, we applied 16S/18S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing and \nmetagenomics to monitor prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbes in the only \nfull-scale PL of the oil sands industry (Base Mine Lake or BML), and compared it \nto two control environments: a freshwater reservoir unaffected by tailings, and \nactive tailings ponds receiving regular industrial input. Microbial communities \nin BML were always intermediate to the two control environments based on alpha \nand beta diversity analyses. BML communities were highly variable with year, \nseason, and water depth, and contained fewer core species than the freshwater \nreservoir. Several hydrocarbon degraders and sulfur cycling bacteria were \nidentified as indicator species of tailings ponds, while several phototrophs \nwere indicative of freshwater. However, all of these species were abundant in \nBML, suggesting that the PL supports food webs characteristic of each control \nenvironment. Over the 6-year study, the relative abundances of some common \nfreshwater phytoplankton (Cryptomonas, Mychonastes, Trebouxiophyceae, Cyanobium) \nand heterotrophic bacteria (Sporichthyaceae, Ca. Fonsibacter, \nIlumatobacteraceae, Microbacteriaceae, Ca. Planktophila) increased in BML. The \nresults suggest that microbial communities and processes in BML represent an \nintermediate state between a tailings pond and a natural freshwater system, and \ndid not stabilize within 10\xa0years of its creation.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Authors. Online ahead of\nprint.\n\nCultivation, genomics, and giant viruses of a ubiquitous and heterotrophic \nfreshwater cryptomonad.\n\nMukherjee I(1), Bulzu PA(1), Boukheloua R(1)(2), Asghar U(1)(2), Park H(1)(3), \nVieira HH(1), Chiriac MC(1), Kasalický V(1), Znachor P(1)(2), Rychtecký P(1), \nŠimek K(1), Salcher MM(1), Haber M(1), Ghai R(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Biology Centre of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Institute of Hydrobiology, \nNa Sádkách 7, 37005 České Budějovice, Czech Republic.\n(2)Faculty of Science, University of South Bohemia, 37005 České Budějovice, \nCzech Republic.\n(3)Department of Biological Sciences and Bioengineering, Inha University, \nIncheon, Republic of Korea.\n\nHeterotrophic nanoflagellates are the chief agents of bacterivory in the aquatic \nmicrobial loop but remain underrepresented in culture collections and in genomic \ndatabases. We isolated and characterised a representative of the previously \nuncultured freshwater Cryptomonad Group 1 (CRY1a) lineage using a \ngenome-streamlined, ultrasmall and abundant microbe Planktophila versatilis as a \nprey and CARD-FISH probe-based screening. The compact genome (ca. 69 Mb) \nrevealed no traces of a photosynthetic lifestyle, consistent with its \nphylogenomic placement as a sister-clade to cryptophytes that are characterised \nby the acquisition of a red-algal symbiont. Moreover, in comparison to its \nphotosynthetic counterparts, its genome presents substantially lower repeat \ncontent and endogenous viral elements. Genomes of two giant viruses, \nTyrannovirus reginensis GV1 and GV2, were also recovered from the same culture \nand represent a viral genus that has been described so far solely by \nmetagenome-recovered genomes. Collectively, these findings provide insights into \ngenomic ancestry and evolution, widespread ecological impact and interactions of \nan elusive protist lineage and illustrate the advantages of culture-centric \napproaches towards unfolding complex tapestries of life in the microbial world.\n\n© The Author(s) 2025. Epub 2025 Jun 2.\n\nMicrobial community development in an oil sands pit lake.\n\nSmirnova AV(1), Verbeke TJ(1), Furgason CC(1), Albakistani EA(1), Nwosu FC(1), \nKim JJ(1), Haupt ES(1), Sheremet A(1), Lee ES(1), Trang E(1), Richardson E(2), \nDacks JB(2), Dunfield PF(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Biological Sciences, University of Calgary, 2500 University Dr. \nNW, Calgary, Alberta T2N 1N4, Canada.\n(2)Division of Infectious Diseases, Department of Medicine, Department of \nBiological Sciences, 1-001 CCIS, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta T6G \n2E1, Canada.\n(3)Department of Biological Sciences, University of Calgary, 2500 University Dr. \nNW, Calgary, Alberta T2N 1N4, Canada. Electronic address: pfdunfie@ucalgary.ca.\n\nSurface mining and extraction of oil sands in Canada produces fluid tailings \nthat contain several compounds of concern for the environment. One option for \nmine reclamation is the construction of Pit Lakes (PLs) to contain and remediate \nthese tailings. Ultimately, PLs should support food webs typical of boreal \nlakes. From 2015 to 2021, we applied 16S/18S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing and \nmetagenomics to monitor prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbes in the only \nfull-scale PL of the oil sands industry (Base Mine Lake or BML), and compared it \nto two control environments: a freshwater reservoir unaffected by tailings, and \nactive tailings ponds receiving regular industrial input. Microbial communities \nin BML were always intermediate to the two control environments based on alpha \nand beta diversity analyses. BML communities were highly variable with year, \nseason, and water depth, and contained fewer core species than the freshwater \nreservoir. Several hydrocarbon degraders and sulfur cycling bacteria were \nidentified as indicator species of tailings ponds, while several phototrophs \nwere indicative of freshwater. However, all of these species were abundant in \nBML, suggesting that the PL supports food webs characteristic of each control \nenvironment. Over the 6-year study, the relative abundances of some common \nfreshwater phytoplankton (Cryptomonas, Mychonastes, Trebouxiophyceae, Cyanobium) \nand heterotrophic bacteria (Sporichthyaceae, Ca. Fonsibacter, \nIlumatobacteraceae, Microbacteriaceae, Ca. Planktophila) increased in BML. The \nresults suggest that microbial communities and processes in BML represent an \nintermediate state between a tailings pond and a natural freshwater system, and \ndid not stabilize within 10\xa0years of its creation.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Authors. Nanopelagicales' (also known as acI or \nhgcI clade) are abundant in freshwaters around the globe. Extensive predation \npressure by phages has been assumed to be the reason for their high levels of \nmicrodiversity. So far, however, only a few metagenome-assembled phages have \nbeen proposed to infect them and no phages have been isolated. Taking advantage \nof recent advances in the cultivation of 'Ca. Nanopelagicales' we isolated a \nnovel species of its genus 'Ca. Planktophila'. Using this isolate as bait, we \ncultivated the first two phages infecting this abundant bacterial order. Both \ngenomes contained a whiB-like transcription factor and a RNA polymerase sigma-70 \nfactor, which might aid in manipulating their host's metabolism. Both phages \nencoded a glycosyltransferase and one an anti-restriction protein, potential \nmeans to evade degradation of their DNA by nucleases present in the host genome. \nThe two phage genomes shared only 6% of their genome with their closest \nrelatives, with whom they form a previously uncultured family of actinophages \nwithin the Caudoviricetes. Read recruitment analyses against globally \ndistributed metagenomes revealed the endemic distribution of this group of \nphages infecting 'Ca. Nanopelagicales'. The recruitment pattern against \nmetagenomes from the isolation site and the modular distribution of shared genes \nbetween the two phages indicate high levels of horizontal gene transfer, likely \nmirroring the microdiversity of their host in the evolutionary arms race between \nhost and phage.\n\n© 2023. The biosynthesis of some antibiotics whose constitutive production \notherwise remains low has been shown to be induced by competing microbes. \nCompetition among macroorganism hosts may further influence the metabolic \noutputs of members of their microbiomes, especially near host surfaces where \nhosts and microbial symbionts come into close contact. At multiple field sites \nin Fiji, we collected matched samples of corals and algae that were freestanding \nor in physical contact with each other, cultivated bacteria from their surfaces, \nand explored growth-inhibitory activities of these bacteria against marine and \nhuman pathogens. In the course of the investigation, an interaction was \ndiscovered between two coral-associated actinomycetes in which an Agrococcus sp. \ninterfered with the antibiotic output of a Streptomyces sp. Several \ndiketopiperazines identified from the antibiotic-producing bacterium could not, \non their own, account for the antibiotic activity indicating that other, as yet \nunidentified molecule(s) or molecular blends, possibly including \ndiketopiperazines, are likely involved. This observation highlights the complex \nmolecular dynamics at play among microbiome constituents. The mechanisms through \nwhich microbial interactions impact the biological activities of specialized \nmetabolites deserve further attention considering the ecological and commercial \nimportance of bacterial natural products.\n\n© 2022. Maintaining \nthe biological cleanliness of NASA's mission-associated cleanrooms, where \nspacecraft are assembled and tested, is critical for planetary protection. The \nreduced microbial competition in these environments enhances the discovery of \nnovel microbial diversity, contributing to the mitigation of microbial \ncontamination and fostering biotechnological innovation. Microorganisms. 2025 Jun 6;13(6):1324. doi: 10.3390/microorganisms13061324.\n\nGenome Sequences of the First Phages Infecting Limnohabitans Reveal Their Global \nDistribution and Metabolic Potential.\n\nDeng B(1), Che R(1), Zhu P(1), Wang Y(1), Li Z(1), Zhang S(2), Xiao W(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Yunnan Institute of Microbiology, School of Life Science, Yunnan University, \nKunming 650500, China.\n(2)Yunnan Engineering Laboratory of Soil Fertility and Pollution Remediation, \nYunnan Agricultural University, Kunming 650201, China.\n\nBacteriophages (phages) are one of the critical biotic drivers of prokaryotic \ncommunity dynamics, functions, and evolution. Despite their importance in \naquatic ecosystems, very few phages have been isolated from freshwater lakes, \nhampering our understanding of their ecological importance and usage in a \nvariety of biotechnological applications. Limnohabitans, with a ubiquitous \ndistribution, is a metabolically versatile, fast-growing, morphologically \ndiverse freshwater lake bacterial genera. It is especially abundant in \npH-neutral and alkaline aquatic habitats, where it represents an average of 12% \nof freshwater bacterioplankton and plays an important role in funneling carbon \nfrom primary producers to higher trophic levels. However, no phages infecting \nLimnohabitans have been reported to date. Here, we describe, for the first time, \nthree phages infecting Limnohabitans, DC31, DC33, and YIMV22061, isolated from \ntwo freshwater lakes in China and characterized using genome content analysis \nand comparative genomics. DC31 and DC33, recovered from the eutrophic Dianchi \nLake, with auxiliary metabolic genes (AMGs), associated with nucleotide \nmetabolism, whereas YIMV22061, isolated from the oligotrophic Fuxian Lake, \ncarried AMGs involved in antibiotic resistance. The AMGs they carried highlight \ntheir impacts on Limnohabitans in different environments. Here, we \naimed to heterologously express 18 HSP20s from 12 thermotolerant bacteria in \nEscherichia coli and evaluate their effects on various physical and chemical \ncellular stresses. Seventeen HSP20s were successfully expressed as soluble \nproteins. Recombinant E. coli cells were subjected to heat, cold, acidic, \nalkaline, and hyperosmolar stress to evaluate the effects of HSP20 proteins on \nstress resistance. Notably, the overexpression of 15 HSP20s enhanced the stress \nresistance of E. coli compared to that of the control strain. In particular, \nHSPs from Tepidimonas sediminis and Oceanithermus profundus improved the stress \ntolerance of E. coli under all tested conditions. To our knowledge, this is the first report of E. coli \ntolerance to prolonged (>\u2009100\xa0h) high-temperature stress. These findings \nindicate the potential of thermotolerant HSPs as molecular tools for improving \nstress tolerance in E. coli.\n\n© 2024. PLoS One. 2024 Oct 25;19(10):e0310595. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0310595. \neCollection 2024.\n\nAquificae overcomes competition by archaeal thermophiles, and crowding by \nbacterial mesophiles, to dominate the boiling vent-water of a Trans-Himalayan \nsulfur-borax spring.\n\nMondal N(1), Dutta S(1), Chatterjee S(1), Sarkar J(1), Mondal M(1), Roy C(2), \nChakraborty R(3), Ghosh W(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Biological Sciences, Bose Institute, Kolkata, India.\n(2)Department of Plant and Environmental Sciences, University of Copenhagen, \nCopenhagen, Denmark.\n(3)Department of Biotechnology, University of North Bengal, Siliguri, India.\n\nTrans-Himalayan hot spring waters rich in boron, chlorine, sodium and sulfur \n(but poor in calcium and silicon) are known based on PCR-amplified 16S rRNA gene \nsequence data to harbor high diversities of infiltrating bacterial mesophiles. \nYet, little is known about the community structure and functions, primary \nproductivity, mutual interactions, and thermal adaptations of the microorganisms \npresent in the steaming waters discharged by these geochemically peculiar spring \nsystems. We revealed these aspects of a bacteria-dominated microbiome (microbial \ncell density ~8.5 × 104 mL-1; live:dead cell ratio 1.7) thriving in the boiling \n(85°C) fluid vented by a sulfur-borax spring called Lotus Pond, situated at 4436 \nm above the mean sea-level, in the Puga valley of eastern Ladakh, on the \nChangthang plateau. Assembly, annotation, and population-binning of >15-GB \nmetagenomic sequence illuminated the numeral predominance of Aquificae. While \nmembers of this phylum accounted for 80% of all 16S rRNA-encoding reads within \nthe metagenomic dataset, 14% of such reads were attributed to Proteobacteria. \nPost assembly, only 25% of all protein-coding genes identified were attributable \nto Aquificae, whereas 41% was ascribed to Proteobacteria. Annotation of \nmetagenomic reads encoding 16S rRNAs, and/or PCR-amplified 16S rRNA genes, \nidentified 163 bacterial genera, out of which 66 had been detected in past \ninvestigations of Lotus Pond's vent-water via 16S amplicon sequencing. Among \nthese 66, Fervidobacterium, Halomonas, Hydrogenobacter, Paracoccus, \nSulfurihydrogenibium, Tepidimonas, Thermus and Thiofaba (or their close \nphylogenomic relatives) were presently detected as metagenome-assembled genomes \n(MAGs). Remarkably, the Hydrogenobacter related MAG alone accounted for ~56% of \nthe entire metagenome, even though only 15 out of the 66 genera consistently \npresent in Lotus Pond's vent-water have strains growing in the laboratory at \n>45°C, reflecting the continued existence of the mesophiles in the ecosystem. \nFurthermore, the metagenome was replete with genes crucial for thermal \nadaptation in the context of Lotus Pond's geochemistry and topography. In terms \nof sequence similarity, a majority of those genes were attributable to \nphylogenetic relatives of mesophilic bacteria, while functionally they rendered \nfunctions such as encoding heat shock proteins, molecular chaperones, and \nchaperonin complexes; proteins controlling/modulating/inhibiting DNA gyrase; \nuniversal stress proteins; methionine sulfoxide reductases; fatty acid \ndesaturases; different toxin-antitoxin systems; enzymes protecting against \noxidative damage; proteins conferring flagellar structure/function, chemotaxis, \ncell adhesion/aggregation, biofilm formation, and quorum sensing. The Lotus Pond \nAquificae not only dominated the microbiome numerically but also acted \npotentially as the main primary producers of the ecosystem, with \nchemolithotrophic sulfur oxidation (Sox) being the fundamental bioenergetic \nmechanism, and reductive tricarboxylic acid (rTCA) cycle the predominant carbon \nfixation pathway. The Lotus Pond metagenome contained several genes directly or \nindirectly related to virulence functions, biosynthesis of secondary metabolites \nincluding antibiotics, antibiotic resistance, and multi-drug efflux pumping. A \nlarge proportion of these genes being attributable to Aquificae, and \nProteobacteria (very few were ascribed to Archaea), it could be worth exploring \nin the future whether antibiosis helped the Aquificae overcome niche overlap \nwith other thermophiles (especially those belonging to Archaea), besides \nexacerbating the bioenergetic costs of thermal endurance for the mesophilic \nintruders of the ecosystem.\n\nCopyright: © 2024 Mondal et al. Therefore, a hypothesis was made that higher urinary and \nvaginal microbiome diversity would be associated with increased urinary \nincontinence severity.\nOBJECTIVE: This study aimed to test whether specific urinary or vaginal \nmicrobiome community types are associated with urinary incontinence severity in \na population of women with mixed urinary incontinence.\nSTUDY DESIGN: This planned secondary, cross-sectional analysis evaluated \nassociations between the urinary and vaginal microbiomes and urinary \nincontinence severity in a subset of Effects of Surgical Treatment Enhanced With \nExercise for Mixed Urinary Incontinence trial participants with urinary \nincontinence. Incontinence severity was measured using bladder diaries and \nUrinary Distress Inventory questionnaires collected at baseline. Catheterized \nurine samples and vaginal swabs were concurrently collected before treatment at \nbaseline to assess the urinary and vaginal microbiomes. Of note, 16S rRNA V4 to \nV6 variable regions were sequenced, characterizing bacterial taxa to the genus \nlevel using the DADA2 pipeline and SILVA database. Using Dirichlet multinomial \nmixtures methods, samples were clustered into community types based on core \ntaxa. Associations between community types and severity measures (Urinary \nDistress Inventory total scores, Urinary Distress Inventory subscale scores, and \nthe number of urinary incontinence episodes [total, urgency, and stress] from \nthe bladder diary) were evaluated using linear regression models adjusted for \nage and body mass index. The analysis of \nurinary incontinence severity in 126 participants with mixed urinary \nincontinence identified a Lactobacillus-dominated reference group with the \nhighest abundance of Lactobacillus (mean relative abundance of 76%). A community \ncharacterized by fewer Lactobacilli (mean relative abundance of 19%) and greater \nalpha diversity was associated with higher total urinary incontinence episodes \n(2.67 daily leaks; 95% confidence interval, 0.76-4.59; P=.007) and urgency \nurinary incontinence episodes (1.75 daily leaks; 95% confidence interval, \n0.24-3.27; P=.02) than the reference group. No significant association was \nobserved between community type and stress urinary incontinence episodes or \nUrogenital Distress Inventory total or subscores. The composition of vaginal \ncommunity types and urinary community types were similar but composed of \nslightly different bacterial taxa. Vaginal community types were not associated \nwith urinary incontinence severity, as measured by bladder diary or Urogenital \nDistress Inventory total and subscale scores. Alpha diversity indicated that \ngreater sample richness was associated with more incontinence episodes (observed \ngenera P=.01) in urine. Measures of evenness (Shannon and Pielou) were not \nassociated with incontinence severity in the urinary or vaginal microbiomes.\nCONCLUSION: In the urobiome of women with mixed urinary incontinence, a \ncommunity type with fewer Lactobacilli and more diverse bacteria was associated \nwith more severe urinary incontinence episodes (total and urgency) compared with \na community type with high predominance of a single genus, Lactobacillus. \nWhether mixed urinary incontinence severity is due to lesser predominance of \nLactobacillus, greater presence of other non-Lactobacillus genera, or the \ncomplement of bacteria consisting of urobiome community types remains to be \ndetermined.\n\nCopyright © 2023. Biofilm. 2025 Apr 16;9:100281. doi: 10.1016/j.bioflm.2025.100281. eCollection \n2025 Jun.\n\nPMA-qPCR to quantify viable cells in multispecies oral biofilm after \ndisinfectant treatments.\n\nSchwendener S(1), Flury M(1), Jenzer J(1), Thurnheer T(1), Karygianni L(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Clinic of Conservative and Preventive Dentistry, Center for Dental Medicine, \nUniversity of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland.\n\nConventional quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) amplifies DNA from viable and \ndead cells, which can lead to an overestimation of live bacteria. Viability qPCR \naims to eliminate DNA from membrane-compromised cells through treatment with \npropidium monoazide (PMA). Here, we evaluated PMA-qPCR to enumerate viable cells \nof Actinomyces oris, Fusobacterium nucleatum, Streptococcus oralis, \nStreptococcus mutans, and Veillonella dispar. Five-species oral biofilms were \ngrown on hydroxyapatite discs for 64\xa0h. The biofilms were exposed to 0.2\xa0% \nchlorhexidine (CHX) or 3\xa0% sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) for 2\xa0min, either once \nbefore cell harvest at 64\xa0h or six times during biofilm growth. The total and \nsingle species cells were quantified by culture (CFU) and qPCR from samples with \nand without PMA treatment before DNA extraction. For species-specific qPCR, \nTaqMan assays were applied. To determine total bacteria counts, a SYBR green \nqPCR was established using universal degenerative primers for the conserved dnaK \ngene. For biofilms treated once with CHX, the addition of PMA led to a 1 to 1.6 \nlog10 reduction in PCR counts. This closely matched CFU and PMA-qPCR counts for \ntotal bacteria and all single species, except for F. nucleatum, where PMA-qPCR \ndetected significantly more bacteria than culture. NaOCl treatment directly \naffected DNA and inhibited subsequent PCR amplification, even in samples without \nPMA. Single treatment of biofilms with 3\xa0% NaOCl and six-fold exposure of \nbiofilms to disinfectants resulted in no viable cell detection by culture. \nHowever, PMA did not completely prevent PCR amplification, indicating that \ndisinfectant efficacy measured by viability PCR could be underestimated.\n\n© 2025 The Authors.\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.bioflm.2025.100281\nPMCID: PMC12051517\nPMID: 40330624\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that they have no known \ncompeting financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared \nto influence the work reported in this paper.'},

Research on fusobacterial pathogenesis has \nmainly focused on the model strain ATCC 23726 from FNN. However, this narrow \nfocus may overlook significant behaviors of other FNN strains and those from \nother subspecies, given the genetic and phenotypic diversity within F. \nnucleatum. While ATCC 23726 is highly transformable, most other Fusobacterium \nstrains exhibit low transformation efficiency, complicating traditional gene \ndeletion methods that rely on non-replicating plasmids. To address this, we \ndeveloped a conditional plasmid system in which the RepA protein, essential for \nreplication of a pCWU6-based shuttle plasmid, is controlled by an inducible \nsystem combining an fdx promoter with a theophylline-responsive riboswitch. This \nsystem allows plasmid replication in host cells upon induction and plasmid loss \nwhen the inducer is removed, forcing chromosomal integration via homologous \nrecombination in the presence of the antibiotic thiamphenicol. We validated this \napproach by targeting the galK gene, successfully generating mutants in FNN \n(ATCC 23726, CTI-2), FNP (ATCC 10953), FNA (21_1A), and the closely related \nspecies Fusobacterium periodonticum. Incorporating a sacB counterselection \nmarker in this conditional plasmid enabled the deletion of the radD gene in \nnon-model strains. Despite this \ndiversity, most genetic research has centered on the model strain ATCC 23726, \npotentially missing key aspects of other strains' pathogenic potential. This \nstudy addresses a critical gap by developing a novel conditional plasmid system \nthat enables gene deletion in genetically recalcitrant strains of F. nucleatum. \nWe successfully deleted genes in the FNN clinical strain CTI-2, the FNA strain \n21_1A, and F. periodonticum for the first time. Our findings, particularly the \nvarying behavior of the radD gene production in coaggregation across strains, \nunderscore the complexity of F. nucleatum and the need for broader genetic \nstudies. This work advances our understanding of F. nucleatum virulence at the \nstrain level and provides a valuable tool for future bacterial genetics \nresearch.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/aem.01816-24\nPMCID: PMC11837546\nPMID: 39853127 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest."}],

In Actinomyces oris, the pilus-specific sortase SrtC2 not \nonly polymerizes FimA pilins to assemble type 2 fimbriae with CafA at the tip, \nbut it can also act as the anchoring sortase, linking both FimA polymers and \nSrtC1-catalyzed FimP polymers (type 1 fimbriae) to peptidoglycan when the \nhousekeeping sortase SrtA is inactive. To date, the structure-function \ndeterminants governing the unique substrate specificity and dual enzymatic \nactivity of SrtC2 have not been illuminated. Here, we present the crystal \nstructure of SrtC2 solved to 2.10-Å resolution. SrtC2 harbors a canonical \nsortase fold and a lid typical for class C sortases and additional features \nspecific to SrtC2. Structural, biochemical, and mutational analyses of SrtC2 \nreveal that the extended lid of SrtC2 modulates its dual activity. Specifically, \nwe demonstrate that the polymerizing activity of SrtC2 is still maintained by \nalanine-substitution, partial deletion, and replacement of the SrtC2 lid with \nthe SrtC1 lid. Strikingly, pilus incorporation of CafA is significantly reduced \nby these mutations, leading to compromised polymicrobial interactions mediated \nby CafA. In a srtA mutant, the partial deletion of the SrtC2 lid reduces surface \nanchoring of FimP polymers, and the lid-swapping mutation enhances this process, \nwhile both mutations diminish surface anchoring of FimA pili. Evidently, the \nextended lid of SrtC2 enables the enzyme the cell wall-anchoring activity in a \nsubstrate-selective fashion.\n\nCopyright © 2024 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Inc. However, little is known about \nhow these effects persist or change after slaughter, particularly in shaping the \ncarcass microbiota. This study investigated the occurrence and enumeration of \nCampylobacter, the overall bacterial community structure in carcasses from \nconventional and free-range broilers, and the influence of slaughter batch \ntiming (early versus late) on contamination and microbiota composition. A total \nof 314 post-chilling carcass samples were analyzed: 160 from conventional and \n154 from free-range production systems, each obtained from two slaughterhouses \nspecialized in their respective production methods. On each sampling day, half \nof the carcasses were collected from the first slaughtered batches, and the \nother half from the last. Campylobacter occurrence was higher in free-range \ncarcasses (96.2 %) than in conventional ones (75 %), although mean counts were \ngreater in conventional carcasses (1.8 log₁₀ CFU/ml) compared with free-range \ncarcasses (1.3 log₁₀ CFU/ml). The timing of slaughter batches did not \nsignificantly affect Campylobacter contamination levels. Sparse Partial Least \nSquares-Discriminant Analysis (sPLS-DA) revealed a clear separation between the \ncarcass microbiota of conventional and free-range broilers. Conventional \ncarcasses were enriched in common gut- and processing-related genera, including \nAliarcobacter, Lactococcus, and Pseudarthrobacter. Free-range carcasses \ndisplayed higher abundances of gut-associated taxa, including Lysinibacillus, \nComamonas, and Rikenellaceae RC9 gut group, as well as genera not typically \nassociated with the broiler gut or processing environments (Ureibacillus, \nPedobacter, Pseudoxanthomonas). Within conventional systems, early batches were \ndominated by bacteria typical of processing environments (Aliarcobacter, \nChryseobacterium, Flavobacterium). In contrast, later batches showed increased \nabundances of gut-associated and spoilage genera (Clostridium, Bacillus, \nRomboutsia, Moraxella). In free-range carcasses, later batches showed a higher \nabundance of the thermotolerant and biofilm-forming Anoxybacillus. Overall, \nthese findings highlight distinct microbial signatures and Campylobacter \ncontamination patterns between production systems and emphasize that \nslaughter-related factors, particularly processing time, further shape carcass \nmicrobiota composition.\n\nCopyright © 2025. In igneous systems, nutrient limitation is critical, as \nbiomass input relies on surface-derived fluids via tectonic fractures. Despite \ngrowing interest in subsurface habitats, little is known about ecosystems \nbeneath arid landscapes, where surface water input is limited by the low annual \nprecipitation. This study compares granitic subsurface environments beneath arid \nand humid surface ecosystems, highlighting the link between surface climate and \nsubsurface biodiversity. Functional analysis revealed \nsulphur, hydrogen, and carbon monoxide as potential inorganic electron donors. \nThese findings expand the current understanding of microbial life in the \nsubsurface of granite rocks showing the influence of surface climate on nutrient \nconditions in the deeper subsurface, providing new insights into the extent and \nfunctional capacity of terrestrial subsurface habitats and their role in global \nbiogeochemical processes.\n\n© The Author(s) 2025. While soil bacterial communities and their \ninteractions with pedo-climatic factors have been well documented, most studies \ntypically focus on broad taxonomic levels, leaving distribution and responses at \nthe genus level unexplored. This study optimized machine learning models to \npredict the distribution of dominant bacterial genera across Australia on a \ncomprehensive dataset of 1971 topsoil samples. Our high-resolution digital maps \n(~1\u2009km resolution) reveal four distinct distribution patterns for the dominant \nbacterial genera: coastal or inland enriched patterns and latitude-related \npatterns. Each genus exhibited unique responses to critical factors, including \ntemperature, precipitation, soil organic carbon (SOC), and pH. Notably, our \nfindings highlight the importance of genus-level analysis, as bacterial genera \nwithin the same phylum can respond markedly differently to pedo-climatic \nconditions. Intensive land use significantly homogenized bacteria composition \nand increased the relative abundance of Rubrobacter, RB41, Microvirga, and \nSphingomonas. Overall, this study enhances our understanding of bacterial \nmacroecological trends and offers insights for more precise interventions to \nimprove soil health and resilience against environmental changes.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s). While the rhizosphere microbiome is regarded as the second \ngenome of plants, how the indica and japonica rice rhizosphere microbial \ncommunities respond to deficit irrigation and their relationship with yield \nremain to be elucidated. Here, we conducted field experiments using 12 indica \nand 12 japonica rice varieties under full and deficit irrigation regimes. \nYield-related traits, including filled grain number, seed setting rate, \ntwo-plant yield, and thousand grain weight, were measured, and the rhizosphere \nmicrobial communities were characterized by 16S rRNA gene sequencing. In line \nwith previous studies, japonica varieties showed superior drought resistance in \nterms of yield performance. Both rice genotype and irrigation regime \nsignificantly influenced the composition and functional potential of the \nrhizosphere microbiome. Compared to indica rice, the japonica rice rhizosphere \nwas enriched with more beneficial microorganisms. Enrichment of \nnitrogen‑metabolism‑related groups, such as Microvirga and Nitrososphaeraceae, \nmay contribute to rhizosphere nitrogen cycling and support nitrogen availability \nfor the rice. Similarly, higher abundance of Streptomyces in japonica varieties \nunder drought conditions may be associated with improved drought tolerance. \nThese microbial genera were closely associated with rice yield. Moreover, the \njaponica rhizosphere microbiome was less disturbed by water limitation, showing \nhigher stability. Overall, the rhizosphere microbiome of japonica rice exhibited \nfunctional optimization under drought stress by promoting the enrichment of \nbeneficial and nitrogen-cycling microbes, thereby enhancing drought resistance \nand yield stability. This study demonstrated a significant correlation between \nrhizosphere microbial communities and rice yield, providing fundamental insights \nthat may contribute to future strategies for optimizing crop productivity \nthrough microbiome management in sustainable agriculture.\n\n© 2025. Currently, studies have examined EGT \nimport systems and its physiological roles in various organisms. Despite the \nbroad applicability of EGT, industrial production with high productivity has not \nyet been achieved. In this study, we aimed to develop fermentative production \nmethods for EGT using Corynebacterium glutamicum as a host and successfully \nachieved the highest yield of EGT (459 mg L-1) reported to date. Interestingly, batch cultivation of the CHS2 \nstrain under high osmotic pressure conditions prolonged the time for EGT \nproduction and increased the intracellular accumulation of EGT. These results \nsuggest that increasing osmotic pressure together with engineering the \nbiosynthesis of cysteine, histidine, and S-adenosylmethionine is an effective \nstrategy for enhancing EGT production in recombinant C. glutamicum harboring \nheterologous EGT biosynthesis pathways. Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. To address this challenge, recent research has increasingly shifted \ntoward biodegradation and upcycling as sustainable alternatives. Microbial \ndegradation of synthetic plastics has shown advancement. This includes the \nintroduction of novel strains like Aspergillus niger MG654699 for the 3.6% and \n5% degradation of polyethylene terephthalate and polystyrene, respectively. \nAlso, Streptomyces sp., Methylobacterium, Arthrobacter, and Sphingomonas have \nbeen studied to be responsible for mulch film degradation. Advances in \nmetagenomics have further revealed the complexity of microbial consortia for \ndriving these processes, whereas kinetic modeling has provided insights into \ndegradation rates and conditions. Building on this foundation, artificial \nintelligence and machine learning are now expediting enzyme discovery, \noptimizing degradation pathways, and enabling intelligent waste management \nsystems. Similarly, biosensors based on Vibrio fischeri and Escherichia coli \nimprove monitoring by detecting plastic monomers. Beyond degradation, the \nintegration of microbial and chemical processes has enabled the upcycling of \nplastic monomers into value-added products such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, \nvanillin, bacterial nanocellulose, fuels, and biochemicals, promoting a circular \nbioeconomy. These advances highlight a paradigm shift from waste accumulation to \nresource recovery, underscoring the potential of biotechnology and engineering \ninnovations to transform plastic management. The review concludes by \nhighlighting the challenges of scalability, environmental variability, and \npolicy support while positioning biodegradation and upcycling as integrated \nstrategies for a sustainable and resilient future.\n\n© 2025. Online ahead of print.\n\nSeasonal variations and functional insights into the urban air microbiome across \npublic transit environments at railway stations in Delhi, India.\n\nKumari SP(1), Hooda S(1), Diwan P(1), Gupta RK(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Microbiology, Ram Lal Anand College, University of Delhi, South \nCampus, Benito Juarez Marg, New Delhi, 110021, India.\n(2)Department of Microbiology, Ram Lal Anand College, University of Delhi, South \nCampus, Benito Juarez Marg, New Delhi, 110021, India. Electronic address: \nrgupta1965@yahoo.com.\n\nAirborne microbial communities play an underappreciated yet critical role in \nshaping urban environmental health, particularly in densely crowded public \ntransit systems. This study aimed to explore the taxonomic and functional \nlandscape of airborne bacteria, highlighting the seasonal disparities across \nsummer and autumn seasons, in the public transit air (railway stations) of \nDelhi, a populated megacity characterized by extreme pollution levels and one of \nthe world's busiest railway networks. Metagenomic analyses revealed distinct \nseasonal signatures in microbial community composition and diversity. Alpha \ndiversity was higher during autumn, though not statistically significant, while \nbeta diversity differed significantly between seasons. LEfSe analysis identified \nseason-specific indicator taxa, including Moraxella, Barrientosiimonas, \nMethylobacterium, for autumn and Stutzerimonas, Caulobacter, Pseudomonas for \nsummer, representing a mix of opportunistic pathogens and environmentally \nsignificant taxa. Correlation networks highlighted distinct seasonal clustering \npatterns. Resistome and virulome profiling revealed the presence of different \nresistance gene classes and virulence factor categories in abundance. \nCorrelation networks uncovered significant associations between specific genes \nand bacterial genera, suggesting ecological partitioning in gene carriage. \nTemperature and air quality index explained a part of the variance observed in \nthe taxonomic and functional dynamics. Metagenome-assembled genomes captured \nseasonally distinct taxa, and biosynthetic gene cluster screening identified 317 \ngene clusters, including terpene, RiPP-like, and hserlactone clusters. The \nfindings underscore the ecological complexity and public health relevance of \nairborne bacteria and raise concerns about their potential role in microbial \ntransmission and long-term respiratory health risks. These insights are crucial \nfor public health surveillance, urban air quality management, and guiding future \ninvestigations into the microbial safety of urban environments.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Elsevier B.V.     'abstract': '1. bioRxiv [Preprint]. 2025 Nov 5:2025.11.05.686764. doi: \n10.1101/2025.11.05.686764.\n\nInverse stable isotope labeling (InverSIL) links predicted catecholate \nsiderophore gene clusters to their products in diverse bacteria.\n\nRobes JMD(1)(2), Liebergesell TCE(1)(2), Medvedeva VP(1)(2), Puri AW(1)(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Chemistry, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, USA.\n(2)Henry Eyring Center for Cell and Genome Science, University of Utah, Salt \nLake City, Utah, USA.\n\nBacteria produce high-affinity iron-chelating secondary metabolites called \nsiderophores to access insoluble Fe(III) in their environments. Genome mining \nhas revealed many predicted siderophore biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) in \nbacterial genomes, however the structures of their siderophore products remain \nmostly undetermined. This limits our molecular-level understanding of how \nbacteria acquire iron, as well as how they interact with other taxa that may use \nthe same siderophores within bacterial communities. Here, we apply inverse \nstable isotope labeling (InverSIL) to rapidly connect predicted siderophore BGCs \nto their products. With InverSIL, bacteria are grown on 13C-substituted carbon \nsources and then fed predicted biosynthetic precursors at their natural isotopic \nabundance to identify BGC products by mass spectrometry, which removes issues \nwith the availability of isotopically substituted precursors. We use InverSIL to \ndetermine the structures of the siderophore products of predicted BGCs from the \nmethylotrophic genera Methylophilus and Methylobacterium, and the siderophores \nproduced by the opportunistic pathogen Chromobacterium violaceum, which were \npreviously shown to be essential for virulence yet remained structurally \nuncharacterized. We next use this approach to reveal the unexpected production \nof enterobactin by the genera Kushneria and Paracoccus, which was difficult to \npredict from genome sequences due to the distributed nature of the biosynthetic \ngenes within the genomes. Finally, we use InverSIL to discover new siderophores, \ncellulochelin A and B, from the cellulose-degrading plant symbiont Cellulomonas \nsp. strain Leaf334. These findings demonstrate the utility of InverSIL for \nfunctional BGC characterization and expand our molecular understanding of \nbacterial iron acquisition strategies.\n\nDOI: 10.1101/2025.11.05.686764\nPMCID: PMC12637720\nPMID: 41280040\n\nConflict of interest statement: CONFLICTS OF INTEREST The authors declare no \nconflicts of interest.'}]},

Antibiotics (Basel). 2025 Feb 27;14(3):241. doi: 10.3390/antibiotics14030241.\n\nThe Therapeutic Potential of West Indian Lemongrass (Cymbopogon citratus) \nEssential Oil-Based Ointment in the Treatment of Pitted Keratolysis.\n\nSchneider G(1), Schweitzer B(1), Steinbach AS(1), Hodován ÁS(1), Horváth M(1), \nBakó E(2)(3), Mayer A(4), Pál S(5).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Medical School, University \nof Pécs, Szigeti st. 12., H-7624 Pécs, Hungary.\n(2)Department of Pharmacognosy, Semmelweis University, Üllői st. 26., H-1085 \nBudapest, Hungary.\n(3)Centre for Translational Medicine, Semmelweis University, Üllői st. 26., \nH-1085 Budapest, Hungary.\n(4)Institute of Clinical Pharmacy, Medical School, University of Pécs, Szigeti \nst. 12., H-7624 Pécs, Hungary.\n(5)Institute of Pharmaceutical Technology and Biopharmacy, Faculty of Pharmacy, \nUniversity of Pécs, Rókus str. 2., H-7624 Pécs, Hungary.\n\nBackground: Due to their antibacterial activities, essential oils can be \npotential alternatives to antibiotics in certain cases. West Indian lemongrass \n(Cymbopogon citratus) essential oil (LEO) is effective against a broad range of \nbacteria by inhibiting spore formation, and is considered safe. In this study, \nwe demonstrated its therapeutical potential in the treatment of pitted \nkeratolysis (PK), a superficial skin infection affecting the pressure-bearing \nareas of plantar surfaces. Methods: For in vitro antibacterial efficacy testing, \nLEO was mixed into different ointment bases, including Hydrogelum \nmethylcellulose FoNo VIII., Ungentum oleosum FoNo VIII. (Ung. oleoso), Unguentum \nstearini FoNo VIII. (Ung. stearin), and Vaselinum cholesterinatum FoNo VIII. \n(Vasel. cholest.), at different concentrations of 1, 3, and 5%. These \nformulations were tested on representatives of three bacterial species \nassociated with PK: Kytococcus sedentarius, Dermatophilus congolensis, and \nBacillus thuringiensis. Results: In the in vitro tests, Hydrogelum \nmethylcellulose (HM) gel best supported the antibacterial effects of LEO, \nreducing the number of living bacteria on agar plates by 4-5 orders of magnitude \nin a concentration-dependent manner during the 30 min exposure times. This was \nalso confirmed by the Franz diffusion cell drug release test; after 30 min, \nseveral active compounds could be detected in the HM samples, in contrast to the \nother bases. Shelf-life experiments showed that the HM base supported the \nantibacterial features of 3% LEO for at least 2 years without significant loss \nof efficacy. Conclusions: Our study highlights that ointments containing \nessential oils potentially have a place in the treatment of PK. Therefore, \nantibiotics may potentially be replaced for the treatment of PK, thereby \nreducing environmental antibiotic pressure, which is one of the driving forces \nbehind the spread of antibiotic resistance.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/antibiotics14030241\nPMCID: PMC11939757\nPMID: 40149054\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.'}],

In the present study, a rapid eco-friendly \nmethod was applied to biosynthesize and optimize copper nanoparticles (CuNPs) \nfrom Kytococcus sedentarius. The CuNPs characteristics were identified using \nX-ray diffractometer (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), Fourier \nTransform infrared (FT-IR), Transmission electron microscope (TEM), \nThermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and UV-Vis spectroscope (UV-Vis). To determine \nthe maximum metabolic yield, the optimum dosage size, pH, temperature, salinity \nand cations were evaluated. Bacteria were \nisolated seasonally from healthy trees (root, stem, bark, trunk, leaf, and crown \ntissues) in four regions of Hormozgan province (i.e., Ahmadi, Siyahoo, Sikhoran, \nRoudan), a subtropical hot region in Iran. A total of 742 strains from 17 taxa, \n3 phyla, and 5 orders were found, most of which belonged to Actinobacteria \n(Actinobacteriales) as the dominant group, followed by Firmicutes (Bacillales), \nProteobacteria (Sphingomonadales, Rhizobiales), and Cyanobacteria \n(Synechoccales). The genera included Altererythrobacter, Arthrobacter, Bacillus, \nCellulosimicrobium, Curtobacterium, Kocuria, Kytococcus, Methylopila, \nMycobacterium, Nocardioides, Okiabacterium, Paracraurococcus, and \nPsychrobacillus. The most frequently occurring species included Psychrobacillus \npsychrodurans, Kytococcus schroetri, and Bacillus cereus. In addition, the \noverall colonization frequency and variability of endophytes were higher on the \ntrunks. The leaves showed the lowest species variability in all sampling \nperiods. The frequency of endophyte colonization was also higher in summer. The \nShannon-Wiener (H') and Simpson indices varied with all factors, i.e., region, \nseason, and tissue type, with the maximum in Roudan. Furthermore, 52.9% of the \nstrains were capable of nitrogen fixation, and 70% produced antagonistic \nhydrogen cyanide (HCN). Thus, C. reticulata harbors a variety of bioactive \nbacterial endophytes that could be beneficial for host fitness in such harsh \nenvironments.\n\n© 2024. The \ninvolvement of the non-H. pylori gastric microbiota in this mechanism remains to \nbe examined. RNA sequencing data, clinical information, and DNA methylation data \nwere obtained from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) STAD project. The Kraken 2 \npipeline was employed to explore the microbiome profiles. The microbiome was \nassociated with occurrence, distal metastasis, and prognosis, and differential \nmethylation changes related to distal metastasis and prognosis were analyzed. \nBi-directional mediation effects of the intratumoral microbiome and host DNA \nmethylation changes on the metastasis and prognosis of STAD were identified by \nmediation analysis. The expression of the ZNF215 gene was verified by real-time \nquantitative PCR (RT-qPCR). Our analysis revealed \nthat H. pylori and other cancer-related microorganisms were related to the \noccurrence, progression, or prognosis of STAD. The related methylated genes were \nparticularly enriched in related cancer pathways. Kytococcus sedentarius and \nActinomyces oris, which interacted strongly with methylation changes in immune \ngenes, were associated with prognosis. Cell experiments verified that \nStaphylococcus saccharolyticus could promote the proliferation and cloning of \ngastric cells by regulating the gene expression level of the ZNF215 gene. Our \nstudy suggested that the bi-directional mediation effect between intratumoral \nmicroorganisms and host epigenetics was key to the distal metastasis of cancer \ncells and survival deterioration in the tumor microenvironment of stomach \ntissues of patients with STAD. IMPORTANCE The burgeoning field of oncobiome \nresearch declared that members of the intratumoral microbiome besides \nHelicobacter pylori existed in tumor tissues and participated in the occurrence \nand development of gastric cancer, and the methylation of host DNA may be a \npotential target of microbes and their metabolites. Current research focuses \nmostly on species composition, but the functional genes of the members of the \nmicrobiota are also key to their interaction with the host. Therefore, we \nfocused on characterizing the species composition and functional gene \ncomposition of microbes in gastric cancer, and we suggest that microbes may \nfurther participate in the occurrence and development of cancer by influencing \nabnormal epigenetic changes in the host. Some key bioinformatics analysis \nresults were verified by in vitro experiments. Thus, we consider that the tumor \nmicrobiota-host epigenetic axis of gastric cancer microorganisms and the host \nexplains the mechanism of the microbiota participating in cancer occurrence and \ndevelopment, and we make some verifiable experimental predictions.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/spectrum.00904-23\nPMCID: PMC10434028\nPMID: 37260411 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest.'}],

Infect Dis Rep. 2021 Mar 14;13(1):230-238. doi: 10.3390/idr13010026.\n\nInsight into Kytococcus schroeteri Infection Management: A Case Report and \nReview.\n\nBagelman S(1), Zvigule-Neidere G(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)International Students Department, Riga Stradins University, LV-1007 Riga, \nLatvia.\n(2)Department of Pediatrics, Riga Stradins University, LV-1007 Riga, Latvia.\n\nBACKGROUND: Kytococcus schroeteri is a member of normal skin microflora, which \ncan cause lethal infections in immunosuppressed hosts. In this review we \nattempted to draw patterns of its pathogenicity, which seem to vary regarding \nhost immune status and the presence of implantable devices. Evidence suggests \nthis pathogen houses many resistance-forming proteins, which serve to exacerbate \nthe challenge in curing it. Available information on K. schroeteri antibacterial \nsusceptibility is scarce. In this situation, a novel, genome-based antibiotic \nresistance analysis model, previously suggested by Su et al., could aid \nclinicians dealing with unknown infections. In this study we merged data from \nobserved antibiotic resistance patterns with resistance data demonstrated by DNA \nsequences.\nMETHODS: We reviewed all available articles and reports on K. schroeteri, from \npeer-reviewed online databases (ClinicalKey, PMC, Scopus and WebOfScience). \nInformation on patients was then subdivided into patient profiles and tabulated \nindependently. We later performed K. schroeteri genome sequence analysis for \nresistance proteins to understand the trends K. schroeteri exhibits.\nRESULTS: K. schroeteri is resistant to beta-lactams, macrolides and clindamycin. \nIt is susceptible to aminoglycosides, tetracyclines and rifampicin. We combined \ndata from the literature review and sequence analysis and found evidence for the \nexistence of PBP, PBP-2A and efflux pumps as likely determinants of K. \nschroeteri.\nCONCLUSIONS: Reviewing the data permits the speculation that baseline immune \nstatus plays a role in the outcome of a Kytococcal infection. West Indian lemongrass \n(Cymbopogon citratus) essential oil (LEO) is effective against a broad range of \nbacteria by inhibiting spore formation, and is considered safe. In this study, \nwe demonstrated its therapeutical potential in the treatment of pitted \nkeratolysis (PK), a superficial skin infection affecting the pressure-bearing \nareas of plantar surfaces. Methods: For in vitro antibacterial efficacy testing, \nLEO was mixed into different ointment bases, including Hydrogelum \nmethylcellulose FoNo VIII., Ungentum oleosum FoNo VIII. (Ung. oleoso), Unguentum \nstearini FoNo VIII. (Ung. stearin), and Vaselinum cholesterinatum FoNo VIII. \n(Vasel. cholest.), at different concentrations of 1, 3, and 5%. These \nformulations were tested on representatives of three bacterial species \nassociated with PK: Kytococcus sedentarius, Dermatophilus congolensis, and \nBacillus thuringiensis. Results: In the in vitro tests, Hydrogelum \nmethylcellulose (HM) gel best supported the antibacterial effects of LEO, \nreducing the number of living bacteria on agar plates by 4-5 orders of magnitude \nin a concentration-dependent manner during the 30 min exposure times. This was \nalso confirmed by the Franz diffusion cell drug release test; after 30 min, \nseveral active compounds could be detected in the HM samples, in contrast to the \nother bases. Shelf-life experiments showed that the HM base supported the \nantibacterial features of 3% LEO for at least 2 years without significant loss \nof efficacy. Conclusions: Our study highlights that ointments containing \nessential oils potentially have a place in the treatment of PK. Therefore, \nantibiotics may potentially be replaced for the treatment of PK, thereby \nreducing environmental antibiotic pressure, which is one of the driving forces \nbehind the spread of antibiotic resistance.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/antibiotics14030241\nPMCID: PMC11939757\nPMID: 40149054\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.'},

The CuNPs characteristics were identified using \nX-ray diffractometer (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), Fourier \nTransform infrared (FT-IR), Transmission electron microscope (TEM), \nThermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and UV-Vis spectroscope (UV-Vis). To determine \nthe maximum metabolic yield, the optimum dosage size, pH, temperature, salinity \nand cations were evaluated. The CuNPs were thermally stable \nthan the bioflocculant as over 80\xa0% of its flocculating activity was retained \neven at high temperatures (121\xa0°C). Acta Dermatovenerol Croat. 2018 Apr;26(1):68-70.\n\nTatami Mats: A Source of Pitted Keratolysis in a Martial Arts Athlete?\n\nBalić A, Bukvić Mokos Z, Marinović B, Ledić Drvar D(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Daniela Ledić Drvar, MD, PhD, University Hospital Centre Zagreb, Department \nof Dermatology and Venereology, School of Medicine University of Zagreb, Šalata \n4, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; daniela.ledic.drvar1@zg.t-com.hr.\n\nDear Editor, Pitted keratolysis (PK), also known as keratosis plantaris \nsulcatum, is a non-inflammatory, bacterial, superficial cutaneous infection, \ncharacterized by many discrete superficial crateriform ''pits'' and erosions in \nthe thickly keratinized skin of the weight-bearing regions of the soles of the \nfeet (1). The disease often goes unnoticed by the patient, but when it is \nnoticed it is because of the unbearable malodor and hyperhidrosis of the feet, \nwhich are socially unacceptable and cause great anxiety to many of the patients. \nPK occurs worldwide, with the incidence rates varying based on the environment \nand occupation. The prevalence of this condition does not differ significantly \nbased on age, sex, or race. People who sweat profusely or wash excessively, who \nwear occlusive footwear, or are barefoot especially in hot and humid weather are \nextremely prone to this condition (2). Physicians commonly misdiagnose it as \ntinea pedis or plantar warts. Treatment is quite simple and straightforward, \nwith an excellent expected outcome if treated properly. We report a case of a \n32-year-old male patient with skin changes of approximately one-year duration \ndiagnosed as plantar verrucae, who was referred to our Department for \ncryotherapy. The patient presented with asymptomatic, malodorous punched-out \npits and erosions along with hyperkeratotic skin on the heel and metatarsal \nregion of the plantar aspect of both feet. The arches, toes, and sides of the \nfeet were spared (Figure 1). Except for these skin changes, the patient was \nhealthy and denied any other medical issues. He was an athlete active in martial \narts and had a history of sweating of feet and training barefoot on the tatami \nmat for extended periods of time. The diagnosis of PK was established based on \nthe clinical findings (crateriform pitting and malodor), negative KOH test for \nhyphae, and a history of prolonged sweating in addition to contact of the skin \nwith tatami mats, which are often a source of infection if hygiene measures are \nnot adequately implemented. Swabs could have been helpful to identify causative \norganisms, but they were not crucial for the diagnosis and treatment. The \npatient was prescribed with general measures to prevent excessive sweating \n(cotton socks, open footwear, and proper hygiene), antiseptic potassium \npermanganate foot soaks followed by clindamycin 1% and benzoyl peroxide 5% in a \ngel vehicle twice daily. At the one-month follow-up visit, the skin changes, \nhyperhidrosis, and malodor were entirely resolved (Figure 2). Pitted keratolysis \nis common among athletes (3,4). The manifestations of PK are due to a \nsuperficial cutaneous infection caused by several bacterial Gram-positive \nspecies including Corynebacterium species, Kytococcus sedentarius, Dermatophilus \ncongolensis, Actynomices keratolytica, and Streptomyces that proliferate and \nproduce proteinase and sulfur-compound by-products under appropriate moist \nconditions (5-7). Proteinases digest the keratin and destroy the stratum \ncorneum, producing the characteristic skin findings, while sulfur compounds \n(sulfides, thiols, and thioesters) are responsible for the malodor. Athletes and \nsoldiers who wear occlusive footwear for prolonged periods of time or even \nbarefooted people that sweat extensively and spend time on wet surfaces such as \nlaborers, farmers, and marine workers are more prone to this problem (3,4,8-11). \nMartial arts athletes are at greater risk of skin infections due to the constant \nphysical contact that can lead to transmission of viral, bacterial, and fungal \npathogens directly but also indirectly through contact with the mat and the skin \nflora of an another infected individual. A national survey of the epidemiology \nof skin infections among US high school athletes conducted by Ashack et al. \nsupported the prevalent theory that contact sports are associated with an \nincreased risk of skin infections. In this study, wrestling had the highest skin \ninfection rate of predominantly bacterial origin (53.8%), followed by tinea \n(35.7%) and herpetic lesions (6.7%), which is consistent with other literature \nreporting (12). Being barefoot on the tatami mat in combination with excessive \nsweating and non-compliance with hygiene measures makes martial arts athletes \nmore susceptible to skin infections, including PK. The diagnosis is clinical, by \nmeans of visual examination and recognition of the characteristic odor. \nDermoscopy can be useful, revealing abundant pits with well-marked walls that \nsometimes show the bacterial colonies (13). Cultures, if taken, show \nGram-positive bacilli or coccobacilli. Because of the ease of diagnosis on \nclinical findings, biopsy of pitted keratolysis is rarely performed. Skin \nscraping is often performed to exclude tinea pedis, which is one of the main \ndifferential diagnosis, the others including verrucae, punctate palmoplantar \nkeratoderma, keratolysis exfoliativa, circumscribed palmoplantar hypokeratosis, \nand basal cell nevus syndrome. If unrecognized and left untreated, skin findings \nand smelly feet can last for many years. Sometimes, if unrecognized, PK can be \nmistreated with antifungals, or even with aggressive treatment modalities such \nas cryotherapy. Appropriate treatment includes keeping feet dry with adequate \ntreatment of hyperhidrosis, preventive measures, and topical antibiotic therapy. \nTopical forms of salicylic acid, sulfur, antibacterial soaps, neomycin, \nerythromycin, mupirocin, clindamycin and benzoyl peroxide, clotrimazole, \nimidazoles, and injectable botulinum toxin are all successful in treatment and \nprevention of PK (14,15). Topical antibiotics are the first line of medical \ntreatment, among which fusidic acid, erythromycin 1% (solution or gel), \nmupirocin 2%, or clindamycin are the most recommended (14). As in our case, a \nfixed combination of two approved topical drugs - clindamycin 1%-benzoyl \nperoxide 5% gel, had been already demonstrated by Vlahovich et al. as an \nexcellent treatment option with high adherence and no side-effect (16). The \ncombined effect of this combination showed signiﬁcantly greater effect due to \nthe bactericidal and keratolytic properties of benzoyl peroxide. Additionally, \nthis combination also lowers the risk of resistance of causative microorganisms \nto clindamycin. Skin infections are an important aspect of sports-related \nadverse events. Due to the interdisciplinary nature, dermatologists are not the \nonly ones who should be aware of the disease, but also family medicine doctors, \nsports medicine specialists, and occupational health doctors who should educate \npatients about the etiology of the skin disorder, adequate prevention, and \ntreatment. Athletes must enforce the disinfecting and sanitary cleaning of the \ntatami mats and other practice areas. Keeping up with these measures could \nsignificantly limit the spread of skin infections that can infect athletes \nindirectly, leading to significant morbidity, time loss from competition, and \nsocial anxiety as well.\n\nPMID: 29782305 [Indexed for MEDLINE]"}],

The \ninvolvement of the non-H. pylori gastric microbiota in this mechanism remains to \nbe examined. RNA sequencing data, clinical information, and DNA methylation data \nwere obtained from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) STAD project. The Kraken 2 \npipeline was employed to explore the microbiome profiles. The microbiome was \nassociated with occurrence, distal metastasis, and prognosis, and differential \nmethylation changes related to distal metastasis and prognosis were analyzed. \nBi-directional mediation effects of the intratumoral microbiome and host DNA \nmethylation changes on the metastasis and prognosis of STAD were identified by \nmediation analysis. Our \nstudy suggested that the bi-directional mediation effect between intratumoral \nmicroorganisms and host epigenetics was key to the distal metastasis of cancer \ncells and survival deterioration in the tumor microenvironment of stomach \ntissues of patients with STAD. IMPORTANCE The burgeoning field of oncobiome \nresearch declared that members of the intratumoral microbiome besides \nHelicobacter pylori existed in tumor tissues and participated in the occurrence \nand development of gastric cancer, and the methylation of host DNA may be a \npotential target of microbes and their metabolites. Current research focuses \nmostly on species composition, but the functional genes of the members of the \nmicrobiota are also key to their interaction with the host. Therefore, we \nfocused on characterizing the species composition and functional gene \ncomposition of microbes in gastric cancer, and we suggest that microbes may \nfurther participate in the occurrence and development of cancer by influencing \nabnormal epigenetic changes in the host. Some key bioinformatics analysis \nresults were verified by in vitro experiments. Thus, we consider that the tumor \nmicrobiota-host epigenetic axis of gastric cancer microorganisms and the host \nexplains the mechanism of the microbiota participating in cancer occurrence and \ndevelopment, and we make some verifiable experimental predictions.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/spectrum.00904-23\nPMCID: PMC10434028\nPMID: 37260411 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare no conflict of interest.'},
