Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. To address this challenge, recent research has increasingly shifted \ntoward biodegradation and upcycling as sustainable alternatives. Microbial \ndegradation of synthetic plastics has shown advancement. This includes the \nintroduction of novel strains like Aspergillus niger MG654699 for the 3.6% and \n5% degradation of polyethylene terephthalate and polystyrene, respectively. \nAlso, Streptomyces sp., Methylobacterium, Arthrobacter, and Sphingomonas have \nbeen studied to be responsible for mulch film degradation. Advances in \nmetagenomics have further revealed the complexity of microbial consortia for \ndriving these processes, whereas kinetic modeling has provided insights into \ndegradation rates and conditions. Building on this foundation, artificial \nintelligence and machine learning are now expediting enzyme discovery, \noptimizing degradation pathways, and enabling intelligent waste management \nsystems. Similarly, biosensors based on Vibrio fischeri and Escherichia coli \nimprove monitoring by detecting plastic monomers. Beyond degradation, the \nintegration of microbial and chemical processes has enabled the upcycling of \nplastic monomers into value-added products such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, \nvanillin, bacterial nanocellulose, fuels, and biochemicals, promoting a circular \nbioeconomy. These advances highlight a paradigm shift from waste accumulation to \nresource recovery, underscoring the potential of biotechnology and engineering \ninnovations to transform plastic management. Sports (Basel). 2025 Aug 26;13(9):288. doi: 10.3390/sports13090288.\n\nThe Skin Microbiome Profile of Contact Sports Athletes-Focus on Sexual \nDimorphism and Athlete-Non-Athlete Differences.\n\nKalabiska I(1), Annar D(1), Babszky G(1)(2), Jokai M(1)(2), Borbas Z(1)(3), \nHajdu G(1)(3), Ratz-Sulyok FZ(4)(5), Jang-Kapuy C(4)(5), Palinkas G(1), Bhattoa \nHP(6), Zsakai A(5)(7).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Research Center for Sport Physiology, Hungarian University of Sports Science, \nAlkotas u. 44, 1123 Budapest, Hungary.\n(2)Kozma Istvan Hungarian Wrestling Academy, Hollandi u. 8, 1213 Budapest, \nHungary.\n(3)Physical Training, Regulation, Metabolism Programme, School of Doctoral \nStudies, Hungarian University of Sports Science, Alkotas u. 44, 1123 Budapest, \nHungary.\n(4)Neuroscience and Human Biology Programme, Doctoral School of Biology, Eotvos \nLorand University (ELTE), Pazmany P. s. 1/c, 1117 Budapest, Hungary.\n(5)Department of Biological Anthropology, Eotvos Lorand University (ELTE), \nPazmany P. s. 1/c, 1117 Budapest, Hungary.\n(6)Department of Laboratory Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, University of \nDebrecen, Nagyerdei Blvd. 98, 4032 Debrecen, Hungary.\n(7)Health Promotion and Education Research Team, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, \nPazmany P. s. 1/c, 1117 Budapest, Hungary.\n\nBACKGROUND: Athletes\' skin is exposed to increased microbial challenges due to \nrigorous physical activity, perspiration, constant "skin-to-skin" contact, \nfrequent showering, use of hygiene products, and environmental factors present \nin training settings. This study aims to characterize the skin microbiome \ncommunities of young wrestlers and kickboxers in comparison with their \nnon-athlete age-peers.\nMETHODS: A total of 56 combat sport athletes (30 males and 26 females, mean age \n± SD = 18.2 ± 1.5 years) and 25 non-athlete youths (control group: 13 males and \n12 females, mean age ± SD = 19.8 ± 1.2 years) voluntarily consented to \nparticipate in the study conducted by our research team in 2023 and 2024. The \nskin microbiome analysis involved standardized sampling, DNA isolation, \nmolecular sequencing, and bioinformatic analysis, thus enabling detailed \ncharacterization and comparison of the skin microbial community in contact \nsports athletes and the control group.\nRESULTS: Our results revealed notable sexual dimorphism in the skin microbiome \ncomposition of youth. Males showed a higher relative abundance of bacterial \ngenera associated with nosocomial infections and respiratory diseases, while \nfemales had more skin inflammation- and infection-related genera (relative \nabundances in males vs. in females: Corynebacterium-12.0 vs. 7.2; \nLuteimonas-4.4. vs. 1.4; Paracoccus-8.8 vs. 5.0; Psychrobacter-6.3 vs. 4.4; \nCutibacterium-6.4 vs. 11.4; Kocuria-1.6 vs. 3.9; Micrococcus-5.8 vs. 8.5; \nPseudomonas-1.2 vs. 3.4; Streptococcus 3.3 vs. 6.2). We also found skin \nmicrobiome differences between athletes and non-athletes in both sexes: \nwrestlers, who experience frequent skin-to-skin contact and wear less covering \nsportswear, had microbiome profiles distinct from both kickboxers and \nnon-athletes (relative abundances in athletes vs. in non-athletes: \nPsychrobacter-7.3 vs. 0.4; Staphylococcus 9.5 vs. 18.5; predominance of genera \nby sports type: relative abundance of Cutibacterium and Streptococcus was higher \nin kickboxers, and relative abundance of Acinetobacter, Enhydrobacter, \nMicrococcus, and Enhydrobacter was higher in wrestlers). Bacteria linked to skin \ninfections (e.g., Aliterella, Arthrobacter, and Empedobacter) were present in \naround 30% of wrestlers and kickboxers but were absent in the control group.\nCONCLUSIONS: These results underscore the heightened risk of skin infections in \ncontact sports and highlight the importance of regular microbiome monitoring and \nhygiene protocols among young athletes.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/sports13090288\nPMCID: PMC12473315\nPMID: 41003594\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that they have no competing \ninterests.'}],

Curr Res Microb Sci. 2025 Nov 14;9:100511. doi: 10.1016/j.crmicr.2025.100511. \neCollection 2025.\n\nHalophytes as holobionts: disentangling the contribution of plant genotype and \nenvironmental factors to the associated microbiome of hydro- and xerohalophytes.\n\nPajuelo E(1), Romano-Rodríguez E(2), Mateos-Naranjo E(2), Flores-Duarte NJ(2), \nRodríguez-Llorente ID(1), Redondo-Gómez S(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Departamento de Microbiología y Parasitología, Facultad de Farmacia, \nUniversidad de Sevilla, 41012 Sevilla, Spain.\n(2)Departamento de Biología Vegetal y Ecología, Facultad de Biología, \nUniversidad de Sevilla, 41012 Sevilla, Spain.\n\nHalophytes are of great interest for their ecosystemic benefits and valuable \nsecondary metabolites. However, they are threatened by factors such as heat \nwaves, drought, increased salinity and pollution, associated with climate change \nand human activity. In this context, their associated microbial communities are \ncrucial for their survival. Despite that, there are no comparative studies on \nmicrobial communities associated with two types of halophytes: hydrohalophytes \n(plants from humid saline environments) and xerohalophytes (plants from saline \narid environments). This study aimed to investigate the factors that determine \nthe structure of microbial communities of three hydrohalophytes of the Southwest \nSpain (Atlantic coastal), in particular Atriplex portulacoides, Salicornia \nperennis and Suaeda vera; and three xerohalophytes of Southeast Spain \n(Mediterranean coast and inland saltmarshes), namely, Atriplex glauca, Anabasis \narticulata and Halocnemum strobilaceum. Samples were collected in three \nlocations and two seasons (autumn and spring) to analyze how plant genetics and \nenvironmental factors influence their microbiota. The analysis was done by \nsequencing the 16S V3-V4 region in samples of different plant compartments: \nendophytes, rhizosphere soils and bare soils. The results showed strong \nattraction of bacteria and archaea to the rhizosphere, although further tight \nselection limits the number of endophytes. A "core" of endophytes common to both \nfunctional halophytes was identified, including the genera Kushneria, Halomonas, \nPseudoalteromonas and Zunongwangia, which were considered generalists. In \naddition, specific genera considered as specialists were found: hydrohalophytes \nshowed affinity for Vibrio, Pseudomonas and Marinomonas, while xerohalophytes \nharbored Marinilactobacillus, Alkalicoccus, Alkalibacterium and Arthrobacter. \nAlthough most endophytes persist across seasons, their relative abundances can \nchange for better adaptation. Clear differences were also encountered among the \nrhizosphere inhabitants in both functional halophytes: whereas halophilic \nammonia oxidizing archaea were prevalent in the rhizosphere of hydrohalophytes, \nversatile adaptive bacteria were predominant in that of xerohalophytes. These \nmicroorganisms play vital roles, including promoting plant growth, participating \nin the carbon and nitrogen metabolisms, and recycling organic matter. In \nconclusion, the study determined that the main factors shaping the microbial \npopulations associated to halophytes were: halophyte type > halophyte species > \nsoil characteristics > seasonality.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.crmicr.2025.100511\nPMCID: PMC12681888\nPMID: 41362317\n\nConflict of interest statement: Halophytes are of great interest for their \necosystemic benefits and valuable secondary metabolites. However, they are \nthreatened by factors associated with climate change and human activity. In this \ncontext, their associated microbial communities are crucial for their survival. \nDespite that, there are no comparative studies on microbial communities \nassociated two types of functional halophytes: hydro- and xero-halophytes, \nliving in marine and arid saline environments. This study aimed to fill this gap \nof knowledge by studying the microbial populations associated to six halophytes \nin two regions and two seasons. The results showed strong attraction of bacteria \nand archaea to the rhizosphere, although further tight selection limits the \nnumber of endophytes. These microorganisms play vital roles, including promoting \nplant growth, participating in the carbon and nitrogen metabolisms, and \nrecycling organic matter. Moreover, many of the bacteria associated to \nhalophytes are important agrotools to improve crop resilience under increasing \nsoil salinity.'},

Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. To address this challenge, recent research has increasingly shifted \ntoward biodegradation and upcycling as sustainable alternatives. Microbial \ndegradation of synthetic plastics has shown advancement. This includes the \nintroduction of novel strains like Aspergillus niger MG654699 for the 3.6% and \n5% degradation of polyethylene terephthalate and polystyrene, respectively. \nAlso, Streptomyces sp., Methylobacterium, Arthrobacter, and Sphingomonas have \nbeen studied to be responsible for mulch film degradation. Advances in \nmetagenomics have further revealed the complexity of microbial consortia for \ndriving these processes, whereas kinetic modeling has provided insights into \ndegradation rates and conditions. Building on this foundation, artificial \nintelligence and machine learning are now expediting enzyme discovery, \noptimizing degradation pathways, and enabling intelligent waste management \nsystems. Similarly, biosensors based on Vibrio fischeri and Escherichia coli \nimprove monitoring by detecting plastic monomers. Beyond degradation, the \nintegration of microbial and chemical processes has enabled the upcycling of \nplastic monomers into value-added products such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, \nvanillin, bacterial nanocellulose, fuels, and biochemicals, promoting a circular \nbioeconomy. These advances highlight a paradigm shift from waste accumulation to \nresource recovery, underscoring the potential of biotechnology and engineering \ninnovations to transform plastic management. The review concludes by \nhighlighting the challenges of scalability, environmental variability, and \npolicy support while positioning biodegradation and upcycling as integrated \nstrategies for a sustainable and resilient future.\n\n© 2025. Microorganisms. 2025 Oct 31;13(11):2513. doi: 10.3390/microorganisms13112513.\n\nMetagenome-Based Functional Differentiation of Gut Microbiota and Ecological \nAdaptation Among Geographically Distinct Populations of Przewalski's Gazelle \n(Procapra przewalskii).\n\nZhang J(1)(2), Jiang F(2)(3), Li X(1), Song P(2)(3), Zhang T(2)(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)State Key Laboratory of Plateau Ecology and Agriculture, Qinghai University, \nXining 810016, China.\n(2)Qinghai Provincial Key Laboratory of Animal Ecological Genomics, Xining \n810001, China.\n(3)Key Laboratory of Adaptation and Evolution of Plateau Biota, Northwest \nInstitute of Plateau Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xining 810001, China.\n\nPrzewalski's gazelle (Procapra przewalskii) is an endangered ungulate endemic to \nthe Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, with a small population size and exposure to multiple \necological pressures. Its gut microbiota may play a crucial role in host \nenvironmental adaptation. To investigate the functional divergence of gut \nmicrobial communities, we performed high-throughput metagenomic sequencing on \n105 wild fecal samples collected from 10 geographic regions around Qinghai Lake. \nThe results revealed significant regional differentiation in key functional \nmodules related to metabolism, antibiotic resistance mechanisms, and \nvirulence-associated pathways. All populations showed enrichment in core \nmetabolic pathways such as carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism, with \ncarbohydrate-active enzymes dominated by glycoside hydrolases (GHs) and \nglycosyltransferases (GTs), exhibiting overall functional conservation. Although \npopulations shared many antibiotic- and virulence-related reference genetic \nmarkers, the marker composition associated with distinct resistance mechanisms \nand pathogenic processes exhibited clear population-specific patterns, \nsuggesting differential microbial responses to local environmental pressures. \nCorrelation network analysis further identified core taxa (e.g., Arthrobacter \nand Oscillospiraceae/Bacteroidales lineages) as key genera linking community \nstructure with core metabolic, resistance-related, and virulence-associated \nmarker functions. Overall, the gut microbiota of Przewalski's gazelle exhibits a \ncomplex spatially structured functional differentiation, reflecting \nhost-microbiome co-adaptation under region-specific ecological pressures. These \nfindings provide critical methodological and theoretical support for \nmicroecological health assessment and regionally informed conservation \nmanagement of this endangered species.\n\nDOI: 10.3390/microorganisms13112513\nPMCID: PMC12654606\nPMID: 41304199\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest."},

J Hazard Mater. 2025 Nov 23;500:140589. doi: 10.1016/j.jhazmat.2025.140589. \nOnline ahead of print.\n\nBiodegradation of PVC by novel bacterial consortia isolated from municipal solid \nwaste dumpsite.\n\nHatwar N(1), Qureshi A(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Sustainable Environmental Processes, Environmental Bioprocesses, CSIR-NEERI \n(National Environmental Engineering Research Institute) Campus, Nagpur 440020, \nIndia; Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, \nIndia.\n(2)Sustainable Environmental Processes, Environmental Bioprocesses, CSIR-NEERI \n(National Environmental Engineering Research Institute) Campus, Nagpur 440020, \nIndia; Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, \nIndia. Electronic address: a_qureshi@neeri.res.in.\n\nIn view of environmental issues related to Polyvinyl chloride (PVC), attempts \nhave been made in the present study, to enrich and isolate novel bacteria from \nlandfill dumpsites, capable of degrading PVC with reduced emissions. A potential \nbacterial consortium (NH_AQ) was designed, which comprised of Lysinibacillus \nspp., Bacillus spp., Staphylococcus spp., Exiguobacterium spp., and Arthrobacter \nspp. Metagenomic analysis of landfill soils indicated predominance of these \nbacterial species, which ensured that the culturable bacteria could be isolated \nfrom landfill sites for PVC degradation. This study was carried out at three \ntemperatures (ambient, 37°C and 50°C). The percentage weight reduction of PVC \nfilms was 31.45\u202f% ± 2 at 37°C. SEM-EDX showed external erosion and changes in \nchemical element composition, due to growth of bacteria as biofilms on PVC films \nat 37\u202f°C. FTIR study confirmed oxidation and dechlorination happening during PVC \nutilization. TGA analysis indicated PVC thermal shifts in presence of consortia \nand ion chromatography too showed a significant reduction in chlorine content. \nOverall findings demonstrated that the designed NH_AQ consortium could degrade \nPVC effectively, offering a promising and sustainable approach to mitigate PVC \npollution through microbial action in future.\n\nCopyright © 2025. These toxins may exceed safe consumption \nlimits and cause adverse health effects in processed potato products. Moreover, \nthe environmental accumulation of these compounds from potato waste and \nbyproducts may disrupt microbial communities and pose risks to aquatics and can \npotentially reintroduce toxins into the food chain. This review explores the \nbiological degradation of α-solanine and α-chaconine, with a focus on microbial \nprocesses mediated by fungi (Plectosphaerella, Gibberella, Aspergillus, \nPenicillium), plant pathogens (Phytophthora infestans) and bacteria \n(Arthrobacter, Bacillus, Glutamicibacter). It highlights key glycosidases such \nas α-rhamnosidase (RhaA), β-glucosidase (GluA), and β-galactosidase (GalA) that \nare involved in deglycosylation and detoxification. A comprehensive review of \nthe literature conducted through PubMed, Web of Science, and Google Scholar was \nconducted to analyze relevant studies. Elucidating these degradation processes \nwill help enhance in our understanding of glycoalkaloid deglycosylation and \nprovide valuable insights into the development of effective strategies to \nmitigate glycoalkaloid contamination in food products and reduce the \nenvironmental impact.\n\n© 2025 The Authors. Online ahead of\n print.\n\nUsing cross-species co-expression to predict metabolic interactions in \nmicrobiomes.\n\nKoetsier RA(1), Reitz ZL(1), Belzer C(2), Chevrette MG(3), Handelsman J(3), Zhu \nY(4), van der Hooft JJJ(1)(5), Medema MH(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioinformatics Group, Wageningen University, Wageningen, the Netherlands.\n(2)Laboratory of Microbiology, Wageningen University, Wageningen, the \nNetherlands.\n(3)Department of Plant Pathology and Wisconsin Institute for Discovery, \nUniversity of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, Wisconsin, USA.\n(4)Institute of Precision Medicine, the First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen \nUniversity, Guangzhou, Guangdong, China.\n(5)Department of Biochemistry, University of Johannesburg, Johannesburg, South \nAfrica.\n\nIn microbial ecosystems, metabolic interactions are key determinants of species' \nrelative abundance and activity. Given the immense number of possible \ninteractions in microbial communities, their experimental characterization is \nbest guided by testable hypotheses generated through computational predictions. \nHowever, widely adopted software tools-such as those utilizing microbial \nco-occurrence-typically fail to highlight the pathways underlying these \ninteractions. Bridging this gap will require methods that utilize microbial \nactivity data to infer putative target pathways for experimental validation. In \nthis study, we explored a novel approach by applying cross-species co-expression \nto predict interactions from microbial co-culture RNA-sequencing data. \nSpecifically, we investigated the extent to which co-expression between genes \nand pathways of different bacterial species can predict competition, \ncross-feeding, and specialized metabolic interactions. Our analysis of the Mucin \nand Diet-based Minimal Microbiome (MDb-MM) data yielded results consistent with \nprevious findings and demonstrated the method's potential to identify pathways \nthat are subject to resource competition. Our analysis of the Hitchhikers of the \nRhizosphere (THOR) data showed links between related specialized functions, for \ninstance, between antibiotic and multidrug efflux system expression. \nAdditionally, siderophore co-expression and further evidence suggested that \nincreased siderophore production of the Pseudomonas koreensis koreenceine BGC \ndeletion-mutant drives siderophore production in the other community members. In \nsummary, our findings confirm the feasibility of using cross-species \nco-expression to predict pathways potentially involved in microbe-microbe \ninteractions. We anticipate that the approach will also facilitate the discovery \nof novel gene functions through their association with other species' metabolic \npathways, for example, those involved in antibiotic response.IMPORTANCEAn \nimproved mechanistic understanding of microbial interactions can guide targeted \ninterventions or inform the rational design of microbial communities to optimize \nthem for applications such as pathogen control, food fermentation, and various \nbiochemical processes. Existing methodologies for inferring the mechanisms \nbehind microbial interactions often rely on complex model-building and are, \ntherefore, sensitive to the introduction of biases from the incorporated \nexisting knowledge and model-building assumptions. We highlight the microbial \ninteraction prediction potential of cross-species co-expression analysis, which \ncontrasts with these methods by its data-driven nature. We describe the utility \nof cross-species co-expression for various types of interactions and thereby \ninform future studies on use-cases of the approach and the opportunities and \npitfalls that can be expected in its application.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/msystems.01321-25\nPMID: 41363457"},

This study aimed to investigate the factors that determine \nthe structure of microbial communities of three hydrohalophytes of the Southwest \nSpain (Atlantic coastal), in particular Atriplex portulacoides, Salicornia \nperennis and Suaeda vera; and three xerohalophytes of Southeast Spain \n(Mediterranean coast and inland saltmarshes), namely, Atriplex glauca, Anabasis \narticulata and Halocnemum strobilaceum. Samples were collected in three \nlocations and two seasons (autumn and spring) to analyze how plant genetics and \nenvironmental factors influence their microbiota. The analysis was done by \nsequencing the 16S V3-V4 region in samples of different plant compartments: \nendophytes, rhizosphere soils and bare soils. The results showed strong \nattraction of bacteria and archaea to the rhizosphere, although further tight \nselection limits the number of endophytes. A "core" of endophytes common to both \nfunctional halophytes was identified, including the genera Kushneria, Halomonas, \nPseudoalteromonas and Zunongwangia, which were considered generalists. In \naddition, specific genera considered as specialists were found: hydrohalophytes \nshowed affinity for Vibrio, Pseudomonas and Marinomonas, while xerohalophytes \nharbored Marinilactobacillus, Alkalicoccus, Alkalibacterium and Arthrobacter. \nAlthough most endophytes persist across seasons, their relative abundances can \nchange for better adaptation. Clear differences were also encountered among the \nrhizosphere inhabitants in both functional halophytes: whereas halophilic \nammonia oxidizing archaea were prevalent in the rhizosphere of hydrohalophytes, \nversatile adaptive bacteria were predominant in that of xerohalophytes. These \nmicroorganisms play vital roles, including promoting plant growth, participating \nin the carbon and nitrogen metabolisms, and recycling organic matter. In \nconclusion, the study determined that the main factors shaping the microbial \npopulations associated to halophytes were: halophyte type > halophyte species > \nsoil characteristics > seasonality.\n\n© 2025 The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1016/j.crmicr.2025.100511\nPMCID: PMC12681888\nPMID: 41362317\n\nConflict of interest statement: Halophytes are of great interest for their \necosystemic benefits and valuable secondary metabolites. However, they are \nthreatened by factors associated with climate change and human activity. In this \ncontext, their associated microbial communities are crucial for their survival. \nDespite that, there are no comparative studies on microbial communities \nassociated two types of functional halophytes: hydro- and xero-halophytes, \nliving in marine and arid saline environments. Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. The RF model, built using differentially \nabundant genera to distinguish recurrence status, achieved an area under the \ncurve (AUC) of 0.721 in the validation set and 0.861 in the test cohort, \nindicating good predictive performance.\nCONCLUSION: Our findings suggest that gut microbiota composition may hold clues \nfor predicting IBD relapse. Environ Monit Assess. 2025 Dec 8;198(1):23. doi: 10.1007/s10661-025-14873-y.\n\nPioneering approaches to plastic biodegradation and upcycling for \nsustainability.\n\nRao PM(1), Radha P(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia.\n(2)Bioprocess Principles Laboratory, Department of Biotechnology, School of \nBioengineering, College of Engineering and Technology, SRM Institute of Science \nand Technology, Kattankulathur, Chengalpattu District, Tamil Nadu, 603203, \nIndia. radhap@srmist.edu.in.\n\nPlastic pollution has become one of the most significant threats to the \nenvironment and human health of the twenty-first century, with more than 300 \nmillion tons of waste generated annually, and conventional disposal methods are \ninadequate. To address this challenge, recent research has increasingly shifted \ntoward biodegradation and upcycling as sustainable alternatives. Microbial \ndegradation of synthetic plastics has shown advancement. This includes the \nintroduction of novel strains like Aspergillus niger MG654699 for the 3.6% and \n5% degradation of polyethylene terephthalate and polystyrene, respectively. \nAlso, Streptomyces sp., Methylobacterium, Arthrobacter, and Sphingomonas have \nbeen studied to be responsible for mulch film degradation. Advances in \nmetagenomics have further revealed the complexity of microbial consortia for \ndriving these processes, whereas kinetic modeling has provided insights into \ndegradation rates and conditions. Building on this foundation, artificial \nintelligence and machine learning are now expediting enzyme discovery, \noptimizing degradation pathways, and enabling intelligent waste management \nsystems. Similarly, biosensors based on Vibrio fischeri and Escherichia coli \nimprove monitoring by detecting plastic monomers. Beyond degradation, the \nintegration of microbial and chemical processes has enabled the upcycling of \nplastic monomers into value-added products such as polyhydroxyalkanoates, \nvanillin, bacterial nanocellulose, fuels, and biochemicals, promoting a circular \nbioeconomy. These advances highlight a paradigm shift from waste accumulation to \nresource recovery, underscoring the potential of biotechnology and engineering \ninnovations to transform plastic management. The review concludes by \nhighlighting the challenges of scalability, environmental variability, and \npolicy support while positioning biodegradation and upcycling as integrated \nstrategies for a sustainable and resilient future.\n\n© 2025. Front Plant Sci. 2025 Nov 18;16:1642078. doi: 10.3389/fpls.2025.1642078. \neCollection 2025.\n\nMechanisms of root exudates and soil microbial responses to nitrogen reduction \nand companion cropping for tomato yield increase and quality improvement.\n\nLiu D(1), He X(1), Liu Y(1), Sun C(1), Su C(1), Lang Y(1), Wu X(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)College of Horticulture and Landscape, Heilongjiang Bayi Agricultural \nUniversity, Daqing, Heilongjiang,\xa0China.\n\nThe utilization of nitrogen fertilizer in excess over an extended period in \nfacility cultivation has been demonstrated to engender a decline in tomato yield \nand quality, thus becoming a bottleneck issue that restricts production. In \norder to explore the biological mechanisms of nitrogen reduction and companion \nplanting patterns on tomato yield and quality, this study conducted a two-year \npot experiment under different nitrogen application levels and planting \npatterns, multisystem analysis of tomato rhizosphere soil microbial communities \nand root secretions was performed using 16S Illumina MiSeq sequencing and \nLC-MS/MS mass spectrometry. The activity of polyphosphate accumulating organisms \n(PAOs) and the composition of biocoenosis are strongly influenced by these \nprocess conditions. Nevertheless, critical knowledge gaps remain regarding the \nrelevance of microbial diversity and the correlations between PAO/GAO community \ncomposition and EBPR process dynamics under different operational conditions. \nThis study demonstrates that Dechloromonas plays a crucial role in the EBPR \nprocess and that the type of carbon source has a more sensitive influence on \nEBPR dynamics than the COD:P ratio, temperature or pH. Tessaracoccus (PAO) and \nMicropruina (GAO) were relevant in the fermentation of glucose and glycerol. No \nsignificant effect on EBPR performance was observed between 12 and 20\xa0°C, and \nPAO activity peaked at pH 7.5. Our findings highlight that PAO-GAO competition \nis overestimated. We anticipate that our study provides a deeper understanding \nof the dynamics in the biocoenosis and emphasizes the relevance of biodiversity \nin EBPR systems, which would help guide relevant applications.\n\nCopyright © 2025 The Author(s). Upon landing on a leaf, the pathogen enters through the \nstomata and continues to develop asymptomatically for up to 28 days before \nsymptoms appear. As previous work has yet to adequately determine how the \npathogen behaves during its infective period, we used transcriptomics to gain \ninsights about the in-planta development of the pathogen and explore its use of \neffectors to facilitate this process. Samples from B73 maize inbreds inoculated \nwith an African reference strain of C. zeina (CMW25467) were harvested in a time \ncourse experiment and used for deep RNA sequencing. We used reads mapped to an \nimproved assembly and annotation of the C. zeina CMW25467 genome as a proxy for \nbiomass accumulation. Following the latent period, C. zeina was found to rapidly \naccumulate biomass and showed a nearly 50-fold increase in biomass as symptoms \nappeared. Two distinct transcriptional waves occurred across the infection \nperiod. The first wave showed expression of genes for cellular growth, \nmaintenance and immune avoidance, whereas the second wave was enriched with \ngenes involved in detoxification and carbohydrate catabolism. A total of 140 \nputative effector genes were differentially expressed over the time course, with \nmost upregulated during the mid stage when the switch to necrotrophy occurred. \nTransient expression of three of these C. zeina effectors (CzEcp2, CzNIS1a, \nCzNIS1b) induced plant immunity in Nicotiana spp. resulting in the development \nof cell death. The CzNIS1a effector required a signal peptide for activity in \nNicotiana benthamiana, indicating that it is most likely secreted into the \napoplast for this function. The previously undescribed CzNIS1b family member has \nan N-terminal domain with high sequence and structural identity to CzNIS1a plus \na C-terminal domain made up of four alpha helices. Orthologues of CzNIS1b appear \nto be limited to the Mycosphaerellaceae. This study suggests that a cohort of C. \nzeina effectors expressed during the mid-stage of infection have functions for \nwhich receptors are present in non-host species like tobacco. Altogether, this \nwork suggests C. zeina behaves as a latent necrotroph and provides a foundation \nfor future research into the infection biology of C. zeina.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Nadasen, Buitendag, Visser, Welgemoed, Hein and Berger.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fpls.2025.1703682\nPMCID: PMC12676973\nPMID: 41358340\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest. The mycotoxins produced by this pathogen not only \nmarkedly reduce the nutritional value of grains but also pose a serious threat \nto public health. The AP exhibits superior control and antimicrobial effects compared to \nMyco, which may be attributed to the synergistic interactions between Myco and \nother antimicrobial components found in the secondary metabolites of BS-Z15. \nThis study provides a theoretical foundation for the further exploration of \nother antifungal components within the secondary metabolites of BS-Z15 and lays \nthe groundwork to develop BS-Z15 as a biological control agent.\n\n© 2025. The \nthree-event stack maize expresses PAT, CP4 EPSPS, CP4 EPSPS L124P, AAD-1 and the \nmaize endogenous protein with altered expression (EPAE) ZMM28 to confer \nherbicide tolerance and to provide the potential for yield enhancement (PYE) \nunder field conditions. The GMO Panel previously assessed the three single maize \nevents and one of the sub-combinations and did not identify safety concerns. No \nnew data on the single maize events or the assessed sub-combination were \nidentified that could lead to modification of the original conclusions on their \nsafety. The molecular characterisation, comparative analysis (agronomic, \nphenotypic and compositional characteristics) and the outcome of the \ntoxicological, allergenicity and nutritional assessment indicate that the \ncombination of the single maize events and of the newly expressed proteins and \nthe EPAE in the three-event stack maize does not give rise to food and feed \nsafety or nutritional concerns. DNA methods are robust \nagainst environmental or harvest variations. The biosensor delivers \nresults within 15-20\xa0min, detecting olive DNA adulteration with as low as 5\xa0% \nsesame, soybean, and sunflower, and 10\xa0% corn. Upon landing on a leaf, the pathogen enters through the \nstomata and continues to develop asymptomatically for up to 28 days before \nsymptoms appear. We used reads mapped to an \nimproved assembly and annotation of the C. zeina CMW25467 genome as a proxy for \nbiomass accumulation. Two distinct transcriptional waves occurred across the infection \nperiod. The first wave showed expression of genes for cellular growth, \nmaintenance and immune avoidance, whereas the second wave was enriched with \ngenes involved in detoxification and carbohydrate catabolism. A total of 140 \nputative effector genes were differentially expressed over the time course, with \nmost upregulated during the mid stage when the switch to necrotrophy occurred. \nTransient expression of three of these C. zeina effectors (CzEcp2, CzNIS1a, \nCzNIS1b) induced plant immunity in Nicotiana spp. resulting in the development \nof cell death. The CzNIS1a effector required a signal peptide for activity in \nNicotiana benthamiana, indicating that it is most likely secreted into the \napoplast for this function. Orthologues of CzNIS1b appear \nto be limited to the Mycosphaerellaceae. This study suggests that a cohort of C. \nzeina effectors expressed during the mid-stage of infection have functions for \nwhich receptors are present in non-host species like tobacco. Altogether, this \nwork suggests C. zeina behaves as a latent necrotroph and provides a foundation \nfor future research into the infection biology of C. zeina.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Nadasen, Buitendag, Visser, Welgemoed, Hein and Berger.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fpls.2025.1703682\nPMCID: PMC12676973\nPMID: 41358340\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest. Upon landing on a leaf, the pathogen enters through the \nstomata and continues to develop asymptomatically for up to 28 days before \nsymptoms appear. As previous work has yet to adequately determine how the \npathogen behaves during its infective period, we used transcriptomics to gain \ninsights about the in-planta development of the pathogen and explore its use of \neffectors to facilitate this process. Samples from B73 maize inbreds inoculated \nwith an African reference strain of C. zeina (CMW25467) were harvested in a time \ncourse experiment and used for deep RNA sequencing. We used reads mapped to an \nimproved assembly and annotation of the C. zeina CMW25467 genome as a proxy for \nbiomass accumulation. Following the latent period, C. zeina was found to rapidly \naccumulate biomass and showed a nearly 50-fold increase in biomass as symptoms \nappeared. Two distinct transcriptional waves occurred across the infection \nperiod. The first wave showed expression of genes for cellular growth, \nmaintenance and immune avoidance, whereas the second wave was enriched with \ngenes involved in detoxification and carbohydrate catabolism. A total of 140 \nputative effector genes were differentially expressed over the time course, with \nmost upregulated during the mid stage when the switch to necrotrophy occurred. \nTransient expression of three of these C. zeina effectors (CzEcp2, CzNIS1a, \nCzNIS1b) induced plant immunity in Nicotiana spp. resulting in the development \nof cell death. The CzNIS1a effector required a signal peptide for activity in \nNicotiana benthamiana, indicating that it is most likely secreted into the \napoplast for this function. Orthologues of CzNIS1b appear \nto be limited to the Mycosphaerellaceae. This study suggests that a cohort of C. \nzeina effectors expressed during the mid-stage of infection have functions for \nwhich receptors are present in non-host species like tobacco. Altogether, this \nwork suggests C. zeina behaves as a latent necrotroph and provides a foundation \nfor future research into the infection biology of C. zeina.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Nadasen, Buitendag, Visser, Welgemoed, Hein and Berger.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fpls.2025.1703682\nPMCID: PMC12676973\nPMID: 41358340\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest. Front Microbiol. 2025 Feb 18;16:1529784. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2025.1529784. \neCollection 2025.\n\nMetagenomic analysis revealed the bioremediation mechanism of lead and cadmium \ncontamination by modified biochar synergized with Bacillus cereus PSB-2 in \nphosphate mining wasteland.\n\nZhang Y(1), Peng J(1), Wang Z(1), Zhou F(1), Yu J(1), Chi R(1)(2), Xiao C(1)(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Key Laboratory of Novel Biomass-Based Environmental and Energy Materials in \nPetroleum and Chemical Industry, Engineering Research Center of Phosphorus \nResources Development and Utilization of Ministry of Education, School of \nEnvironmental Ecology and Biological Engineering, Wuhan Institute of Technology, \nWuhan, China.\n(2)Hubei Three Gorges Laboratory, Yichang, China.\n\nINTRODUCTION: Phosphate mining wasteland is contaminated with heavy metals, such \nas lead (Pb) and cadmium (Cd), which pose significant environmental risks. \nEcological restoration of these lands is crucial, but limited research has \nfocused on the remediation of heavy metal-contaminated soils using modified \nbiochar and functional microorganisms.\nMETHODS: In this study, we investigated the bioremediation of phosphate mining \nwasteland soil using modified biochar in combination with the \nphosphate-solubilizing bacterium Bacillus cereus. The effects of this \nsynergistic approach on soil nutrient content, heavy metal immobilization, and \nmicrobial community structure were assessed.\nRESULTS AND DISCUSSION: The results indicated that the available phosphate \ncontent in the soil increased by 59.32%. Janibacter, Lysobacter, Ornithinimicrobium, Bacillus, and \nSalinimicrobium were the main functional flora during soil remediation, with \nsignificant correlations for the promotion of Pb2 + and Cd2 + immobilization and \nthe increase of available phosphate and organic matter. Furthermore, the content of nicotine, protein, \ntotal nitrogen, and Cl- in diseased leaves significantly increased by 47.86%, \n17.46%, 20.08%, and 72.77% in comparison to healthy leaves, while the levels of \ntotal sugar and reducing sugar decreased by 59.59% and 70.0%, respectively. \nNotably, the wildfire disease had little effect on the content of starch and K+. \nRedundancy analysis revealed that Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus, Cladosporium, and \nWallemia displayed positive correlations with nicotine, protein, total nitrogen, \nCl- and K+ contents, while Pantoea, Erwinia, Sphingomonas, Terrisporobacter, \nAspergillus, Alternaria, Sampaiozyma, and Didymella displayed positive \ncorrelations with total sugar and reducing sugar contents. Brevibacterium, \nBrachybacterium, and Janibacter were found to be enriched in diseased leaves, \nsuggesting their potential role in disease suppression. Co-occurrence network \nanalysis indicated that positive correlations were prevalent in microbial \nnetworks, and the bacterial network of healthy tobacco leaves exhibited greater \ncomplexity compared to diseased tobacco leaves. This study revealed the impact \nof wildfire disease on the microbial community and chemical compositions of \ntobacco leaves and provides new insights for the biological control of tobacco \nwildfire disease.\n\n© 2023 The Authors. Evidence has shown \nthat skin-microbiome fluctuations may precede eczema development, but their \npredictive value for eczema phenotypes remains unknown. We aimed to investigate \nthe early-life evolution of the skin microbiome and its temporal associations \nwith different pairs of eczema phenotypes (transient versus persistent, atopic \nversus non-atopic) in Chinese children. We followed 119 term Chinese infants \nfrom birth to 24 months old within a Hong Kong birth cohort. The skin microbes \nat the left antecubital fossa were serially sampled by flocked swabs at 1, 6, \nand 12 months for bacterial 16S rRNA gene sequencing. The atopic sensitization \nat 12 months was strongly associated with eczema persisting to 24 months (odds \nratio 4.95, 95% confidence interval 1.29-19.01). Compared with those with \nnon-atopic eczema, the children with atopic eczema had reduced alpha diversity \nat 12 months (p < 0.001) and transiently higher abundance of the genus \nJanibacter at 6 months (p < 0.001). Our findings suggest that atopic \nsensitization at 12 months may predict persistent eczema by 24 months, and \natopic eczema at 12 months is associated with unique skin microbiome profiles at \n6 and 12 months. BMC Microbiol. 2025 Jan 11;25(1):14. doi: 10.1186/s12866-024-03665-y.\n\nDifferences in gut microbial diversity and composition between growth phenotypes \nof farmed juvenile sandfish, Holothuria scabra.\n\nTabardillo JA Jr(1), Juinio-Meñez MA(2), Reitzel AM(3), Ravago-Gotanco R(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)The Marine Science Institute, College of Science, University of the \nPhilippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines. jtabardillo@msi.upd.edu.ph.\n(2)The Marine Science Institute, College of Science, University of the \nPhilippines Diliman, Quezon City, Philippines.\n(3)Department of Biological Sciences, University of North Carolina at Charlotte, \nCharlotte, North Carolina, USA.\n\nBACKGROUND: The observed growth variability of different aquaculture species in \ncaptivity hinders its large-scale production. For the sandfish Holothuria \nscabra, a tropical sea cucumber species, there is a scarcity of information on \nits intestinal microbiota in relation to host growth, which could provide \ninsights into the processes that affect growth and identify microorganisms with \nprobiotic or biochemical potential that could improve current production \nstrategies. To address this gap, this study used 16\xa0S rRNA amplicon sequencing \nto characterize differences in gut and fecal microbiota among large and small \njuveniles reared in floating ocean nurseries.\nRESULTS: We recovered 5915 amplicon sequence variants and diversity indices \nrevealed significant differences between large and small juveniles (p\u2009<\u20090.05). \nGut microbiota of large juveniles had lower bacterial diversity than its smaller \ncounterparts. The genus cluster Burkholderia-Caballeronia-Paraburkholderia (BCP) \nis the most common and abundant taxa found in the gut for both size categories \nbut less abundant in fecal samples. Small juveniles had a higher abundance of \nmembers from the Roseobacter clade (Rhodobacteriaceae) such as Ruegeria, Shimia, \nPsuedoruegeria and Marivita among others while the genus Schlegelella \n(Caldimonas) and Bosea were primarily found in larger juveniles. Predicted \nphysiological functions identified signatures of metabolism, biosynthesis, and \nbiodegradation pathways unique for each size category. Significant differences \nin diversity and composition were also exhibited between the pooled fecal and \ngut sample types.\nCONCLUSIONS: The bacterial composition in the intestinal tract of the sandfish \nH. scabra is an important factor in the observed growth variability in \naquaculture. The results show differences in diversity, composition and \npredicted physiological functions between the size groups, despite being from \nthe same cohort and environment. It was also evident that the fecal microbiota \ndiffers from the gut and does not correspond to size category, warranting \ncaution in using the fecal matter as a proxy to infer microbial composition and \ninteractions in the gastrointestinal tract. Understanding the roles that these \nmicroorganisms play in sandfish growth could support the development of \nstrategies to manage size variation in captive-bred sea cucumbers, or for the \npromotion and selection for faster-growing individuals.\n\n© 2024. The Author(s).\n\nDOI: 10.1186/s12866-024-03665-y\nPMCID: PMC11724480\nPMID: 39799280 [Indexed for MEDLINE]\n\nConflict of interest statement: Declarations. The animal is \nlisted as endangered in the IUCN Red List and is regulated for collection and \ntrade by the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources through Administrative \nCircular 248\xa0S.2013 but a permit to collect for scientific purposes was granted \nfor the project. The animals used in this study were produced in the hatchery \nfollowing induced spawning of broodstock collected from wild populations. \nBroodstock were returned to its natural habitat, thus natural populations of the \nanimals were not adversely affected by the study in adherence to the IUCN Policy \nStatement on Research Involving Species at Risk of Extinction. Microbial platforms characterized by halophilic \nand thermophilic properties, specifically Halomonas halophila and Caldimonas \nthermodepolymerans, were utilized to tackle issues related to sterility demands, \nprocess efficiency, and sustainability. J Environ Manage. 2025 Jan;373:123869. doi: 10.1016/j.jenvman.2024.123869.\nEpub  2025 Jan 1.\n\nThe feasibility of batch-wise polyester degradation and recycling using \nrecombinant Escherichia coli expressing PHB depolymerase (PhaZ(Cma)).\n\nLin YC(1), Zhong-Johnson EZL(2), Sinskey AJ(2), Li SY(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Chemical Engineering, National Chung Hsing University, \nTaichung, 402, Taiwan.\n(2)Department of Biology, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, \nUSA.\n(3)Department of Chemical Engineering, National Chung Hsing University, \nTaichung, 402, Taiwan. Microb Biotechnol. 2025 Feb;18(2):e70103. doi: 10.1111/1751-7915.70103.\n\nAn Initial Genome Editing Toolset for Caldimonas thermodepolymerans, the First \nModel of Thermophilic Polyhydroxyalkanoates Producer.\n\nGrybchuk-Ieremenko A(1), Lipovská K(1), Kouřilová X(2), Obruča S(2), Dvořák \nP(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Experimental Biology (Section of Microbiology), Faculty of \nScience, Masaryk University, Brno, Czech Republic.\n(2)Faculty of Chemistry, Institute of Food Science and Biotechnology, Brno \nUniversity of Technology, Brno, Czech Republic.\n\nThe limited number of well-characterised model bacteria cannot address all the \nchallenges in a circular bioeconomy. Therefore, there is a growing demand for \nnew production strains with enhanced resistance to extreme conditions, versatile \nmetabolic capabilities and the ability to utilise cost-effective renewable \nresources while efficiently generating attractive biobased products. Particular \nthermophilic microorganisms fulfil these requirements. Non-virulent \nGram-negative Caldimonas thermodepolymerans DSM15344 is one such attractive \nthermophile that efficiently converts a spectrum of plant biomass sugars into \nhigh quantities of polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHA)-a fully biodegradable substitutes \nfor synthetic plastics. Microorganisms can S-methylate H2S and MeSH, which can \nbe cytotoxic, to yield non-toxic DMS via MddA or MddH enzymes in largely \nterrestrial or marine environments, respectively. However, the potential of many \nimportant and abundant bacteria like Actinomycetota is underestimated due to \nunknown Mdd enzymes. The final compost satisfied \nagronomic and safety criteria, including organic matter stabilisation, neutral \npH, pathogen elimination, and heavy metal concentrations. The product yields are significantly \ninfluenced by the optimization of stress factors and culture conditions. These modern \ntechniques aim to minimize environmental impact while maximizing efficiency and \nselectivity. World J Hepatol. 2025 Oct 27;17(10):108700. doi: 10.4254/wjh.v17.i10.108700.\n\nIncidence of spontaneous fungal peritonitis in patients with liver cirrhosis in \na Mexico City population.\n\nFajardo-Felix CF(1), Rodriguez-Negrete EV(2), Morales-González JA(3), \nTriana-Romero A(1)(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Gastroenterology, Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social, Mexico \nCity 06720, Ciudad de México, Mexico.\n(2)Department of Gastroenterology, Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social, Mexico \nCity 06720, Ciudad de México, Mexico. jev_rn@yahoo.com.mx.\n(3)Escuela Superior de Medicina, Instituto Politécnico Nacional, Mexico City \n11340, Ciudad de México, Mexico.\n(4)Digestive Physiology and Motility Lab, Universidad Veracruzana, Veracruz \n91400, Mexico.\n\nBACKGROUND: Individuals with liver cirrhosis (LC) are likely to experience \nmultiple infectious processes due to the immune dysfunction caused by the \ndisease. Our hypothesis is that this group of patients is predisposed to fungal \ninfections. To date, the incidence of spontaneous fungal peritonitis (SFP) has \nnot been determined in Mexico; this endeavor is of great importance because many \npatients may be suffering from this condition without receiving targeted \ntreatment, which may increase mortality.\nAIM: To report the incidence of SFP in patients presenting with decompensated LC \nwith ascites.\nMETHODS: This was a prospective, single-center, descriptive, observational and \ncross-sectional study where patients presenting with decompensated LC with \nascites were evaluated from November 2023 to May 2024 in Mexico City. Fungal \ncultures of ascites were performed and the samples kept in an incubator for 10 \ndays to 14 days, and molecular tests (the API 20 C AUX test) were used for \nmolecular characterization.\nRESULTS: Of the 48 patients included, 54.2% were women, 77.1% had a comorbidity, \n47.9% had LC secondary to metabolic dysfunction, 43.8% were classified as \nChild-Pugh C with a model for end-stage liver disease 3.0 median score of 22, \nand 10.4% were in secondary prophylaxis for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis \n(SBP). Only four patients had positive cultures where Candida parapsilosis and \nCandida albicans were isolated, with two of the four patients being positive for \nRhodotorula minuta; an SBP incidence of 8.3% was thus calculated. Chronic kidney \ndisease [P = 0.012 and relative risk (RR) = 15] and secondary prophylaxis for \nSBP (P = 0.049 with RR = 8.6) were statistically significant and associated with \na high mortality risk (P = 0.001 with RR = 33).\nCONCLUSION: The presence of infection of fungal origin in ascites in patients \npresenting with cirrhosis increases short- and medium-term mortality; therefore, \nit is recommended that fungal culture tests are performed in those patients who \nvisit the emergency room or experience continuous admission with acute \ndecompensation and no bacteria identified in ascites cultures, and even more so \nin patients with chronic kidney disease and a history of antibiotic use as \nprophylaxis for SBP. Further studies are needed for the identification of \nclinical and biochemical data that can help to define SFP so that its presence \nmay be assessed without the need to wait for a positive fungal culture. Thus, \ntreatment may be initiated early in the hope of having a positive impact on the \nprognosis in this group of patients.\n\n©The Author(s) 2025. Published by Baishideng Publishing Group Inc. This study characterized 30 d biofilm \nassembly dynamics on polyethylene (PE), polyamide (PA), and biodegradable \npoly(butylene adipate-co-terephthalate)/polylactic acid (BP) in simulated \nwastewater treatment systems. Integrated multi-parametric analyses revealed \ncyclic di-guanylate monophosphate (c-di-GMP) as a key biomarker of biofilm \nmaturity, peaking at 15-22 d alongside maximal biomass and extracellular \npolymeric substances (EPS). Subsequent detachment was mediated by β-glucosidase \nand lysozyme, inducing autolysis. Stage-specific transitions included: Initial \nattachment (0-10 d); Microbial colonization (10-22 d); Maturation/Detachment \n(post-22 d). EPS-secreting and plastic-degrading taxa (Pseudomonas and \nRhodotorula) facilitated initial attachment, followed by functional taxa \nmediating nitrogen transformation (Ochrobactrum, Aminobacter, and Cupriavidus) \nand potential biofilm-stabilizing fungi (Rozellomycota-gen-incertae-sedis). PA \nenhanced colonization via amide-driven nitrogen enrichment and elevated c-di-GMP \nlevels, leading to robust biofilms with functional consortia (Zavarzinia, \nSphingopyxis, and Rozellomycota-gen-incertae-sedis). Conversely, BP promoted \ninitial bacterial recruitment (Pseudomonas and Enterobacter) but later inhibited \nsustained growth because of cytotoxic leachates and nutrient competition, \ncausing biomass decline and fungal inhibition at 20 d. These findings elucidated \nplastisphere succession pathways, enabling more accurate assessment of their \necological impact and improved MP pollution management strategies in wastewater \ntreatment.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Elsevier B.V. Single-cell oils (SCOs) from \noleaginous yeasts, enriched in unsaturated fatty acids, were evaluated as \nlarvicides. Yeasts from soils and decaying fruits were screened for lipid \naccumulation under nitrogen limitation, identified by molecular methods, \noptimized in shake flasks across pH, carbon source, and carbon-to-nitrogen (C/N) \nratios, and the top strain was scaled in a 7-L bioreactor. SCOs were extracted \nand characterized by FTIR, GC-MS, and NMR. Larvicidal activity against \nthird-instar A. aegypti was assessed by mortality, pupation delay, and \ninhibition of adult emergence, and IC50/IC90 values were estimated by probit \nanalysis. Four oleaginous yeasts were confirmed: Moesziomyces aphidis KHL-99, \nRhodosporidium toruloides KHL-101, R. toruloides KHL-103, and Rhodotorula \nsinensis KHL-108. SCOs from KHL-99 and KHL-108 were most active (IC50 ≈ 75 ppm), \nand sublethal doses reduced adult emergence by ~35-40%. Optimization showed that \nnitrogen limitation, pH 5.0-5.5, glycerol as carbon source, and higher C/N \nratios increased lipid accumulation. In bioreactor, KHL-99 reached 8.1 ± 0.4 g/L \nbiomass and 4.75 ± 0.2 g/L lipids (41% dry cell weight). SCOs were enriched in \noleic (C18:1) and linoleic (C18:2) acids, supporting a biochemical basis for \nlarvicidal effects. These findings indicate that yeast-derived SCOs function as \nactive larvicides and can be produced at scale, positioning them as practical \nadditions to integrated vector management. Because these SCOs consist of \nnaturally occurring fatty acids rather than synthetic neurotoxins, they are \nexpected to pose minimal risk to non-target organisms and offer an \nenvironmentally safe alternative for field application.\n\n© 2025. Fatty acid profiling revealed a composition \ndominated by oleic and linoleic acids, with over 54% comprising unsaturated \nfatty acids. Notably, γ-linolenic acid, cis-10-pentadecenoic acid, and \ncis-11-eicosenoic acid rare fatty acids with distinct physicochemical and \nnutraceutical properties were detected, highlighting the strain's potential for \nspecialty lipid production. This study establishes a scalable, statistically \noptimized bioprocess for PDW valorization using an environmental isolate of R. \nglutinis, contributing to circular bioeconomy strategies for sustainable \nmicrobial lipid biomanufacturing.\n\n© 2025. AMR genes in bacteria are often carried on mobile \nelements, such as plasmids. The horizontal movement of plasmids allows AMR genes \nand resistance to key therapeutics to disseminate in a population. However, the \nquantification of the movement of plasmids remains challenging with existing \ncomputational approaches. Here, we introduce a novel method that allows us to \nreconstruct and quantify the movement of plasmids in bacterial populations over \ntime. To do so, we model chromosomal and plasmid DNA co-evolution using a joint \ncoalescent and plasmid transfer process in a Bayesian phylogenetic network \napproach. This approach reconstructs differences in the evolutionary history of \nplasmids and chromosomes to reconstruct instances where plasmids likely move \nbetween bacterial lineages while accounting for parameter uncertainty. We apply \nthis new approach to a five-year dataset of Shigella, exploring the plasmid \ntransfer rates of five different plasmids with different AMR and virulence \nprofiles. In doing so, we reconstruct the co-evolution of the large Shigella \nvirulence plasmid with the chromosome DNA. Adults \nshowed a significantly higher burden of VCO1 and corresponding phages compared \nwith children <5 years (P < 0.001). Seasonal analysis revealed significant \ncorrelations between VCO1 (37.3%) and corresponding phages (57.6%) peaking in \nlate September in both clinical (r = 0.53, P < 0.0001) and environmental \nwastewater specimens (r = 0.65, P < 0.001). To our knowledge, this is the \nfirst study that longitudinally investigated major diarrheal pathogens and their \nphages in both clinical and environmental sources to assess the potential of \nbacteriophages as a tool to improve diarrheal surveillance. The high frequency \nof phages compared to the host bacterial counterparts suggests a valuable, yet \nunderutilized, role for phages in surveillance systems. Strong seasonal \nalignment between V. cholerae O1 and its phages, both peaking in late September, \nsuggests that phage dynamics may reflect pathogen transmission. These \npreliminary observations raise the possibility that wastewater-derived Vibrio \nphages could function as early indicators of cholera burden. Future research \nshould aim to explore the complex and poorly understood interactions between \nphages and their bacterial hosts, particularly how these dynamics shape pathogen \npopulations in endemic settings.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/mbio.02654-25\nPMID: 41363802'},

The development \nof new antibiotics is slow and challenging, underscoring the need for \nalternative therapeutic strategies. One promising approach involves leveraging \ngut microbiota-derived bacteria that confer colonization resistance against \nenteric pathogens. In this study, we screened a human gut microbiota culture \ncollection and identified Bifidobacterium longum as the most effective species \nin inhibiting S. Typhimurium and S. flexneri in vitro. To evaluate its \nprotective potential in vivo, we utilized Caenorhabditis elegans as a model \nsystem. Our findings demonstrate that B. longum significantly reduced pathogen \nburden and enhanced host survival following infection. Mechanistic analysis \nrevealed that B. longum inhibits S. Typhimurium primarily through acidification, \nwhile S. flexneri suppression appears to involve a protein-mediated or \nheat-stable metabolite-dependent mechanism. Additionally, B. longum modulated \nhost immune pathways, downregulating genes associated with the p38 MAPK and \ninsulin/IGF-1 signaling pathways. These results highlight the potential of B. \nlongum as a non-antibiotic therapeutic for controlling Salmonella and Shigella \ninfections. However, further validation in mammalian models is required to \nassess its clinical relevance.\nIMPORTANCE: Gut infections caused by Salmonella and Shigella are major global \nhealth threats. As an alternative to novel drug discovery, which is \ntime-consuming and faces several challenges, this study explores the potential \nof gut bacteria to protect against these pathogens. We identified \nBifidobacterium longum, a common gut microbe, which can significantly reduce \ninfection by both Salmonella and Shigella in a lab setting and in a simple \nanimal model. The bacterium functions by creating an environment that is hostile \nto pathogens and by modulating the host's immune responses. These findings \nsuggest that B. longum could be developed as a natural, non-antibiotic treatment \nto control or reduce these enteric pathogen infections. This approach opens the \ndoor to using probiotics as effective tools in the global fight against \nantibiotic resistance.\n\nDOI: 10.1128/spectrum.01842-25\nPMID: 41347508"},

Front Microbiol. 2024 Jun 19;15:1411753. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2024.1411753. \neCollection 2024.\n\nSpatiotemporal patterns and co-occurrence patterns of dissimilatory nitrate \nreduction to ammonium community in sediments of the Lancang River cascade \nreservoirs.\n\nYuan B(1), Guo M(2), Zhou X(2), Li M(1), Xie S(3).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)College of Geology and Environment, Xi'an University of Science and \nTechnology, Xi'an, China.\n(2)Faculty of Water Resources and Hydroelectric Engineering, Xi'an University of \nTechnology, Xi'an, China.\n(3)College of Environmental Sciences and Engineering, Peking University, \nBeijing, China.\n\nDissimilatory nitrate reduction to ammonium (DNRA) is an important nitrate \nreduction pathway in freshwater sediments. Many studies have focused on the DNRA \nprocess in various natural habitats. However, the joint operation of cascade \nreservoirs will affect the physical and chemical properties of sediments, which \nmay change the DNRA process and bacterial community pattern in the surface \nsediments of cascade reservoirs. Our study was the first to investigate the \nspatiotemporal distribution patterns of potential DNRA rate, nrfA gene \nabundances, and DNRA bacterial community diversity in surface sediments of the \nLancang River cascade reservoirs. The results of slurry incubation experiments \ncombined with the 15N isotope tracer experiment ascertained that the potential \nrates of DNRA were 0.01-0.15\u2009nmol-N\u2009cm-3 h-1, and qPCR results indicated that \nthe abundance range of nrfA was 1.08\u2009×\u2009105-2.51\u2009×\u2009106 copies g-1 dry weight. \nHigh throughput sequencing of the nrfA gene revealed that the relative abundance \nof Anaeromyxobacter (4.52% on average), Polyangium (4.09%), Archangium (1.86%), \nGeobacter (1.34%), and Lacunisphaera (1.32%) were high. Pearson and RDA \ncorrelation analysis exhibited that nrfA gene abundance was positively \ncorrelated with altitude, pH, OC, and sand concentration. Anaeromyxobacter was \npositively correlated with reservoir age and DNRA potential rate. The \ndeterministic environmental selection process plays a crucial role in the \nformation of the DNRA bacterial community. Network analysis displayed that the \ndominant DNRA genus was the key population of the DNRA microbial community in \nthe sediments of Lancang River cascade reservoirs. This study reveals that the \nvariation of DNRA bacterial activity and community structure is largely driven \nby the construction of cascade reservoirs, and provides a new idea for further \nunderstanding the characteristics of the DNRA community in the cascade reservoir \necosystem.\n\nCopyright © 2024 Yuan, Guo, Zhou, Li and Xie.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2024.1411753\nPMCID: PMC11219630\nPMID: 38962138\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest."},

Electronic address: jiahuama@swust.edu.cn.\n\nPresent study investigates the impact of chitosan microspheres-based \ncontrolled-release nitrogen fertilizer (Cm-CRNFs) on biological characteristics \nof Brassica rapa ssp. pekinensis (Chinese cabbage) and soil. The study was \ncarried out under various four treatments, urea (0.8033\xa0g), blank chitosan \nmicrospheres (without urea), Cm-CRNFs (0.8033\xa0g), and a control group (CK). The \nresults indicated that Cm-CRNFs significantly prolonged the nitrogen release and \nenhanced the plant shoot length, shoot diameter, number of branches, pods, total \namino acids, and vitamin C of Brassica rapa ssp. pekinensis as well as increased \nthe soil nutrient availability. Chao index of bacterial diversity analysis \nshowed a significant reduction of 15.89\xa0% in Cm-CRNFs, but the Shannon index \nvalue in Cm-CRNFs was increased by 23.55\xa0% compared to CK. Furthermore, Cm-CRNFs \ntreatment significantly influenced genus richness level of Arthrobacter, \nArchangium, Bacillus, and Flavihumibacter. Moreover, relative abundance of \nbacteria significantly enhanced Cm-CRNFs, including Acidobacteriota, \nAcitinobacteriota, Cloroflexi, Cyanobacteria, and Patescibacteria. Soil enzyme \nactivity such as: urease, acid phosphatase, and catalase enzymes in Cm-CRNFs and \nurea treatment significantly increased. Besides, other enzymes such as: \ncellulase and β-glucosidase activity decreased in the Cm-CRNFs treatment. It was \nconcluded that Cm-CRNFs potentially prolonged discharge of micro/macronutrients \nand improved soil bacterial diversity, which ultimately enhanced the soil \nfertility and improved the soil enzyme activity.\n\nCopyright © 2023 Elsevier B.V. We assess the BGC content of all isolates and observe differences \nbetween Myxococcia and Polyangiia clusters.\nDISCUSSION: Continued discovery and sequencing of novel myxobacteria from the \nenvironment provide BGCs for the genome mining pipeline. Utilizing complete or \nnear-complete genome sequences, we compare the chromosomal organization of BGCs \nof related myxobacteria from various genera and suggest that the spatial \nproximity of hybrid, modular clusters contributes to the metabolic adaptability \nof myxobacteria.\n\nCopyright © 2023 Ahearne, Phillips, Knehans, Hoing, Dowd and Stevens.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2023.1227206\nPMCID: PMC10435759\nPMID: 37601375\n\nConflict of interest statement: SD was employed by Molecular Research LP (MR \nDNA). Front Microbiol. 2025 Jan 22;15:1501573. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2024.1501573. \neCollection 2024.\n\nCommunity structure and diversity of myxobacteria in soils from Inner Mongolia, \nChina.\n\nWu Z(#)(1)(2), Li S(#)(1), Wang X(1)(3), Liu H(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)College of Life Sciences, Inner Mongolia Agricultural University, Hohhot, \nChina.\n(2)College of Ecology and Environment, Baotou Teachers' College, Baotou, China.\n(3)Jilin Institute for Drug Control, Changchun, China.\n(#)Contributed equally\n\nMyxobacteria are a special kind of Gram-negative bacteria that can slide and \nproduce a variety of bioactive substances against bacteria, fungi, and viruses. \nIt has great development and research value in medicine and agriculture. \nAlthough myxobacteria have become a research hotspot at home and abroad, there \nare few systematic studies on the relationship between its diversity, \ngeographical location, and environment factors. In order to solve these \nproblems, 133 soil samples were collected from the east to the west of Inner \nMongolia Autonomous Region and divided into five groups. The water content, pH, \norganic matter, available phosphorus, hydrolytic nitrogen, and available \npotassium content of soil samples were determined by national standards and \nother methods. The quantitative assessment of the abundance of myxobacteria in \nthe soil sample was performed by quantitative real-time PCR. The composition of \nmyxobacteria in the soil was determined by 16S rRNA high-throughput sequencing \ntechnology to analyze the differences in the community structure of myxobacteria \namong different groups, explore the relationship between the diversity of \nmyxobacteria resources and the distribution and physical and chemical properties \nof the soil, and predict and analyze its community function. The results showed \nthat there were abundant myxobacteria resources in the soils of Inner Mongolia, \nand the average relative abundance of myxobacteria in the soil samples from the \ncentral part of Inner Mongolia was higher than that in the eastern and western \nparts, but the richness and diversity of samples from the central to eastern \nregions were significantly higher than those from the western regions. The \nmyxobacteria resources in the whole region included 10 families and 22 genera, \namong which the dominant genera were Labilitrix, Sandaracinus, Archangium, and \nHaliangium. The analysis of the species composition of myxobacteria among \ndifferent groups found that the distribution of soil and soil type had an impact \non the species composition of the samples. The species with significant \ndifferences in relative abundance among the five groups of samples were \nLabilitrix, Archangium, Sandaracinus, Minicystis, Polyangium, and Myxococcus. In \naddition, the latitude and longitude of the sampling point and the soil pH, \nwater content, available phosphorus content and organic matter content had a \ngreater impact on the myxobacteria community structure of samples, while the \naltitude of the soil sample and the contents of available potassium and alkaline \nnitrogen had a relatively small impact. Our data suggest that the distribution, \ntype and nutrient composition of soil samples have an impact on the relative \nabundance and species composition of myxobacteria community. The completion of \nthis work can provide basic data for the in-depth study of myxobacteria in the \nsoil.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Wu, Li, Wang and Liu.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2024.1501573\nPMCID: PMC11794786\nPMID: 39911708\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest."},

Front Microbiol. 2024 Jan 4;14:1320827. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2023.1320827. \neCollection 2023.\n\nCharacteristics of a lipase ArEstA with lytic activity against drug-resistant \npathogen from a novel myxobacterium, Archangium lipolyticum sp. nov.\n\nZhou Y(1), Chen H(1)(2), Jiang H(2), Yao Q(3), Zhu H(1).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Key Laboratory of Agricultural Microbiomics and Precision Application (MARA), \nGuangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Microbial Culture Collection and \nApplication, Key Laboratory of Agricultural Microbiome (MARA), State Key \nLaboratory of Applied Microbiology Southern China, Institute of Microbiology, \nGuangdong Academy of Sciences, Guangzhou, China.\n(2)Guangdong Key Laboratory for Veterinary Pharmaceutics Development and Safety \nEvaluation, College of Veterinary Medicine, South China Agricultural University, \nGuangzhou, China.\n(3)College of Horticulture, Guangdong Province Key Laboratory of Microbial \nSignals and Disease Control, Guangdong Engineering Research Center for Litchi, \nSouth China Agricultural University, Guangzhou, China.\n\nBacteriolytic myxobacteria are versatile micropredators and are proposed as \npotential biocontrol agents against diverse bacterial and fungal pathogens. \nIsolation of new myxobacteria species and exploration of effective predatory \nproducts are necessary for successful biocontrol of pathogens. In this study, a \nmyxobacterium strain CY-1 was isolated from a soil sample of a pig farm using \nthe Escherichia coli baiting method. Based on the morphological observation, \nphysiological test, 16S rRNA gene sequence, and genomic data, strain CY-1 was \nidentified as a novel species of the myxobacterial genus Archangium, for which \nthe name Archangium lipolyticum sp. nov. was proposed. Subsequent predation \ntests indicated that the strain efficiently lysed drug-resistant pathogens, with \na higher predatory activity against E. coli 64 than Staphylococcus aureus GDMCC \n1.771 (MRSA). The lysis of extracellular proteins against ester-bond-containing \nsubstrates (tributyrin, tween 80, egg-yolk, and autoclaved drug-resistant \npathogens) inspired the mining of secreted predatory products with lipolytic \nactivity. Furthermore, a lipase ArEstA was identified from the genome of CY-1, \nand the heterologously expressed and purified enzyme showed bacteriolytic \nactivity against Gram-negative bacteria E. coli 64 but not against Gram-positive \nMRSA, possibly due to different accessibility of enzyme to lipid substrates in \ndifferent preys. Our research not only provided a novel myxobacterium species \nand a candidate enzyme for the development of new biocontrol agents but also \nreported an experimental basis for further study on different mechanisms of \nsecreted predatory products in myxobacterial killing and degrading of \nGram-negative and Gram-positive preys.\n\nCopyright © 2024 Zhou, Chen, Jiang, Yao and Zhu.\n\nDOI: 10.3389/fmicb.2023.1320827\nPMCID: PMC10794672\nPMID: 38239728\n\nConflict of interest statement: The authors declare that the research was \nconducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could \nbe construed as a potential conflict of interest.'},
