World J Microbiol Biotechnol. 2024 May 29;40(7):219. doi: \n10.1007/s11274-024-04032-9.\n\nBiotransformation of docosahexaenoic acid into 10R,17S-dihydroxydocosahexaenoic \nacid as protectin DX 10-epimer by serial reactions of arachidonate 8R- and \n15S-lipoxygenases.\n\nLee TE(1), Ko YJ(2), Shin KC(3), Oh DK(4).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Bioscience and Biotechnology, Konkuk University, Seoul, 05029, \nRepublic of Korea.\n(2)National Center for Inter-University Research facilities (NCIRF), Seoul \nNational University, Seoul, 08826, Republic of Korea.\n(3)Department of Bioscience and Biotechnology, Hankuk University of Foreign \nStudies, Yongin, 17035, Republic of Korea. kcshin@hufs.ac.kr.\n(4)Department of Bioscience and Biotechnology, Konkuk University, Seoul, 05029, \nRepublic of Korea. deokkun@konkuk.ac.kr.\n\nProtectins, 10,17-dihydroxydocosahexaenoic acids (10,17-DiHDHAs), are belonged \nto specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs). Protectins are generated by \npolymorphonuclear leukocytes in humans and resolve inflammation and infection in \ntrace amounts. However, the quantitative production of protectin DX 10-epimer \n(10-epi-PDX, 10R,17S-4Z,7Z,11E,13Z,15E,19Z-DiHDHA) has been not attempted to \ndate. In this study, 10-epi-PDX was quantitatively produced from docosahexaenoic \nacid (DHA) by serial whole-cell biotransformation of Escherichia coli expressing \narachidonate (ARA) 8R-lipoxygenase (8R-LOX) from the coral Plexaura homomalla \nand E. coli expressing ARA 15S-LOX from the bacterium Archangium violaceum. The \noptimal bioconversion conditions to produce 10R-hydroxydocosahexaenoic acid \n(10R-HDHA) and 10-epi-PDX were pH 8.0, 30\xa0°C, 2.0 mM DHA, and 4.0\xa0g/L cells; and \npH 8.5, 20\xa0°C, 1.4 mM 10R-HDHA, and 1.0\xa0g/L cells, respectively. Under these \noptimized conditions, 2.0 mM (657\xa0mg/L) DHA was converted into 1.2 mM (433\xa0mg/L) \n10-epi-PDX via 1.4 mM (482\xa0mg/L) 10R-HDHA by the serial whole-cell \nbiotransformation within 90\xa0min, with a molar conversion of 60% and volumetric \nproductivity of 0.8 mM/h (288\xa0mg/L/h). To the best of our knowledge, this is the \nfirst quantitative production of 10-epi-PDX. Our results contribute to the \nefficient biocatalytic synthesis of SPMs.\n\n© 2024.     'abstract': '1. Int J Syst Evol Microbiol. 2015 Nov;65(11):4032-4042. doi: \n10.1099/ijsem.0.000533. Some enzymic and \nhydrolysing reactions of the type strains are described. K. pneumoniae has two \npathotypes: classical (cKp) and hypervirulent (hvKp). CKp typically causes \nopportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals in healthcare settings \nand often is multi-drug resistant. HvKp can be community-acquired and cause \nhigh-mortality infections in immunocompetent individuals. Concerningly, \nantibiotic-resistant cKp strains with hypervirulence-associated genes and traits \nhave recently emerged. Determining if and how hv-associated genes contribute to \nincreased virulence of cKp strains is essential to addressing this growing \nthreat. The rmpADC operon is an hv-associated locus that confers \nhypermucoviscosity (HMV), a key virulence phenotype, and rmp genes are often \nfound in convergent strains. It \nis essential to understand how hvKp genes impact virulence phenotypes and \nidentify the cKp strain backgrounds most amenable to enhanced virulence. \nHypermucoviscosity (HMV) is a critical virulence factor in hypervirulent K. \npneumoniae, conferred by the rmpADC locus. The rmp genes are encoded on mobile \ngenetic elements and have been detected in convergent antibiotic-resistant K. \npneumoniae strains of concern. In this study, we explored the impact of rmp \nacquisition in a broad set of classical clinical isolates. We observed that HMV \nappears necessary, but not sufficient, for increased virulence. Sequence type, \ncapsule type, and HMV capacity could not predict which classical isolates gain \nan rmp-dependent colonization benefit. J Med Virol. 2025 Dec;97(12):e70735. doi: 10.1002/jmv.70735.\n\nHSV-1 US3: A Master Mimic Hijacking Host Kinase Networks for Viral Dominance.\n\nHossain I(1)(2), Nelson CJ(1)(2), Dutta O(1)(2), Mohan H(1)(2), Hasan M(1)(2), \nKousoulas KG(1)(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Department of Pathobiological Sciences, Louisiana State University School of \nVeterinary Medicine, Baton Rouge, Louisiana, USA.\n(2)Division of Biotechnology and Molecular Medicine, School of Veterinary \nMedicine, Baton Rouge, Louisiana, USA.\n\nHerpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) encodes the serine/threonine kinase US3, a \ncentral regulator of host-virus interactions that promotes viral replication, \nlatency, and reactivation. Despite limited sequence homology to cellular kinases \nsuch as Akt or PKA, US3 phosphorylates diverse substrates to manipulate multiple \npathways. This review summarizes current knowledge of US3 functions across \nseveral major areas, including suppression of innate immune responses through \nmodulation of NF-κB, ERK/MAPK, TBK1/IRF3, RIG-I; promotion of cell survival via \nphosphorylation of canonical Akt substrates such as TSC2, FOXO1/3, and BAD; and \nfacilitation of nuclear egress through modification of lamin A/C, emerin, and \nthe nuclear egress complex proteins UL31 and UL34. By comparing US3's strategies \nwith those of cellular kinases and other viral effectors, this review highlights \nconvergent mechanisms of host manipulation. This study designed and evaluated \nthe performance of an in-house multiplex real-time PCR for simultaneous \ndetection of these viruses. Materials and Methods: Plasma samples from 270 \ntransplant patients were tested using an in-house multiplex real-time PCR assay \nspecifically designed for HSV, VZV, and EBV. Analytical specificity and the \nassay's limit of detection (LOD) were determined. Statistical analyses were \nperformed to evaluate the agreement between the in-house assay and the reference \nkit. Results: The method had a specificity of 98% for HSV, 97% for VZV, and 95% \nfor EBV, alongside 100% sensitivity for all three viruses. No cross-reactivity \nwas observed with other viral or bacterial DNA. The LOD for the in-house assay \nwas determined to be 6.25, 25, and 25 copies/mL for HSV, VZV, and EBV, \nrespectively. Additionally, precision analysis showed low CV values in both \nintra-assay and interassay evaluations (HSV: 1.5%-1.8%; VZV: 2.3%-2.6%; and EBV: \n3.7%-3.9%), confirming the assay's robust analytical precision. Bland-Altman \nanalysis showed mean differences of 1.35, -3.29, and 1.75 for HSV, VZV, and EBV, \nrespectively. This multiplex real-time PCR method enables detection at lower \nconcentrations. Cross-reactivity testing confirmed no interaction with DNA from \nother viruses or nontarget microorganisms. Bland-Altman and linear regression \nanalyses also showed a strong agreement between commercial and in-house methods. \nConclusion: These findings, compared to Altona diagnostic kits, highlight the \nvalue of designing and applying advanced diagnostic assays in managing viral \ninfections in transplant patients.\n\nCopyright © 2025 Reyhaneh Kalhor et al. Of the \nfive known viral TAP inhibitors, only the herpes simplex virus (HSV) protein \nICP47 has been structurally resolved. We now report cryoelectron microscopy \nstructures of TAP in complex with the remaining four: BNLF2a (Epstein-Barr \nvirus), hUS6 (human cytomegalovirus), bUL49.5 (bovine herpesvirus 1), and \nCPXV012 (cowpox virus), assembling a structural atlas of viral TAP evasion. \nDespite employing divergent sequences, folds, and conformational targets, these \nviral inhibitors converge on a common strategy: they stall TAP from the \nalternating access cycle, precluding peptide entry into the ER and shielding \ninfected cells from cytotoxic T cell surveillance. The knowledge of their potential harm to wildlife, livestock, and \npets is fragmentary. These ectoparasites have been historically understudied, as \nthey were only considered nuisances to various occupational groups and the \npublic. However, there is also mounting evidence that they may be pathogen \nvectors as several infectious disease agents, including Acinetobacter, \nAnaplasma, Bartonella, Borrelia, Coxiella, Francisella, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, \nChlamydia-like organisms, Trypanosoma, Babesia, and viruses such as Sigmavirus \nlipoptenae and Thrombocytopenia Syndrome Virus, have been detected in deer keds. \nIn this context, deer keds should be considered a highly probable vector for \nBartonella schoenbuchensis. Persons at risk include anyone who travels or \nresides in the habitats of deer keds, primarily forests and their immediate \nsurroundings in the Northern Hemisphere, whether for leisure or work purposes, \nparticularly in temperate regions of Europe, Siberia, China, and North America. \nThey also occur in Central and South America, the Russian Federation, South \nKorea, Thailand, Japan, Algeria, and Southern Spain. The ongoing rise in \ntemperatures due to climate change is likely to favor the spread of deer keds, \nas it alters host distributions and increases their activity levels. Measures to \nprevent bites include avoiding areas with a high occurrence of deer keds, \nwearing protective clothing, including permethrin-treated clothing, and \nconducting a thorough body check for deer keds and bite sites after spending \ntime or working in a risk area. Medical professionals should consider deer ked \nbites in their differential diagnoses. To ensure occupational and public health \nsafety, it is crucial to educate and train at-risk workers (such as woodsman, \nforesters, employees of national parks, naturalists, farmers, and veterinarians) \nand those recreating in forests (such as walkers, hikers, hunters, or mushroom \npickers) about deer ked bites, their symptoms, and possible zoonotic \nimplications. This review summarizes the recent knowledge regarding the health \nrisks posed by deer keds, applicable to both occupational groups and anyone who \nmay encounter them within their geographic distribution.\n\n© 2025. PeerJ. 2021 Apr 15;9:e11231. doi: 10.7717/peerj.11231. eCollection 2021.\n\nDiversity patterns and drivers of soil microbial communities in urban and \nsuburban park soils of Shanghai, China.\n\nZhang W(1)(2), Han J(1)(2), Wu H(1)(2), Zhong Q(1)(2), Liu W(1)(2), He S(1)(2), \nZhang L(1)(2).\n\nAuthor information:\n(1)Key Laboratory of National Forestry and Grassland Administration on \nEcological Landscaping of Challenging Urban Sites, Shanghai Academy of Landscape \nArchitecture Science and Planning, Shanghai, China.\n(2)Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Landscaping on Challenging Urban \nSites, Shanghai, China.\n\nBACKGROUND: The rapid expansion of urbanization leads to significant losses of \nsoil ecological functions. Microbes directly participate in key soil processes \nand play crucial roles in maintaining soil functions. However, we still have a \nlimited understanding of underlying mechanisms shaping microbial communities and \nthe interactions among microbial taxa in park soils.\nMETHODS: In this study, the community variations of bacteria and fungi in urban \nand suburban park soils were investigated in Shanghai, China. Real-time PCR and \nhigh-throughput Illumina sequencing were used to examine the microbial abundance \nand community composition, respectively.\nRESULTS: The results showed that soil molecular biomass and fungal abundance in \nurban park soils were significantly higher than those in suburban park soils, \nwhile no significant difference was observed in the bacterial abundance between \nurban and suburban park soils. The alpha diversity of soil microbes in urban and \nsuburban park soils was similar to each other, except for Chao1 index of fungal \ncommunities. The results of similarity analysis (ANOSIM) revealed remarkable \ndifferences in the composition of bacterial and fungal communities between urban \nand suburban park soils. Specifically, park soils in urban areas were enriched \nwith the phyla Methylomirabilota and Verrucomicrobiota, while the relative \nabundance of Gemmatimonadota was higher in suburban park soils. Moreover, the \nfungal class Eurotiomycetes was also enriched in urban park soils. Compared with \nsuburban park soils, nodes and average paths of the bacterial and fungal \nnetworks were higher in urban park soils, but the number of module hubs and \nconnectors of the bacterial networks and negative interactions among bacterial \ntaxa were lower. Compared with suburban park soils, Acidobacteriota bacterium \nand Mortierellomycota fungus played more important roles in the ecological \nnetworks of urban park soils. Soil available Zn was also the most important factor \naffecting the bacterial community composition in this study.\nCONCLUSION: There were significant differences in the soil molecular biomass, \nfungal abundance, and the community composition and co-occurrence relations of \nboth soil bacterial and fungal communities between urban and suburban park \nsoils.
